Introduction to Project Management
What is Project Management?
Welcome to "What is Project Management?"
After watching this video, you will be able to define project management, identify the six types of 
project management constraints, and explain the benefits of effective project management
The Project Management Institute defines project management as follows:
"Project management is the use of specific knowledge, skills,
tools, and techniques to deliver something of value to people."
Examples of projects might include the development of software, the construction of a building, or 
a relief effort after a natural disaster.
Projects can be generally defined as a collection of tasks, activities, and deliverables that must be 
carefully organized and executed to produce value.
Project managers are the people responsible for managing this organization and the delivery of 
projects.
Because project management is first and foremost about the management of projects, this makes it 
distinct from general or operations management.
While general management involves the ongoing management of a team, project management 
begins and ends with a project.
Project management begins when a project is kicked off,
and it ends when all project requirements have been completed to the customer's satisfaction.
Although the informal process of managing projects has existed for centuries, project management 
as a distinct practice emerged in the mid-20th century.
It was born out of a need in the aerospace, engineering, pharmaceutical, and telecommunications 
industries to manage projects of increasing complexity.
Effective project management allows companies to increase the success rate of projects, mitigate 
project risks, and reduce overall costs.
For team members, effective project management allows them to better understand their roles and 
responsibilities, collaborate, and utilize resources.
A key aspect of project management is understanding your project's requirements. The entire team 
should agree on the project's goals.
Often, projects are kicked off by developing requirements.
Today, projects are everywhere.
We live in a Project Economy, in which projects are the primary method by which work is 
accomplished, and value is produced.
Project management skills are key for success in a project-based economy.
Project management involves a range of skills, including technical knowledge to interpersonal 
skills.
As a result, it is relevant to a wide variety of roles and situations.
Learning project management can be helpful to everyone, ranging from a student working on a 
science project to an executive negotiating personality disputes.
Project management helps prevent organizations from simply jumping into a new project without a 
plan.
Without proper management, many projects fail to meet their original objectives, if they are 
completed at all.
Project management provides focus and direction for the project team.
It allows businesses to outline their requirements from the beginning, apply project management 
techniques, and monitor project activities.
This mitigates risk by preventing resources from being wasted or put into failed projects.
Project management may reduce risks, but it does not guarantee that projects will not encounter any 
problems or surprises.
Project management will, however, provide standardized practices that can be used to respond to 
and prevent risk.
There are six types of constraints to keep in mind when planning a project.
These are cost, scope, quality, risk, resources, and time.
Cost is the project's budget.
Project management balances the budget so that projects neither overspend nor underspend.
Scope is both the desired features and functions of the final product and the work required to deliver 
them.
Accurately estimating scope is a crucial part of the planning process.
Project quality refers to the standards the project must meet to be effective.
The final product must be able to accomplish its intended task, deliver the expected benefits and 
value, or both.
It must additionally meet certain levels of availability, reliability, and maintainability.
Managing risk means addressing external factors that can potentially harm your project.
It refers to both the probability of these negative events and the consequences if they do.
Resources are what is needed to accomplish the project.
This includes people, equipment, facilities, funding, and anything else required to deliver the final 
product.
Time is the time needed to finish a project.
Tasks and their estimated durations must be accurately identified and estimated to ensure that 
projects stay on schedule.
Balancing these six types of constraints throughout project delivery is the challenge that project 
managers address.
The benefits of effective project management include:
Managing budgets and timelines, so that projects are able to be successfully completed within the 
planned budget and timeframe.
Improving productivity, efficiency, and quality of work.
Addressing project risks proactively.
Improving communication between team members and with stakeholders.
Increasing customer satisfaction by planning and meeting expectations.
In this video, you learned that project management is the application of knowledge, skills,
and tools to a project to deliver intended outcomes and produce value, considers constraints 
including cost, scope, quality, risk, resources, and time, has many benefits, including managing 
budgets and timelines, improving productivity, addressing project risks, improving communication, 
and increasing customer satisfaction.

Expert Viewpoints: What do Project Managers do?

Welcome to Expert Viewpoints: What do project managers do?
In this video, we will hear from several project managers explaining what project managers do and 
discussing examples of their involvement with their projects.
If you ever have an opportunity to go ahead and talk with any kind of an experienced project 
manager, ask them what their job description is.
In most cases, you'll hear something like my job is to go ahead and provide new products and new 
services on time, within budget and hopefully within the scheduled timelines that the customer 
requires.
Project managers are responsible for scheduling organization of the overall project,
and in reality, they're actually owners of the project and are held responsible.
Many projects require budgeting, making sure we have resource alignment.
Building those relationships between business stakeholders and internal stakeholders.
I like to believe that project managers are the cement that holds everything together.
You're the person who's in the middle, organizing everything and
bringing all the necessary elements together for successfully completing the work at hand.
And this means that you're working with everyone from upper management
down to every member of your team and figuring out how do you get them into
the optimum position for doing the very best work.
Next, we will hear about examples of projects that these experts worked on
and they will tell us a little bit about their involvement as a project manager.
It starts right from the beginning.
We work internally with cross-functional teams including our sales team.
Our pre-sales team, the consultants,
even our technical account managers for some or our customer success
managers we go ahead and start building the internal relationship from the kickoff call.
We build an external relationship with our stakeholders.
We also help with scheduling, organizing everything, making sure everybody is involved
that should be on the calls,
or just should be notified for any reporting.
So recently I worked with a small company to help them move their systems,
move their customer information to a new customer relationship management tool.
So there was some technology that was being changed.
We needed to train their employees on a new system,
and there was lots to be done in terms of creating some automations, transferring
the data, and really doing that training and creating things like FAQs and documentation.
So one of my roles for one of my roles for the project was to be the project manager.
And so the first thing that I did was I met with the company,
met with a couple of people on the team.
One of the first things that I did was meet with some people
on the team to talk about what the project objectives were.
Our project goals were and kind of get a basic sense of the timeline.
Now, let me tell you about a project I did years ago because it
was really an epiphany about what makes a great project manager.
Years ago I was specializing in fixing troubled projects,
projects that were over budget, behind schedule,
and I was down in Sarasota, Florida managing an HR software development project for Arthur 
Anderson,
and the project was millions of dollars over budget and over a year behind schedule.
Within three weeks, everything was ticking and everyone was shocked that
the project was back on schedule and was hitting deadlines every week
finishing key pieces of it,
and what I found was, the most important thing that a project
manager can do is being the person who can translate between the business and
the dev team in a way that makes it possible for everybody to get what it is they want.
Recently I've been working for Green River College here in the Seattle area.
The college and I decided that perhaps coming up with a new continuing education
program for a business analyst track was a very, very good idea.
We used something called the PDCA methodology. PDCA stands for: plan, do, check, act.
And this is a methodology that is tried and true.
First of all, we did our planning.
We took a look at the potential curriculum,
the potential audience, how long this particular course should take.
Then we went into the D, which stands for do, we developed all of the different courses.
The next step was C, which plans for check.
What we did was we ran a quick beta class.
We got feedback from a lot of the different participants.
We upgraded what we needed to go ahead and fix and then finally the A was act.
We're now ready to go ahead and roll out this new curriculum on a full-time, basis.
An example of a project that I have worked on is a cybersecurity course in the cybersecurity 
program
for UC Berkeley, and my involvement in that process was working with external stakeholders,
which were the faculty, working with our internal stakeholders, which were
several different types of roles,
there were people who were working on graphics where that course people who
are working at production for that course and that people who are also on the support end.
So, my role was to make sure that external stakeholders were very
clear on the different milestones that they had to accomplish in order to make
sure that the internal stakeholders were able to do their job and that
we were able to successfully launch the course on time for our online students.

Program, Project, Portfolio - What's the 
Difference?

Welcome to "Program, project, portfolio - What's the difference?"
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Compare and contrast a program, a project, and a portfolio in project management.
And differentiate between project, product, and portfolio managers.
The terms project, program, and portfolio are often confused or used interchangeably.
However, these terms have distinct meanings in the context of project management.
First, what is a project?
The Project Management Institute, also known as PMI, defines a project as a "temporary
endeavor undertaken to create a unique product, service, or result."
Projects are temporary, meaning they have a clear beginning and end.
They are complete when the project goals are achieved or when the project is no longer
viable.
Projects can stand independently or be part of a larger program or portfolio.
A successful project meets or exceeds the stakeholders' expectations.
Projects are distinct from operations.
To determine if what you are working on is a project, ask yourself the following questions:
Is it unique?
Is there a way to determine when the project will be completed?
Is there a way to measure stakeholder satisfaction?
It is a project if you have answered yes to all these questions.
An example of a project might be a social media campaign for a product.
This meets all three criteria from the previous slide:
it is unique because the product will launch only once, it has an end state because after
launch the project concludes,
and produces measurable value, such as the percent increase in product usage after the
campaign.
Next, a program is a group of similar or related projects managed as a group rather than 
independently.
Programs are most useful when a group of projects sees benefits from being managed that it 
wouldn't
see individually.
The goal of a program is to realize the advantages for the entire organization.
Implementing programs makes it easier to determine which projects produce value for the business.
Like projects, programs are temporary organizations.
When all projects in a program are complete, the program is also complete.
All programs share four traits.
They are:
Large, incorporating multiple projects with a wide scope.
Long-term, as it takes a while for a business to see the benefits from multiple projects.
General, able to encompass a range of relevant projects.
Strategic, serving the overall strategic goals of the organization rather than a single project.
An example of a program might be all marketing campaigns that use multiple channels for a
single product,
including social media platforms, digital advertising, and print advertising.
While the individual marketing campaigns in each channel serve as separate projects; together
they form a single marketing program.
By contrast, a portfolio is a group of programs and projects within the same organization.
These programs and projects may or may not be related.
Like programs, portfolios are useful when a group of projects and programs would benefit
from being managed as a whole.
Unlike programs and projects, managing a portfolio is a continuous process,
and new programs and projects are included in the portfolio as they are started.
All portfolio elements must align with the company's overall strategy and goals.
The goal of a portfolio is to help an organization meet its long-term objectives.
If a project is a social media campaign, and a program is the entire marketing campaign
on multiple channels,
then a portfolio would be all the projects and programs that concern the product.
A portfolio could include all social media campaigns for all of the organization's
products.
This might include marketing and other departments such as production, design, and distribution.
As there are differences between a project, program, and portfolio, there are differences
between a project manager, program manager, and portfolio manager.
A project manager has a responsibility to ensure that an individual project is managed
within time, cost, and quality constraints.
They typically focus on how to get work done at a tactical level, and their day-to-day
tasks mainly focus on timelines, resource allocation, and assigning tasks.
A program manager, on the other hand, is responsible for ensuring a larger group of projects is
completed.
They are focused on ensuring that the overall program is meeting key business objectives.
Their day-to-day tasks mainly involve resource management across multiple projects, improving
processes and tools, and tracking long-term timelines and large budgets.
A portfolio manager is responsible for ensuring that groups of programs that may not be related
to one another are being delivered and that they are contributing to broader business
objectives.
They are primarily focused on ensuring that the portfolio of programs is aligned to the
overall organizational strategy.
Day to day, they meet with executives, build portfolio-level roadmaps to provide direction
to program and project managers,
and track and balance resources and costs across multiple programs.
In this video, you learned that:
A project is an endeavor that is unique, temporary, completable, and measurable.
A program is a collection of projects that is large, long-term, general, and strategic
projects.
A portfolio is a collection of projects and programs that is ongoing and aligns with the
organization's strategic objectives.

The Role Project Management Plays in 
Projects
Welcome to "The Role Project Management Plays in Projects."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
List traits of successful project management
Explain the six aspects of a project that a project management addresses
Explain the purpose of monitoring and reporting on a project
As you have learned previously, project management is utilizing skills, tools,
and knowledge to manage projects successfully.
It is used not to manage day-to-day operations but to manage temporary and unique projects.
Karen Tate is president and founder of The Griffin Tate Group, Incorporated,
a Project Management Institute Charter Global Registered Education Provider
specializing in training for the project management community.
She says, "Trying to manage a project without project
management is like trying to play a football game without a game plan."
Successful project management helps create successful projects.
Project management aims to:
Prevent projects from going over budget or running late,
Provide tools like work breakdown structures,
client information sheets, and project plans to help teams navigate their work,
Clarify roles and responsibilities across the team,
Communicate across all project team members and key stakeholders to build alignment,
Manage how the project is delivered, including clarifying dependencies and downstream impacts,
Assess and manage risks and issues that the project faces,
Drive quality assurance for the outputs of the project,
Monitor and report on results to the team, leadership, and key stakeholders,
The purpose of a project is to achieve a particular objective and produce measurable value.
The objective of project management,
on the other hand, is to control how these project goals are achieved.
Project management is about estimating and controlling six constraints:
scope, schedule, financials, risk, quality, and resources.
The project scope establishes objectives, requirements, and extent of the work.
A project schedule determines how and when the work is executed.
Project financials determine how much can be spent to achieve the
project's goals and should be managed for budgeting purposes.
A project risk assessment identifies any events that may have a negative impact
on any other of the project constraints and puts a plan in place to mitigate those risks.
Project quality includes the standards and criteria set by stakeholders and is
managed through quality assurance processes that review a project's performance on a regular basis
Lastly, the project's resources include the people, equipment,
or technology required to complete a project.
You've learned that an example of a project would be a social media campaign for a product.
The successful completion of a social media campaign project would involve
determining the objectives of the social media campaign and
any requirements and scheduling social media campaign releases.
It would also include estimating the cost, ensuring the social media meets
the organization's quality standards, assessing risks such as making sure advertised assets are
in place in a timely fashion, and allocating the appropriate personnel for the work.
Monitoring the status of a project is crucial to project management.
In order to control these six constraints, projects must be regularly monitored.
While monitoring a project's progress against the required objectives and deliverables,
project managers may find they need to adjust the project's schedule or budget.
Monitoring may also identify risks or resource issues that
may require requirements to be altered.
When monitoring a project's progress, project reporting is regularly needed
to communicate the project's status to the team and stakeholders.
Reports should maintain and update the project's
schedule and progress against the requirements and deliverables.
Reports may also contain budget information.
As a project's schedule and budget are living documents,
they may change as the project progresses.
Reporting communicates these changes regarding the project to the team.
Regular reporting should convey information that accurately assesses, reports on,
and notifies team members about any other changes to the project as necessary.
Project managers may use digital tools to monitor and report on their projects.
Project management monitoring tools are used to track the tasks,
due dates, who is responsible, spending, issues, and status of project assets.
For reporting, they may have a presentation template they update
weekly to communicate the status and issues to key stakeholders.
They may also have email templates they use to send out reports on a regular cadence.
In this video, you learned that:
Successful project management keeps projects within budget and on time,
provides needed tools to the team, clarifies responsibilities, facilitates communication,
manages delivery and risk, drives quality, and monitors and reports results
Project management seeks to control the scope, schedule,
financials, risk, quality, and resources of the project
Monitoring is used to assess the progress of a project against its deliverables,
whereas reporting communicates this progress to the team


Expert Viewpoints: What's a project?

Welcome to Expert Viewpoints: What's a project?
In this video, we will hear from project managers describing what a project entails and the
role project management plays in a project's success.
Question number one is, what's a project for me to correctly respond to that question,
I'll share the project Management Institute's three-phase definition of a project.
First and foremost, a project is unique.
Every project is different.
A project manager needs to really understand how each project is different and tailor their
planning accordingly.
Secondly, every project has a defined beginning and a defined end.
It's very, very important for the project manager to not only understand when the project
begins, but how it's going to end as well.
What will you do with the final product or service?
Who will you transition it to? the third piece of the PMI definition is all projects are
achieved through progressive elaboration.
What do we mean by that?
When we first begin a project, we really don't understand what the total scope of the project
is.
The first step that you're going to take is creation of a project charter.
This explains the scope at a very, very high level.
Level progressive elaboration means that as we continue to go ahead and understand the
details of the project, we become more and more detailed and more and more granular until
at the end we have a project plan that is detailed to the point where you can execute
the project.
Simply put, it's a sequence of tasks that have an outcome.
With that, it could be easy as making a PB and J.
Okay, so you start with two slices of bread, peanut butter, and jelly, but it's the overall
outcome.
How do you go ahead and create the task in order to complete your PB and jelly?
That way you can enjoy it.
A project can be called any work that is gathered around a specific set of goals.
So what is it that the business wants to accomplish,
and putting it together and understanding how you're going to accomplish it.
So in my experience as a project manager, a project is something that really kind of
has an end date.
It has a specific goal that a team or company is trying to accomplish, and it's really something
that is pretty contained in and of itself.
A project can be anything.
My focus has been in online learning but a project can be anything that has a deadline
that is going to mark its launch or its delivery.
So my focus has been in digital products for online learning, but it can be anything.
What role does project management play in a project's success?
Well, one of the things that you'll learn is RACI.
This is a way of defining roles and responsibilities for a particular team member.
R stands for responsible, A accountable, C console, and I inform.
In a nutshell, the project manager is responsible to do work accountable for the outcomes of
the work.
A consultant in terms of providing expertise and needs to be a provider of information
and a receiver of information as well.
We are the key responsible players that are responsible for the overall project itself.
When it comes to the outcome, somebody is going to have to go somewhere and be like
who's responsible.
They go to the project manager.
They have to manage scope, budget and schedule in order to have a successful project.
Sometimes we might go a little bit out of budget, but where do we budget out from?
Is it going to be from the scope and we're going to do less scope?
Or do we slow down the schedule or speed it up if we have it increased budget?
So this can, you know, vary from team to team, project to project, but very often includes
the project manager in gathering the business requirements,
working with the business analysts and the business side all the way up to the C-suite
to understand what the business.
And then starting the planning.
You have everything from the diplomacy that you have to do in terms of working and inspiring
those that are on your team to dealing with troubleshooting when things go wrong and things
will go wrong.
I believe that a good project manager really helps make a project successful because they
help move that project along.
They help resolve any issues or blockers they have relationships with all of the stakeholders
and they're really able to get clarification on questions if members of the team have questions,
they're able to resolve issues if people on the team have issues.
They're the person making sure that all of the different stakeholders are keeping to
their milestones and ultimately, they're the one responsible, or at least one of the people responsible 
for making sure that the product launches on time.
And if for any reason it doesn't launch on time that the proper communication channel has been 
opened so that it's not going to happen on time, that there's a plan, that someone knows that it's not 
going to happen on time and that there's a Plan B.
So, they're the person shuffling every single different step along the way, making sure
that everyone is successful.

Expert Viewpoints: Misconceptions about 
Project Management
Welcome to Expert Viewpoints: Misconceptions about Project Management.
In this video, we will hear from project managers discussing some common misconceptions about
project management and tasks that fall outside the purview of a project manager's responsibilities.
That's a very easy response for me.
One of the biggest misconceptions is that a project manager has to be the expert.
The project manager needs to be understanding of all aspects of everything that is happening
in the project, that is a huge misconception.
One of my favorite quotes that I've heard in the past is,
"Know what you know, know what you don't know, and surround yourself with people who
know what you don't know."
A good project manager does not quote-on-quote bite off more than he or she can chew.
You need to be in control of the project.
You need to make sure that all of the different moving parts are moving in the right direction.
You do not necessarily have to be the expert.
A lot of the times in terms of their own workload, a lot of people have this kind of misconception
that project managers are there micromanaging people on the team,
and the most successful project managers that I have seen really are there with not only
a vision but a very clear directive,
and then once the team has that directive and they have all the information they need,
they're able to really self-manage even more successfully and efficiently than if they
don't have that information.
Now, a lot of it has to do with the idea that people expect that if you're a project manager,
that you've basically planned out the entire project and scheduled everything.
Some misconceptions about project management are that they are the manager of every single
person on the project.
So an important thing to know about a project manager is that while they're communicating
with different stakeholders along the way,
they are quite often, and most often not the actual manager of those different stakeholders.
So they're managing the task, managing the timeline, but they're not the direct managers
of the different people involved.
So they have to communicate, if necessary, if there's any escalations with those stakeholder's
managers.
So there's a separate kind of dotted line with these roles.
What falls outside the scope of project management?
We always want to plan prior, we workout with the statement of work.
If there is one, we go ahead and all agree.
As far as the scope and then we move forward with implementation, anything outside of the
agreed upon scope is technically considered as either a scope creep or just out of scope
altogether.
I think project managers, while they are responsible for resourcing things like resourcing and
budgets,
they aren't HR professionals or finance professionals so they need to have great relationships with
people in HR and in the finance department,
but they don't need to be responsible or something that falls outside of the scope of project
management is for them to really have those skill sets in human resources and finance.
In terms of what falls outside the realm of project management, my opinion is nothing.
As a project manager, I've been called to add value everywhere from idea all
the way down to final distribution of a product, a website, a piece of software.
So as a project manager, my feeling is you have to be ready to do whatever it takes to
get the job done.
What falls outside of the scope of project management is direct leadership to different
stakeholders.
So as I mentioned previously, stakeholders are not managed by project managers.
The project managers focus on the timeline, so the project manager does not have to be
responsible for different parts of each stakeholders' jobs.
Their only focus on the timeline, on communicating obstacles across the team, and making sure
that they're removing those obstacles,
but they are not the actual leadership member that is directly involved with managing each
stakeholder.

Module 1 Summary: What is project 
management?
1.	Project management is the application of knowledge, skills, and tools to a project to deliver 
intended outcomes and produce value. It has many benefits, including managing budgets 
and timelines, improving productivity, addressing project risks, improving communication, 
and increasing customer satisfaction.
2.	Project management seeks to control the scope, schedule, financials, risk, quality, and 
resources of a project.
3.	Successful project management keeps projects within budget and on time, provides needed 
tools to the team, clarifies responsibilities, facilitates communication, manages delivery and 
risk, drives quality, and monitors and reports results
4.	The three primary levers that project managers drive include time, quality, and resources.
5.	A project is an endeavor that is unique, temporary, completable, and measurable, while a 
program is a collection of projects that is large, long-term, general, and strategic projects. A 
portfolio is a collection of projects and programs that is ongoing and aligns with the 
organization's strategic objectives.
6.	Common project management resources that can be used to learn more about project 
management include the Project Management Body of Knowledge, or PMBOK.

Who Project Managers Work With
Welcome to "Who Project Managers Work With."
After watching this video, you will be able to list who project managers interact with when 
managing projects, and summarize the types of interactions project managers have with those they 
work with.
Stakeholders are individuals, groups, and organizations that can impact or be impacted by a project.
This can include impact during the production of the project, or it can include impact after the 
completion of the project.
Basically, anyone involved with the project is a stakeholder.
Engaging with stakeholders is essential to managing projects.
Project managers must be able to effectively identify, analyse, and proactively engage with 
stakeholders from the beginning to the end of the project.
By effectively interacting with various stakeholders, project managers and stakeholders alike can 
align their goals with the project's objectives.
This also allows the project team to adjust the project in response to changes and new 
developments.
Some key individuals and teams that the project manager interacts with include:
Executives,
Legal,
Sales and marketing,
IT,
Operations,
HR and recruiting, External stakeholders, and Project teams.
Project managers work with executives on a number of different tasks.
Executives must work with project managers without their roles overlapping.
Project managers work with executives to:
ensure their roles do not overlap, align the project to corporate strategy, communicating a goal and 
vision for the project,
build support for the project and gain assistance evangelizing, encourage and champion team 
members, work to gain budget and resources for the project, and create an environment for the 
project manager and team to thrive.
Project managers also work with legal teams.
Interactions with legal teams are especially necessary when there are specific laws,
contractual obligations, and legal concerns that the project and its team must pay attention to.
Project managers may also work with the legal team
when they are involved in contracts for project work.
Another department that project managers may work with include sales and marketing.
There are interactions with sales and marketing if the project produces a product or service to sell,
or it changes an existing product or service,
sales and marketing departments will likely be involved.
Sales and marketing departments can provide crucial information on sales, messaging, and customer 
satisfaction.
Project managers will also work with the IT team to manage any systems, internal or external, 
required for a project.
IT will provide technical support to the team for project success.
If the project involves software development, project managers will need to work with developers 
in IT as part of the project team.
In some instances, IT professionals can be leveraged as members of the project team in order to 
lend technical support.
Project managers may also work with the operations department.
If the project delivery or outcomes will impact how the organization functions.
The project manager will also involve operations to ensure a smooth project transition from 
development into operations.
Another department that project managers may work with is human resources, often referred to as 
HR and recruiting.
Since project managers are responsible for managing labor resources and the team members 
involved who work on a project, they may need to bring people in from other departments or hire 
external personnel or contractors.
In these cases, HR and recruiting can help project managers get the workers they need.
Project managers interact with many people outside the organization.
Individuals they frequently meet with include:
suppliers who provide a service required for the project, clients who request the services or the 
product being developed for the project, customers who may be contacted if they are involved in the 
design or testing of the product, and consultants who provide expertise on one or more aspects of 
the project.
Finally, the project team is also a group of stakeholders.
Project managers work with all team members to gather status, manage issues and risks,
drive the timeline and budget, and more to support the project's completion.
Project teams actively work with other stakeholders in order to ensure that
everyone understands the other's interests, needs, and opinions.
This maximizes project performance and outcomes, and it increases stakeholder satisfaction.
In this video, you learned that project managers work with executives, to align projects to corporate 
strategy, legal, to address legal and contract issues, sales and marketing, to manage products that are 
being sold, IT, to help with technical systems, operations, to ensure smooth transitions if the project 
affects the organization,
HR and recruiting, to recruit personnel,
external stakeholders, to work with suppliers, clients, customers, and consultants, and
project teams, to support the project's completion.

Working Across Teams, Functions, and 
Different Organization Structures
As you have learned, project management is the process of planning, organizing, and leading a team 
to achieve specific goals and objectives. It is a critical function in any organization, as it helps 
ensure that projects are completed on time, within budget, and to the satisfaction of stakeholders. 
One of the key challenges of project management is working within different organizational 
structures and across different teams, as it requires effective communication and collaboration to 
ensure that everyone is working towards the same goal.
In the article, the following organizational structures are discussed:
•	Vertical or hierarchical
•	Matrix
•	Functional
•	Flat or horizontal
•	Hybrid
In addition, the following teams are discussed:
•	Executive staff
•	Legal and compliance
•	Finance
•	Marketing
•	Design
These structures and teams are used as examples throughout the article to discuss the unique 
challenges and considerations that project managers must keep in mind when working with them 
and how to navigate within each structure accordingly.
Working Within Different Types of Organizational Structures
The type of organizational structure can have a significant impact on project management and the 
role of the project manager. Each structure has its own characteristics and challenges, and the 
project manager must be aware of these to effectively lead the project and navigate the organization.
Hierarchical or Vertical Structure
In this type of structure, a clear chain of command and decision-making authority flows from the 
top of the organization to the bottom. Project managers in this structure may face challenges in 
getting buy-in and support from upper management. They need to ensure that project goals and 
objectives are aligned with the overall organizational strategy and that they keep upper management 
informed of the project's progress and any issues that arise.
Matrix Structure
This type of structure is characterized by cross-functional teams that work together on specific 
projects or initiatives. Project managers in this structure may have more complex relationships to 
navigate, as they must manage multiple stakeholders. They need to be skilled in communication and 
collaboration and effectively lead and manage cross-functional teams. Additionally, project 
managers need to be able to navigate the different priorities and goals that each functional team may 
have and align them with the overall project goals.
Functional Structure
This structure is organized around specific functions or departments, such as accounting, marketing, 
or human resources. Project managers in this structure need to be aware of the different processes 
and systems used by each department and ensure that they are working with the right experts in 
each area. They may also need to work closely with department managers to ensure that project 
goals and objectives are aligned with the goals of each department.
Flat or Horizontal Structure
This type of structure has a relatively flat hierarchy with few or no levels of management. Decision-
making authority is distributed among all employees, and there is little centralization of control. 
Project managers in this structure need to be comfortable with a high degree of autonomy and be 
able to lead and inspire the project team with minimal oversight. They may also need to build 
consensus among team members, as there may be fewer formal structures in place for decision-
making.
Hybrid Structure
This type of structure is a combination of two or more of the above structures, tailored to suit the 
specific needs of the organization. In this case, the project manager must be aware of the 
organization's characteristics and goals and adapt the project management approach accordingly.
In all cases, project managers need to be aware of the decision-making process, have the skills to 
plan and lead the project accordingly and align the project efforts with the organization's goals and 
objectives. The structure of an organization can significantly affect the complexity and effort of a 
project, and a good project manager will be adaptable and able to work effectively within the 
structure of the organization.
Working across different teams and functions 
While there are different organizational structures, many organizations have similar functions and 
teams. When working across different teams, project managers must be able to effectively 
communicate and coordinate with a wide range of stakeholders, including executive staff, legal and 
compliance, finance, marketing, design, and other functional teams. Each team may have unique 
goals, objectives, and responsibilities, and the project manager must be able to align these with the 
overall project goals and objectives.
Project managers must keep in mind the unique challenges and considerations when working with 
different teams. Some strategies that project managers can use to effectively manage these 
challenges and foster productive relationships with each team include:
Executive Staff
Project managers must be able to clearly communicate project goals and objectives, timelines, and 
expectations to the executive team and be able to effectively listen and respond to feedback. They 
must ensure that project goals and objectives are aligned with the overall organizational strategy 
and keep upper management informed of the project's progress and any issues that arise.
Legal and Compliance
Legal and compliance teams may have specific regulations and guidelines that must be adhered to. 
Project managers must work closely with legal and compliance teams to ensure that projects are 
following all relevant laws and regulations and to mitigate legal risks. They should also be aware of 
any legal considerations that might affect project schedules or costs.
Finance
Project managers must work closely with finance teams to ensure that projects are completed within 
budget. Project managers may work closely with the finance teams to develop a detailed project 
budget, including all expected costs, such as labor, materials, and equipment. They will also 
regularly update the budget, track actual costs throughout the project, and take guidance from the 
finance team on how best to allocate resources based on the budget.
Marketing
Project managers must work closely with marketing teams to ensure that the organization's products 
or services are effectively promoted to customers and the general public. If the team is developing a 
new product or service, project managers may work with the marketing team to understand the 
marketing timeline for launching the new product.
Design
Project managers must work closely with design teams to ensure that visual designs and concepts 
are consistent with the organization's branding and aesthetic requirements. Project managers may 
also work closely with design to gather user feedback and do user testing. The project team may 
also depend on the design team for user experience/user interaction designs, so the project manager 
will need to communicate with that team to ensure project plans include those considerations.
With all teams, it is important to maintain open lines of communication and actively seek feedback 
from all team members. Regular project status meetings, workshops, and report-outs can help keep 
everyone informed and on the same page. Also, involving key stakeholders and team members in 
decision-making processes and seeking their buy-in can help build trust and buy-in for the project.
Finally, it is essential for the project manager to have the ability to navigate across different 
cultures, backgrounds, and working styles, which will greatly help in fostering productive 
relationships with each team and across organizational structures.
Conclusion
Project managers must navigate complex organizational structures and many functions and teams, 
as well as many cultures, backgrounds, and working styles. With that in mind, effective 
communication is crucial as it helps to ensure that everyone is on the same page and that any issues 
or concerns are addressed in a timely manner. Collaboration is also essential as project managers 
must be able to bring together different perspectives, ideas, and expertise to achieve the project 
goals and objectives. They must be able to establish clear roles and responsibilities for each team 
and create an environment where team members feel comfortable sharing their ideas and providing 
feedback. Finally, this requires a high degree of flexibility and adaptability and a deep 
understanding of each team's unique characteristics, goals, and processes.
In summary, effective project management requires the ability to work across different teams, 
navigate complex stakeholder relationships and align the efforts of multiple parties toward a 
common goal. Successful project managers are skilled in communication, collaboration, 
adaptability and are able to work effectively with a wide range of stakeholders to achieve project 
objectives.
Project Management Methodologies
Welcome to "Project Management Methodologies."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
"Explain the purpose of the Project Management Body of Knowledge.
The P. M. B. O. K. List commonly used project management methodologies
Compare and contrast project management methodologies, including waterfall, critical path, critical
chain, agile, lean, and Six Sigma
The Project Management Institute, known as the PMI, is a leader in project management
and provides a set of project management guidelines called the Project Management Body of 
Knowledge,
or PMBOK.
The PMBOK is a set of project management guidelines, best practices, and processes.
The PMBOK intends to make project management more effective within cost, scope, and time
constraints.
The PMI provides a certification based on the PMBOK, called the Project Management
Professional, or PMP, certification.
The 7th edition, or PMBOK, was released in 2021.
PMBOK 7 shifted from PMBOK 6's phase-based project management to principles-based project
management.
With the principles-based project management focus, the PMBOK7 enables the guidelines
to be readily applied to different types of projects
- say to a manufacturing project instead of a software development project.
Details and tools are provided for each principle.
The PMBOK 7 also enables tailoring the project management approach to a suitable adaptation
for that project's environment.
The PMBOK can be applied via a wide variety of project management methodologies.
We will discuss several: waterfall, critical path, critical chain, agile, lean, and Six
Sigma.
The waterfall method is one of the oldest project management methodologies.
It consists of linear, non-overlapping phases, including identifying requirements, analysis,
design, building, testing, and operations.
It is a rigid, structured approach to project management that doesn't provide flexibility
for changing requirements.
The structured approach to managing the project, gathering product requirements, and gaining
approvals helps to minimize cost overruns if the estimation is accurate and requirement
changes are minimal.
The critical path method of project management is like waterfall but accounts for dependencies.
The project manager works with the stakeholders to identify and order requirements using a
work breakdown structure.
Each task's completion time is estimated.
Like waterfall, the critical path method does not provide room for changing requirements.
In this example, you see three paths that can be worked on simultaneously.
The critical path is the path that takes the longest amount of time.
The critical path is shown here in blue.
Since the critical path is the longest, it estimates the length of the project.
There are three main parts to the critical chain method: the critical path,
the feeding chain, and resource buffers.
The feeding chains are concurrent, secondary paths to the critical path, also comprised
of dependent tasks.
The feeding chains eventually merge into a single task within the critical path.
Resource buffers are additional resources built into the critical path to provide a
measure of leeway in the critical path in case the path does not go as planned.
Resource buffers include additional team members, equipment, or time to the critical path tasks.
Agile was designed to address waterfall's shortcomings, namely its inflexibility and
changing requirements later in the process.
Instead of having long and strict project phases, the project is run in iterations that
are typically two weeks, called sprints.
Design decisions, implementation decisions, prototypes, and client feedback are processed
during the sprint, consistently allowing the stakeholders to provide regular feedback,
and consequently iterating on the project's development.
Agile is often paired with other, more robust project management strategies such as Kanban,
scrum, or extreme programming.
Four core values govern Agile methodology.
These values are
individuals and interactions over processes and tools,
working software over comprehensive documentation,
customer collaboration over contract negotiation.
responding to change over following a plan.
It also has 12 guiding principles developed to produce self-governed, highly collaborative,
and adaptable teams.
The lean project management methodology focuses on delivering value and minimizing the waste
of resources or time.
One of the key principles of lean is flow.
Flow is about moving the product through stages quickly, continuously, and efficiently, making
room for the next.
Work is done in a steady flow rather than in batches.
While Agile has bi-weekly sprints, lean is a continuous pipeline.
Agile is well-suited for development processes such as software, whereas lean is better applied
to production.
The Six Sigma Method is a collection of tools and techniques to improve processes. This
method originated in manufacturing and is data-driven.
The term "Six Sigma" comes from statistics referring to the number of defective products
that are equal to or less than six standard deviations from the mean in a normal distribution.
The Six Sigma methodology is often credited with revolutionizing quality management by
innovating it into its profession versus something handled by the production team.
To apply the Six Sigma method, accurate data is needed.
One of the main criticisms of this method is the over reliance on this type of documentation.
In this video, you learned that:
The PMBOK is a set of project management best practices, guidelines, and processes
intended to make project management more effective.
Waterfall, critical path, and critical chain methodologies use a linear, structured approach
where tasks take place in either mutually exclusive phases or sequences.
Agile focuses on development, and development is run iteratively, where iterations consistently
improve on the previous one.
Lean is focused on continual production flow while delivering value and minimizing waste.
Six sigma is data-focused and manufacturing-driven.

Expert Viewpoints: Project Management 
Methodologies

Welcome to Expert Viewpoints: Project Management Methodologies.
In this video, we will hear from project managers discussing the project management methodologies
they have used as a project manager, such as agile, waterfall, or something else.
At my company, we do a lot of technical implementations directly with frontline
customers, whether it's from finance, health, tech, whatever it might be.
We have so many different types of companies,
typically at my company we do like to go ahead and use hybrid or agile methodologies.
They just are best fit for our company.
However, we do see many different types of customers that have preferences,
whether it's agile, waterfall, hybrid scrum and we go ahead and just customize towards them.
As a project manager, I've used a variety of methodologies.
The two biggest ones being both Agile and waterfall.
So I cut my teeth early stages of the computer revolution as a
waterfall project manager using Microsoft Project.
But even then, In the early days, well before, Agile was a formulated methodology.
We were often using agile techniques,
everything from having stand ups daily generally in the morning.
But depending on where the team was, it could be spread around
all the way to how we were formulating our ability to do rapid prototyping.
And then within that, you know, the beauty of really learning
all the different things that can be used to properly manage your
project is creatively putting those together depending on the project.
The most common methodology that I have used in my career has been a hybrid model.
A hybrid approach where you do most of your work day-to-day, work in an agile fashion.
You have all of the agile ceremonies like daily stand-ups and retrospectives,
but a lot of the work is also kind of managed at a higher level in a waterfall approach,
so a lot of the work that I have done has been in a kind of a hybrid agile waterfall approach.
In my experience, I've had the opportunity to manage
and be part of a variety of different projects.
I've been part of typical waterfall projects where we plan, we do, we check, and we act.
I've been part of agile projects as well where we plan, do, check and learn.
The one piece of advice that I'd like to go ahead and share with you in terms of
choosing a methodology was developed by a gentleman named Ralph Stacy.
Whenever you are encountered with the challenge of managing a new project,
look at two aspects of the project. Aspect
number one, how much agreement is there among stakeholders in terms
of the deliverables that are going to be required?
Consideration number two, how complex is technology and how much innovation
and creativity is going to be required.
If the agreement on what success looks like is low and the complexity is very, very high,
then I recommend that you lean toward an agile methodology to complete the project.
If the agreement among stakeholders on deliverables is very, very high and the
complexity is relatively low, then in all likelihood a predictable waterfall
project will be most appropriate for you to be successful on the project.
The methodology is that I have used in my own projects,
have been both waterfall and agile timelines,
and when I first started in overseeing projects it was very waterfall based
because the volume of projects was not as big as it was later on in my career.
So the waterfall method was really good for having a smaller amount of projects,
where we could manage these waterfall-style milestone calendars for different stakeholders.
Agile really came into play when there were a lot more projects that were launching all at once.
My experience has been online learning so to put that into perspective, I could have been
at one point launching maybe two or three quarters, two or three courses a quarter,
where later on in my career it was a lot closer to 10 courses per quarter.
So that meant having to be a lot more agile in the calendars and
being able to actually be identify points of flexibility and also open
up better communication channels to launch the courses on time.

Traditional vs Modern Project Management
Welcome to "Traditional versus modern project management."
After watching this video, you will be able to
describe features of traditional project management and modern project management.
Compare and contrast advantages of modern and traditional project management
Traditional project management is based on predictable cycles, processes, and tools.
This is, in part, what has made it so successful for so long.
Rather than working in short cycles, on atomic pieces of work,
traditional project management plans the work linearly from start to finish,
that is executed sequentially with a focus on upfront planning, documentation,
and the project management lifecycle.
Changes are only made when necessary.
But there have been several shifts in project management towards a more modern method.
Modern project management is the type of project management
that you have been learning in this series.
Instead of large, inflexible projects, modern project management breaks large objectives
into smaller, more manageable pieces with clear end goals.
Modern project management often incorporates an agile, or hybrid, project management 
methodology
allowing teams to be more flexible in their scope, processes, and tools.
As organizations have evolved to be more fast-paced and global,
modern projects have required an evolution of project management.
Traditional project management involved static, fixed, projects where,
timelines, budgets, deliverables, and resources changed infrequently.
Requirements were set at the beginning of the project and changed little.
In contrast, modern project management involves projects that fluctuate.
They require fluidity and must be managed such that they are agile and flexible.
Development happens iteratively.
They are often large and involve multiple teams working together.
Due to trends in globalization and remote work, and the development of project
management and collaboration software, modern projects can also now be managed virtually.
The evolution to modern project management has several advantages, including:
Increased flexibility that allows organizations to
respond to changing business objectives, competitive pressures, or global events.
Faster time to market,
Identifying and fixing issues more quickly, increases in productivity and retention,
Capital and operational cost savings from a remote workforce.
There are also a few disadvantages of modern project management:
Teams can lose sight of the overall vision and objectives for a project,
so the project can seem to have no "end"
Project deliverables can go to market unfinished,
with the view that the team will complete it later.
Since teams focus on delivering project deliverables, necessary
documentation can be forgotten or incomplete.
Team members can feel as though they aren't connected to the organization
or that they aren't supported. There have also been shifts in
how organizations are structured and operate that have had an impact on modern project 
management.
Organizations have become far more global with the rise of modern technology.
Many organizations have teams that work across time zones and countries.
This means that organizations have diverse
cultures and have a more flexible work environment.
Globalization, and an increase in remote work,
also means that more work is done virtually and globally.
Project management and collaboration tools have also supported this shift.
While many organizations have evolved their project management styles,
modern project management has both advantages and disadvantages.
Agile project management methods allow organizations
to manage projects with more flexibility.
That increased flexibility allows organizations
to change their project deliverables or outcomes based on any number of factors.
This means that organizations can more easily adapt in an ever-changing world.
But this flexibility can also become a disadvantage when an organization does not have
a clear vision at the beginning of the project, or it changes its project objectives many times.
Teams can lose sight of what they are working on,
and it may feel like there is no definite end to the project.
Modern project management methods also focus on increasing an organization's time to market.
While this is a benefit, as organizations can start realizing value from their
projects more quickly, occasionally project deliverables can go to market
unfinished as teams believe they can just complete it in the next cycle.
Another benefit is that teams can identify and fix issues with project deliverables more quickly.
But, since teams are focused on delivering project deliverables quickly, and fixing
issues, there is often a lack of focus on documentation and reducing technical debt.
Finally, the rise of automated tools and
software has also provided modern project teams several advantages.
New collaboration tools allow teams to collaborate more effectively as well as virtually.
Additionally, new tools can automate the time-consuming,
manual processes in traditional project management, such as spreadsheet calculations,
report building, monitoring, and exporting data.
These tools give project managers more control and flexibility, allowing them to spend more time
optimizing the project rather than spending time performing tasks that can be automated.
Finally, globalization, remote work and the rise of project management tools
and software allows teams to work virtually from all over the globe.
This gives organizations increases in productivity and employee retention.
It can also create capital and operational cost savings by having a remote workforce.
But, in a virtual and remote work model,
team members can feel as though they aren't supported, or connected to the organization.
In this video, you learned that:
Traditional project management is predictable,
continuous, and sequential, and it requires planning beforehand.
This stability is an advantage of traditional project management.
Modern project management is flexible, used for unique projects,
and can be started without planning a project all the way to the end.
Some of the advantages of modern project management include being able to respond
to changes and client feedback, having more flexibility in how work is accomplished,
and using tools to automate management processes.

Recent Trends in Project Management
Welcome to "Recent Trends in Project Management."
After watching this video, you will be able to
list current trends in project management, and
summarize how current trends impact the project management role.
Current trends in project management include an emphasis on the use of:
Artificial intelligence, or AI,
project management software,
data analytics,
remote teams and a global workforce,
hybrid project management methodologies and
soft skills.
Recently, more and more organizations have been adopting the use of Artificial intelligence,
called AI, across their businesses.
The use of AI benefits organizations, and project managers, in multiple ways.
AI can provide insights to project managers and
stakeholders by quickly analyzing previous project performance data.
With this data, as well as data from other sources,
AI can also be used to estimate resource and budget usage and predict risks and issues,
helping organizations plan projects with a higher degree of confidence
and make quicker decisions while mitigating risks more accurately.
Additionally, in the near future, AI is expected to be able to automate many
minor administrative tasks that project managers currently do,
allowing them to focus more on higher-level, strategic activities and planning.
AI could assist project managers by automatically allocating
resources and updating the project schedule and budget based on data.
Thanks to the introduction of AI and cloud technologies,
project management software has also been upgraded.
Project management tools such as Asana, Wrike, and Trello are now cloud-based
and utilize AI features to facilitate efficient project management operations.
A major benefit of project management software is
that it allows all stakeholders to easily track project status at any given time.
Project management tools can help project managers automatically track costs and time
spent working on tasks and use that information to develop cost and resource projections.
These projections can help project managers see potential risks and
issues earlier in the project and make course corrections based on the data.
Additionally, project management software is often used across
all an organization's projects and programs.
This allows organizations to monitor their projects to have a better
understanding of how their projects and programs are working together,
and helps executives make quick, strategic decisions on staffing,
cost saving measures, technology decisions, and more.
Project management software, and the adoption of AI, have given project
managers and project stakeholders access to more data than ever before.
As discussed, that data is used to help everyone
from project managers up to the C-suite make decisions.
Project manager can use data to estimate scope, measure project progress, and assess risk.
But, an abundance of data has also required the adoption of data visualization tools.
Tools like IBM Cognos, Looker Studio, or Tableau can take project and resource data,
and combine it with other data from the organization to develop a complete picture
of key performance indicators and project health.
Another trend in project management is the rise of virtual teams.
Because of developments in technology, changing corporate values,
and the growth of the gig economy, virtual teams have become more common.
The onset of the COVID-19 pandemic in early 2020 also increased the adoption of
work-from-home policies that allowed some team members to complete work from nearly 
anywhere.
Collaboration tools such as Slack, Zoom,
and Microsoft Teams, along with project management software such as Jira,
help teams to work together even when they are working across different time zones.
These tools are particularly helpful for project managers
who manage numerous resources across different locations.
Hybrid project management methodologies are another trend that has been increasing in recent 
years.
Hybrid project management methodologies incorporate different project management
methodologies such as agile, scrum, XP, scaled agile framework , waterfall, and lean.
Organizations are increasingly turning to hybrid methodologies to address the need for flexibility.
This allows organizations to find a unique approach that works best
in a particular situation, project, or industry.
This means that project managers must be familiar with many project management methodologies,
but also gives them a broader toolbox with which to manage projects.
Finally, with the development and adoption of numerous AI tools,
and project management software, as well as the rise in remote (or hybrid remote) teams,
the project management profession has seen an
increase in the need for project managers with strong soft skills.
Skills such as emotional intelligence, conflict resolution, communication,
negotiation, and mentoring are in high demand.
As new technologies like AI and project management software handle more administrative work,
project managers are now focusing on other
responsibilities that require some of these key soft skills.
By developing these skills, project managers are able to better contribute to a project's success.
In this video, you learned that new trends in project management include the use of:
Artificial intelligence, which can automate administrative tasks.
Project management software, which can help project managers monitor
a project's resources and schedule in real-time.
Data analytics, which can help organizations make data-driven decisions about their projects.
Remote teams and a global workforce, which allow teams to work across locations and time zones.
Hybrid project management methodologies, which apply
multiple project management methodologies to the projects they are best suited.
Soft skills, like communication, which are increasingly valuable
as emerging technologies do administrative work.


Key Takeaways From This Course
This course provided a comprehensive introduction to project management. You learned what 
project management is, its benefits, and the constraints it helps manage. You also learned the role 
played by project managers and how recent trends, such as remote work, have shaped modern 
project management.
The course covered opportunities for different careers within project management and discussed 
jobs across different industries and experience levels, as well as the various technical and soft skills 
required for project management work.
In particular, key takeaways from this course include that:
•	Project management applies knowledge, skills, and tools to projects to produce value, 
manage budgets and timelines, improve productivity, address risks, and increase customer 
satisfaction.
•	Successful project management controls project scope, schedule, budget, risk, quality, 
resources, and maintains positive working relationships with stakeholders.
•	A project is unique, temporary, completable, and measurable, while a program is a collection 
of large, long-term, general, and strategic projects. A portfolio is an ongoing collection of 
projects and programs aligned with an organization's strategic objectives.
•	Project managers drive time, quality, and resources and use Waterfall, Critical Path, Critical 
Chain, Agile, Lean, and Six Sigma methodologies.
•	Recent project management trends include the use of AI, project management software, data 
analytics, remote teams, hybrid methodologies, and an emphasis on soft skills.
•	Practical technical skills for project managers include knowledge of project management 
methodologies, business administration, and software and information technology.
•	Valuable soft skills for project managers include communication, time management, 
problem-solving, interpersonal and leadership skills, and self-motivation.
•	Project managers are responsible for project planning, execution, monitoring and reporting, 
post-project evaluation, and project closing.
•	Project management employment in the construction, engineering, IT, finance, healthcare, 
and manufacturing industries
•	Is expected to increase consistently over the next ten years across the construction, 
engineering, IT, finance, healthcare, and manufacturing industries.
•	IT project managers have unique responsibilities, such as implementing IT strategy, 
managing IT resources, and communicating with IT managers, employees, and clients.
•	Becoming a project manager may require a degree, specific certifications, and years of 
experience, with entry-level, mid-level, and senior executive roles available, including 
project coordinator, project manager, senior project manager, program manager, portfolio 
manager, director of project management, and chief operating officer.

Expert Viewpoints: Trends in Project 
Management

Welcome to Expert Viewpoints: Trends in Project Management.
In this video, we will hear from project managers discussing the
evolution of project management and what they like or dislike about recent trends.
I'm going to go ahead and share two terms with you: #1 virtual,
#2 technology.
Virtual has become a key consideration in project management.
We, as project managers, no longer have the luxury
of having an in-place team co-located where we can meet and greet each day.
So, a project manager needs to be well-versed in how to
handle a virtual project and the tools and techniques that are available to him or her.
The second is technology.
In the past, project management was very easy.
Make sure that you have a pad of paper and a pen and write good notes and send emails.
Now we have a variety of different platforms.
We have JIRA, we have Teams, we have Asana, we have Box.
You name it, there's a different technology that is out there that
can greatly assist us in managing our projects,
but the key challenge is learning them.
From my last company where I was in office over to where I'm currently at,
which is fully remote, things have changed majorly in project management.
Previously everything had to be in-person meetings.
We thought that it would be much better for our business relationship.
Which is great to meet people in person, of course, and have that face-to-face,
you could see their emotions, their body language.
However, in the new space of remote, you can reach out to
anybody at any time and have a quick response just through a quick chat.
A big thing that's changed just recently for most of the world is working with remote teams.
That's, you know, caused a lot of challenges for project management. From as simple as dealing
with the time differences of working with offshore teams or teams in other places.
You have to deal with differences in culture attitudes.
You know, it, it becomes a little bit more complicated, you know, motivating your team,
working with them, putting together a way so that the workflow is going smoothly.
The proliferation of the cloud and cloud-based tools like JIRA,
cloud-based tools like Trello and Asana, that have really allowed us to digitize things,
like user stories and then using data and now artificial intelligence to
really help us understand things, like what is our burndown rate,
how many people do we need on a project at any given time,
and what does our resourcing look like for the next three to six months for this project?
There's a lot more tools out there that use data,
artificial intelligence, that use the cloud for even basic communication.
The ways of project management have evolved over time tremendously.
When I first started, I feel like I know Agile has been around for a while,
but when I started we were definitely a lot more focused on waterfall methods,
and Agile really didn't come into play later, and especially as our teams became more dispersed.
It became really important to be honed in on one method of project managing.
So, if we were managing a few projects that were going to launch per quarter, but it changed to
managing twice, double, triple or that we had to update our methods to be more agile,
but we also had to identify which ways agile is going to work for us.
So that meant not just having once-a-week project meetings for updates,
it meant having daily stand-ups, which were really helpful when our team members were dispersed.
So, I had team members in New York, I had some in Chicago, I had some international
members, so we had to identify key points for us to be able to
meet and be able to communicate about the projects at stake.
What do you like or dislike about new ways of project management?
I truly love the opportunity of being able to work with everyone virtually.
I can easily talk to people that are in cross-functional teams, like my sales team over to
marketing or product management and having those true live updates within a matter of seconds.
Some of the dislikes is definitely it's much harder to build those
relationships because it's quick answers.
You don't get to see everyone.
Plus, sometimes, especially when you're meeting with your stakeholders,
you wanna know what they're thinking,
and when you see them in person at least you can see their body language and their overall tone.
You can get some of that over a call,
especially like a Teams meeting, for example, or Webex.
However, you don't see it all, especially if we don't use cameras.
There's a lot of data out there and as we move as project managers, move information and manage
their projects using these tools. It's very easy to get bogged down in all of the data
and all of the reports that are available and all of the information that's out there
and really to not only overwhelm themselves, but overwhelm their teams, their stakeholders with.
You know, just massive processes or lots of
information that they don't need to get a project done.
What I like about new ways for project management is that there
are so many more options to be able to manage projects,
and that means using different software to be able to figure out what's best for your project.
I've worked in smart sheets before and I've also worked in Asana, and there are plenty
of other software, plenty of other software available out there for project management,
so I really like that you can find the specific one that caters to your particular project.
What I dislike about new project management methodologies is that there are so many
options and I think that you can get really sucked into figuring out and
trying to figure out the different software to see where it lines up for your project.
And I think that can start to distract from actually getting in there and doing it, so
it's a love-and-hate relationship with some of the new parts of project management that are 
evolving.
Well, something that I like is the technology.
Something that I dislike is the learning curve
that's required to adapt and understand the new technology.
And in addition, I do enjoy the opportunity to manage projects in a virtual environment,
but I also understand the challenges that come along with a virtual project
and the need to really communicate well in that particular environment.

Module 2 Summary: Working as a Project 
Manager
Potential stakeholders on a project include team members, executives, clients, and various other 
departments such as legal, sales, IT, operations, and HR in an organization.
•	Project managers build and maintain positive working relationships with stakeholders by 
effectively identifying, analyzing, and proactively engaging with stakeholders from 
beginning to end.
•	By working across teams, functions, and departments, project managers can align their goals 
with the project's objectives. This allows the project team to adjust the project in response to 
changes and new developments.
•	Waterfall, critical path, and critical chain methodologies use a linear, structured approach in 
which tasks take place in either mutually exclusive phases or sequences. Agile is focused on 
iterative development and constant improvement. Lean is focused on continual production 
flow, and Six Sigma is data-focused and manufacturing-driven.
