•	Recent trends in project management include the use of artificial intelligence, project 
management software, data analytics, remote teams, and a global workforce, hybrid project 
management methodologies, and an emphasis on soft skills.
•	The advantages of traditional project management over modern project management are that 
it is predictable and stable. The advantages of modern project management are that it is 
flexible, responsive, and automated.

Soft Skills for Project Management
Welcome to "Soft skills for project management."
After watching this video, you will be able to
explain the term soft skills,
and describe the soft skills required for effective project management.
While other parts of this course focus on the technical skills required for project management
-for instance, proficiency in spreadsheet software-
this video emphasizes the importance of soft skills.
Soft skills include intangible skills such as personality traits,
interpersonal skills, and attitudes cultivated from your life experiences.
They are not as readily quantifiable, taught, and learned as technical skills.
The soft skills that are helpful for project managers will be discussed in this video.
This video organizes soft skills into four categories:
Proficiencies
Competencies
Traits
Mindsets
We will discuss examples from each category that are helpful for a project manager's success.
Proficiencies describe expertise in a particular
area and the ability to utilize this knowledge effectively.
There are a number of these proficiencies required to be a successful project manager.
This includes skills in research, analysis, negotiation, and report writing:
Research enables project managers to find accurate
information within or outside of the organization quickly.
Analysis allows project managers to take the information they've gathered,
evaluate, and interpret it, then make decisions based on that information.
Negotiation skills provide the ability to get two or
more parties with different points of view to come to an agreement.
Project managers should be proficient in report writing to create effective reports,
tailored to a specific audience, which are well-organized and accessible.
Competencies are areas of expertise for which you have sufficient knowledge to perform.
For project managers, relevant competencies include written and oral communication,
time management, public speaking, decision-making, and relationship-building.
Though most modern professional jobs require communication skills,
project managers in particular must be effective written and verbal communicators,
as they are responsible for communicating with, between, and two different stakeholders.
Effective time management is necessary for project managers.
They are responsible for planning projects, and time management is a crucial part of that.
They should be able to accurately estimate how long a task will take,
effectively stay on the task themselves, and help their team manage their time.
Project managers must be comfortable speaking
publicly to direct meetings and deliver presentations.
Using their research and analysis skills, project managers should be able to make
decisions based on relevant information by identifying and assessing alternatives.
Project managers are responsible for building relationships among stakeholders.
These strong relationships are based on trust, communication, respect, and inclusion.
Traits are aspects of your personality. Traits
can be developed and improved with attention and practice.
Some traits necessary for project managers are being self-motivated,
creative, detail-oriented, and able to task-switch.
If project managers are motivated, they can better persuade and motivate others effectively.
They can guide themselves and their team members through the
ups and downs of project development and stay motivated to stay on task with their work.
Project managers may find themselves in situations where they must devise
creative and unconventional solutions to problems.
Being curious, seeking out new connections,
and keeping an open mind are ways to become more creative.
Projects are comprised of lots of small, moving parts.
Project managers should be able to keep an eye on all
these small parts without losing track of them;
spreadsheets, project tracking software, and detailed plans help a project manager identify,
manage, and keep track of a project's many details.
To task-switch, project managers should be able to switch between tasks rapidly and efficiently.
Project managers must keep track of numerous tasks simultaneously
and go back and forth between projects frequently and quickly.
They need to task-switch without taking time to
re-orient themselves among the tasks they are responsible for.
Mindsets describe an overall mental attitude.
They guide how project managers approach their work.
The main mindsets required of project managers are characterized by leadership,
goal orientation, critical thinking, collaboration, and problem-solving.
Project managers should remember that they are leaders and responsible for
the growth and success of their team members.
By setting achievable, measurable goals,
project managers set themselves and their teams up for success.
Project managers should be able to bring a critical lens
to their project planning and managing activities.
This will help them find effective solutions to problems as they arise.
Project managers must always be conscientious of their teammates and other stakeholders.
They should approach problems and tasks with an attitude of cooperation.
A problem-solving mindset requires project managers to approach problems by identifying
their causes, coming up with possible solutions, and then applying the most appropriate one.
In this video, you learned that project management requires many soft skills, including:
Proficiencies in research, analysis, negotiation, report writing, and presentation.
Competencies such as written and oral communication, time management,
public speaking, decision-making, and building effective relationships.
Traits such as self-motivation, creativity, detail orientation, and task-switching.
Mindsets characterized by leadership,
goal orientation, critical thinking, collaboration, and problem-solving.

Technical Skills for Project Management

Welcome to "Technical skills for project management."
After watching this video, you will be able to list and describe the technical skills
and competencies required for project management.
While soft skills are becoming increasingly important in project management, successful
project managers must also have several technical skills,
sometimes known as hard skills.
Organizations expect project managers to have technical skills in three areas:
Project management methodologies and processes,
Business administration and management,
Software and information technology.
Technical skills in project management involve managing all aspects of a project's life cycle.
This means that project managers must understand the different phases of the project life cycle
and be familiar with project management
methodologies such as waterfall, agile, Kanban, PMBOK, and Lean.
Project managers must also understand the role that cost, time, and resource constraints
play in each project.
Project managers use this knowledge of project management methodologies to execute the project
planning process.
This is when they will define a project's scope and goals, develop strategies for directing
their teams, and determine how to complete project deliverables within the agreed cost,
time, and resource budgets.
A project manager's main role involves project execution.
To successfully execute a project, project managers will need to be able to conduct risk
assessments and take appropriate action to mitigate identified risks,
which may include working with compliance to understand legal and regulatory risks.
They must be able to track and monitor project status, identify blockers, and escalate issues
to appropriate stakeholders
Project managers must also ensure that teams are complying with relevant business processes
and policies, such as Standard Operating Procedures, also called SOPs, and compliance control 
processes.
Successful execution of a project will also require that project managers be comfortable
with common business administration practices.
Project managers should have a familiarity with:
Identifying business needs and determining solutions to business problems,
Developing project budgets and monitoring project spending,
Determining, tracking, and reporting key performance indicators to ensure projects meet the defined
objectives within agreed-upon cost, time, and resource budgets.
Since project managers work directly with teams and stakeholders to plan and execute
projects,
they should also have strong skills in resource planning, business process improvement, and
change management.
Project managers are often responsible for allocating tasks to team members based on
capacity and skill sets and maximizing team efficiency by managing utilization rates and
monitoring progress.
They may also need to identify, analyze, and improve existing business processes, particularly
processes that teams can reuse between many projects.
At times, project managers may also need to implement strategies that effect change and
help teams adapt to changes, such as transformation of an organization's goals, processes, or
technologies.
Project managers must have technical skills in software and information technology.
Project managers use software to plan, track, and monitor projects, as well as collaborate
with team members and stakeholders.
Software that project managers are frequently expected to be familiar with include:
Collaboration tools such as Slack, Zoom, and Microsoft Teams,
Productivity suites that include spreadsheets, email, calendar, and word processing programs
such as such as Microsoft Office and Google Workspace,
Project management tools such as Asana, ZenHub, Jira, GitHub, and Trello.
Project managers may also benefit from data management skills and a working knowledge
of cloud technologies.
Data management involves understanding basic database structures such as relational databases
and organizing and modifying data.
Project managers may use data to understand market trends, and user needs, as well as
visualizing key performance indicators or product testing data.
Project managers may also need to use software and tools within a cloud environment, so they
should be aware of various cloud technologies and services.
Data analysis and reporting tools include IBM Cognos, Salesforce Tableau, and Google
Looker.
If you are interested in being an IT project manager, organizations may require additional
specialized skills.
Common skills needed for IT project managers include:
Knowledge of the Software Development Life Cycle, also known as the SDLC,
Knowledge of Object-Oriented Analysis and Design, also called OOAD,
which breaks applications into objects and develops requirements and designs around objects
and their relationships.
Experience with agile and waterfall project management and development methodologies.
Knowledge of the practices, tools, and philosophies critical to DevOps, which brings software
development and IT operations together to reduce software time to market.
Some familiarity with programming languages such as Python, C sharp, Java, JavaScript,
or CSS, which can be useful for communication with development teams.
Additional skills are often required for IT project managers who manage IT projects including:
Incident management to respond to unexpected interruptions and restoration of services.
Monitoring, managing and optimizing an organization's information technology systems.
Quality management to ensure the quality and consistency of a product or service using
QA processes and software testing methodologies.
Information systems security and security standards to ensure the safety of information
system assets.
IT fundamentals such as hardware, operating systems, software & applications, networking,
storage, cybersecurity and cloud and the technology landscape related to the product
area they operate in.
In this video, you learned that
There are many technical skills that may be expected of a project manager.
These largely fall into several categories.
Project management methodologies and processes such as project lifecycles and executing project
planning processes.
Business administration and management such as budgeting and KPIs.
Software and information technology such as collaboration tools, productivity suites and
project management tools.
Additional skills required for IT project managers include incident management, monitoring,
quality management, and cybersecurity.

Interpersonal Skills and Leadership in Project 
Management
Welcome to "Interpersonal skills and leadership in project management."
After watching this video, you will be able to
describe the need for interpersonal and leadership skills when managing a project,
list leadership skills that are crucial to project management, and
interpersonal skills and leadership are invaluable skills for project managers.
Project managers are not only managers but leaders for their teams.
In addition to managing many aspects of a project,
they are also responsible for leading a group of different team members and stakeholders,
often with varying backgrounds, experiences, and opinions.
Project leadership brings together team members in order to work towards a common goal.
There is no rule book or set steps to becoming a leader,
and many personality types can effectively lead a team.
Leadership and management are similar skills with plenty of overlap,
but they also have distinctions.
Management involves methodically planning, organizing, and coordinating tasks and resources.
This could include budgeting, creating schedules, and working with outside contractors.
On the other hand, leadership involves motivating and encouraging others.
Leadership is not about controlling team members but more about enabling them to do their best.
Project managers must be both managers and leaders.
They need to not only manage details but also often need to inspire a team
and communicate a guiding vision for everyone to work towards.
Being a leader involves a wide range of interpersonal skills.
These skills include
communication,
team building,
motivation,
trust building, and
conflict management.
We will discuss examples of each category that are helpful for a project manager's success.
Project managers should be able to effectively communicate with their team members.
Communication not only includes the ability to speak and persuade but
the ability to ask the right questions and listen.
Project managers should also be able to facilitate effective communication between
individual team members and groups such as different departments in an organization.
Project managers should be able to build teams across the organization.
Because project teams often involve people from across departments,
project managers must bring these people together to achieve a common goal even
if they have different interests in the project.
Project managers can use their knowledge of a teams' skills, personality traits,
and interests to not only form teams but also to foster team relationships.
Project managers should be able to motivate the team and stakeholders.
Project managers must be able to maintain morale,
encourage team members to do their best, and keep them interested in their work on the project.
Project managers must understand the needs and motivators of each team member and stakeholder
on the project and use that knowledge to help the team meet the objectives of
the project and be satisfied with the work they are accomplishing.
Project managers should be able to build trust in the team.
Project managers should foster an environment of
trust between the team members and stakeholders involved in a project.
Trust is an important element of project success and can lead to more effective communication,
increased productivity, and decreased risk.
Project managers can build trust by following through
on their commitments and creating an environment where team members
feel comfortable discussing project blockers and giving honest feedback.
Project managers should be able to manage conflict.
Given the diversity of most project teams, conflict is often unavoidable.
Project managers can avoid some conflict by clearly defining project objectives,
roles, and responsibilities from the beginning of the project.
When conflict does arise, they can use a number
of conflict resolution strategies to mitigate the impact of the conflict.
There are usually five steps to conflict resolution:
acknowledgment, clarification, mediation, solution identification, and monitoring.
Let's look at an application of this strategy in practice next.
For example, say Marty is new to a project that Gene has been working on for weeks.
Marty needs guidance from Gene, but Gene is up against a tight deadline.
Consequently, they both feel frustrated with each
other because Gene doesn't feel like Marty is doing her share of the work,
and Marty feels discouraged because she doesn't know how to get started.
The first step is acknowledgment.
As the project manager, you let them know you recognize the issue.
Next, you clarify.
You ensure they know you are aware of the problem.
Third, you mediate by discussing the issue with both of them.
Then, as the solution, you find another resource to help reduce Gene's workload
and confirm with Gene that he now has the bandwidth to assist Marty,
and you let Marty know Gene has been under a tight
deadline but you have found someone else to assist with some administrative tasks.
Gene and Marty now have some time to work together.
For the last step, follow-up,
you check in later to ensure that Marty gets the training from Gene she needs.
In this video, you learned that interpersonal and leadership skills help project managers to:
Work more effectively with team members and stakeholders.
In addition to the managerial skills that help project managers work with budgets,
resources, and schedules, leadership skills help
project managers inspire a team to work towards a shared vision.
Some of the interpersonal skills needed for leadership in project management include
communication, team building, motivation, trust building, and conflict management.
There is no single best way to utilize these skills, and project managers
benefit from having a variety of styles that they can draw on to lead a project.


Transferable Project Management Skills
Project management and similar skills found 
in other careers
Project managers oversee all aspects of a project, from start to finish. They manage the budget and 
resources, organize the team, and provide feedback at every process stage. They ensure deadlines 
are met and the final product is of high quality. Being a project manager comes with tremendous 
pressure because a project manager is responsible for the success and failure of a project. The best 
project managers should possess the soft and technical skills to address the responsibilities 
associated with their position.
Many of these skills and characteristics are transferrable from other jobs. By the time you finish 
reading this article, you will know how to compare positions that overlap with project management 
and which roles could easily transfer into project management.
Roles with skills that transfer to project management
•	A data analyst may be good with organization and math; both are vital skills for project 
managers because they need to keep an organized schedule to keep the project on plan and 
budget their allocated resources to stay within their quota.
•	A project coordinator is like a project manager; it is common to find a project coordinator 
assisting a project manager in their projects. Both roles involve coordinating, organizing, 
writing documentation, and having the ability to manage time wisely.
•	A technical writer is someone who writes content about technical subjects. Like project 
managers, they must be good with grammar, writing documentation, analyzing, and 
researching because these skills are also used in many everyday tasks of a project manager.
•	A contract manager is a professional who handles a company's legal documents and 
contracts. They weigh the pros and cons of new contracts and negotiate to ensure their 
company gets everything they need to get the job done. Contract managers must be good at 
negotiation and risk management. Project managers must also be able to weigh the pros and 
cons of different budget and resource strategies and negotiate with stakeholders to come to 
the best possible outcome for the entire group. Project managers must also be able to 
manage risk.
•	A budget analyst must think critically and be able to analyze data to solve a problem or find 
an answer. A budget analyst's role typically includes reviewing budgets and providing 
guidance on how to manage the company's budget. Project managers must also think 
critically and look at all factors to determine the appropriate course of action. Some project 
managers will also handle project budgets, so they must be able to look at the budget and 
determine how to move forward. For example, if materials for the project are more 
expensive than originally planned, they may need to find another vendor, renegotiate a 
contract, or reallocate budget resources.
•	An event planner must take many moving pieces and align them to ensure an event goes 
smoothly. They have to consider the stakeholder's budget, the scheduling of events, and 
ensure everyone and everything coordinates. Event planners make great project managers 
because events are very similar to projects.
•	A quality control inspector monitors the standards of manufactured products. They must be 
meticulous in catching any product mistakes before leaving the facility. They must also be 
good at documentation to improve quality control with each new batch of products. A 
project manager must be equally meticulous to ensure catching mistakes in a project before 
sending it to a client or going live. Project managers are also responsible for documenting 
processes to ensure continuous improvement.
Skills that transfer to project management
As you have seen, other careers with skills that transfer well to project management include event 
planners, technical writers, data analysts, and operations managers. But many soft and technical 
skills found in other positions also transfer well to project management, such as
•	time management
•	written communication
•	verbal communication
•	budgeting
•	foundational computer skills
•	time management
•	leadership
Therefore, many other roles can provide you with skills you can apply in a project management 
role. So long as you possess (or are willing to learn) the soft and technical skills to address the day-
to-day tasks and responsibilities associated with a project management role, you can be a successful 
project manager.
Project Manager Responsibilities
Welcome to "Project manager responsibilities."
After watching this video, you will be able to
list the responsibilities of a project manager, and
describe the responsibilities of a project manager.
Project managers have several responsibilities throughout the lifecycle of a project.
A responsibility is something that the project manager is
accountable for that is within their control.
Project managers are responsible for:
project planning, project execution,
project monitoring and reporting, post-project evaluation and
project closing.
Project managers fulfill these responsibilities by completing
a number of tasks before, during, and after a project.
Tasks are definable pieces of work that are assigned to or expected of the project manager.
One of the primary responsibilities of a project manager is project planning,
which begins as soon as the project initiates.
Project managers are responsible for making sure that project goals and deliverables
have been determined and that there is a plan in place to meet those objectives.
During the planning phase, project managers:
Build a project overview or business case to define project objectives,
and identify key performance indicators or success metrics for the project
Estimate the time and effort required to complete a project and create a project plan,
Kanban board, or Gantt chart that clarifies the project plan and schedule
Project managers develop a project budget.
They must create a financial plan that outlines the anticipated usage of project resources.
This budget includes costs, profits, expenditures, and sources of funding.
Project plans and budgets can be created for the
entire project (such as in a waterfall or hybrid project management model),
or they can be created for a small, definable portion of the project (as in the case of agile).
Once a project plan is in place, the project manager is responsible for the execution of
the project and making sure that team members deliver on project objectives.
To do this, project managers must create, disperse, and maintain:
An accountability matrix to help team members
understand their individual roles and responsibilities as well as,
resource and utilization plans that guide the management of project resources,
and a risk assessment and issue management tracker to facilitate risk and issue management.
During the project, project managers are also responsible
for monitoring and reporting on the project's development.
They must monitor the project's execution compared to time, cost,
and resource plans created during the planning phase.
Communication is also a key responsibility of project managers, and they must ensure that
stakeholders receive regular reports regarding the status of the project.
The project manager must determine who needs to receive what specific information,
when they will receive it, and what communication channels will be used.
To facilitate monitoring, reporting, and communication, project managers may:
Build project dashboards to monitor the status of projects,
track risks and issues and then communicate project status with all stakeholders.
Project managers may also facilitate regular meetings with stakeholders,
keeping detailed agendas and notes to discuss the status of the project.
They also need to track resources and costs and may need to participate in a timesheet,
invoice, or expense approval.
These responsibilities require project managers to keep track
of several details about team members and stakeholders, as well as the project itself.
There are several project management, communication,
and collaboration tools that can assist project managers with these tasks and responsibilities.
Finally, project managers are also responsible for the evaluation and closing of a project.
They must be able to critically assess a project's performance, whether the project
met its defined goals and objectives, and how the team may improve the process in the future.
After evaluating the project, they must ensure that all project deliverables and
information are finalized, stored, and dispersed for future use.
Project managers may review project deliverables and evaluate key performance indicators, or 
KPIs,
which provide quantifiable measures of performance.
These indicators help project managers evaluate
the efficiency and effectiveness of a project's performance and delivery.
Using this data, they can identify strengths and
weaknesses in the project process and target areas for improvement.
This stage is also an opportunity to highlight
what went well and reward team members for strong performances.
Project managers may also create a post-project report or hold a
retrospective, where they document key project learnings and possible process improvements.
They may also ensure that all project deliverables are packaged,
and project information is archived and readily available for future use if needed.
In this video, you learned that
A project manager's responsibilities include
project planning, execution, monitoring, reporting, evaluation, and closing a project.
Project planning and execution is the initial
phase that establishes a project's goals, deliverables, and schedule.
While monitoring and reporting,
project managers assess and communicate project status to all stakeholders.
And evaluation and closing involve assessment of the project's effectiveness after its completion,
packaging project deliverables, and archiving project information.


A Day in the Life of a Project Manager
Welcome to "A Day in the Life of a Project Manager."
Hi, I'm Nery, and I work as a project manager for a large enterprise in Seattle.
When I arrive at work in the morning, I spend some time reviewing my email
I receive overnight and review messages on Slack, our team communication tool.
I also take a quick look at my calendar to see what meetings I have for the day.
We just finished the design phase of our project and began the implementation phase.
I need to check in with the development lead
to ensure her team is ready to start this stage of the project.
Later in the day, I'm running our weekly project status meeting with our stakeholders.
I spend a few minutes creating some agenda notes for our status meeting,
and I make a copy of our meeting note templates for both the standup and our status meeting.
Before the status meeting, I review our project
plan and task tracker to see what tasks are currently in progress.
I want to ensure that the team has all the resources they need
for the implementation phase of the project.
I also review our risk assessment and issue log to make sure I'm prepared to
address any blocking issues that the team may bring up during our status meeting.
Next, I meet with the development lead.
We discuss the makeup of the team and who is assigned to
deliver the various pieces of the project.
She informs me that they're down a person due to infant
care leave and won't be able to meet the scheduled dates without a replacement.
We discuss a few strategies and schedule options that
we can bring to the team at the status meeting later in the day.
I also commit to discussing the matter with our manager.
After my meeting, I review the project schedule and begin planning for the next phases.
Implementation is planned to take three months, which brings us up
against a corporate holiday and a time of the year when many people take time off.
I built that into the schedule already, but design took longer than we planned,
so I make a few adjustments to accommodate the delay.
I send an email to all the project leads to let
them know of the adjustment and to inform their teams.
I plan on reinforcing this schedule update during the upcoming status meeting.
After a meeting with my manager, it's time for lunch.
I have lunch with another project manager, Mette, who is getting ready to kick off another project.
We talk about how the project will be resourced and realize that her project
will require some of the same resources that currently are on my project.
We discuss the timelines for both our projects and confirm there will be overlap.
We spend some time discussing how we can
accommodate both projects using the resources across the teams.
We agree that we need to raise this situation with our manager, so he's aware.
Mette also lets me know that she's been told the vendor budget might be expanded next year.
We discuss the impact of this, and she suggests that it is one
way we might be able to address our problem with overlapping resources.
Next, I have a meeting with my program manager to inform him of the status of the project.
We talk about the previous phase, the design phase, and how that went.
We talk about the outcome of that phase and how it will impact implementation.
I tell him that we are down a designer and a developer and that we could use some vendor
budget so we can hire temporary employees to fill in for the gaps.
I also inform him of the schedule update,
and he tells me that I need to pull my dates in a few days.
We talk about options for doing this and decide that if he's able to get the vendor budget,
we may be able to bring the schedule in a couple of days.
We decided to table the discussion until he explores the vendor budget question.
During the design phase, I offered to help the design
manager transcribe videos from a previous project.
By doing this work, it helps me stayed plugged
into the team and better understand the work they do on a daily basis.
After lunch, I spend an hour on this project and then inform the design manager of my progress.
I then have a meeting with the test manager and the development manager
to discuss a conflict between two of their direct reports.
The tester and the developer disagree about how much tolerance to allow on an error condition.
The developer believes there should be more room for the condition to trigger,
and the tester wants the numbers to be tighter.
Both managers agree that there isn't a clear answer on which position to prefer,
but the test manager agrees to take the developer's position and take
point in communicating that message to both teams.
During the project status meeting, I share updates
with the project stakeholders and answer any concerns that the stakeholders have.
We invited a member of our leadership to join the
status meeting as she had some information to share.
Our leadership is happy with the progress that we've made in the design phase,
but lets the team know that there is a new requirement
for the product based on some compliance and policy changes.
We discuss the new requirement and address potential impacts to the overall timeline.
We end the meeting by reviewing the plan for the following week
and determining agenda items for the next meeting.
I spend the rest of my afternoon answering emails, checking Slack for any new messages,
and updating our schedule based on the conversations I had today.
I also create a few new scheduling models to
test some other ideas in case the published version doesn't work.
I also work on an executive summary of the current
status of the project and archive files on our file share from the design phase.
Before I know it, it's time to head home.

Expert Viewpoints: A Day in the Life of a 
Project Manager

Welcome to Expert Viewpoints: A Day in the Life of a Project Manager.
In this video, we will hear from project managers discussing a
typical day working as a project manager.
Let me introduce a new concept.
If you've never heard of it before, it's called WBS, the work breakdown structure.
A work breakdown structure is a hierarchical breakout of all of the different tasks that
are required, hopefully in the order in which they need to occur.
A good project manager will create a work breakdown structure,
and that particular work breakdown structure will guide his and her every day.
You take a look at what has been accomplished.
You take a look at what is in progress.
You take a look at what is planned, and you plan accordingly.
I love to start my day out with a cup of coffee and just
read through my emails to see what is needed.
Any big tasks that are added or any updates for projects from there I typically have about
3 to 4 technical meetings and they could be a configuration call or a design call for example.
Then I also have about two to three PM syncs and with those PM syncs, let's just check
in with our stakeholders to let them know updates and give them the weekly reports,
and then from there, I love to make sure that all my accounts
are updated with the weekly notes or just what happened throughout that day,
and then, I will go ahead and close out my day.
Since I'm running a lot of agile projects over the last years
very much the day starts with standups.
My last project, I was managing four different projects at one point,
so that meant four different virtual standups.
You using Zoom every morning after that,
it's really a matter of keeping organized, you know, using whatever tools you have.
We've been using Jira most recently for organizing and keeping track of all the tasks.
Then within Outlook, I use you know, tasks to keep track of everything I need to do.
Early in the morning, it's reviewing all the emails,
responding, and making sure nothing new has come.
And then throughout the day, checking with the team, uh, slowly going through and figuring out
who needs assistance, what can I do to empower them to do their job well?
And then throughout the rest of the day,
it's really a matter of working on all the various tasks. There may be documentation.
There may be budgeting. There may be people that need to be hired or found even.
A typical day in my job will always start with me
taking a look at our milestone calendars to see which date is
coming up the soonest, and depending on where we are
on the calendar and how that milestone is doing,
that'll base how the rest of my day is going to go.
So if we are approaching a milestone date and I haven't heard from that stakeholder
about the progress for that particular milestone, then I'll check in with them,
see where we're at, and if there's an obstacle in making sure that milestone is completed.
Then I'll contact that stakeholder, see how we need to mitigate the issue, whether we
have to meet or gather other stakeholders and figure out a Plan B, then there's,
What do I do next?
and then I also typically start to plan for the next phase depending on how much
problem-solving is involved at the beginning of the day, then during the end of the day,
I'll start to take a look through what's coming up
next and identify pieces of that project from there.
What items do you only do once or twice in a project?
The Project Charter. A project charter is a document that should be created once.
It's very, very high level, and the purpose of a
project charter is to describe what the project is, why it's important,
and who needs to be involved, according to the Project Management Institute.
A project charter rarely changes everything that you will do.
It's going to be based on that particular project charter in terms of planning,
execution, control, and closure.
Typically, I will only do a kickoff call once at the beginning of the project.
Otherwise, we might do it again if we have a different team that is taking over for
a different part of the project, like a new product, for example.
Typically, we also only review the project once, so you should have a
very good understanding at the beginning of what is needed and what the scope is.
You can, of course, reference back to the scope.
However, doing that true, thorough review of the
scope of the project should only really be done once.
And then transition the project over to our support team, for example,
or another team if anything else is needed.
You know, something that's not really routine,
that happens every once in a while, is you might have a conflict between two
team members that you need to resolve, and you need as a project manager.
You work to facilitate getting those challenges and those issues resolved.
I think that occasionally on a project, you'll have a time where you miss a deadline,
or a big issue comes up, or a risk that you've tried to mitigate actually happens.
And then you have to spend time working through those risks and mitigating those issues.

Module 3 Summary: What does being a 
project manager require?

Soft skills are more intangible than technical skills and may include qualities such as personality or 
attitude. Soft skills are not as readily quantifiable or able to be taught as technical skills, but they 
can be developed and improved.
•	Useful technical skills for project managers include project management methodologies and 
processes, business administration and management, and software and information 
technology. 
•	Useful soft skills for project managers include research, analysis, written and oral 
communication, time management, decision-making, self-motivation, task-switching, and 
problem-solving. 
•	Interpersonal and leadership skills allow project managers to work more effectively with 
team members and stakeholders. Skills such as communication, team building, and conflict 
management help project managers inspire a team to work towards a shared vision. 
•	Project managers are responsible for project planning, execution, monitoring and reporting, 
post-project evaluation, and project closing. Project managers fulfill these responsibilities by 
performing tasks such as budgeting, assessing risk, evaluating key performance indicators, 
and many more.
•	A typical day in the life of a project manager usually involves communications and 
calendars. They often attend a daily standup meeting and other meetings such as a sprint 
review, sprint retrospective, or project status meetings. 
•	Many soft and technical skills found in other positions such as time management, writing 
well, good verbal communication, and leadership transfer well to project management.
Careers in Project Management Overview

Welcome to "Careers in Project Management."
After watching this video, you will be able to
list possible positions for project managers from the entry-level to senior level,
their responsibilities, and average salaries, and
describe the projected growth in project management-oriented employment
Industries are changing.
Rather than role-based, they are increasingly becoming project-based.
Industries are finding that a project-based approach leads to innovation and allows more
efficient operations, readily responding to increases or decreases in demand.
Ultimately, this means there is a greater need for project management across most industries.
Depending on knowledge and experience, project managers can find roles at all
levels of an organization including entry level, mid-level, and executive levels.
Entry-level project management positions include
Assistant Project Manager or Project Coordinator roles.
Assistant project managers and project coordinators are similar roles.
Other similar roles are called project associate or associate project manager.
They support project managers in various administrative and technical tasks.
These positions can expect to schedule meetings,
update reports, and identify resource requirements.
These roles require very little, to no, project-management experience.
Entry-level project managers can expect to make an average of $55 to $65,000 a year.
With some experience, there are many mid-career-level jobs for project managers.
These positions might include being a Project Manager, a Scrum Master, or a Project Team Lead.
In some organizations, a project manager can be called a project officer or project engineer.
A mid-level project manager tends to take on a leadership role with regard to the project team
and makes an average salary of about $78,000 a year and Scrum masters specialize in Scrum,
a framework for product development, and they help teams plan and meet their goals.
They take on a facilitator role rather than a leadership one.
They earn an average of $97,000 a year.
Project team leads have expertise in the field in which they are leading the team.
They specialize in motivating a team, managing conflict,
and understanding the strengths and synergies of team members.
They make an average of $81,000 a year.
Mid-level roles typically require some project management experience, a degree in a relevant
field such as business administration, and/or a project management certification.
Project managers can also find roles at the executive level.
Positions at the executive level may include Senior
Project Manager or Director of Project Management.
A senior project manager typically has at least ten years of experience
supervising projects, planning strategies, and leading teams.
They develop project plans, host project meetings, and coordinate vendor and supplier resourcing.
The average salary of a senior project manager is $97,000.
A director of project management is usually the highest position in project management.
A director of project management provides strategic directions for a company's
projects by defining how those projects fit into the business's strategy and goals.
The average salary of a director of project management is $146,000.
Project management is a rapidly growing field.
According to the Project Management Institute, or PMI, the global economy will require 2.3
million new project professionals every year to close the talent gap by 2030.
A recent survey by the PMI revealed that project management was one of
the top-five areas that business leaders sought to prioritize.
The growth rate of project management-oriented employment is expected to be higher than
overall employment in industries that are becoming increasingly project-oriented.
This includes industries such as information and publishing,
finance and insurance, and manufacturing and construction.
According to an analysis of U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics data, the greatest
project management-oriented employment growth is expected to take place in software 
development.
In this video, you learned that:
Possible positions in project management include working as an assistant project
manager, project coordinator, project manager, scrum master,
project team lead, senior project manager, or director of program management.
Project management is a growing field, and many more jobs open up every year.
Project management-oriented employment is lucrative,
particularly as entire industries become more and more project-oriented.

Project Management Across Industries
Welcome to "Project Management across Industries."
After watching this video, you will be able to
explain the importance of Project Management in various industries, and
describe what a Project Manager requires to succeed in an industry.
Some of the industries that usually require project management professionals include:
Construction
Engineering
Information technology
Finance
Healthcare
Manufacturing
Let's first try to understand the importance of project managers in the construction industry.
Despite the increase in demand, concerns like rising prices and
regulations make it difficult to make profits in this industry.
This is where project managers become valuable.
For various projects such as residential buildings, commercial properties,
or industrial facilities, project managers need to effectively coordinate with multiple stakeholders
and resources such as architects,
engineers, city planners, public work employees, and construction crews.
Project manager involvement keeps the construction
of buildings and facilities on track, from budgeting and schedule development
to managing day-to-day activities throughout the project life cycle.
Apart from quality management, contract
administration, and risk management are important aspects of their job.
Let's explore the significance of project managers in the engineering industry.
Engineering projects ranging from mechanical, civil, industrial,
aerospace, chemical, biomedical, electrical, nuclear, agricultural,
and marine engineering projects all require project managers.
Engineering projects require careful planning and communication of the plan to their teams.
Project managers in engineering must have a bachelor's degree or,
in some cases, even a master's degree in the specific engineering field of interest,
as well as project management knowledge and skills such as risk management,
process integration, quality assurance, and procurement.
The IT sector includes industries related to hardware, semiconductor,
and internet service providers, also called ISPs,
as well as those involving software application development, technological upgrades,
computer and network infrastructures, equipment installation, and cybersecurity.
With such a wide range of options, IT project managers must know the fundamental and conceptual
technical knowledge related to networks, hardware, software lifecycle, and cybersecurity.
They need to know terminology commonly used by developers to communicate with them 
effectively.
They also need business acumen to understand project planning, cost, and feasibility.
Efficient finance project managers are required in
the finance industry to enhance productivity and reduce costs.
They oversee a company's financial project planning,
modifications to financial systems, and implementation of technological advances.
They need to be proficient in financial analysis, budgeting, and forecasting.
While finance project managers manage cash flow for payroll and project-related expenses,
many also develop revenue-boosting strategies.
Financial reporting is critical to their job
as they work closely with top executives and other influential people in an organization.
The stakes are high with project management in healthcare,
but quality project management can improve the quality of patient care.
Not only does project management need to facilitate lower costs and improved outcomes,
but patient care is also a major factor.
Healthcare project managers are necessary not only for hospitals and
clinics but also for pharmaceutical and medical device manufacturers.
Some potential projects handled by healthcare project managers include:
Development of web apps and portals
Facilitation of the construction of new hospital buildings/departments, and
Implementation and integration of new equipment in a facility
To meet such needs, specialized field knowledge is required.
Regulation is a big consideration while managing healthcare-related projects.
A degree in health management, public health, or any related studies is often beneficial.
In the case of the manufacturing sector, project management is
needed when an existing process changes or the need for a new process arises.
When it comes to manufacturing, project managers must keep risks,
hazards, and safety issues in mind.
Unique skills that project managers in this sector must have include vendor account management,
vendor and relationship management,
and streamlining production processes.
In this video, you learned that:
Construction project managers effectively coordinate with stakeholders and resources
while managing day-to-day activities throughout the life cycle of a project.
In the engineering industry, project managers often need a degree in the
specific field, as well as project management knowledge and skills.
To manage projects in the IT industry,
project managers need both technical knowledge and business acumen.
Finance project managers need proficiency in financial analysis, budgeting, and forecasting.
Project management in the healthcare industry is
high stakes because quality patient care is paramount.
In the manufacturing industry, project management is needed for
changes to existing processes or for implementing a new process.

Information Technology Project Management

Welcome to "IT Project Management."
After watching this video, you will be able to
describe the opportunities and demand for IT project managers,
summarize the responsibilities of IT project managers, and
explain the specialized skills required for IT project managers.
Information Technology, commonly known as IT, Project Management is a promising field.
Recent surveys have found that there will soon be over 800,000
projected employees in IT project manager positions,
Twenty-five percent of all IT job descriptions call for IT project management skills and
there was a fifty percent increase in demand for IT project managers from 2021 to 2022.
Information Technology has the most project managers compared to other
industries and tends to have higher average salaries than other fields.
It is no surprise that becoming an IT Project Manager is a popular choice for PMs.
An IT project manager is a project manager in the information technology industry.
The projects they are expected to manage might be initiatives
to create new products or improve and expand existing technology and systems.
The role of the IT project manager, like any other project manager,
is to manage the project's budget and schedules, and lead project teams.
An IT project manager has many responsibilities, many of which
overlap with the responsibilities of a non-IT project manager.
The primary responsibilities of an IT project manager include:
Managing multiple small to medium-sized projects throughout the project lifecycle,
Establishing a clear project definition, scope,
goals, and deliverables with support from the project management team,
Working within deadlines and budgets, monitoring progress,
organizing meetings, and creating status reports,
Identifying gaps, following the team's project governance structure,
and optimizing the project and process,
and may involve managing testing programs like beta software releases.
Implementing strategies that deliver projects on schedule and within budget,
Managing resources for projects, such as computer equipment and employees,
Communicating with stakeholders such as IT managers, project personnel, vendors,
and end-users regarding project requirements.
In addition, IT project managers are also expected to have some specialized skills.
For instance, they should be familiar with various concepts and practices such as:
The Software Development Life Cycle, or SDLC.
The SDLC is a structured process that enables the production of high-quality,
low-cost software in the shortest possible production time.
An IT project manager should be familiar with the SDLC stages of planning, analysis,
design, development, testing, implementation, and maintenance.
They should also be familiar with software engineering fundamentals,
including Object-Oriented Analysis and Design, or OOAD,
a method to analyze and design an application through an
object-oriented approach and the testing process.
Additionally, they should be able to work with Agile methodology and frameworks,
such as Scrum or Kanban.
They should also be familiar with the Waterfall methodology,
which breaks project activities down into linear and sequential phases.
Another important skill is knowledge of Information Systems Security.
IT project managers will be expected to assist in establishing safe practices and system
configurations in order to protect information systems from unwanted access or destruction.
They should also have a working knowledge of
information systems security standards and practices,
such as access control, system hardening, system auditing,
log file monitoring, security policies, and incident handling.
IT project managers should also have a conceptual understanding
of API integrations, the connection of two application programming interfaces;
and DevOps, a set of practices, tools, and philosophies that bring together IT
operations and software development to more quickly produce new software
Another valuable skill is incident management.
IT project managers will have to respond to unplanned events or service
interruptions and be able to restore the service to an operational state.
They should also be familiar with IT management,
or the monitoring and administering of an organization's IT systems.
This includes understanding the organization's hardware, software,
and networks, as well as how to make them run more efficiently.
Finally, IT project managers may also be responsible for quality
management or ensuring that the quality of an organization's product or service is consistent.
This could involve tasks in quality planning,
quality assurance, quality control, and quality improvement.
As you can see, there are many skills and responsibilities that are unique to
IT project managers, as well as those shared across different types of project managers.
In this video, you learned that IT project management:
Is a growing field, with a projected 30,000 jobs to open up in the next ten years.
Job openings are expected to grow at a higher rate than average.
In addition to the usual responsibilities, it requires unique responsibilities
such as implementing IT strategy,
managing IT resources, and communicating with IT managers, employees, and clients.
Other requirements include technical skills, familiarity with concepts
like the SDLC, OOAD, API integrations, and DevOps;
the ability to work with Agile and Waterfall methodologies; and IT-relevant knowledge,
including Information Systems Security, incident management, IT management, and quality 
management.

Welcome to Expert Viewpoints: Industry-specific skills.
In this video, we will hear from project managers discussing which
project management skills are transferrable and which are unique between industries.
The great thing about project management is
you can easily change your skills from one industry over to another.
It's very similar.
The biggest impact I would say, especially if you're new,
you just need to know how to make those changes from one company to another.
So for example, a company A that I worked at before we use a lot
of waterfall methodologies versus now I have to use many different types,
so I had to make that adjustment when I first made that change.
I really, truly feel as a project manager you can go from telecom for

Sometimes we just have to relearn.
What I've found is
your soft skills translate perfectly between industries. You know, being good with people
being able to be that diplomat that's able to motivate people to
figure out what's going wrong and how to fix it.
Those are all very important and translate.
Besides that, your obvious skills, just knowing the software, Jira, Smartsheets,
Microsoft Project, whatever you're doing, being well versed in all of those things,
being detailed oriented understanding, scheduling, all of those things translate well.

and there's a lot of skills that I find that transfer to differ
and from different jobs into project management. So, things like being detail-oriented,
that's something that, you know, is useful whether you are a finance professional,
whether you're a teacher or a writer.
Anything really.
Being detail-oriented is a, is a skill that can be transferred, organization and kind of
having that mindset where you can take a complex problem and break it down into smaller parts.
That's a skill set that can be transferred between many industries.

Let me share with you some of the key skills that a project manager is recommended to try to attain.
A project manager needs to be a good motivator, a good negotiator, a good conflict manager,
a good coach, a good influencer, a good decision maker, a good team builder, and also a good
project manager needs to be aware of all of the different cultures that he or she is dealing with.
If you are a project manager, a process manager, a product owner, regardless of
the position and management that you're in, those skills required to be an effective project
manager are similar to the skills required for success in any management position.
If there is one skill that is unique to project management,
it is understanding the particular life cycle and following that particular life cycle and process.
A traditional project goes through 5 phases, initiating, planning,
executing, monitoring, controlling, and closing.
These life cycles are very specific to project management and this is something that the project 
manager needs to be aware of if you follow the process, you have a great chance of being 
successful.

Path to Becoming a Project Manager

Welcome to "Path to becoming a project manager."
After watching this video, you will be able to
compare and contrast formal and informal project management training,
identify common project management certifications and their requirements,
discuss different ways to gain experience in project management.
Qualified project managers are required in almost every industry more than ever before.
The role of a project manager can be enriching.
However, before you begin your career path as a project manager, you need to understand
what qualifications are required to be successful in this role.
Some important qualifications are:
training,
certifications,
and experience.
While many jobs require an undergraduate degree, and a degree may help you qualify for more
job options, there are still several jobs that hire without a degree.
And, while project management training is not always a requirement for qualification,
some amount of training is generally recommended.
There are two forms of training that people can take who aspire to become project managers:
formal and informal.
You can receive formal project management training at an institution while getting a
degree.
While there are not many colleges that offer project management degrees, many colleges
offer project management certificates that you can earn while getting your degree or
after you graduate.
These certificate programs offer in-person or online courses in project initiation, detailed
project planning, risk management, and more.
For those that require greater flexibility in their schedules, there are also informal
training opportunities.
There are many self-paced online learning courses, such as this one, as well as many
professional certificates from companies like IBM, Google, and Microsoft.
The Project Management Institute also offers self-paced courses.
Many project management professionals start their careers in non-project management roles.
Occasionally, organizations will provide project management training in-house with professional
development courses and training programs.
These organizations guide and mentor the candidates to become project managers.
Your manager may also know of opportunities within the organization to gain project management
skills and experience.
Certifications are the process by which you prove that you have the knowledge, skills,
and experience to perform in a project management role.
The following certifications are developed and administered by project management bodies
such as the Project Management Institute or PMI, Scrum Alliance, Comp-TIA, and the Global
Academy of Project Management or GAPM.
Obtaining a certification in project management or a relevant field is an excellent way to
gain technical knowledge and credibility.
Most certifications provide insight into the role and industry, as well as hands-on learning
and experience.
Plus, they quickly show potential employers the experience and skills you have in project
management.
In addition to project management certifications, some employers in specific industries will
also favor candidates with other industry-related certifications as well.
For example, an IT project manager could benefit from both a project management certificate
and a CompTIA ITF+ certification or perhaps even an A+ certificate.
A PM in the construction industry might need both a project management certificate and
an associate constructor certificate from the American Institute of Constructors.
There are many project management certifications that are available, but here are a few common
certifications to explore.
Many entry-level project managers begin with a CAPM certification.
The Certified Associate in Project Management certificate, administered by the Project 
Management
Institute, is a starting point for anyone interested in a project coordinator or project
associate role.
To qualify to take the CAPM, you must have a secondary degree such as a high school diploma,
GED, or equivalent, and have at least 23 hours of project management education.
After getting CAPM certified, many people go on to get the Project Management Professional,
called the PMP certification.
The PMP certification requires a secondary or 4-year degree, either 36 or 60 months of
experience leading projects, and at least 35 hours of project management education or
a CAPM certification.
Common project management certifications in agile project management include Certified
ScrumMaster or CSM through the Scrum Alliance.
To become a Certified ScrumMaster, you must complete a CSM course and pass the CSM test.
You can also get a Professional Scrum Master or PSM Certification through Scrum.org.
There are no requirements to take the PSM certification assessment, but you may find
it useful to review the Scrum Guide and practice assessment provided by Scrum.org.
Finally, if you are interested in a career in IT project management, it may be useful
to get a CompTIA A+ certification.
The Computing Technology Industry Association or CompTIA provides this certification to
display knowledge in IT support tasks
such as troubleshooting, identifying, and configuring hardware and software troubleshooting.
Nine to twelve months of experience is recommended but not required to take the certification
exams.
Lastly, the most important qualification a person can have is experience.
But how does one get experience for your first job?
One way to gain experience is by turning a personal goal like planting a garden or writing
a book into a project.
Use project management methods and tools to manage your project and reach your goal.
Another way to gain experience is by volunteering.
Many non-profit organizations have projects they need to lead.
This can give you an opportunity to gain exposure to new projects and learn about leadership
management.
You may find that you can get an apprenticeship, internship, or co-op.
These roles are often designed as partnerships between community organizations, colleges,
students, and corporate employers.
In these types of programs, you can get on-the-job training and mentoring while you work and
explore specific careers and industries.
Finally, you can see about co-leading a project or shadowing a project manager in your current
industry or school.
Learning experiences such as these boost your confidence and prepare you for more responsible
roles.
In this video, you learned:
Many colleges offer project management certificates that you can receive while you are getting
your degree.
Informal training opportunities are available through self-paced courses for those that
require more flexibility with schedules.
Certifications are the process by which you prove that you have the knowledge, skills,
and experience to perform in a project management role.
Common certifications for project management include the CAPM, PMP, CSM, and PSM.
You can get experience for your first role in project management through a number of
ways,
including managing personal projects, volunteering, co-ops, internships, and shadowing or co-
leading
a project in your current role.

Career Progression in Project Management
Welcome to "Career Progression in Project Management."
After watching this video, you will be able to
outline the various career paths available to project management professionals, and
describe the roles and responsibilities in each position.
Project management professionals can pursue a variety of career paths.
Project managers may progress from entry-level roles to more senior roles.
They can eventually progress to senior executive-level roles.
Let's explore the career progression from an
entry-level project coordinator to more senior roles such as a VP of Operations.
While most careers do not follow a straight-forward, linear path,
the typical role progression in an organization would be:
Beginning a career as a Project Coordinator,
then becoming a Project Manager, then a promotion to Senior Project Manager.
After years of experience managing individual projects with complex parts,
a senior project manager may move into the role of program manager and then
portfolio manager.
Some program and portfolio managers who lead many successful projects may attain roles such as
Director of Project Management or VP of Operations.
Those interested in a career in project management may start as an
entry-level project coordinator.
This is an administrative position in charge of the generation and
distribution of project reports and often also deals with scheduling.
A project coordinator is a member of the project management team who
assists with the project.
Project coordinators will
attend meetings and assist on minor aspects of the project,
meet with the project team regularly to report on progress and
discuss any potential roadblocks,
prepare meeting agendas and notes, and maintain project and meeting schedules.
After some time as a project coordinator, you can progress to a project manager.
A project manager is an entry- or mid-level role who uses appropriate tools, techniques,
and processes to complete a project successfully.
A project manager is responsible for:
balancing resource availability with resource requirement,
working within project constraints that include budget, scope, and schedule, and
meeting and managing key stakeholders'
expectations related to quality standards.
Experienced project managers can then become senior project managers.
A senior project manager is often also a member of a larger management team.
A senior project manager may be in charge of
projects that have a broader scope or are more complex.
They may also oversee multiple projects and must determine which
projects and tasks need to be prioritized.
After gaining a rich experience of working at the project level in an organization,
a project management professional can advance to the role of program management.
A program is a collection of projects managed together to reap benefits
that would not be possible had they been managed individually.
Program management involves greater responsibility as it requires
overseeing multiple, simultaneous projects that are dependent on one another.
To succeed, a program manager must:
develop program-level plans,
strategically manage several projects,
analyze the business benefits of a program, and
manage project dependencies.
As someone continues to progress in their career,
they advance into a senior role and may become a portfolio manager.
This position carries a great deal of responsibility and,
hence, requires rich experience and expertise.
A portfolio manager is responsible for a group of
projects and programs managed together to achieve strategic business goals.
Hence, a portfolio manager is in charge of the centralized
management of one or more portfolios to achieve the goals of an organization.
Very experienced project management professionals can attain senior and executive-level positions,
such as Director of the Project Management Office (PMO) and Vice President of Operations.
The Director of Project Management is a senior management-level position that requires five or
more years of managerial experience plus project management experience.
They oversee other senior-level project, program, and portfolio managers.
They are responsible for guiding, instructing, and developing project management operations and 
structuring processes and workflows.
They ensure overall project governance by establishing project delivery standards, protocols, and 
tools.
The Vice President of Operations is an executive-level position that requires ten years of industry 
experience.
The Vice President is accountable for developing and implementing efficient and cost-effective 
operations that drive the current and future goals of the organization.
They are responsible for operating, managing, planning, and coordinating the overall operations of 
an organization.
They ensure operations run smoothly by setting a strategic, operational vision and enforcing an 
organization's policies and procedures.
In this video, you learned that:
A project coordinator is an entry-level administrative position responsible for creating and 
distributing project reports.
A project manager is responsible for managing the necessary tools, techniques, and processes to 
successfully complete a project.
A senior project manager oversees multiple projects and decides which needs to be prioritized.
A program manager oversees multiple projects, analyzes business benefits, manages project 
dependencies, and develops program-level plans.
A portfolio manager supervises the centralized management of one or more portfolios to achieve 
organizational goals.
The Director of Project Management guides, instructs, and develops project management
operations, structures the workflow, and ensures overall project governance.
The Vice President of Operations is in charge of operating, managing,
planning, and coordinating a project's overall operations.

for job hunting and progressing in a career as a project manager.
Number one, find a mentor, find someone that you can follow,
find someone who will be a coach to you.
Someone that you can respect, someone that you can understand,
someone who has had a successful career in project manager.
Number two, be an active listener, you have two ears.
You have two eyes, and you have one mouth.
There's a reason why we have two ears.
Listening will allow you to absorb more information than speaking.
Find that mentor, find that individual who has a quote on quote,
"Been there and done it," and listen closely.
In addition, make sure that you learn from both positive and negative examples.
As a project manager, you're going to see some people who just flat out do not do it well.
You're going to see others who are very, very successful.
Watch the people who do not do project management well.
Try to determine why did they fail.
Watch the people who perform project management well, ask yourself.
Why did they succeed?
Oftentimes the positive examples are outstanding,
but in reality, we oftentimes learn more from the negative examples.

Any type of job that you're thinking about going into.
It's very helpful. You can understand from their point of view what it's like in their day-to-day.
