Module 4 Summary: Careers in Project 
Management
•	Project managers work across a variety of industries including construction, engineering, IT, 
finance, healthcare, and manufacturing. Each industry comes with its own requirements and 
types of projects.
•	Because industries are becoming more project-based, project management-oriented 
employment is expected to increase consistently over the next ten years.
•	In addition to the usual responsibilities of project management, responsibilities unique to IT 
project management include implementing IT strategy, managing IT resources, and 
communicating with IT managers, employees, and clients. Required technical skills also 
include familiarity with IT concepts and software development methodologies.
•	There are different ways to become a project manager. Certain industries or positions require 
a degree, as well as certain certifications such as the Project Management Professional 
(PMP), Certified Associate in Project Management (CAPM), PMI Agile Certified 
Practitioner (PMI ACP), and Agile/Scrum. Higher-level positions typically require a certain 
number of years of experience.
•	Generally, project management professionals will move from lower-level positions to more 
senior or executive ones. Entry-level positions include project coordinator and project 
manager, while mid-level positions include senior project manager, program manager, or 
portfolio manager. After that, senior executive level roles in project management include 
titles such as a director of project management or chief operating officer.

Key Takeaways From This Course
This course provided a comprehensive introduction to project management. You learned what 
project management is, its benefits, and the constraints it helps manage. You also learned the role 
played by project managers and how recent trends, such as remote work, have shaped modern 
project management.
The course covered opportunities for different careers within project management and discussed 
jobs across different industries and experience levels, as well as the various technical and soft skills 
required for project management work.
In particular, key takeaways from this course include that:
•	Project management applies knowledge, skills, and tools to projects to produce value, 
manage budgets and timelines, improve productivity, address risks, and increase customer 
satisfaction.
•	Successful project management controls project scope, schedule, budget, risk, quality, 
resources, and maintains positive working relationships with stakeholders.
•	A project is unique, temporary, completable, and measurable, while a program is a collection 
of large, long-term, general, and strategic projects. A portfolio is an ongoing collection of 
projects and programs aligned with an organization's strategic objectives.
•	Project managers drive time, quality, and resources and use Waterfall, Critical Path, Critical 
Chain, Agile, Lean, and Six Sigma methodologies.
•	Recent project management trends include the use of AI, project management software, data 
analytics, remote teams, hybrid methodologies, and an emphasis on soft skills.
•	Practical technical skills for project managers include knowledge of project management 
methodologies, business administration, and software and information technology.
•	Valuable soft skills for project managers include communication, time management, 
problem-solving, interpersonal and leadership skills, and self-motivation.
•	Project managers are responsible for project planning, execution, monitoring and reporting, 
post-project evaluation, and project closing.
•	Project management employment in the construction, engineering, IT, finance, healthcare, 
and manufacturing industries
•	Is expected to increase consistently over the next ten years across the construction, 
engineering, IT, finance, healthcare, and manufacturing industries.
•	IT project managers have unique responsibilities, such as implementing IT strategy, 
managing IT resources, and communicating with IT managers, employees, and clients.
•	Becoming a project manager may require a degree, specific certifications, and years of 
experience, with entry-level, mid-level, and senior executive roles available, including 
project coordinator, project manager, senior project manager, program manager, portfolio 
manager, director of project management, and chief operating officer.

Key Project Management Resources
The Project Management Institute (PMI)
https://www.pmi.org/
•	PMI is a not-for-profit professional association that writes publications, proposes guidelines 
and best practices, organizes and hosts educational events and conferences, gives training, 
and offers professional certifications.
•	PMI offers the Project Management Professional (PMP) certification, the PMI Risk 
Management Professions (PMI-RMP), the Disciplined Agile Coach (DAC), and the Program 
Management Professional (PgMP) certifications, along with others. On the PMI site, you 
can also get recommendations for what certifications to take based on your experience.
The Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK) Guide - 7th edition
https://www.pmi.org/pmbok-guide-standards/foundational/pmbok
•	Published by the PMI, The Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK) Guide - 7th 
edition provides a set of twelve project management principles structured around eight 
performance domains. The twelve principles are identified and outlined in this PDF
•	. These principles are widely taught in many Project Management Courses.
PMP Exam Prep 2022 and 2023 Study Guide
PMP Exam Prep 2022 and 2023 Study Guide
•	This study guide gives you practice test questions and a similar test layout to prepare you for 
the PMP exam. It offers valuable tips, strategies, and a complete review of the Project 
Management Body of Knowledge test sections.
•	A fair number of jobs with PMP listings require you to have a PMP certification, which 
requires you to take the PMP exam. A PMP study guide is not necessary to take the test, but 
it can help.
The Agile Leader
The Agile Leader
•	This book by Simon Hayward (2021) provides advice on how to lead teams using Agile 
methodologies to quickly adapt and respond to shifting organizational priorities. It analyzes 
several industry case studies to apply expert leadership strategies. The book also illustrates 
how leaders can stabilize their teams during uncertainty and change.
Introduction to Agile Development and Scrum
https://www.coursera.org/learn/agile-development-and-scrum
•	This course offered by IBM on the Coursera platform teaches concepts such as adaptive 
planning, iterative development, test-driven development, and continuous improvement. In 
this hands-on course, you apply the spring planning process, write user stories, track user 
stories with a Kanban board, create burndown charts, and use metrics to enhance 
productivity and promote client satisfaction.
The Lean Enterprise Institute and Blog
https://www.lean.org/
Articles - Lean Enterprise Institute
•	The Lean Enterprise Institute is a non-profit research-based organization that promotes lean 
thinking and practices. They provide educational experiences and learning materials, foster 
partnerships, and host conferences focused on lean principles.
•	They also have an excellent blog about how to apply the Lean methodology in different 
business environments. There you can also find Lean trends and success stories.
Project Management for Dummies
Project Management for Dummies
•	This book by Stanley E. Portny (any edition, but newer versions will have more pertinent 
information and be more closely related to the modern-day PMP exam) introduces the core 
principles of successful project management.
•	The book teaches you about organizing, estimating, and scheduling projects efficiently and 
discusses how to motivate any team to gain maximum productivity. It's a valuable resource 
that gives you all the math equations, concepts, and conflicts you may see as a PMP and 
shows you how to apply them before applying for the PMP exam. It also points you in the 
right direction to help you find more resources in case you need additional help.
•	The back of the book has more further resources that you can use to help you not only 
become a project manager but also improve your project management skills once you've 
become a project manager.
Six Sigma Principles
https://www.coursera.org/learn/six-sigma-principles
•	This course, presented by the University System of Georgia, introduces you to the 
foundational knowledge of Six Sigma and Lean principles, roles, and responsibilities. You 
will also be introduced to tools and metrics that are critical to Six Sigma.
•	Lean Six Sigma and Project Management
•	Lean Six Sigma and Project Management
•	This informative article discusses what Six Sigma is, what project management is, 
and how the two can be applied to achieve successful projects. It also discusses the 
similarities and differences between Six Sigma and project management.

Project Management Foundations, Initiation, and Planning

Welcome
Welcome to Project Management Foundations Initiation and Planning. This is a six-week 
course, where you can expect to spend approximately 2-4 hours per module.
This course forms part of two Project Management certificate series:
•	IBM IT Project Manager Professional Certificate
•	Project Management Professional Certificate
Here are some tips to make sure that you get the best experience and gain the required knowledge 
for a job interview or a certification, or for that matter, to enhance your skills.
Tip 1: Get familiar with the course content
Browse through the module structure to get a feel of the topics and associated assets. This will help 
you navigate through the course easily and also help you to understand the mandatory and optional 
topics in the module.
Familiarize yourself with the order of topics, as this will help you connect the ideas together and 
form a cohesive whole. The outline with the modules and lessons in the course is available later in 
this topic.
Tip 2: Create your schedule to complete the course
Set a target date when you want to finish the course and schedule time each day to study. Set a 
reasonable goal for yourself to complete each module.
Tip 3: Be an active learner
•	Set some time aside for studying the course. Avoid distractions.
•	When watching instructional videos, make sure to take notes. You can download transcripts 
and highlight parts of the narration that you think are important. Alternatively, you can take 
notes elsewhere.
•	Keeping yourself engaged is important to learn more as well as measure your understanding.
•	Go through the readings thoroughly as they help connect the instructional videos and real-
life scenarios.
•	The course contains Expert Viewpoints, which bring out answers to project management-
related questions from experts in the field. Compare what the experts say to what you 
learned in the instructional videos and readings.
•	Make sure to review the demo videos and attempt the labs. This will help you get used to the 
different project management-related activities that you will need to as a project manager 
role.
•	Attempt all of the practice quizzes and read the feedback for correct and incorrect responses. 
Retake them until you get all of the answers correct.
•	Complete all of the graded quizzes. If you get a response wrong, you can revisit the topic 
where that information was addressed. Review the topic, identify the correct response, and 
understand why that answer is correct. While there is a minimum passing score, you can 
retake graded quizzes for a higher score.
•	Discussion forums are optional. However, it is recommended that you actively participate in 
the discussion forums. Provide thoughtful responses to the prompts and engage by 
responding to others' posts.
Tip 4: Inform your family and friends about course goals
Signing up for the course was the first step. You must make yourself accountable and commit to the 
course. Inform your family and friends about this commitment. If there are topics where you need a 
different perspective, get family and friends involved. 
Tip 5: Follow through with your plan
You create a schedule for yourself in Tip 2. Make sure to stay motivated and achieve your set goals. 
Commit and execute! Be unstoppable and keep yourself motivated!

Course Introduction
Welcome to this course on Project Management Foundations, Initiation and Planning.
After completing this course, you will be able to:
Explain project management concepts, principles, and terminology,
Design effective project management templates for launching your projects,
Integrate clear, understandable, and practical methods to improve project management results
in real-world scenarios,
Use skills and tools to carry out activities required to set up and initiate a project,
Describe how project management is changing in the modern era,
And distinguish between various methodologies for project planning and management.
The first module in this course, titled "Why Project Management?"
defines project management and the role project managers play in overseeing projects.
You will learn about the skills, competencies, traits, and mindset required to be a successful
project manager.
In Module 2: Traditional Project Management, you will learn traditional methodologies,
as well as high-level information about the 10 leading project management approaches.
This module also covers project management phases or process groups, organizational types,
definitions, and the role of the project management office (or PMO).
The third module, Modern Project Management, introduces concepts relevant to today's
world, where teams are frequently dispersed globally and more collaboration tools are
available.
The module begins by defining modern project management, including principle-based project
management, and later discusses its benefits and drawbacks.
In Setting Up the Project for Success, you will learn about and practice some key tools
a project manager uses to initiate a project.
It involves a project charter, project brief, a Responsible Accountable Consulted and Informed
(or RACI) chart, stakeholder analysis and matrix, and project budget.
The fifth module is Project Planning, which introduces you to developing a project management
plan.
This includes end-to-end scope, schedule, and budget planning.
You will learn essential project planning tools such as a work breakdown structure (or
WBS), a project network diagram, and three-point budget estimation.
Finally, in the Final Project and Assessment module you will review the key takeaways of
the course, complete a final project, and take the final quiz.
This course uses various teaching methods, including instructional videos, discussion
activities, scenario-labs, and quizzes.
In the guided instructional videos, a subject matter expert (or SME) walks you through project
management concepts with essential need-to-know facts.
The discussion activities reinforce what you've learned in the course videos and encourages
you to apply new knowledge and skills as you learn.
In the labs, you will develop a project charter, an RACI chart, a stakeholder matrix and analysis,
and a project budget.
Once completed, these key tools can be added to your portfolio to demonstrate your project
management skills to potential employees.
Practice and graded quizzes are included in each module to assess your learning and validate
the key concepts introduced.
Once you have completed this course, you will receive certificate that can be shared with
prospective employers to demonstrate your knowledge of project management.
Good luck, and let's get started!

Project management can be a highly rewarding career path.

of this position.
Project management entails leading a team through all the stages of a project successfully.
Project managers are chiefly responsible for the planning, development, delivery, and closure
of a project in a set timeframe.
To accomplish the mission, project managers should be well-versed in project management
tools, techniques, and processes.
To explain in greater detail and provide insights to learners, we aim to create a course that

role.

the situations and the different phases of a project.

with stakeholders.

cover in the series will be beneficial to achieving your career goals.

success.

Expert Viewpoints: Importance of Project 
Management

Welcome to Expert Viewpoints: Importance of Project Management.
In this video, we will hear from project managers discussing why project management is important.
So I think that great project management really allows members of a team to focus intently
on the work that needs to get done to meet the project objectives rather than spending
a lot of time trying to figure out what needs to get done or doing rework because they aren't
working maybe on the right things or they don't have all the information that they need
to complete the tasks that they need to get done.
I think very good project managers help teams anticipate and mitigate and even resolve risks
and issues that come up in challenges that come up during the lifecycle of the project.
And then I also think that having clear deliverables that are communicated clearly, that are defined
early on in the project, they're communicated frequently.
They help the team know exactly what's going on and when it needs to get done.
I think project management is more important now than ever.
There are so many more remote project teams than ever before and teams are spread across
multiple timezones.
And while teams are physically apart, the speed of communication is happening fast through
collaboration tools like Slack and Microsoft teams.
So, you need that central person to track the broad and rapid communication and make
sure information is getting to the right people at the right time so everyone can deliver
their best quality work.
The project manager really is the rudder that kind of steers the project ship.
When you think about what the project manager does, they are responsible for managing the
schedule, managing all the individual tasks that need to happen.
They're responsible for communicating with upper management and with the team about the
project status, about changes and requirements.
So, the project manager really is that person that's responsible for making sure that the
project is moving in the direction that it's supposed to be moving in.
Think about a government without government officials or a corporation without a CEO.
The project manager really is essential in ensuring that the project goals are met and
that the project meets those goals.
When I think about a project without a project manager or even projects that have poor project
management projects end up, you know, doing similar work over and over again.
They end up repeating tasks or missing schedules or deadlines.
There's been some projects that I've been a part of that have been self-managed where
the team tries to manage the tasks and schedules on their own and there's too many voices.
People assume things are getting done when they're not getting done.
People assume they know the tasks when they really don't know the tasks that need to be
accomplished for a project.
So, the project manager is the individual or the team that takes all of the essentials
of a project and ensures those essentials are being accomplished, those goals are being
met.

Expert Viewpoints: Project Management - The 
Journey
Welcome to Expert
Viewpoints: Project Management - The Journey.
In this video, we will hear from project managers discussing the journey and destination of
project management.
Let's begin with the destination.
What is the destination?
What is the ultimate goal of a project?
On time, within budget, and providing scope to satisfy the customer's needs.
Being able to move the bar for the organization to provide value.
But it's not all about the destination.
The journey is working together, building the team, gaining new skills, building new
relationships.
It's achieving success not only for the organization
but for yourself.
It's about in addition to being empowered to make a difference.
Within a project itself, you can think about the actual journey is going through the project.
What happens at the very beginning, during the middle, and then towards the end?
How did you get to your destination, which is the end result?
So, did you actually complete the project at time with its scope and budget and then
also add in what your lessons are learned?
The difference between the journey and the
destination of project management is the difference
between the tasks and the people and the schedule that is meant to accomplish the goals of the
project and the final deliverable.
The final product that you're delivering.
So let's suppose that a project is building software.
They're building a software package.
The journey is about the process that's involved in building that software.
Who's going to do what jobs, what resources do we need to accomplish our goals?
What are the goals?
What's the vision of the product?
What are some potential roadblocks?
What are dependencies that this project has?
What do we need to make sure that we have in place so that we can accomplish all of
our tasks.
The destination is the software product itself, along with any extra things that are needed
to get that software to the customer.
So for example, marketing or some advertising manuals that the, or user guides that the
software will need to support it.
Ensuring that there's a software support system in place for that software package.
That's the destination.
Ensuring that all those things are in place.
Well, first of all, I would advise all of you to try to understand, as best you can,
the art of project management.
This includes effective communications, influencing
motivation, coaching and more.
Learn these skills.
Try to be as good at these skills as you can.
But along with those business skills or soft skills.
Understand the science of project management as well, understand lifecycles.
Know how a project needs to be planned from beginning to end and know what you know and
know what you don't know and surround yourself with people who know what you don't know.
One of the big myths is that the project manager needs to be the expert in everything that
is wrong.
A project manager needs to understand where they are, the expert, but also where they're
not the expert and surround themselves with people who are.
A successful journey is well thought out and well-planned.
It doesn't skip the planning part of the actual journey.
You have to have that in order to have a
successful journey.
From there, you're able to gather all the right resources.
It might be products.
It might be people involved like your team members, but making sure that you have all
the right resources.
And then to have a successful destination as to understand the true scope and expectations.
I think there's many things that a project manager can do to ensure a successful journey
and to ensure that the destination is reached.
In my experience, probably the biggest aspect of a good project manager is (communication.
A project manager has to be both a coach as well as a person that's able to drive the
project forward.
I don't think a project manager needs to be a subject matter expert on every aspect of
the project or what the project team is building.
But they do need to be able to talk about what that project comprises.
Some of the technical aspects of that project, and they need to have that that level of expertise
so that they can communicate properly to every
stakeholder and and person involved in accomplishing
the goals of that project.
So, communication to me is a big one.
Another one is being able to manage time.
And this it sounds like a it sounds like it's a very basic thing to be able to manage time.
We all have to manage time in our day and what we're going to accomplish and what we're
going to be doing in a given day.
But when I talk about time management, I'm talking about being able to know how different
aspects of the project need to get accomplished, in what order.
A third aspect for ensuring that the journey is done in a way that accomplishes the project's
goals is to know how to weight things.
And what I mean by that is not everything is worth calling a meeting for or not.
Everything is worth sending out a broad email to upper management and to the team.
Some things need to be ignored sometimes.
So, that weighting aspect, I think is very, very important.
So, that that those three aspects along with a bunch of other things.
But those to me are very critical for ensuring that the journey of a project is successful.
Ensuring that the destination is successful really means to me thinking through what does
the end game look like?
I think a lot of project managers look at the tasks that need to be accomplished and
what the team is going to do for those tasks.
But they forget that once the project is is done, once that the product is built or whatever
it is that you're delivering as is accomplished.
What does that look like?
How do you communicate that out that things are completed?
How do you ensure that stakeholders are satisfied?
You may think that you accomplished the project's goals, but your stakeholders, the people that
are actually receiving the product, may not agree with you.
So, you might ask a question like, Is there going to be a follow on to this project where
things that we weren't able to get to in the first version we want to accomplish in the
second version.
Asking those types of questions.
Once you've delivered the product or the project is complete so, that your stakeholders have
an opportunity to provide more input there.
So, the destination really is about thinking about it ahead of time, playing it out in
your mind, almost role playing.
The project is now done.
What does that mean?
How do we get this to the customer?
How do we get this to the user?
How do we get this to upper management?
So, really ensuring that the the stakeholders are happy.
Upper management is happy and your team is happy at the end of the project.

Welcome to Expert Viewpoints: Project Management - The Journey Example. In this video,

That's the project management institute and I want to share ever so briefly a very

First of all, the challenge, a catastrophic weather event, destroyed roads and cut
off British Columbia's lower mainland, including Vancouver from the rest of Canada.
A huge project was needed. What was the solution? British Columbia's Ministry
of Transportation and Infrastructure used a project management approach based on a guide
to the project management Body of Knowledge, the acronym for that is the PMBOK Guide.
They use this guide to prioritize repairs and reopen critical routes as quickly as possible.
This included network analysis, identifying critical paths, requirements analysis, creating
a work breakdown structure, communications planning, implementing communication
protocols, risk management, preparing risk assessment and responses. And in addition,
soliciting the management of contributors and interested parties as well. What I shared with

the principal corridor for transportation of goods to and from the Port of Vancouver, Canada,
was reopened to commercial traffic in 35 days. This is a successful project and we hope that all
of your projects can be equally as successful. So, I got a project that my last company and
it was very large. I had over 200 sites and it was global. And to give you a key idea,
it was a plastics company. So, they're all over the world. COVID hit in the middle of it. We
had our plan really thought out as far as our overall journey. And of course, it changed. But
since we plan so well in advance, we were able to easily shift around the different locations.
And then we still had the end result for our destination, which was to complete those sites.
An example of a project that I thought run really well and met the criteria of successful
journey as well as a successful destination was at my time at a big corporation. I was on
a team that was developing a product that was essentially last in the competitive landscape
and our team had to play catch up. And there was a project manager that
helped us get there from a marketing perspective and what she would do is get us all into her
room twice a week. And she had a really nice spreadsheet and she would have everyone go
through their items in the spreadsheet. She kept our project time boxed or line items.
She kept our line items time boxed so that we didn't, you know, rattle on about things
that weren't important. If, as we were giving our status, we went off track,
she would ensure that we stayed on track and she would gently nudge us back into the right
frame of minds that we were talking about, the items that we needed to talk about.
And I remember at the time, I thought that even though she was very direct and she kept the
project moving and she kept us all on task, she did it in a way that actually kept us motivated.
So as we saw project progress every other day or, you know, twice a week we actually
got motivated. It was a lot of work and she kept us on task and we weren't allowed to not deliver,
but she did it in a way that I always felt like, hey, we're actually doing something.
We're getting. We're making the project better. We're moving this project forward by ensuring that
our customers know what our product does and why it does it better than the competition.
So in terms of that journey, she was a really good project manager for helping us make progress,
you know, every day that we had to work on something and informing the rest of our
peers and management about that progress and then being able to see the impact of
that progress in our product in the, the general product that we were building. But
also see that result in the marketplace as we are making you know reaching those goals

How is this Course Different?

stand out, And list the three common project constraints.
This course focuses on project management methodologies, structures, and principles.
Principles and methodologies do provide the foundation needed to address most project
scenarios.
But this course goes further than other project management courses by focusing on both the
science and the art of managing a project.
We achieve this unique combination of art and science by encouraging project managers
to look at the project through a new lens and to adopt creative approaches, including
innovative solutions and unique methods, such as data-driven decision-making and involving
stakeholders.
This approach ensures the long-term sustainability and effectiveness of projects.
With most projects leaders are overburdened, and the production team has aggressive goals.
And as a result, supply orders may become delayed.
A project manager must work within a defined budget and timeframe despite these constraints
and tight deadlines.
A successful project manager should know how to navigate these and other challenging scenarios.
In this course, we will explore concepts, tools, and tips and tricks to execute projects
successfully.
Business leaders often face three main project management constraints:
Time, Cost,
And scope.
Managing these three constraints can be challenging for a project manager, but it is also the
primary goal.

Introduction to Project Management 
Certification
Introduction
Project management is a critical function in any organization. Establishing your credibility in this 
growing and competitive market can be exceptionally challenging. Certifications in project 
management can help you in a few different ways, including:
•	Landing a better-paid job
•	Boosting your career opportunities
•	Being part of a project management community
A popular and prominent project management-related certification body is the Project Management 
Institute (PMI). PMI offers various certifications to cater to individuals in different stages of their 
careers. 
Certified Associate of Project Management (CAPM)and Project Management Professional (PMP) 
are two popular project management certification offerings from PMI. This course helps you 
prepare for both certifications. 
Certified Associate of Project Management (CAPM)
CAPM is an entry-level certification from PMI. Anyone trying to start their career in project 
management can take this certification. The key project management domains that form part of the 
CAPM certification include the following: 
•	Project management fundamentals and core concepts
•	Predictive, plan-based methodologies
•	Agile frameworks/methodologies
•	Business analysis frameworks
For more details about the CAPM certification, refer to https://www.pmi.org/certifications/certified-
associate-capm.
Project Management Professional (PMP)
With over a million PMP-certified professionals across the globe, PMP certification is a popular 
offering from PMI. PMP is for working professionals and project managers who want to boost their 
careers in any industry. The PMP certification requires the individual to have project experience and 
management training. 
For more details about the PMP certification, refer to https://www.pmi.org/certifications/project-
management-pmp
.
PMI also provides various other certifications. For a complete list, refer to 
https://www.pmi.org/certifications
.

Overview of Key Project Management Models
This article will teach you about phase-oriented project management models and their principles. It 
will also cover a few adaptive project management models and their principles.
The Waterfall model
The Waterfall model serves as the foundation for almost every project management approach. It is 
one of the core models of project management. It adopts an approach where the project activities 
are divided into sequential phases. Each phase must be completed before the next can begin.
Phases of the Waterfall model
These include:
•	System and software requirements
•	Analysis
•	Design
•	Coding or build
•	Testing
•	Operations
The Waterfall model was first implemented in the manufacturing and construction sectors, where 
altering a plan would be exceedingly costly early in the process. Cost overruns were reduced 
because of a disciplined approach to project management, gathering product specifications, and 
obtaining approvals. Due to the inflexibility of the Waterfall model, other modified versions have 
been developed, including ones with risk management and overlapping stages. Winston W Royce 
included risk management notes to the model in the 1970s to address the model's inherent risks.
Project Management Body of Knowledge edition 7 (PMBOK7)
The Project Management Institute (PMI) is well known for its certifications. To obtain these 
credentials, you must first pass a test based on the Project Management Body of Knowledge, or 
PMBOK. The latest edition, known as PMBOK7, marked a significant transition from phase-based 
project management to principles-based project management. Phases remain significant to the 
PMBOK7 approach, though. For this course, we are adopting the phase names from 
PMBOK6.PMBOK7's emphasis on principles-based project management makes it possible for 
guidance to be easily deployed to various project types, such as those adopting the Waterfall 
approach or those working in sprints. For each principle, information and resources are offered. You 
may also note that the emphasis is on customizing your project management strategy, also known as 
a tailored approach.
Projects In Controlled Environments (PRINCE2)
This model is based on the Waterfall approach and is governed by six aspects, seven principles, 
seven themes, and seven processes. The six aspects are scope, timescale, risk, quality, benefits, and 
cost. The seven principles that represent the guidelines include continued business justification, 
learning from experience, defined roles and responsibilities, management by stages, management by 
exception, focus on products, and tailoring to suit the project environment. The seven themes that 
represent the tools include business case, organization, quality, plans, risk, change, and progress. 
The seven processes that represent the roadmap include starting up a project, initiating a project, 
directing a project, controlling a stage, managing product delivery, managing stage boundaries, and 
closing a project.
A practitioner certification program is available if you want to dive deeper into PRINCE2.
Critical Path Method
The Critical Path Method is widely used with the Program Assessment and Review Technique 
(often called PERT). The longest series of interdependent project activities form a critical path. The 
length of the project is then estimated based on this path. To schedule project activities, the Critical 
Path Method employs an algorithm and the critical path.
Critical Chain Project Management
Eliyahu M. Goldratt created Critical Chain Project Management based on the Critical Path Method 
to help keep resources balanced throughout the project. Compared to the Critical Path Method, this 
approach to project planning and management places greater emphasis on resources, such as team 
members, tools, and software.
Adaptive project management models
These project management models lay great emphasis on responsiveness and flexibility. Like the 
phase-based models we discussed earlier, these models have entire courses and certificates 
dedicated to them. 
These models, which are more adaptable and flexible, include:
•	Agile
•	Scrum
•	Six Sigma Method
•	Lean
•	Kanban
Agile
In an Agile project management model, a project is carried out in iterations using sprints, which are 
typically week-long, as opposed to long and rigid project phases, as followed in Waterfall. Weekly 
processing of design decisions, implementation decisions, prototypes, and client feedback allows 
the end user to be more involved in the design process and enables the team to react swiftly if 
necessary.
Agile: Core values
The Agile Manifesto was created in 2001 and is a declaration of a unifying concept for frameworks 
like Scrum, Extreme Programming, and Feature-Driven Development (FDD). 
The original Agile Manifesto identified four core values that govern Agile. These include:
•	Individuals and interactions over processes and tools
•	Working software over comprehensive documentation
•	Customer collaboration over contract negotiation
•	Responding to change over following a plan
It is designed to create self-governed, highly collaborative, and adaptable teams.
Agile can be used for most projects. However, for best results, it should be combined with a more 
robust project management approach.
Scrum 
The next project management model is the Scrum methodology, which is ideally suited for Agile 
projects. It is also built to work in sprints, making it agile and adaptable. One significant difference 
is that Scrum has clearly defined Scrum roles.
Scrum roles
Some of the roles include:
•	A Scrum master 
•	A Scrum product owner
•	A Scrum team
A Scrum Master is primarily a project manager. This role involves managing the project in 
accordance with Scrum processes and guidelines. The key responsibility of this role is to remove 
roadblocks for the project team.
A Scrum product owner represents the voice of the customer for the team. The owner establishes 
priorities for the product backlog and ensures that the project achieves a high return on investment 
(ROI).
A Scrum team consists of members who have the technical expertise to contribute to a project. They 
work toward delivering the project on time and with quality.
Six Sigma method
Another project management model is the Six Sigma method. It is a set of tools and techniques used 
for process improvement. Bill Smith, a Motorola engineer, invented this model in 1986. Six Sigma 
is a statistical term that refers to the original goal of having an extremely low rate of product 
defects. Six Sigma is frequently credited with transforming quality management into a profession 
rather than something handled by the production team.
Overall, the Six Sigma method is data driven. Data accuracy is required. It is a system of 
systematically identifying errors and providing methods to eliminate them. Some project managers 
have recently combined Six Sigma and Lean, creating a method known as Lean Six Sigma. With 
Six Sigma's emphasis on variation and Lean's emphasis on process implementation and waste 
reduction, these two methods complement each other well.
Lean 
The application of Lean concepts to project management is referred to as the Lean project 
management model. Lean means delivering value while minimizing waste. Note that waste here 
means improper utilization of resources and time. A bottleneck in a process, for example, is 
considered waste. In such cases, project managers need to take prompt corrective measures to 
prevent bottlenecks. Lean, frequently associated with Just-In-Time (JIT) manufacturing, aims to 
align production with demand by emphasizing productivity, efficiency, and waste reduction.
Lean principles
Lean principles include creating flow, value and value stream, and perfection. 
Creating flow is an important Lean principle. Moving a product through different phases swiftly, 
continuously, and effectively allows space for the next product. Instead of working in huge batches, 
each task is completed in a continuous flow. While Agile has weekly sprints, Lean is a continuous 
process from the beginning to the end. Value and value stream are other key Lean principles. The 
consumer defines the value, and the value stream actively works to reduce waste throughout the 
process. The last Lean principle is perfection. It refers to delivering the best product with the least 
amount of waste.
Kanban
Kanban was developed and used by Toyota as part of the Lean manufacturing model.
The key feature of the Kanban model is real-time communication about capacity and complete 
transparency related to work. Note that Kanban is a Japanese word that means "visual board." Work 
assignments are visually represented on a board. This allows the team members to know the status 
of every work at any stage. This model is based on the pull system, which means that production is 
based on the customer's demand. It is not based on the push system, where a product is produced 
and pushed into the market. The goal is minimizing waste without impacting production and 
creating customer value without increasing costs.
Application of Kanban
The six rules for the application of Kanban were outlined by Taiichi Ohno in Toyota Production 
System: Beyond Large-Scale Production in 1988. They are as follows:
1.	Each process issues requests (Kanban) to its suppliers when it consumes its supplies.
2.	Each process produces according to the quantity and sequence of incoming requests.
3.	No items are made or transported without a request.
4.	The request associated with an item is always attached to it.
5.	Processes must not send out defective items to ensure that the finished products will be 
defect-free.
6.	Limiting the number of pending requests makes the process more sensitive and reveals 
inefficiencies.
These rules very closely follow the Lean methodology guidelines, including eliminating waste to 
streamline processes.
Conclusion
In conclusion, there are different project management models available, each with its own set of 
principles and best practices. The choice of the model depends on the specific needs of the project 
and the environment in which it is being executed. It is important to select the appropriate model for 
the project and to adapt it as needed to ensure project success.

Traditional Project Management
Welcome to "Traditional Project Management."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Identify two key factors considered to evaluate a project.
Explain four major approaches to project management.
Define the composition of an agile team.
Describe Stacey's Matrix.
Delivering a project can be a challenging task.
A project manager's role is crucial in today's corporate world.
There is a growing need for facilitating high-level processes in businesses.
A project manager needs to consider two key factors when evaluating a project:
First is the frequency of deliverables.
Some clients require products or services to be delivered at the project's end, while
others prefer frequent deliveries throughout the project's lifecycle.
Second is the frequency of modifying specifications of project deliverables.
The project manager must plan accordingly.
In this video, you learned that: The two factors project managers use to evaluate
a project include the frequency of deliverables and the frequency of modifying specifications
of project deliverables.
The four approaches to project management are predictive, incremental, iterative, and
agile, An agile team is an organized group of members
collaborating to deliver a product using an iterative approach.
The project manager role does not exist in the agile team.
Instead, leadership responsibilities are divided among the product owner and the scrum master.
Stacey's Matrix assists project managers in determining the type of approach they need
to deliver a project successfully.
The matrix enables the analysis of two critical criteria:
Requirement uncertainty And the technical degree of uncertainty.

I prefer an agile or scrum approach.
When agreement among stakeholders is high and complexity is low,

Project Management Phases

Welcome to Project Management Phases.
After watching this video, you'll be able to:
Discuss the purpose of project management phases.
Describe different ways to approach creating phases in a project and some models for doing so.
And list the project phases that will be used in this series of courses.
Project management models consist of phases that a project will go through. Dividing a project
into phases segments the workload into more manageable pieces, making the project manager's
role of planning and guiding a project easier. Phases give the project structure and logical
steps to achieve goals and deliver high quality products. Providing this high-level structure
for the program makes it easier to plan the activities and tasks to complete each phase.
The phases used in project management vary,
and there are different opinions about how many phases to use. Let's look at a few examples.
T
The number of names for the different phases and different structures available is basically
limitless, and new ones will surely be invented in the future as businesses and the project
management profession evolve. If you look closer at the many versions of phases available for
project management, you'll notice that although each set of phases may have different names,
they are generally aligned on the activities needed to complete a project. They are also
usually aligned on the activities that are required to complete a phase. You can look at
the variety of available models and select one that will work best for each project.
For the purposes of the three courses in this series, we will use the project phases
as defined in the Project Management Body of Knowledge edition 6 guide, also known as 
PMBOK6.
The 5 phases we will use are:
Initiation
Planning
Execution
Monitoring and Controlling
Closing
As you work your way through the course materials, keep in mind that we have anchored the course 
on
these commonly used phases. Names and combinations of activities may change,
but you should be able to map the activities from one model to another. For example,
you might be using the waterfall model on your project with its six phases:
requirements, system design, implementation, testing, deployment, and maintenance. To map
these phases back to the phases used in this course, you could consider both the
implementation and testing phases part of the execution phase in the PMBOK6 model.
Tweaks and adjustments like this are part of tailoring your approach and understanding
how the different models can be adjusted to fit a specific project. In the third
course of this series, we will discuss how a project manager's activities shift
throughout the project lifecycle. From setting up templates through the final closing report,
the role of the project manager shifts throughout the phases.
In this video, you learned that:
Dividing a project into phases helps a project manager plan how to complete a project.
Different models and project structures call for different numbers and names for phases,
but they can often be aligned to a core set of activities.

Different Types of Organizations
Welcome to "Different Types of Organizations."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Describe the effect of organizational structure on project management.
Identify types of organizational structures.
Define how to align project objectives with the organizational strategy.
Organizational structure refers to how a company organizes its tasks, allocates resources,
and coordinates different teams within the organization.
It determines each employee's role and place in the organization and is essential for organizational
growth.
There are different types of organizational structures, and project managers must be able
to identify which model suits them most.
It is important for project managers to understand the fundamental principles of building an
organizational structure.
These include the project manager's authority, role, resource availability, budget control,
and project management administration staff.
With the authority principle, a project manager can make decisions, issue orders, and perform
resource allocation to achieve the set goal.
In some organizations, the authority of a project manager is greater, which enhances
their ability to influence others and achieve the team and organizational goals.
Another principle of building an organizational structure is the project manager's role.
Some organizations hire project managers part-time, while others employ full-time project 
managers,
which impacts project management in the organization.
Next is a project's resource availability.
Some organizations provide resources to plan and manage a project at a high level.
In other organizations, a project manager might face challenges in getting the required
level of support.
Another principle is budget control.
In some organizations, a project manager manages and controls the budget.
While in others, a functional manager manages and controls the budget.
And finally, there's the Project management administration staff.
The staff size may differ depending on the organizational structure.
Staff size impacts how a project manager manages a project.
The two organizational structures the Project Management Institute (or PMI) recognizes are
functional and matrix.
The functional organizational structure follows a hierarchical model.
An organization with a functional structure groups employees into departments based on
specialization.
Every department designates a leader experienced in managing and supervising the functions
of each employee.
Such organizations have a top-down decision-making process in place.
The decision-making power is centralized.
Leaders of different departments communicate regularly to frame the organizational strategy,
and the low-level employees have little information about what's happening outside their 
department.
In the matrix organizational structure, teams or groups report to multiple team leaders.
Each team leader is assigned a member or a team from each functional area applicable
to the project.
So, the functional team member reports to two bosses, the project leader, and the functional
manager.
The three types of matrix structures are weak, balanced, and strong.
In the weak matrix structure, a project manager directly reports to the functional manager
and provides support as a project coordinator with limited power.
The balanced matrix structure is like the weak matrix structure.
Except that in the former, the project manager has more authority and decision-making power.
In the strong matrix structure, a project manager has more power than the functional
manager, can use their project management skills on projects, and can determine resource
allocation.
A project manager needs to have project objectives aligned with the organizational strategy.
Its advantage is that: The project is of high quality and stays within
the budget and timeline, and All the stakeholders understand the project's
goals and objectives.
In order to align the project objectives, managers should complete these five tasks.
Communicate the project's value and aim and encourage significant sponsorship and backing.
Plan to ensure the projects comply with the scope, schedule, and budget and meet the stakeholders'
needs.
Determine what resources are required to complete the project successfully.
Identify the stakeholder's essentials for the project's success and seek their assistance.
Finally, create a project charter that enables you to gain authority, support for hiring
and planning, and clear sponsorship.
In this video, you learned that: An organizational structure is how a company
organizes its tasks, allocates resources, and coordinates teams within the organization.
The fundamental principles of building an organizational structure include the project
manager's authority, role, resource availability, budget control, and administration staff.
.
The Project Management Office

Welcome to "The Project Management Office."
After watching this video, you'll be able to:
Define a project management office,
Describe the common functions of project management offices,
And list the three types of project management offices.
One other important role of the PMO is driving accurate documentation.
The PMO works with project managers to see that documentation, such as timelines and
meeting notes, is captured and posted.
When the project is closed, the PMO will review it; if everything is accounted for, it will
archive the project.
PMOs are often responsible for reporting budgets and projects to company leadership.
Project managers may work closely with PMO team members to prepare materials for these
leadership updates.
PMOs keep their eye on the future and the big picture.
They work to identify commonalities so they can be addressed cohesively.
Because the PMO works with so many projects, they can see the big picture and its trends.
They can guide and coordinate the project managers with a high-level perspective that
others may not be able to see.
Of course, no two PMOs will ever be exactly alike, but three common types have emerged:
Supportive: This type exerts a low level of control in decision-making but does provide
best practices, common oversight, and templates.
A supportive PMO shares information and best practices in project management across the
enterprise.
Controlling: This type has some decision-making capabilities but not absolute control.
They often review project managers' work to ensure it meets the organization's practices,
templates, and standards.
A controlling PMO shares information in the same way as a supportive PMO.
Controlling PMOs, however, establish rules for compliance and monitor adherence to those
rules.
Directive: This type leads with a high degree of control over the processes, standards,
templates, reporting, and documentation.
The directive PMO provides information and may also manage compliance.
The most significant difference is the control of resources.
Directive PMOs may manage all project management resources and assign them to projects to meet
the organization's needs.
PMOs can also be layered.
For example, one layer of PMO may provide best practices, templates, and processes,
with a higher-level PMO to govern and report to leadership.
In this video, you learned that: PMOs are responsible for activities that support
project managers at a strategic level.
A PMO standardizes processes, including accurate documentation, and facilitates sharing of
resources.
PMOs can be grouped into three types: supportive, controlling, and directive.
PMOs are much more than just project managers for project managers.
They are essential to an organization and key to reaching its strategic goals.

Office

In this video, we will hear from project managers discussing PMOs, or project management offices.
Well, first and foremost, we need to define what a PMO is.

Number one, they provide needed guidance and support.
They show you the way.
Number two, they may ensure compliance to policies and procedures.
They try to make sure that everyone is on the same page and everyone is doing it the

And last but certainly not least, some PMOs may manage project management assignments

if you were a project manager, you would be assigned to the PMO.

Imagine a scenario where everybody's doing something different.
There's no consistency.
Nobody knows who to contact.
There's no ownership of a process.
There's no ownership of projects.
That's what it looks like without a PMO.
PMOs bring all of this together.
They create policies, procedures and make sense of the project management world for

When you have a project management organization where the project managers are of various

When the team can't expect that every project manager is going to be a solid PM, I think
that creates a lot of anxiety on the team and a lot of unevenness in the results of
those projects.
The primary purpose of a good project management office is to serve the needs of the organization's
project managers.
A common joke that I've heard on many occasions is concerning the government.
When a government official comes and looks at you in the eye and says, We're here to
help.
Normally, that's a pretty good laugh line.
Well, unfortunately, that laugh line can hold true for PMOs as well.
When a project management office PMO is perceived as value added and moves the organizational

managers in the organization.
However, when a project management office becomes adversarial and is looked upon as
a blocker, then the value is reduced.
When you have a manager or stakeholder that doesn't want a PMO to actually be in an organization,
things that you can do to help present and help negotiate to have one would be a of course,
to come with the data be planned as much as possible, come with testimonies, talk about
how you had one at your previous job and how is very beneficial.
Talk about the pros and cons of not having a PMO and what will happen.
Oh, well, just don't walk up to them and say, I've got this great idea.
Let's create a project management office.
The best approach is to perform a root cause analysis of the organization's project management
function as a whole.
Determine what is working, what is not working, what needs to start, what needs to stop, what
needs to stay, and what needs to change.
As part of that root cause analysis, try to determine how creation of a project management
office could potentially help provide needed solutions and propose that this new PMO configure
itself and its duties based on that objective analysis.
Be able to show the data, show what needs to be done, and show how a PMO creation is
the best choice to achieve that goal.
Well, I've been to this process before and it is a challenge, but it isn't impossible,
especially in an organization where project management may not be the priority or seen
as a priority.
And that type of process may not be valued.
And now I want you to understand, it can't be done right away.
It has to be over time.
This isn't something you're going to come in and do in six months or a year or two years.
It's something that you have to gain the favor of management.
So that's the first step, is really getting management to support it.
The second step is showing that value.
And that may be some kind of pilot for a couple of projects.
And then you can start to develop that and put some real strong policies and procedures
around that.
But rolling it out slowly and incrementally is really the best way to approach that.

Traditional Project Management in Action
This article will teach you traditional project management, using an example 
based on "identifying the customer."
The following are aspects of traditional project management:
•	Key project management models
•	Tailoring your project approach
•	Project phases
•	Different types of organizations
•	The PMO
Here is an example of traditional project management in action.
For any project, it is important to identify "Who is the Customer?" Using the traditional waterfall 
approach, let's walk through the process of identifying who the customer is.
You may recall the following phases in a waterfall approach:
•	System and software requirements
•	Analysis
•	Design
•	Coding or Build
•	Testing
•	Operations
This is an example of Company X, which offers the best-selling smartphone. The key features of 
this smartphone are:
•	It is cost-effective,
•	has a good quality camera, 
•	and has a great storage capacity.
With time, the sales of the product started declining. The primary customers of this product include 
the youth. Company X conducted market research to understand the reason for the reduction in 
sales. According to the study, consumers purchase dual-camera phones, while their current 
smartphones lack this feature. Thus, a new version of the smartphone with a dual camera was 
developed.
Traditional PM methodology
The company opted for the Traditional PM approach or the waterfall method to execute this project 
and performed the following steps:
•	System requirements: The project team developed a detailed project plan that included the 
development of the new smartphone's hardware and software components. They also laid 
down a timeline for production and the end product hitting the market. The project team also 
made a broad projection of the cost/price.
•	Design: In this stage, the project team designed the new camera model based on the 
requirements and analysis performed in the previous phases. This stage also included 
prototyping.
•	Engineering: The team developed the camera and integrated it with the phone.
•	Testing: When the product was readied by engineering, the testing team performed a series 
of tests internally before launching the product in the market. For example, they tested the 
camera for functionality, security, performance, and so on.
•	Operations: In the final stage, the new smartphone was launched in the market for users. 
Ongoing maintenance and support were provided to the users.
•	Analysis: The team developed wireframe models, diagrams, and other documentation to 
help the team better understand and design the system requirements.
•	Analysis was made based on the following questions:
•	Which screens will be displayed when the user clicks on a button?
•	What functions/buttons should be on the phone's home page?
•	What navigation buttons and filters will the new camera have?
•	What will be the backend and frontend processes of the camera?
In this scenario, the company identified its core customers and modified its product according to 
their demands. The team completed the project on time by opting for TPM. The company opted for 
the Traditional Project Management approach for the following reasons
•	To provide a clear structure for planning, executing, and monitoring a project.
•	To predict the project's outcome and timeline more accurately.
•	To ensure proper allocation of resources.
•	Also, the Traditional Project Management approach requires documentation at each stage. 
This helped to provide a clear audit trail of the project's progress.
Stacey Diagram Analysis
The Stacey Diagram analysis tool allows decision makers to determine the best approach to 
planning and executing a project. This analysis is based on two parameters:
•	Level of Agreement: Agreement scoring normally is an indicator of how much change you 
can anticipate. The less agreement you have, the more change can be anticipated. Agreement 
scores and complexity can impact the delivery cycles. In most cases, low agreement and 
high complexity levels normally lead to the need to deliver more frequently to ensure you 
are meeting project objectives.
 
•	Technology Complexity: Technology complexity is an indicator of the level of innovation 
that will be needed to plan and execute the project. Evaluation ranges span known 
technology to totally new and unknown technology.
 
The following table presents four scenarios. Using the Stacey Diagram analysis tool, you can see 
how they would likely be evaluated and scored. Note that the total score is calculated by 
multiplying the Agreement Score by the Technology Score.
