Meeting agenda template
Let us now look at the template to write the meeting agenda. Select the file below to download an 
example of a Meeting Agenda template.
The first step is to state the goal of the meeting. Also, mention the feedback you would like to 
receive after the meeting. The goal of the meeting can be:
•	Persuade
•	Inform
•	Entertain 
The second step is to specify the overview of the meeting. The overview should relate to the 
meeting's specific goals. It specifies the areas discussed in the meeting and the quantifiable results 
you aim to achieve.
Project managers should note that objectives should have value to the attendees.
After specifying the objectives, the next step will be to write the agenda's body. Apply the rule of 
three to ensure all key topics and action items are covered. The elements must operate together. The 
objectives and the aim should be connected in some way. Build the agenda items in the following 
manner for success:
Objective: Responsible Team Members. The expected result of discussions.
For example, Review project budget expenditures. Responsible: Joy, Sandy, Aman, and Priya. 
Result:  Show planned versus actual expenditures to date. Provide recommendations and comments.
The last step will be to write the summary. Include the following elements in the summary:
•	Review your accomplishments and shortcomings.
•	Discuss future actions.
•	Request feedback or a synopsis of everyone's "Takeaways."
Here are a few points:
•	Ensure that everyone in the meeting has a role. Participants need not be present if they have 
no responsibility. You can send minutes to them instead. 
•	Each participant should summarize their key learnings. Never presume a team member 
understands or accepts responsibility for a task unless they clearly state what they do.
•	Use a "Parking Lot" to stay on track. If a member wants to discuss something not on the 
agenda, note that in the parking lot and discuss it later.
•	Follow the 48/24 Rule. Post the schedule 48 hours before the event. Minutes are published 
24 hours after the meeting.
Meeting minute template
A Meeting Minute Template is a document that records the key points and decisions made during a 
meeting. Select the file below to download an example of a Meeting Minute Template.
•	A Meeting Minute Template includes the following elements:
•	Date and subject of the meeting: Mention the meeting's date and briefly overview the main 
topics covered.
•	A list of those who attended the meeting.
•	The following are the meeting's quantifiable goals:
•	List the items in the "Parking Lot." Also, add a plan to address them.
•	Key Commitments and Next Steps: List key action items and validate commitment from 
stakeholders. End with the next steps.
Conclusion
In this article, you learned about the meeting agenda and meeting minutes. You also learned how to 
create templates for meeting agendas and meeting minutes.

Influencing for Results

PMI suggests creating a team charter to establish ground rules and conventions that direct the team.
Provide guidance to members whenever they need it. The management strategy known as
"Management by Wandering About" (MBWA) involves the manager spending time talking to and 
watching
the employees while they are at work. Finally, feedback is crucial to growth.
Discuss what works well and what needs improvement.
Set goals while cooperating with the team. Team members should get the chance
to develop their talents. In this video, you learned that:
Effective influencing abilities and behaviors allow individuals to convince and encourage
others to follow a desired course of action. And five common aspects essential to team
development include: Objective awareness
Early role assignments Project team operations
Guidance Feedback


The first model is Theories X, Y, and Z.
These are three different approaches to understanding employee motivation and management styles,
which can impact effective influencing.
Theory X was proposed by Douglas McGregor.
This theory assumes that employees are motivated primarily by self-interest, which is essentially
a desire to increase earnings with the least amount of work.
Therefore managers use financial incentives and punishments as the primary drivers of
employee behavior.
Such team members can be influenced by using a hands-on and top-down management approach.
Theory Y, which was also proposed by Douglas McGregor, says employees genuinely want to
work, enjoy their jobs and are innovative and creative.Such team members can be influenced
by using a personal coaching style.
It also encourages discussion and innovation and helps to create a positive work environment.
Theory Z assumes that employees are motivated by a sense of community and a shared sense
of purpose.
If a manager holds a Theory Z mindset, he is more likely to prioritize team-building,
collaboration, and open communication to influence the employees.
This effective approach can create a strong sense of connection and commitment to the
organization.
The Drexler/Sibbet Team Performance Model or 7-Step Team Performance Model is a framework
that describes the stages of team development and provides instructions on how to proceed
through each phase successfully.
This model has 7 stages that are divided into two groups: creating stages and sustaining
stages.
The Creating Stages include the four initial stages of group development.
They focus on establishing the team's purpose, building relationships, and clarifying goals.
They are: Orientation,
Trust building, Goal clarification and
Commitment.
The Sustaining Stages start after the group has adjusted and established itself.
During this stage, they identify and share actions for enhancing sustainability and performance
in the team.
And these last 3 steps include: Implementation,
High performance, and Renewal
The first step, orientation, answers the question, "why am I here?"
The team needs to understand its purpose and what being a member means.
The second step is the trust-building stage.
It answers questions related to "who"?
Team members work together to create trust and establish open communication.
They learn about each other's strengths and weaknesses and begin to rely on one another
to achieve goals.
The third step answers the question "What are we doing?" and gives goal clarification.
The team defines its goals and decides how it will evaluate success.
The main focus is on setting clear and quantifiable goals based on the stakeholders' expectations
and requirements.
The fourth step is commitment.
It answers questions related to "How will we do it?"
The team decides how exactly it will reach its objectives by discussing particular courses
of action, deciding how to distribute resources, and defining each member's responsibilities.
The fifth step, implementation, involves sequencing and scheduling tasks.
The team asks itself questions like "who does what?", "when?" and "where?
The team executes its plan, and members work together to complete tasks and achieve goals.
The next step is high performance.
A team enters the high-performance stage when it has mastered its operations and can adapt
to changes and achieve its objectives.
Now, the team members work together and require minimal oversight.
There is a sense of shared ownership and accountability for achieving goals.
The seventh and final step of the 7-Step Team Performance Model is renewal.
As the team reaches the end of its journey, they reflect on their accomplishments and
learn from the experiences.
Team cohesion is evaluated at this stage, and required changes are made.
New members could also be employed.
The third model is the Influence Diagram.
This diagram is a graphical representation of the factors involved in making decisions.
It represents and analyzes the factors that motivate or demotivate decision-making.
The diagram can be used by a team or individually.
An Influence Diagram shows the factors for increasing and reducing influence.
Factors that reduce influence are: Poor communications,
Poor issues management, Limited growth opportunities,
And Lack of project vision Factors that increase influence are:
Building relationships, Being accessible,
Building trust, And Active listening.
In this video, you learned that: The PMI defines the following methods for
influencing stakeholders: Theory X, Y, Z,
The 7-Step Team Performance Model, and The Influence Diagram
Theory X, Y, Z is made up of three approaches to understand employee motivation and management
styles, The 7-Step Team Performance Model is a framework
that describes the stages of team development, And the Influence Diagram is a graphical 
representation
of the factors involved in decision-making.


Leading Change
Welcome to "Leading Change."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Describe elements of change management, and Explain the three common change models.
Change happens in all projects.
It can affect systems, behaviors, activities, business requirements, and culture.
The project manager and team must know how to manage change.
According to the Project Management Institute (or PMI), change management consists of five
interrelated elements, including: formulating change,
planning change, implementing change,
managing the transition, and sustaining change.
The first element is formulating change, where the project manager communicates the value
and purpose of the change.
The second element is planning the change.
The project manager identifies and plans any changed project operations.
Planning eases a stakeholders' transition, especially if they are involved in the delivery.
In the implementing change element, the project manager must identify potential problems and
fix them.
This includes requesting feedback from the team and making the required changes to keep
the project on track.
The next element, managing transitions, addresses issues during the project's transition from
the present to future conditions.
The project manager must fix unresolved issues to achieve the desired state.
The last element is sustaining change.
Now the project manager must see that the change is sustained in the future state.
And if not sustained, what needs to be fixed.
Organizations can choose from several models to plan and implement change effectively.
Commonly used models are the ADKAR model,
the Kotter Change model, and the Bridges Transition Model.
The ADKAR model is outcome-oriented.
It outlines specific objectives that provide long-lasting effects.
The ADKAR model consists of five stages: Awareness,
Desire, Knowledge,
Ability, and Reinforcement.
The first step is creating awareness of the need for change.
The project manager explains why the change is necessary, what it will entail, and its
impact on the team.
The second stage involves explaining the benefits and risks of the change.
In the third stage, the team receives training and knowledge of how to change by discussing
roles and responsibilities, innovative techniques, and procedures.
In the fourth stage, anyone who needs help with the change will receive resources, tools,
and support.
In the last stage, the project manager reinforces change by adding incentives, kudos, criticism,
and assessment to promote the winning situation and sustain the transition successfully.
The Kotter change model, introduced by John Kotter, is an eight-step process for successfully
implementing organizational change.
In this top-down approach, the need originates at the organization's top.
The model has eight steps: Create a sense of urgency
Form a powerful coalition Create a vision for the change
Communicate the vision Remove obstacles
Create short-term wins Build on the change and
Anchor the changes in corporate culture.
First, establish a sense of urgency for the change among managers and employees.
Ask for their input on what is driving the need for change.
You must identify potential threats or opportunities driving the need for change.
Also, it is essential to share the value proposition.
Next, create a powerful coalition by building a capable team with the necessary abilities,
qualifications, reputation, connections, and authority to lead the change activities and
influence stakeholders.
In the third step, all stakeholders must share a clear and compelling vision for the change,
consistent with the organization's values and goals.
In the fourth step, you communicate the vision and the strategies to inspire the rest of
the company to accept and support changes.
There may be challenges in implementing this organizational transformation.
Next, remove obstacles like inadequate processes, employee reluctance to change, supervisors
who lack authority, corporate policies, and structure.
In the sixth step, short-term targets that the team can achieve are set.
This is critical to maintaining momentum and inspiring employees to support the initiative.
Recognize small victories to enhance confidence, maintain momentum and spread excitement 
throughout
the company.
Next is to build on the change.
While the team is celebrating their short-term wins from step six, more challenging goals
should be pursued to continue improvement.
Finally, the last step anchors the changes in corporate culture.
The leaders must cultivate the new culture to sustain change by sharing the vision and
success stories with everyone.
And the last model commonly used to plan and implement change effectively, the Bridges
Transition Model by William Bridges, helps individuals understand and manage a transition's
emotional and psychological aspects.
The three stages an individual experiences during change are
ending, losing, and letting go, the neutral zone,
and the new beginning.
In the ending, losing, and letting go stage, individuals acknowledge their losses and learn
to cope by deciding what they will preserve or lose.
The experience could cause sadness, loss, or relief.
The second stage is the neutral zone.
In this transitional period, individuals have not yet adjusted to the new situation.
Some individual's productivity may drop during this stage due to continued frustration
or confusion, while others will grow as they open to new possibilities.
The third and final stage is the new beginning.
Individuals have adjusted to change and are moving forward.
They may feel a sense of accomplishment and optimism in taking on new challenges and 
opportunities.
In this video, you learned that: Change can affect systems, behaviors, activities,
business requirements, and culture.
The PMI's five interrelated elements of change include:
Formulating change, Planning change,
Implementing change, Managing the transition, and
Sustaining change.
Three commonly used models to implement change include:
The ADKAR Model, The Kotter Change Model, and
The Bridges Transition Model
Managing Quality


Welcome to "Managing Quality."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Define the PMI project management quality process.
Differentiate between Quality Assurance (QA) and Quality Control (QC).
And, discuss tools and techniques used in quality management.
Project quality management ensures that the deliverables are valuable and conform to requirements.
It requires careful planning and execution to accomplish this.
The Project Management Body of Knowledge 7th edition (or, PMBOK7) breaks out the costs of 
quality into two categories: costs of compliance and costs of non-compliance.
The project manager must weigh the costs of investing in project quality against the benefits.
Compliance costs abide by the laws, rules, and regulations issued by regulatory bodies, 
governments, or industry standards.
There are two categories of compliance costs: Prevention costs, and Appraisal costs.
Prevention costs include expenses to prevent defects.
Prevention costs also include: Product or service requirements, Quality planning, Quality assurance, 
and Training.
Appraisal costs evaluate the degree of compliance.
Appraisal costs include these expenses: Verification, Quality audits, and Supplier assessments and 
ratings.
Non-Compliance costs do not obey laws, rules, or industry standards.
These expenses can be internal or external failures.
Internal failure includes expenses to find and correct defects before delivering the final product.
Internal failure costs are: Waste, Scrap, Reworks, and Failure analysis External failure expenses 
happen after the product is delivered.
They are: Repairs and servicing, Warranty claims, Complaints, Returns, and Reputation
Project quality management is a straight-forward, three-step approach.
Plan Quality management, Manage quality, and Control quality Planning Quality Management is a 
process that determines the project's requirements, standards, and procedures to attain the desired 
quality.
It also develops a quality management plan.
The Quality Assurance (or QA) stage puts the quality management plan into practice, and ensures 
that the project conforms to standards, policies, and procedures.
It employs quality audits to prevent issues from arising.
Throughout the project, Quality Control (or QC) monitors project outcomes to make sure they meet 
the quality standards.
QC identifies problems in the product or service and addresses them before they affect final 
delivery.
Quality Control examines the product's or service's completeness, compliance, and suitability for 
use.
So, how do you differentiate between QA and QC?
QA is a preventative process, but QC is a corrective process.
QA is a proactive process before production or delivery.
QC is a reactive process during or after production or delivery.
And, QA focuses on improvement and process optimization, while QC focuses on finding and 
fixing defects.
Some tools and techniques commonly used in quality management to improve the quality of 
products or services include: Affinity diagrams, Histograms, Cause and effect diagrams,
Scatter diagrams, Designing for X, SIPOC Diagrams, Flow charts, Mind mapping, Logical data 
models, and Matrix diagrams.
First, the affinity diagram.
An affinity diagram organizes and classifies large amounts of data or ideas collected through 
brainstorming sessions.
Then, the ideas are grouped based on relationships and similarities.
A Histogram is a bar chart depicting a variables' distribution over time.
It represents the distribution by mean.
Histograms are commonly used in Quality Management to evaluate and improve processes, identify
areas of variation, and track performance over time.
Cause-and-effect diagrams show the relationship between the results and root causes of problems.
The Ishikawa diagram, named after its creator, Japanese quality control expert Kaoru Ishikawa, is 
also known as the fishbone diagram, since it's structure resembles a fish, with the problem or effect 
being the "head" of the fish and the potential causes represented as the "bones."
Scatter diagrams discover patterns and trends in data to show the strength and direction of a 
relationship between two variables.
In this illustration of two statistically independent variables, the two variables are plotted along two 
axes, and the pattern of the resulting points reveal the correlation.
The Design for X, or "Design for Excellence," lays out guidelines for reaching a product's 
objectives.
It reviews and improves the new product and process design before manufacturing.
SIPOC stands for Suppliers, Inputs, Processes, Outputs, and Customers.
A SIPOC diagram, a six-sigma tool, identifies the critical elements of a process, defines its 
boundaries, and determines the stakeholders involved.
A flowchart visually represents the sequence of steps and decisions needed.
The diagram includes notes for each step.
Steps are linked by connecting lines and directional arrows.
The Logical Data Model is used to identify the areas where quality issues arise.
It identifies potential solutions.
Mind maps record and arrange concepts and data systematically.
They involve creating a diagram representing the main idea or topic in the center, with related ideas 
branching out hierarchically.
Matrix diagrams visualize complex relationships.
They help identify how different elements in a project interact and depend on one another.
In a table format, rows and columns represent different categories or dimensions.
The intersections of these rows and columns describe the relationship between the categories.
In this video, you learned that: Project quality management ensures that deliverables are valuable 
and conform to quality requirements.
The PMBOK7 breaks down the costs of quality into two categories:
Compliance costs, which abide by the laws, rules and regulations issued by regulatory bodies, 
governments, or industry standards, and Non-compliance costs which do not obey laws, rules or 
industry standards.
The project quality management three-step approach includes:
Planning quality management, Managing quality, and Controlling quality.
QA is a preventative, proactive process which identifies and prevents potential defects in a project 
whereas QC is a corrective, reactive process which identifies weaknesses in a project to take 
corrective action.
Tools and techniques that managers use in quality management include:
Affinity diagrams, Histograms,
Cause and effect diagrams, Scatter diagrams,
Designing for X, SIPOC Diagrams,
Flow charts, Mind mapping,
Logical data models, And Matrix diagrams.

Module 3 Summary and Highlights: Modern 
Project Management
Congratulations! You have completed this module. At this point in the course, you know:
•	The 12 key principles listed in the Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK) 7th 
edition and how these principles impact project management.
•	Primary reasons for project failure and recommendations to avoid these causes. Project 
management is an art and a science. Practice your interpersonal skills to be effective, 
understand the significance of lifecycles, and follow them.
•	Essential tools and techniques to manage projects in a virtual environment. Virtual is a 
reality in today's modern project management environment. Understand virtual challenges, 
plan ahead, and work to overcome them.
•	The importance of organizing and leading effective meetings, including knowing when 
meetings are necessary. You reviewed the 12 key success factors of effective meeting 
management. Meetings are a core means of project communications. Practice meeting 
management techniques and ensure meetings are productive.
•	Best practices for creating and managing a meeting agenda and minutes.
•	Effective influencing techniques and how to motivate others. You learned how to motivate 
the project team. A project manager must motivate the team and stakeholders to commit to 
performing the project's activities. Situationally influence each individual by understanding 
their needs and issues.
•	Common models the Project Management Institute (PMI) recommends for influencing 
stakeholders. These models include Theory X, Y, and Z, The 7-step Team Performance 
Model, and the Influence diagram.
•	The importance of leading change and several common change models were reviewed. 
Remember, you can manage change, or it can manage you. Change is inevitable. If change is 
required, approach change management in a structured and proactive manner.
•	The PMI project management quality process was defined, including distinguishing between 
quality assurance (QA) and quality control (QC), and essential tools managers use in project 
quality management.

Stakeholder Register

Welcome to "Stakeholder Register."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
• Explain a stakeholder register, and • Describe what a stakeholder register includes.
In order to understand what a stakeholder register is, one needs to know what stakeholders
are.
One of the key goals of the project initiation phase is to identify those who need to be
part of the project.
It means identifying the core team, sponsors, department directors, Subject Matter Experts
(SME), customers, operations, and other key roles.
These people are called stakeholders.
They are an important part of a project as they provide the support necessary for the
project to succeed.
Their decisions play a vital role in the project's success.
There are several advantages to identifying stakeholders early in a project.
• Stakeholders must be aware of the project to be able to assist in or contribute to project
management later.
They should be given prior notice so that they can plan their participation.
• Before committing to support, stakeholders must be aware of their roles and obligations,
which must be understood, successfully conveyed, and assigned.
• In some cases, stakeholders might be unable to provide the required support for a project.
A project manager, in this case, must identify potential gaps in support and act quickly
to resolve problems.
• There can be a need for further training due to inadequate skill levels or workforce
crisis.
A project manager needs to address these problems.
• Effective communication is essential to manage a project successfully.
Lists of stakeholders who need to communicate are available in a stakeholder register.
A stakeholder register is a document that lists all the stakeholders associated with
a project, along with relevant information about each of them.
This information may be used to monitor and manage stakeholder expectations throughout
the project life cycle.
A stakeholder register includes certain columns.
Some of these include: Name or Position, which implies the name or
position of each stakeholder.
Organization, which implies the department or organization that the stakeholder is associated
with and is a column that can be deleted or left blank if it doesn't apply.
The role, which implies an accurate, brief, and clear explanation of a stakeholder's
role.
And RACI, which is a responsibility-defining matrix and stands for Responsible, Accountable,
Consulted, and Informed.
For successful project management, it is important that everyone involved in a project understands
their role and responsibilities.
This can be achieved through a RACI chart.
It defines the roles and responsibilities of all stakeholders in a project.
The four roles that RACI defines include the following:
• Responsible, which means the person is in charge of performing the work or producing
the desired outcome.
• Accountable, which means the person is responsible for the task or result and makes
the final decision about its accomplishment.
• Consulted, which means the person is consulted but not authorized to make decisions, and
• Informed, which means the person is kept informed of progress and results but is neither
consulted nor responsible for the task or result.
There are a few more important points to consider regarding the stakeholder register.
• A single stakeholder may have one or multiple RACI designators.
• It's not necessary to name every stakeholder.
For instance, seven marketing personnel will be working on a project, and you need help
with marketing.
Choose a single liaison that can assist the marketing team as a whole.
If more than one entry is needed, try to functionally group as many members of the marketing team.
• It is not important to list every member of a project team.
The addition of core team members actively engaged in project planning is necessary.
• A stakeholder register is an evolving document and expands as the project progresses.
Maintaining a stakeholder register up to date and using version control is important.
It may be helpful to look at an example of the stakeholder register format.
In this register are the names of the different stakeholders, their organizations, and their
roles in the project.
You can also view the task they are required to perform.
In this video, you learned that: • A stakeholder is anyone who needs to be
a part of a project.
• A stakeholder register is a document that lists stakeholders associated with a project,
• This register includes the stakeholder's name, organization, role, and RACI,
• A stakeholder may have one or multiple RACI designators,
• Not every stakeholder needs to be named, • Not every member of a project team needs
to be listed, • And the stakeholder register is ever evolving.

Decision Making

Welcome to "Decision Making."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Describe the importance of effective decision-making.
And identify various methods used to make effective decisions.
Effective decision-making means making informed, timely, and well-considered decisions that
support the successful completion of a project.
Effective decision-making in project management can lead to better project outcomes, improved
teamwork and stakeholder relations, and more informed and effective resource allocation.
According to the Project Management Institute (or PMI), a project manager should seek "expert
judgment" while making an important decision instead of making a unilateral decision.
Involving experts in the decision-making process improves the chances of project success and
increases stakeholder confidence in the process and outcome.
A project manager should handle group discussions carefully, as they have pros and cons.
In group discussions, team members are more likely to feel involved in decisions they
have helped design, which can enhance their buy-in and commitment.
However, it can be a time-consuming process, which may result in lengthy discussions and
debates.
As per the PMI, a project manager should pursue team decision-making more often.
Each team member can share their ideas, and the group works collaboratively to arrive
at a decision.
A project manager should encourage participation from all stakeholders and acknowledge their
contribution.
However, the project manager is ultimately accountable and should try to make project
decisions as early as possible.
A project manager and team members must understand each decision's importance and nature and
adopt an optimal approach to ensure a successful outcome.
The PMI has documented a few important methods for making effective decisions.
These include:
Voting,
Fist-to-Five,
Nominal group technique (or NGT),
Autocratic,
Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis (or MCDA), and
Wideband Delphi.
Voting is a popular method for collective decision-making.
It can help make decisions effectively in certain situations by allowing democratic
participation and representation.
However, it can also lead to conformity as sometimes participants feel pressured to choose
what the rest of the group wants them to do.
There are three ways to determine a voting result.
Unanimity involves 100% support for the decision path from the voting members.
The Majority, which involves more than 50% support for the decision path from the voting
members.
And Plurality indicates the largest group determining the decision path.
It is possible to have a plurality of opinions, resulting in a decision made by less than
50% of the group.
Fist-to-Five is a quick way to collect user input in a group or to determine general agreement.
The leader restates a course of action and requests that the others express their level
of support by putting up several fingers ranging from 0 to 5.
Five represents a complete agreement, whereas clenching your fist indicates strong disagreement.
After indicating their support levels, the group can quickly see where most of the support
lies and decide based on that.
The Nominal Group Technique (or NGT) is a systematic approach to group brainstorming
that promotes contributions from all participants and allows speedy agreement on the relative
importance of topics, problems, or solutions.
Team members begin by writing down their ideas and selecting which is best.
After team members are ready, everyone presents their favorite idea, and the group discusses
and prioritizes the suggestions using a point system.
An autocratic leadership style is one in which a single individual, usually a manager or
leader, makes all the decisions without seeking input from others.
Autocratic decision-making is most effective when the leader clearly understands the situation
and needs to decide and act quickly.
Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis (or MCDA) is a weighted decision-making method that
involves choosing between options when multiple criteria (or objectives) are available for
consideration.
It helps ensure that decisions involve systematic and objective evaluation of the available
options.
This example compares two providers on several variables, including pricing, capacity, delivery,
competence, and reputation.
The last method recommended by the PMI is Wideband Delphi.
This method is employed when a decision needs to remain confidential.
The project manager facilitates this method.
The method is used when participants hesitate to voice their ideas publicly or for the widely
dispersed team.
Here is an overview of the process:
Step 1: The facilitator presents the problem to the concerned team in a group or individually.
Step 2: Participants present their ideas or solutions through their choice of communication,
like posts, emails, or text messages.
Step 3: The facilitator collects the feedback and tabulates the results.
Step 4: The results are declared, but the identification of the participants and votes
are kept confidential.
Another helpful method to make effective decisions is the Owner, Approver, Reviewers, and 
Participants
(or OARP) method.
Although not documented by PMI, this is a useful technique for making effective decisions.
It is a structured process of making decisions that involve uncertainty.
Note that the actual process steps arrange the acronym to be O-P-R-A.
There are four steps in the OARP method.
Step 1: The "owner" of the decision, often the project manager, identifies the issue,
the opportunity, and the action required.
Step 2: The "participants" and the owner discuss the decision-making process.
Participants are often the decision-making stakeholders who will be most affected and
may include operators, end users, consumers, technical support staff, or other individuals.
Step 3: The "reviewers," a group of stakeholders who are often managers of the participants,
work with owners to review decision criteria and participant input.
Reviewers develop opinions they believe are not feasible for moving forward.
Step 4: The "approver" is usually the sponsor in a project environment and reviews
proposed options and makes a final decision.
This decision is relayed to the owner for communication and execution.
In this video, you learned that:
Effective decision-making means making informed, timely, and well-considered decisions that
can lead to:
Better project outcomes
Improved teamwork and stakeholder relations
And informed resource allocation
Methods used to make effective decisions include:
Voting
Fist-to-Five
Nominal Group Technique (or NGT)
Autocratic
Multi-Criteria Decision Analysis (or MCDA)
And Wideband Delphi .

Stakeholder Engagement Plan

Welcome to "Stakeholder Engagement Plan."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Define a stakeholder engagement plan (or SEP)
and its importance, and Describe how to create an SEP matrix.
A stakeholder engagement plan (or SEP) is a formal document that outlines the strategy
to communicate with stakeholders interested in a project.
An SEP identifies stakeholders, and their interest levels, power, and influence.
It is continuously updated to meet stakeholder needs.
The goal of an SEP is to achieve the level of stakeholder commitment required to properly plan and 
execute a project.
Note that this is a plan held close to one's vest.
Only the core project team has access to this plan.
After the project charter is authorized, this
is the first finished plan.
An SEP consists of:
The names of important stakeholders whose commitment to the project is crucial,
The Current State mentioning the level of commitment at present,
The Desired State mentioning the level of commitment that is ideal and required,
And the Strategy needed to move stakeholder commitment from the present state to the desired one.
The SEP matrix is a tool to identify the level
of engagement required of each stakeholder group, based on their level of interest and
influence in the project. The matrix identifies five distinct levels
of commitment designators: Unaware, which indicates that the stakeholder
is unaware of the project and its impacts; Neutral, which indicates that the stakeholder
is aware of the project but has not determined the level of support they need to extend;
Resistant, which indicates that the stakeholder does not support the project and is resistant to 
change;
Supportive, which indicates that the stakeholder
supports the project and is supportive of change; and
Leading, which indicates that the stakeholder is supportive and actively engaged in ensuring the 
project is a success.
Consider the following scenario to understand an SEP better.
John is managing a business application development project.
In this project, Rahul is the sponsor and
is quite supportive of the project.
Mary is the customer and is not sure whether she agrees with the project.
Ram is the Subject Matter Expert (or SME) who does not support the project and thinks the project 
is a waste of time.
Evan is an Information Technology (or IT) professional and supports the project.
And John wants Evan to perform some tasks related to the project.
Shown here is the SEP matrix that clearly defines the roles of all the stakeholders,
along with a strategy to involve them actively for project success.
In this video, you learned that: The stakeholder engagement plan (or SEP) is
a document that includes: Project stakeholder names
Current State, which indicates the stakeholder's present commitment level,
Desired State, which indicates the stakeholder's ideal commitment level,
And the Strategy the manager needs to move the stakeholder from the Current to Desired State.
The SEP matrix is a tool project managers
use to identify the level of engagement required of each stakeholder group.


Key Financial Metrics


Welcome to "Key Financial Metrics."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Describe the importance of financial metrics, and
Define some key financial metrics to determine a project's efficiency.
Financial metrics are quantitative indicators that evaluate a company's financial performance
and stability.
These indicators assist investors and analysts to study data on various aspects of a company,
including its revenue production, profitability, and financial stability.
A project manager should know some key financial metrics, such as:
Opportunity cost,
Time value of money, and
Depreciation.
Opportunity costs are the possible benefits that a person, investor, or company forgoes
while deciding between two options.
This concept addresses project tradeoffs.
For example, the value of Project A is $60,000, and Project B's value is $40,000.
You can only choose one project, so you select Project B.
By doing so you "lose" the chance to benefit from Project A's worth.
Therefore, choosing Project B has an opportunity cost of $60,000.
In the case of multiple projects, the opportunity cost is always the value of the highest-valued
project not chosen.
Twenty years ago, $100 could buy more than what it does today.
So, some financial calculations consider the time value of money.
The time value of money is a concept stating that the value of a currency decreases over
time.
However, the value of the currency increases if we invest the money.
Invested money earns a return, creating a more significant amount of money in the future.
Depreciation determines an asset's value loss over time because of regular wear and
tear, aging, and technological advancements.
The devaluation of assets allows an organization to reduce its taxes and claim the lost value
of the investment.
There are two methods of calculating depreciation:
The Straight-line method, and
Accelerated depreciation.
The simplest method of calculating depreciation is the straight-line method.
The amount of depreciation subtracted from an asset's value is same for every year
of its life.
If an asset is worth $100,000 and depreciates by $20,000 annually over five years,in order
to calculate annual deduction, divide the asset's value by its useful life.
The accelerated depreciation method allocates a higher portion of an asset's cost in the
early years of its life as compared to later years.
This approach considers that assets are often more productive in their early years than
later years.
The accelerated depreciation method includes:
Double Declining Balance, and
The sum of the years' digits.
You will not need to know these depreciation calculations for the CAPM testing.
Some additional financial metrics that influence the choice of projects are:
Payback,
Return on investment,
Return on invested capital (ROIC),
Benefit-cost ratio (BCR),
Economic value added (EVA),
Internal rate of return (IRR), and
Net present value.
The payback period is the time required to recover the initial cost of an investment.
It is the break-even point at which the total investment equals the total revenue.
The payback period equals the initial investment divided by the periodic cash flow.
The Return on investment (ROI) is a metric that tells us an investment's profitability.
It determines the amount of investment return concerning the cost of the investment.
ROI equals the net profit divided by the investment cost and multiplied by 100.
The Return on Invested Capital (ROIC) determines how well a company allocates capital to 
profitable
projects or investments.
It calculates the returns a company generates for every dollar invested in it.
ROIC equals the Net Operating Profit After Taxes (NOPAT) divided by the invested capital
and multiplied by 100.
For example, in a project where the investment is $100,000, and the first-year returns are
$10,000, the ROIC will be 10%.
The benefit-cost ratio (BCR) is a technique to compare the benefits of a project with
its costs.
A BCR that is more significant than 1 indicates a profitable project.
BCR is equal to the total benefits divided by the total costs.
For example, in a project where the total benefits are $10,000 and the total costs are
$8,000, the BCR will be 1.25.
The Economic Value Added (EVA) measures the value a company generates for its shareholders.
This concept suggests that projects should provide returns beyond their cost of capital.
When shareholders generate more wealth, profitability increases.
The net present value (NVP) is the difference between the present value of your cash inflows
and the present value of your cash outflows over a period.
The Internal Rate of Return (IRR) is the discount rate that makes the net present
value (NPV) of a project zero.
In order to calculate the IRR, the discount rate must be determined so that the present
value of future cash flows equals the cost of initial investment.
The IRR compares the efficiency of different investments and determines
a project's profitability.
Finally, the Net Present Value (NPV) is the difference between the present value
of your cash inflows and the present value of your cash outflows over a period.
To calculate NPV you need to use a cash flow chart - like an IRR cash flow chart
and select a discount rate for devaluing returns.
NPV provides the dollar value.
The following scenario demonstrates how to use financial calculations to determine project
benefits
A project has an investment valued at $100,000 and an annual return of $50,000.
The payback is the break-even point at which the total investment equals the total revenue,
which, in this case, is two years.
The ROI is 50%.
The IRR is 23.38%.
And the NPV is $22,130.
Note: the IRR and NPV of the project were calculated using a formula in Microsoft Excel.
In this video, you learned that:
Financial metrics are quantitative indicators that evaluate a company's financial performance
and stability.
Key financial metrics project managers use include:
Opportunity cost,
Time value of money,
Depreciation,
Payback,
Return on investment (or ROI,
Return on invested capital (or ROIC),
Benefit-cost ration (or BCR),
Economic value added (or EVA),
Internal rate of return (or IRR), and
Net present value (or NVP).

Welcome to "Project Budgets."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Define budget levels of accuracy, Summarize budget estimation models, and
Discuss key project budget considerations.
A budget estimate approximates the time and resources required to plan and complete a
project.
Budget estimates are essential for planning and decision-making, as they provide a framework
for allocating resources and managing costs.
There are two levels of budget estimates: Level 1 is Rough Order of Magnitude (ROM),
and Level 2 is definitive estimate.
The project manager includes a Rough Order of Magnitude (or ROM) estimate in the project
charter.
It provides decision-makers with a broad parameter to determine if best- and worst-case budget
estimate limits are acceptable.
A ROM estimate is -25% to +75%.
For example, a ROM for a $100,000 budget estimate might range from $75,000 to $175,000.
The definitive estimate level is the most exact estimate, which the team determines
after completing all project planning.
This level of budget estimation generally serves as the boundaries a budget needs to
conform with before the project close.
A definitive estimate is -5% to +10%.
For example, a definitive estimate for a $100,000 budget might range from $95,000 to $110,000.
You may wonder why there is an under-budget threshold.
If a project ends under budget, the unused funds are returned to the organization.
However, those unused funds sat idle throughout the project and were not providing a return
on investment.
Zero percent returns lose value due to inflation.
If possible, a project manager and team should avoid being over and dramatically under budget.
There are several estimation models project managers use to determine project costs.
A project budget generally uses multiple models based on the cost categories under analysis.
These estimation models include analogous, parametric, and bottom-up.
With the analogous estimation model, the project manager compares the current project to similar
past projects and uses that data to estimate the costs and resources required for the current
project.
The analogous model is also called expert or top-down estimation.
It is most reliable when the previous projects are similar in fact and not just in appearance.
With the parametric estimation model, the quantity of work that the team is to perform
is multiplied by the productivity rate of the team.
This model uses regression analysis and learning curve techniques.
For example, if 30 drawings are required, and the cost is $100 for each drawing, the
total cost would be $3,000.
In this example, the drawings are the quantity of work, and the productivity rate is $100.
The parametric model is also called a mathematical model.
Finally, with the bottom-up estimation model, the project manager estimates each work package 
individually
and then compiles the total project costs.
This model requires a Work Breakdown Structure (or WBS) to be effective.
The bottom-up model has a high level of accuracy in budget estimation.
Project managers should remember these nine considerations when planning and executing
a budget.
Enlist the support of Subject Matter Experts (or SMEs).
Their knowledge is critical to budget estimating success.
Ask a team member to validate estimates and act as a second pair of eyes to catch any
mistakes.
Track planned versus actual expenditures throughout the project to recognize variances early.
Proactively make course corrections and share project status with stakeholders.
Validate all assumptions.
Use information and technology to assist in overall project cost management.
The Project Management Institute (or PMI) refers to these systems as Project Management
Information Systems.
Use value-added decision-making models such as analogous, parametric, or bottom-up.
Review past lessons learned to avoid past budget and planning mistakes and leverage
opportunities previously discovered.
Understand funding limit reconciliation.
This PMI term means that funds allocated to your project must be used only on that project.
Any unused funds must be returned to the organization.
Understand project funding requirements, which is another PMI term.
Let the sponsor know when project funds are needed.
In most cases, the entire project budget will not be available on day one.
In this video, you learned that: A budget estimate approximates the time and
resources required to plan and complete a project.
There are two levels of budget estimates: Level 1 is Rough Order of Magnitude (or ROM)
And Level 2 is definitive estimate.
Estimation models assist project managers in determining project costs.
Three common models are: Analogous
Parametric And bottom-up
And there are nine considerations project managers should remember when planning and
executing a budget.

And Level 2 is definitive estimate.
Estimation models assist project managers in determining project costs.
Three common models are: Analogous
Parametric And bottom-up
And there are nine considerations project managers should remember when planning and
executing a budget.


Project Planning
This article will teach you about project planning in detail and the steps to accomplish it. It will also 
cover the responsibilities of a business analyst and the development process managed by a business 
analyst. This article will also illustrate how the role of a business analyst and a project lifecycle 
intersect.
Introduction
A project manager organizes, plans, and executes projects while working within budget and 
timeline constraints. The key responsibility of the project manager is to ensure the project is 
completed on time and meets the desired quality standards. This is achieved by end-to-end planning 
specifications that a project manager is required to manage and oversee.
Project planning
Project planning is concerned with how to complete a project within a specific timeframe using the 
resources available. It entails developing a comprehensive project plan outlining the project's 
objectives, scope, timeline, budget, and deliverables. There is a process to plan a project 
successfully. It involves the following steps:
•	Developing a Project Charter
•	Project scope planning
•	Schedule and budget planning
•	Support planning
•	Sponsor's approval
Project planning process
Here is each step of project planning in detail.

The first step is to develop a Project Charter. A project charter is a document that formally 
authorizes the existence of a project. It provides an overview of the project's goals, objectives, 
scope, stakeholders, and key deliverables. It is created at the beginning of a project and must be 
completed and approved before project planning can begin. A requirement should not be planned if 
it is not documented in the Project Charter.
The second step is project scope planning. It defines the objective of the project and sets the project 
goals, roles, and responsibilities. Scope planning also facilitates the allocation of resources so that 
the project can be finished on time, within budget, and the stakeholder expectations.
After planning, the project's scope, schedule, and budget planning are accomplished. Schedule and 
budget planning are critical for keeping the project on track and within the fixed budget. It must be 
ensured that sufficient time and funds are available to complete the project's scope. If not, 
negotiation is done with the project sponsor to come up with a final settlement.
The fourth step is support planning. Support planning in a project involves identifying and planning 
for resources and activities that will be needed to support the project throughout its lifecycle. It 
includes the following important elements:
•	Resource planning
•	Communication planning
•	Risk management planning
•	Change management planning
•	Quality management planning
•	Procurements planning
Finally, the sponsor's approval is taken. The Sponsor's consent must be obtained at the end of the 
project planning process. Prior to starting a project, a meeting must be planned, and stakeholder 
approval must be obtained.
Role of a business analyst
Business analysts work closely with stakeholders to identify opportunities for improvement and to 
develop solutions that align with the organization's goals and objectives. They conduct research and 
analysis in order to come up with solutions to business problems and introduce systems to improve 
performance.
They work together with the project manager to successfully complete a project. The role of a 
business analyst involves focusing on the analysis and documentation of the requirement, while a 
project manager focuses on deliverables and timelines.
Development process
A business analyst oversees the following step-by-step development process:
•	Need Assessment,
•	Stakeholder Engagement,
•	Elicitation,
•	Analysis,
•	Traceability and Monitoring, and
•	Solution evaluation.
Need Assessment
Business analysts closely collaborate with the executive team of the organization to find potential 
project opportunities. They evaluate the present state, determine the required future state, and 
produce potential solutions. When solutions are accepted, they provide suggestions and create 
roadmaps for development.
Stakeholder Engagement
The second role performed by a business analyst is stakeholder engagement. This includes 
communicating with stakeholders to ensure that their needs are understood and that they are kept 
informed about the progress of the project from the beginning to the desired result.
Elicitation
Elicitation refers to the process of gathering and documenting the requirements of a project from 
stakeholders. Eliciting requirements is one of the business analyst's primary responsibilities. They 
choose the most effective elicitation strategy, make a game plan, carry out the elicitation, and verify 
the outcomes.
Analysis
The next role performed by a business analyst is analysis. This includes reviewing and analyzing 
current business processes to identify inefficiencies and areas for improvement. The business 
analyst makes use of a variety of analysis tools to identify and rank requirements, create models, 
and establish project acceptance standards.
Traceability and Monitoring
Traceability and monitoring include managing change related to implementing new processes or 
systems, including communicating the change to stakeholders and ensuring that the change is 
adopted effectively. For this, the business analyst develops a Traceability Matrix. It is defined as "A 
grid that links Product requirements from their origin to the deliverables that satisfy them."
Solution evaluation
Solution evaluation involves assessing the potential impact and value of a proposed solution for a 
business problem or opportunity. The business analyst also aids in getting solutions approved for 
release.

Business analysis and project management link
Here is a quick overview of where and how the business analyst's duties relate to the project 
management lifecycle. As shown in the picture:
The project management Initiation Phase is followed by the Business Analysis activity.
The creation of the project charter is the last phase of the needs analysis.
Stakeholder analysis, elicitation, and engagement take place simultaneously with the needs 
assessment.
The Traceability Matrix is completed at the end of the Needs assessment and is used by the project 
manager to track development progress.
The business analyst participates in solution acceptance and testing and assists the project manager 
with project closeout, transition, and release.
Conclusion
Project planning is a crucial phase in project management that sets the foundation for the entire 
project. Effective project planning is critical for the success of any project. It helps to ensure that 
the project is well organized, that resources are allocated effectively, and that the project is 
completed within budget and on time. Business analysts play a critical role in project planning by 
helping to ensure that the project meets the needs of the business, stays on track, and delivers the 
intended outcomes.

Project Planning: Role of a Business Analyst 
Expanded
Product Roadmaps
The Business Analyst supports the development of Product Roadmaps. Product Roadmaps show 
high-level aspects of a product planned for delivery. The roadmap creates shared expectations on 
product deliverables and the order in which the client will receive them.
A well-defined roadmap contains multiple components shared with product owners and project 
managers.
•	It describes the product vision, how the product supports organizational objectives, required 
features, timelines, and a recommendation for the optimal project lifecycle that best supports 
product development.
•	This information is provided to product owners when the manager determines that an 
adaptive project lifecycle is best suited to product development. Or the manager may 
provide it to project managers if a predictive lifecycle is the best fit.
Tools and Techniques to Identify Requirements
A Business Analyst (BA) uses several tools and techniques to identify initial requirements that will 
lead to the development of project charters.
•	The BA conducts interviews, sends out surveys, facilitates workshops, and reviews lessons 
learned to determine potential problems the team can solve or opportunities to capture.
•	The BA develops user stories that determine what various organizational roles need and the 
value the product will deliver. They work closely with product owners and the development 
teams to define functionality and features that satisfy the customer's needs.
•	The BA may develop use cases to drive product development. A use case describes how a 
customer or user interacts with a system or product. A use case may establish the success 
scenarios, failure scenarios, product key performance indicators that the team must meet, 
and any critical variations or exceptions. These use cases help the product owner or project 
manager determine the requirements the team must achieve by the project end.
•	The BA may develop a product traceability matrix. This tabular overview of product 
development phases maps out precisely how a product will be designed and developed and 
which stakeholders must be involved during each phase to ensure success.
•	Finally, a Business Analyst can work closely with stakeholders to define acceptance criteria 
that will allow the project team to know if a product is ready for release and delivery.
The Business Analyst ensures that the product requirements meet the organization's needs. The 
product owner and project managers work to deliver the solution.
Conclusion
The Business Analyst plays a crucial role in supporting the development of Product Roadmaps, 
which outline the planned delivery of high-level product aspects. The Business Analyst also uses 
various tools and techniques such as interviews, surveys, workshops, user stories, use cases, and 
product traceability matrix to identify requirements and drive product development. The 
collaboration between the Business Analyst, product owner, and project managers leads to 
successful deliverables.

Scope Planning

Welcome to "Scope Planning."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Summarize end-to-end scope planning, Explain requirements planning,
Describe the contents of a scope statement,
Describe the contents of a work breakdown structure (or WBS),
And explain the importance of a WBS dictionary.
The scope planning process includes identifying, outlining, and maintaining a project's scope.
It is arguably the most critical project planning you will perform.
The Project Management Institute (or PMI) states that a project manager needs to accomplish
the project on time, within budget, and within the required scope.
In the real world, however, if you don't deliver scope that adds value, being on time and within
budget won't matter much.
The PMI has a four-step scope planning approach.
It is a solid conceptual model that works in real working situations.
The four steps are:
Plan scope management,
Collect requirements,
Define scope,
And create a Work Breakdown Structure (or WBS).
The first step is to plan scope management.
The PMI recommends that the project manager develop and share a scope management plan.
This is not the final scope but is a simple plan that provides process and direction to
the team on how to define, develop, monitor, control, and validate scope.
This "how-to" plan describes how the project manager analyzes, documents, and manages 
requirements.
The next step in scope planning is requirements planning, which the PMI refers to as the collect
requirements process.
The project manager reviews the project charter and other applicable documentation.
Here are some important points to remember for the requirements planning process:
The project manager provides requirement documentation that defines the requirements in the 
project's
scope.
The goal of this phase is to summarize project charter requirements.
Strive for actionable and measurable requirements and define them in terms of action and result.
For example, "acquire a venue."
If the business analyst did not previously develop a project traceability matrix, the
manager or analyst develops it at this point.
The following scenario describes a simple project that shows an example of scope planning
documentation.
A manufacturing firm is planning an all-hands meeting, and you are the project manager.
These are key excerpts from the project charter for this scenario.
The event time and date have been set, and the venue is still to be determined.
The firm is to provide transportation for attendees, and catering will be provided.
The number of attendees and speakers has been determined, and the firm will provide technical
support for the event.
As the project manager, you would now determine the scenario collection requirements for this
project based on the information provided by the project charter.
This includes:
Acquiring the venue,
Planning transportation,
Planning catering,
Identifying speakers,
And planning audiovisual and technical support.
The next step in scope planning is defining the scope by developing a scope statement.
The PMI states that a scope statement is the most detailed version of the scope.
It clearly explains the project's aims.
The scope statement has four components.
Scope description or overview,
Deliverables,
Acceptance criteria, and
Exclusions.
Here is an example scope statement // describing the project scenario to plan and implement
an all-hands meeting in four ways.
This document:
Describes the project,
Lists all requirements or deliverables,
Identifies who can accept the final deliverables,
and lists exclusions.
Exclusions are a list of what the project will not provide.
The last step is to construct the work breakdown structure.
A WBS breaks down the scope statement into a hierarchical list of tasks necessary to
fulfill the project requirements.
The hierarchy plan runs from most general, starting with the whole project, through the
project phases, to the specific tasks, known as work packages.
A best practice is to break down the work packages using logical phasing.
The project manager should use the Plan Do Check Act (or PDCA) method.
And, all WBS work packages should be actionable, estimable, and measurable.
This is an example of a WBS using the project scenario.
The WBS is a hierarchical breakout of the project; a visual roadmap.
It looks like an organizational chart with the project in the top row,
then breaking down into Project Phase columns in the second row of boxes, followed by rows
of boxes with the activities required, or work packages, for each phase in the order
they occur below that.
The first project phase column in the second row represents planning the project.
The second column is the next phase, executing the project, and so on.
After the project manager constructs the WBS, it is essential to complete the WBS dictionary.
This document defines the tasks required to accomplish a WBS work package.
Some points to remember while completing the WBS dictionary are:
Each work package in the WBS is broken out into specific tasks.
The manager should assign a lead team member to each work package.
And the WBS dictionary becomes the primary source for the team to check the progress
status throughout the project.
This example WBS dictionary, based on our scenario, breaks out the specific tasks for
the first activity (or work package), Manage the Venue, listed under our 1st phase in the
WBS.
The Manage the Venue specific tasks are:
Research available venues
Select the appropriate venue, and
Sign the contract
In this video, you learned that:
The scope planning process is the manager's most critical project planning area.
The PMI has a four-step scope planning approach which includes:
Plan scope management,
Collect requirements,
Define scope,
And create a WBS.
A scope statement is the most detailed version of the project's scope.
A WBS breaks down the scope statement into a list of tasks.
And a WBS dictionary defines the tasks required to accomplish a WBS work package.


Schedule Planning

Welcome to "Schedule Planning."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Explain schedule planning and the steps involved,
Discuss types of dependencies,
And illustrate a project network diagram.
Schedule planning is the process of organizing and arranging tasks, events, and activities
in a structured manner to allocate time and resources effectively.
It involves setting priorities, determining available time slots, and using tools and
techniques to plan and monitor progress toward meeting goals and deadlines.
Schedule planning aims to improve efficiency and productivity by ensuring tasks are completed
promptly and in an organized manner.
The Project Management Institute (or PMI) has developed a five-step schedule planning
approach.
Create a schedule management plan,
Define activities,
Sequence activities,
Estimate activity durations, and
Develop a schedule.
The first step is to create a schedule management plan.
A project manager creates a schedule plan to specify the beginning and end dates of
a project, the key checkpoints along the route, and a deadline to finish each job individually.
The second step is to define activities.
The manager lists the tasks, activities, and events to include in the schedule. Each activity
must be defined to the point where time and cost durations can be reasonably estimated.
Avoid ambiguity.
Next, the project manager carefully considers each activity to determine which ones are
dependent on others to be completed.
All project dependencies must be defined so that the manager can appropriately schedule
the work and prevent delays.
After establishing dependencies among the activities, the manager can sequence them
to create an effective flow.
Project managers use the three-point method to determine how long each work package will
take. This method can be applied to both time and cost durations.
There are a few terms associated with this method. The first is "predecessor," which
defines an activity that happened first. Another term is "successor," which is the activity
that happened second.
In this illustration, Activity A is the predecessor to Activities B and C. Activities B and C
are the successors to Activity A.
Activities B and C depend upon the completion of Activity A. Activities B and C do not depend
on each other. The team can accomplish these activities simultaneously.
The PMI shares four distinct dependency determinations.
Mandatory dependencies are legally required or inherent; the team cannot ignore them.
These dependencies can impact the overall timeline and schedule of a project.
Examples of mandatory dependencies include:
Part sourcing before assembling,
And hardware installation before software installation.
An external dependency involves factors that are external to the project. These factors
are usually legal or regulatory by nature.
Examples of external dependencies include:
Approvals from external organizations or government agencies,
Availability of resources or equipment sourced from outside suppliers,
And compliance with regulations or laws.
Internal dependency refers to a situation where a task in a project depends on other
tasks in the project for completion. This creates a relationship between tasks and a
sequence for their completion.
Typically, the project manager and team have complete control over these dependencies.
An example of an internal dependency is the internal testing of product components before
the product is assembled.
The final type of determination is a discretionary dependency. Sometimes, there may be more than
one way to accomplish a task, and the project management team must decide which method to
follow.
The decision is based on their experience, best practices, and lessons learned.
An example of a discretionary dependency can be best explained with a scenario.
Activity A is booking an airline ticket, and activity B is buying travel insurance. The
project team can either book an airline ticket before buying travel insurance or do it the
other way around.
Returning to the five-step schedule planning approach, in the fourth step, the project
manager and the team members must estimate how long each activity or work package will
take to complete.
The best way to estimate the duration is to use data from similar past activities.
Finally, the project manager and the team members develop the final schedule.
The manager informs the sponsor and important stakeholders about this schedule for review
and approval. Once the sponsor and stakeholders approve the schedule, it becomes the project's
schedule baseline.
A network diagram is a useful tool that shows how all work packages need to be accomplished
and in what order. A work breakdown structure (or WBS) is required to build a network diagram.
The diagram shows the flow of activities, dependencies, and the critical path, which
helps in project planning, monitoring, and control.
The following scenario shows how a network diagram is built.
The nodes in the diagram represent tasks, while the arrows represent the dependencies
between them.
This project has five activities.
Activities A and B have no dependencies and can be accomplished simultaneously.
Activity C depends upon completing Activities A and B.
Activities D and E can also be accomplished simultaneously. They are both dependent upon
the completion of Activity C before work can begin.
The final step in building a network diagram is to add the durations to each activity,
as shown in the illustration. Durations are determined by days.
Activity A will take 5 days, Activity B will take 3 days, and so on.
Now that the network diagram is complete, the next task is to determine how many paths
are possible to complete the project. This example has four paths.
The critical path is the path with the longest duration. In this example, the longest path
is ACE. <speak A C E>
The critical path identifies the duration of the project. The duration of each activity
is summed up to calculate the critical path.
In this example, Activity A's duration is 5,
Activity C's is 8, and Activity E's is 7.
So 5 plus 8 plus 7 equals 20.
The critical path is 20 days.
The final step in schedule planning is ensuring that sponsors and important stakeholders are
informed about the network diagram and length.
The project manager obtains approval from the stakeholder and the sponsor, and the schedule
baseline is finalized.
In this video, you learned that:
Schedule planning is the process of organizing and arranging tasks, events, and activities
in a structured manner.
The PMI's 5-step planning approach includes:
Planning schedule management,
Defining activities,
Sequencing activities,
Estimating activity duration,
And developing a schedule.
The four types of dependency determinations are:
Mandatory,
External,
Internal,
And discretionary.
A network diagram is a useful tool for visualizing and analyzing a project schedule.
And the critical path is the path of the longest duration of a project.

Welcome to a short project budgeting demo.
In this demo we will illustrate tools used in building and presenting a project budget

Let's begin with a two step approach to build a project budget.
Step number one is to begin with a review of the total cost for the project.
A simple Excel spreadsheet will often suffice.
Break out the costs by direct, indirect and reserve requirements.
A general rule is that contingency reserves are usually 10% times direct costs.
Management reserves are for unknown risks.
If you suspect there are many unknown risks, add additional contingency under the management
reserves.
Let's look at a simple example.
This is a project for the annual executive meeting support project.
We begin by defining our costs in this particular case, you'll notice we have them categorized
by venue, set up in venue, clean up, audio, visual, etc.
Next, we try to determine if they are direct or indirect costs.
As you notice in the notes, a direct cost is a cost that is charged to the project.
So, let's find our first example.
You'll notice that under direct cost set up and venue cleanup contractor supported.
This is a direct cost.
This means that the project manager needs to acquire $2,000, and the project will be
required to go ahead and disperse those funds to the contractor.
But we have another type of cost as well.
These are indirect costs, looking at our notes.
Indirect costs.
These are paid for by an external source.
If these costs were not paid by an external source, the project would need to plan an
account for them.
So, let's look at our example.

What is this for?
Going across to the cost description.
This is for the venue, but you'll notice we have a note.
This is going to be paid for by the organization.
So, while the project is not paying for the venue, this is a cost to the project.
It's just being paid for by another third party.
In calculating the total costs of a project,
we add up all of the direct costs in this particular case, $6,000 and all of the indirect
costs.
In this case, $5,000, our total
project costs are $11,000.
One last piece of information.
We need to go ahead and calculate contingency reserves.
Contingency reserves are those extra dollars that are set aside in case risks occur.
Normally, contingency reserves are 10% times the direct costs.
So, if you look at this illustration, we have $600, we take 10%, we multiply it by 6000,
and we end up with 600.
This is dollars that we do not have access to unless we request them.
However, they are available in case a risk occurs.
Now let's take a look at step two.
Here, we determine when the funds are needed.
You need to phase your project funding requirements for a real-world project, allocating costs
to each work package or activity in the work breakdown structure, and using your network
diagram to determine when costs will be incurred, is a best practice.
Here's how that calculation could work.
But remember, only request direct costs.
Ensure what you are asking for
