meeting requirements in this case to support the catering.
These funds are required on the 20th of February and we're going to pay the outstanding catering
invoice on the 24th.
Again, take a look at the totals.
The total requirement is our direct cost of $6,000.
Now, one final area that we want to discuss regards estimation.
There is a methodology that is commonly used called three-point estimation.
Many project managers use single-point estimation.
They estimate time and cost by providing their best guess.
There are some costs that are set when this is the case.
Single-point estimation suffices in most cases, however, estimates may be impacted by a variety
of factors.
Three-point averaging requires the project manager and the team to analyze three estimates.
The most likely estimate is what the team believes will be the most likely costs.
The pessimistic estimate considers risk and the worst-case scenario.
The optimistic estimate considers opportunities that may reduce costs.
There are two ways to calculate three point.
Note that the three-point estimation is applicable to both cost and schedule estimates.
So, looking at three-point averaging,
we have a pessimistic amount of 45.
Most likely, it's going to cost us 25.
And if everything works out perfectly, we may escape with only spending 20.
Each one of the pessimistic, most likely, and optimistic numbers and estimates are multiplied
by one.
We multiply the pessimistic 45 times one equals 45.
Most likely, 25 times one equals 25.
Optimistic 20 times one equals 20, 45, 25 and 20 equals 90.
We divide this 90 by three, and the estimate that we're going to go ahead, and use is 30.
Now we have something called three-point estimation using PERT. PERT stands for program 
evaluation
review technique and this method is a little more complicated than the averaging method.
The PERT method weighs the optimistic, most likely, and pessimistic estimates based on
statistical norms.
Studies have shown that the pessimistic and optimistic estimates will occur one out of
every six times.
The most likely estimate will occur four out of every six times.
This weighted criterion is based on the conclusion that estimation accuracy follows a statistical
standard distribution.
The most likely falls within one standard deviation of the mean, or approximately 67%
of the time.
The optimistic and pessimistic estimates fall within two or more standard deviations from
the mean or approximately 16% for both.
Hence the weights one, four, and one.
Use the PERT method in our example.
Let's go ahead and take a look.
We have our optimistic, most likely, and pessimistic estimates.
They have not changed.
However, the multipliers do.
We multiply the pessimistic by one, one times 45 for 45. Why?
Because the pessimistic is going to occur
one out of every six times we multiply the most likely estimate of 25 times four to equal
100. Why?
According to the standard distribution,
the most likely normally occurs four out of six times or 67%.
We multiply the optimistic 20 times one to equal 20. Why?
Because the optimistic is only going to occur
one out of every six times or approximately 16%.
We add up our totals 45, 120 to get to 165.
However, we're now going to divide 165 by six, when we take 165 and divide it by six,
now, the estimate that we're going to use is 27.5.
This concludes our overview of project budgeting as a quick summary.
Remember, we have two steps or we can combine the two steps with one step called the resource
breakdown structure.
And we learned an estimation technique called three-point. Thank you for your attention,
and we look forward to sharing more project management
best practices with you in demos to follow.
Have a great rest of your day.


Budget Planning
This article will teach you end-to-end budget planning.
Budget planning
Budget planning is the process of allocating and managing your income and expenses over a given 
period of time. It involves assessing your current financial situation, setting financial goals, and 
planning to achieve those goals.
PMI has defined a three-step budget planning approach.
•	Plan cost management,
•	Estimate costs
•	Determine budget
Plan cost management
The plan outlines how the team estimates, budgets, manages, oversees, and controls expenditures. 
This is also a "How to" plan process. PMI recommends developing and sharing this plan.
Estimate costs
An estimate cost involves estimating the costs of the resources required to complete the project. 
There are three types of costs: direct, indirect, and reserves.
•	Direct costs are expenses incurred directly in the process of producing a good or providing a 
service. These are paid out of the project budget. The project manager must calculate and 
request these funds from the sponsor. For example, labor costs, raw materials
•	Indirect costs are the overhead expenses that aren't directly connected to a product or 
service's manufacture or delivery. These expenses are difficult to link to a particular item, 
service, or undertaking. Indirect costs could be the cost of venues, utilities, full-time 
employee salaries, and often required training funded by the company.
•	Reserves are the percentage of the project budget set aside for unplanned or unanticipated 
expenditures throughout the project. There are two types of reserves: contingency and 
management reserves. Contingency Reserves are allocated to support known or identified 
risks, whereas management reserves are allocated to support unknown risks.
Determine costs
Determining cost is the process that involves aggregating and calculating the estimated costs of the 
project activities to establish a cost baseline. This baseline represents the authorized budget for the 
project and is used to monitor and control project costs. A solid budget documents direct costs, 
indirect costs, and reserves.
Conclusion
Budget planning is an essential financial tool that provides individuals and organizations with 
financial discipline, control, and flexibility to achieve their financial goals. The budget must reflect 
the individual or organization's financial situation accurately by considering all types of costs while 
planning.

Project Support Planning

Welcome to "Project support planning."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Explain project support planning, and Discuss key objectives of project support
planning.
Project support planning is identifying and managing the resources and support needed
to successfully execute a project.
This involves including personnel, equipment, technology, training and financial resources.
It begins after the scope, schedule, and cost baselines are approved and accepted.
The key objectives of support planning include: Quality management planning,
Resource Breakdown Structure, Communications management plan,
Risk planning, Procurement planning, and
Stakeholder engagement planning.
Quality management planning involves the development of a plan to ensure that the project 
deliverables meet the required quality standards.
A quality management plan documents the methods and guidelines applied in quality management.
This plan also describes Quality Assurance planning and Quality Control planning.
The Resource Breakdown Structure visually represents the project's resource requirements.
It divides those resources into smaller, easier-to-manage components.
Here is an example of an RBS that specifies the planning and managing of resources.
Create a column that lists people responsible for each Work Package.
You may also enlarge the RBS to include start and finish dates for every WBS work package.
A communications management plan outlines the communication requirements and expectations
for a project.
It is developed by the project manager during support planning and approved by the sponsor.
This plan identifies key communication items, Assigns team leads to each item,
Provides audience and media information, Outlines timing issues,
And tells the purpose of the communication.
Here is an illustration with a sample entry.
Risk planning is the process of identifying, evaluating, and managing risks to reduce their
influence on a project or organization.
It includes the following three elements: Plan Risk Management,
Identify Risks and Monitor Risk.
The first step is to develop a risk management plan that outlines shared methods, roles and
responsibilities, and risk-scoring standards.
The second step is to identify risks.
To accomplish this step, evaluate the project and record the risks.
This helps to create solutions to lessen threats and increase opportunities.
The last step is to monitor risks.
Perform periodic reassessment of risks to monitor them.
This will help to determine any new risks and implement risk responses whenever needed.
Procurement planning is the process of identifying and procuring the products and services required
to complete a project.
It is essential to ensure that organizations are able to acquire the goods and services
they need in a timely and cost-effective manner.
This process involves developing a procurement management plan which includes all information
and guidance necessary to manage the end-to-end procurement process.
The last plan is stakeholder engagement planning.
It involves identifying and evaluating the stakeholders engaged in a project or initiative
and successfully interacting with them throughout the project's life cycle.
Involvement of stakeholders is essential to success.
Therefore, the project manager and team assess each stakeholder's current and desired levels
of commitment and develop strategies to sustain or achieve desired levels of commitment.
In this video, you learned that: Project support planning is the identification
and management of the resources and support a project requires for successful execution.
And the key objectives of project support include:
Quality management planning, Resource Breakdown Structure,
Communications management plan, Risk planning,
Procurement planning, and Stakeholder engagement planning.


Project Procurement Management
Project Procurement Management includes processes necessary to purchase or acquire products, 
services, or results needed from outside the Project Team. This includes management and control 
processes to develop and administer agreements such as contracts, purchase orders, Memorandums 
of Agreement (MOA), or Service Level Agreements.
The project manager oversees the creation of a Procurement Management Plan. This plan drives all 
procurement activities required to support the project. The project manager also manages and 
controls the end-to-end procurement process and ensures all seller deliverables meet the needs of 
the buyer organization. The Project Manager is not required to be an expert in procurement 
management but must identify experts who are.
Procurement Management Plan Contents
The Procurement Management Plan should include the following:
•	How the team will integrate procurement into the project scope, schedule, and cost baselines
•	Procurement schedules
•	Procurement metrics or key performance indicators goals
•	Procurement roles and responsibilities
•	Any assumptions or constraints that may impact procurement
•	Legal considerations that affect the procurement
•	Determination of independent estimates to validate seller proposal feasibility is needed
•	Source selection criteria that the team will use to select sellers
•	Risk factors that affect procurement
•	Prequalified Sellers-those sellers authorized to submit proposals
Types of Contracts
The project manager must determine the type of contract that will support the procurement. There 
are three common contract types to consider:
•	A Fixed Price contract enables the seller to provide a bid to provide services. The costs are 
known up-front, which reduces risk to the buyer.
•	With a Cost Reimbursement contract, the seller describes what they need. The costs are 
unknown up-front; the team receives invoices throughout the project. This contract type 
places risk on the buyer.
•	The manager usually uses a Time and Material contract for quick and easy procurements. 
The benefit of this type of contract is a fast procurement cycle with minimal negotiations 
needed.
The Procurement Management Plan becomes part of the finalized Project Management Plan 
approved by a Sponsor and accepted by stakeholders.
Conclusion
Project Procurement Management involves acquiring projects, services, or results from external 
sources through contracts and purchase orders. The Project Manager creates a Procurement 
Management Plan, which guides procurement activities and identifies experts. The manager uses 
different contract types, such as Fixed Price, Cost Reimbursement, and Time and Material.

Planning Earned Value Management
This article will teach you the concept of Earned Value Management. It will also cover key data 
points used to calculate real-time EVM.
Earned Value Management (EVM) 
Earned Value Management (EVM) is continuous, real-time monitoring of project progress, 
considering costs and schedule constraints. Comparing scope, schedule, and cost provides a status 
that can be shared or used to direct the course of action throughout the project. 
Here is a list of key data points to understand EVM.
Budget at Completion (BAC) 
Budget at Completion (BAC) is the total budget allotted to the project to cover all direct 
expenditures. For example, the allocated budget to complete the project is $100,000.
Planned Value
Planned Value (PV) represents the cost budgeted for a specific task or activity in the project plan up 
to a certain time, which provides a baseline for assessing project performance and progress. 
For example, if your BAC was $100,000 and you are halfway through the project, you will plan to 
spend $50,000 of the allotted budget now.
Actual Costs (AC) 
Actual Costs (AC) are the amount the project has spent. For example, if PV was $50,000, and you 
have spent $60,000, then you are $10,000 over budget.
Earned Value (EV) 
Earned Value (EV) represents the value of the work completed up to a certain point in time based on 
the project plan. To calculate the EV, multiply the planned percentage of completion by the 
budgeted cost for the specific task. 
For example, Assuming a task is 50% complete up to a certain date and its total budgeted cost is 
$10,000, then its EV up to that point is $5,000 (50% x $10,000).
Conclusion
Project managers can use these information points to determine the performance of a project and 
make informed decisions that will help to keep the project on budget.

Gaining Project Approval and Acceptance
This article will teach you about the project management plan (PMP) approval process, project 
kickoff meeting, and how to make an effective presentation.
A project management plan (PMP)
A project management plan (PMP) is a document that a project manager creates to clearly define the 
project's goals, the processes the team will implement, and how the manager will monitor and 
control the processes to accomplish the project goals. This plan is essential for project success. 
Without a PMP, you cannot expect a project to be delivered timely and successfully. Developing 
this plan requires a lot of work, analysis, and collaboration.
The PMP approval process
Here are the steps involved in the PMP approval process.
First, the project manager must gain sponsor approval for the project. The project manager presents 
a baseline presentation to the sponsor to achieve this goal. After sponsor approval, the project 
manager schedules a kickoff meeting to present the complete plan to stakeholders. After the 
stakeholders accept the plan, the plan becomes the project's baseline.
Reviewing the kickoff meeting
A kickoff meeting should be brief. The information you provide to stakeholders should have been 
presented, discussed, and negotiated at the planning stage.
According to the Project Management Institute (PMI), presentations can be formal or informal. 
Formal presentations, such as a kickoff, are recorded and shared with a wide audience. Informal 
presentations do not need to be shared. Note that the conversations made before the formal meeting 
to gain consensus are informal.
Making effective presentations
Five important factors determine the effectiveness or success of a presentation. These include:
•	Being prepared
•	Being organized
•	Using the expertise of a Subject Matter Expert (SME)
•	Documentation
•	Meetings before the meeting.
Being prepared
The most important factor in determining presentation success is "be prepared." Never present if 
you do not understand the presentation material. As a project manager, the project sponsor expects 
you to be an expert in understanding and managing the project. You should anticipate potential 
questions and be ready to respond satisfactorily.
Being organized
Another important factor related to a successful presentation is "be organized." Develop an agenda 
for the kickoff meeting and stay within it. The agenda should:
•	Introduce and overview the project and the project team,
•	Share key project details such as the scope, schedules, costs, and risks, and
•	End with a formal recommendation for approval, cancellation, postponement, etc.
Using the expertise of a Subject Matter Expert (SME)
Being a project manager, you should try to learn as much about the project as possible. That said, 
you might not be able to answer all the questions that participants ask during the kickoff meeting. 
Therefore, ensure an SME is available and ready to answer these questions.
Documentation
Documentation is another crucial factor that a project manager must consider making an effective 
presentation. You must document every step you've taken before the kickoff meeting. This includes 
the approval from the sponsor and the acceptance obtained from the stakeholders. You should share 
this documentation with the stakeholders during the kickoff meeting.
Meetings before the meeting
The last important factor a project manager should consider for a successful presentation is "having 
meetings before the kickoff meeting."
The information shared in the baseline presentation and during the kickoff meeting should not 
surprise the stakeholders. Before the kickoff meeting, collaboratively, all the necessary negotiations 
must be made, and the project manager should define the scope, schedule, and budget. Collaborate 
with the sponsor and the key stakeholders at every stage of the planning process. The best approval 
and acceptance meetings are approved.
Conclusion
Developing a PMP is crucial for the success of any project. It helps to clearly define the project 
goals, processes, and how the project manager will monitor and control the processes to achieve the 
desired outcomes. The project manager must be prepared and organized, use the expertise of an 
SME, document every step taken, and collaborate with the project sponsor and key stakeholders at 
every stage of the planning process to ensure a successful presentation. By following these steps 
and considering these factors, project managers can increase the chances of project success.

Expert Viewpoints: Project Support Planning

Welcome to Expert Viewpoints: Project Support Planning.
In this video, we will hear from project managers on project planning.
There's three things that immediately come to mind that can impact the effectiveness
of project planning.
First, is racing through it and not spending enough time, planning and researching and
understanding what it is that you as the project manager need to do in order to make the project
successful.
If you don't dedicate enough time early on and you decide that you want to build the
plane as you go, it's only going to lead towards much more risk and much more change 
management
than what you want to manage, and the negative impact that that can have can be quite devastating
on the project from a quality standpoint.
From a timeline perspective and from a budgetary perspective. You may think that you're saving
time by racing through project planning, but in the end it might end up taking more
time than ever.
Second, the second thing that is key to project planning is having the right resources involved.
Your project team when you're planning may be different than the project team when you're
executing, there may be just a few folks who will go over into the escalation, or they
may just be a few people who roll over into the execution
phase of your project.
But assuring that you've got the right resources in planning will help you with that transition
and also make sure that the project is staffed correctly from the beginning.
And then third is clear understanding of the scope.
Part of project
planning is doing the work breakdown schedule and setting
up the timeline.
And if you don't have a clear project scope, then neither of those activities will be successful
and your project
team will not have a clear vision of what it is
that
they need to get done.
So the three most important things for project planning is one, allow sufficient time and don't
race through it; two, ensure
that you have
the proper resources that you need to both plan and execute the project; and then three,
to make sure
that you have a
very clear understanding of the goals and the
scope of work that needs to be done.
Impacts of effective project planning can include a change in the scope or stakeholders,
the amount of time estimated becomes unfeasible and needs to make changes.
A lack of team building and communication can really impact
your overall project.
Well, let me be honest with you.
We could probably spend the next hour or two discussing this question, because there are
plenty of things that can impact the effectiveness of your planning.
But let me begin with one of my favorite quotes from Benjamin Franklin.
"If you fail to plan, you are planning to fail."
So here are my top four reasons or impacts, if you will. Number one,
failure to gain approval of a project charter even beyond that, failure to even develop a
project charter in the first place.
Remember that the project charter is the basis for all planning.
It lists the project goals and high-level objectives.
Planning accomplished without the benefit of a project charter will likely lead to
scope creep and project failure
in the end. A little bit more on that point later.
Secondly, another quote, "Know what you know, know what you don't know, and surround yourself
with people who know what you don't know."
Ensure you have the subject matter experts available to help you effectively plan, otherwise,
your plan will likely be flawed.
Failure to have the meeting before the meeting.
Share your scope, schedule and budget with key stakeholders as they are developed.
Do not wait until everything is completed.
Effective project planning addresses scope first.
Once the scope baseline is approved,

Finally, support planning is completed.
Be inclusive and get sign off each step along the way.
Finally, assumptions, definition: assumptions are factors we believe to be true but have
not validated.
Remember this:
assumptions lead to risks,
risks lead to issues, issues lead to problems and potential project failure.
Don't assume; validate your assumptions.

Module 5 Summary and Highlights
Congratulations! You have completed this module. At this point in the course, you know:
•	The end-to-end planning process and all project managers should follow this process to 
improve the potential for success. You also learned about the role of the business analyst 
(BA). The role of the BA and the BA framework is a key area of emphasis on the CAPM 
test.
•	The distinct processes provide a roadmap to follow when planning scope, schedules, and 
costs. All planning should be approved and accepted to finalize the scope, schedule, and cost 
baselines. Remember to plan the scope first. The scope should meet the entire needs of the 
project as defined in the project charter.
•	Support planning begins after the manager finalizesthe scope, schedule, and cost baselines. 
Support planning ensures that the team addresses and plans for project quality, resources, 
communications, risk, and procurements accordingly.
•	Earned Value Management (EVM) is used in many organizations and is a great way to show 
the project's progress. EVM analysis also allows project managers to make directional 
changes as needed to get a project back on track when it falls behind on schedule, budget, 
and production of deliverables. EVM is an area of concentration on the CAPM test.
•	The project manager is responsible for gaining project management plan approval and 
acceptance. 

Key Takeaways


A solid foundation in project management initiation and planning can help you unlock the potential 
of successful project execution. This course guided you in learning about project initiation and 
planning processes.
The key takeaways from this course include:
•	Projects may use a predictive or adaptive method. Predictive, or Waterfall, projects are a 
traditional approach that relies on planning and a predetermined project scope. Adaptive, or 
Agile, projects are a flexible, iterative approach that embraces change and focuses on 
adaptability.
•	The Project Management Institute (PMI) developed the most common project phasing 
method, which includes initiating, planning, executing, monitoring and controlling, and 
closing.Project managers can improve the potential for project success by following this 
end-to-end planning process.
•	Organizations can impact a project manager's ability to be successful. The primary impact is 
on authority, role, availability of resources, availability of staff, and control of the budget.
•	The Project Management Office (PMO) is an organization's centralized department or team 
responsible for establishing and maintaining project management standards, practices, and 
methodologies. The three types of PMOs are supportive, controlling, and directive.
•	The twelve key principles listed in the Project Management Body of Knowledge 7th edition 
(PMBOK7)are:
•	Being a diligent, respectful steward
•	Creating a collaborative project team environment
•	Engaging with stakeholders
•	Focusing on value
•	Recognizing, evaluating, and responding to system interactions
•	Demonstrating leadership behaviors
•	Tailoring based on the context
•	Building quality into processes and deliverables
•	Navigating complexity
•	Optimizing risk responses
•	Embracing adaptability and resiliency
•	Enabling change to achieve the envisioned future state
•	Project management is an art and a science, and you should practice your interpersonal skills 
to be an effective project manager and avoid project failure.
•	The virtual environment is a reality in today's modern project management world. Project 
managers should expect virtual challenges and be ready to plan around them.
•	Organizing and leading effective meetings is a critical project management skill. Meetings 
are a core means of project communications.
•	A project manager must motivate the team and stakeholders to commit to performing the 
project's activities.
•	The PMI's common models for influencing stakeholders include Theories X, Y, and Z, The 
7-step Team Performance Model, and the Influence Diagram.
•	Change is inevitable, and it's important to remember you can manage change, or it can 
manage you. If change is required, approach change management in a structured and 
proactive manner. 
•	The PMI project management quality process includes quality assurance (QA) and quality 
control (QC).
•	A business case, a project charter, and project briefs are important documents that project 
managers must often create or execute. 
•	A business case outlines the justification for undertaking the project initiative. It provides a 
detailed analysis of the project's potential benefits, costs, risks, and feasibility.
•	A project charter is a formal document that authorizes the existence of a project and provides 
a high-level overview of the project, outlining its objectives, scope, stakeholders, and key 
deliverables.
•	A project brief is a concise document that provides an overview of a project. It outlines the 
essential details and requirements of the project, serving as a communication tool between 
stakeholders, project managers, and team members.
•	A stakeholder register defines the roles and responsibilities of the stakeholders essential for 
project success.
•	Decision-making is a critical skill essential to a project manager's success. Some decision-
making techniques project managers use are voting, fist-to-five, nominal group technique 
(NGT), autocratic, multi-criteria decision analysis (MCDA), and Wideband Delphi.
•	Do not assume stakeholder commitment; instead, use the stakeholder engagement plan to 
develop strategies to keep stakeholder commitment high.
•	Project managers must understand financial metrics as many projects are approved to 
improve monetary returns. Financial analysis is a critical project selection process, and 
project managers must plan budgets correctly to support scope and schedule requirements.
•	The project scope should be planned first and meet the project's needs as defined in the 
project charter.
•	Support planning begins after the project manager finalizes the scope, schedule, and cost 
baselines. Support planning ensures that the team addresses and plans for project quality, 
resources, communications, risk, and procurements.
•	Earned Value Management (EVM) is used in many organizations and is a great way to show 
the project's progress. EVM analysis allows project managers to make directional changes to 
get a project back on track when it falls behind. 
•	The project manager is responsible for gaining project management plan approval and 
acceptance.

Lifecycle Overview

Welcome to Expert Viewpoints: Lifecycle Selection Management.

In this video, we will hear from Project Managers discussing common Project lifecycles they
use in their organization, and how they'd use the lifecycles in a project
Based on my experience, I just really want to share three of them.
One of them is the traditional Waterfall Model.
This is wonderful for events, straightforward projects.
You simply plan, once you have your plan, you implement the plan.
You do it; you check to make sure that the plan is working, and you follow up.
And you deliver the product or the service, or you go back and fix it.
I do an awful lot of process development and process improvement work as well, and another
common lifecycle that I like to use is what we call
the DMAIC model.
DMAIC stands for define, measure, analyze, implement, and control.
If you ever study for Six Sigma, if you're looking to become a green belt, or perhaps
even a black belt, you will be asked to go ahead and implement a Six Sigma project, a
process development or process improvement project, and you will get an opportunity to
use that DMAIC model.
The last model that I want to go ahead and share is an agile model, but in particular
- Scrum.
I enjoy using Scrum when we need some kind of an iterative process when the customer
is looking for quick deliveries, and when we anticipate an awful lot of change.
A common life cycle that we use in our organization includes initiating, planning, executing,
monitoring, and controlling, and closing.
In practice, in my organization, I work closely with our Google Partnership.
, We initiate our project with Google, but this can apply to any project by really discovering
the scope of what needs to be accomplished through the project.
So if they want to make refresh a certificate, for example, let me have a conversation with
Google to understand well which components are we refreshing.
What is our timeline?
What's our budget?
And from there, we move on to selecting a vendor, and when we talk to the vendor, we
let them know the scope of the project then and give them more granular details of what
needs to be accomplished, and then come back to us with their proposed timeline as well
as their proposed deliverables based on what Google needs, which then moves us over to
planning.
Planning is very collaborative.
In my particular instance, involves Google and vendors, and that's where we really get
through finalizing the timeline, finalizing the smaller, the more granular chunks of a
specific timeline when we want to have specific deliverables like videos assessments, readings,
etc.
And then when we also want to time a lot time for QA and review.
Then that moves us over to executing, and in the execution phase, that's when we really
get into putting our heads down and doing the work.
And that brings us over to monitoring and controlling.
I think there are different ways to handle monitoring and controlling.
I personally like to have weekly check-ins and then also disperse larger check-ins between
the vendor and Google, and myself, where we really delved into the details of the project.
However, I do have colleagues that do something more like daily stand-ups, which I have done
in the past as well, and then something more like biweekly meetings.
I think it really just depends on the cadence of your or your desired cadence as well as
how everyone works together, and then finally, that brings us over to closing of the project,
assuming everything goes well, and you always hope that it does you close right on time
and if it does not, then you will figure out where you have room to extend your deadline.
And at closing, I think it's always fun to celebrate the projects, celebrate milestones
and then also do a recap of what went well and what did not go well.
There's a gentleman named Ralph Stacey who came up with a wonderful model that is a best
practice in project selection today.
Stacey said that, take a look at two key aspects of a project.
One of them is technical complexity and the other is the level of agreement.
And by agreement, I mean agreement among the stakeholders in terms of what does
success look like at the end of the day?
When the technology is extremely complex, and there
is minimal agreement, which means the majority of the
stakeholders really have no clue what they want in the end, then agile is probably the
best way to go.
However, if the technology is relatively straightforward, you don't anticipate a lot of problems, and
there is general agreement among the stakeholders that regardless of how long this particular
project takes, at the end of the day, this is what we want, then probably Waterfall is
your best bet.

Adaptive Lifecycles

Welcome to "Adaptive Lifecycles."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Identify artifacts used in adaptive projects,
Define the purpose and make-up of a user story and a product backlog,
And explain the adaptive flow through plan, execution, and closure.
Artifacts are templates, documents, outputs, or deliverables.
In adaptive projects, there are three common artifacts to remember and be aware of:
Product backlog,
Sprint backlog,
And product increments.

The product backlog is a list or repository for all project requirements which the product
owner develops and maintains.
In adaptive project management, the product owner defines and documents requirements as
a user story.
The product owner then adds and prioritizes user stories to the backlog and works with
the team to determine which user stories the team will accomplish in a single iteration
or sprint.
A product launch may have a few or many user stories.
In addition, a product backlog may include user stories for single or multiple product
launches.
A minimal viable product (or MVP) is an increment the team produces in a single sprint.

Next, the agile team develops the sprint backlog.
The team selects a set number of user stories for implementation in each sprint.
The sprint backlog breaks each user story into tasks the team must accomplish.
The project owner lists tasks in the order in which they occur and assigns them to individual
team members.
The team uses the sprint backlog to stay on track and reduce the potential for scope creep.
In a traditional predictive project, the sprint backlog has the same characteristics as a
work breakdown structure (or WBS).
Product increments are deliverables from each iteration the team produces and delivers to
the customer for feedback through a product demo or review.
Every sprint should provide value as an increment.
However, this increment does not necessarily represent the final product.
During an agile project, the team builds a product one part at a time.
The final product will typically require multiple sprints before launching the finished product.
There are two parts to a user story.

Part 1 of the user story is the requirement description the product owner completes with
the customer.
The user story requirement contains three statements:

The role, or who needs this requirement,

The need, or what the specific need of the customer is,

And the business value of satisfying the need.

Part 2 of the user story is the acceptance criteria.
The product owner collaborates with the agile team and determines solutions to satisfy the
user story.
The product owner shares solutions with the customer, gains sign-off, then includes the
user story in the backlog.
Product owners should follow the DEEP model when creating a product backlog.
Detail: The product owner should ensure they include enough detail in each user story to
allow the team to build the solution successfully.
Estimate: Each user story requirement and solution definition must be specific and measurable
to the point where a team can determine the time and cost required.
Emerge: The product backlog will change after each sprint.
Customers may wish to add or modify requirements due to feedback the team receives at the demo.
Prioritize: Product owners should prioritize all user stories for the team to accomplish
them.
Product owners prioritize user stories on value and the logical order of product completion.

The agile product management overview process consists of nine steps.
Step 1: The product owner meets with customers to determine their product requirements and
discuss schedules and budget considerations.
Step 2: The product owner develops user stories to satisfy all product requirements with the
customer.
Step 3: The product owner meets with the team, who reviews each user story and proposes the
acceptance criteria to develop an increment or MVP.
Step 4: The product owner shares the user story acceptance criteria with the customer,
which validates the user story.
Step 5: The product owner places all user stories in the product backlog and prioritizes
them in the order in which they occur.
Step 6: The team meets with the product owner and determines how many user stories the team
will accomplish in the first sprint.
The team selects the user stories and develops a sprint backlog.
Step 7: The team works to complete the user story MVP.
Remember that agile sprints are time-boxed.
The norm is fifteen or thirty days.
If the team cannot complete all user story requirements, the team carries the user story
over to the next sprint.
The agile sprints do not extend.
Step 8: The team provides a demo at the end of the sprint for customer feedback.
The product owner refines or updates the product backlog.
The team meets for a retrospective meeting to discuss what went well and what change
makes the most sense to implement in the next sprint.
Step 9: The team continues to repeat this process from Step 6 until the team completes
all sprints to produce a final product

In this video, you learned that:
Artifacts are templates, documents, outputs, or deliverables.
There are three common artifacts:
The product backlog is a list of all project requirements the product owner develops and
maintains,
The sprint backlog is specific tasks from the user story that the agile team develops,
And the product increment is deliverables from each sprint that the team provides to
the customer for feedback.
A user story is the requirement description and acceptance criteria.
The product backlog follows the DEEP model.
The nine-step-by-step overview of the agile project management process.

Project Initiation
Welcome to "Project Initiation" After watching this video, you will be able to:
Summarize the project initiation phase.
Explain the roles and responsibilities of the project manager.
Describe the project charter and stakeholder register.
And explain the project charter approval process.
The project initiation phase provides an opportunity to define a project for stakeholder approval
and to begin effective project planning.
The steps for correctly initiating the project include:
The problem or opportunity is identified.
The initial business case with a benefits analysis/statement of work (SOW) is approved.
The project charter is developed.
The stakeholder register is developed.
The pre-baseline is approved by stakeholders.
The project charter is approved for planning.
The benefits of using the project initiation phase include:
Ensuring the project meets the organization's needs.
Gaining agreement on project objectives.
Mapping the project to the programs and portfolio.
Identifying and informing stakeholders of responsibilities.
And it authorizes the project manager to proceed to the planning phase.
The key roles project managers must complete in the initiation phase include the following:
Working closely with program and portfolio managers to understand the business needs
and benefits of the project.
Reviewing the business case driving the project, if applicable.
Understanding the role of a business analyst to develop a business case, in the event a
business analyst is not part of the project.
Working with stakeholders to ensure understanding of the project objectives.
And, presenting the project charter to the project sponsor in a "pre-baseline presentation."
Here are the key responsibilities of project managers during the initiation phase.
Developing and staffing key documents for approval, including a business case, project
charter, or stakeholder register.
Determining key stakeholders required to achieve project success.
Also, documenting roles and responsibilities and gaining stakeholder commitment to the project.
Gaining project charter approval before moving to the planning phase.
And, working with the project team to determine if the project adds value to the problem.
A project charter may include an approval or recommendation to defer or cancel a project.
The project charter and stakeholder register are part of a four-step process to achieve
project success.
Steps 1 and 2 define what and why and are accomplished in the project charter.
Step 3 defines who needs to be involved and is accomplished in the stakeholder register.
Step 4 defines how and is accomplished in the planning phase.
The project charter is completed by the project manager in a straightforward process.
Understand the business case and project benefits.
Develop the project charter and stakeholder register with stakeholders.
Present the charter to the project sponsor in a "pre-baseline" presentation with a recommendation
to approve, defer, or cancel the project.
Share the charter with stakeholders and begin project planning.
In this video, you learned that: The project initiation phase defines the project
for stakeholder approval.
The key roles and responsibilities of the project manager during the initiation phase
include: Understanding business needs of the project.
Developing key documents for approval.
Identifying stakeholders and gaining their commitment.
Working with stakeholders to understand objectives.
Presenting a "pre-baseline presentation" to the project Sponsor for approval.
The project charter defines what and why of a project.
And finally, the stakeholder register defines who is involved in the project.

Project Planning

Welcome to "Project Planning"
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Describe the importance of the project planning phase.
Explain the roles and responsibilities of the project manager.
Describe the importance of an organized project planning approach.
And explain the project management plan approval process and kick-off meeting.

The project management lifecycle aligns with the Plan-Do-Check-Act (PDCA) methodology.
The project management Institute (PMI) framework outlines forty-nine steps recommended to plan
and deliver a project successfully.
Twenty-four of those steps fall in the planning phase; this is close to fifty percent of the
total project steps!
Planning is critical.
The project manager guides and controls the end-to-end planning process.
The project manager enlists the support of the project team but is ultimately responsible
for the project results.
If the project fails, the project manager is held accountable.
Now, the key responsibilities of the project manager include:
-Ensuring subject matter experts (SMEs) are documented and approved in the project 
charter.
-Documenting personnel support needs in the stakeholder register.
-Ensuring key support personnel have the skills and capacity to support the project.
-Developing and following a comprehensive project management plan.
-Working with the planning team and supporting their needs, including addressing blockers.
-Being inclusive in the planning process.
-Staffing each major part of the plan and getting buy-in before moving forward.

The project management plan consists of a series of smaller plans compiled to provide
an overall view of the project.
Understanding the steps involved in developing a comprehensive project management plan for
the Certified Associate in Project Management (CAPM) test is essential.
Once the Project Charter is approved, the Project Management Plan steps are to
Define the scope, Define the schedule and budget,
Complete support planning, Approve the project plan,
Conduct a kick-off meeting, And create a project baseline.
The first planning step is to plan the scope of the project.
The scope should reflect all requirements listed and approved in the project charter.
Even if there is not enough time and budget to implement the total scope of the project,
we still plan the full scope at this step.
Project managers may conduct negotiations if the scope needs reduction.
And stakeholders and sponsors receive the proposed scope during a "meeting before the meeting."
The next step for the project manager is to develop a project schedule and budget to meet
the total scope needs of the project.
The project manager may need to "balance the triangle" if there is not enough time
or budget to meet the comprehensive needs of the project.
The triangle represents scope, time, and cost.
Project managers negotiate the scope, schedule, and funding to determine an acceptable solution
for project implementation.
The team may need to revisit scope planning to downsize the scope in order to meet realistic
plans and budget resources.
After the project manager develops the scope, schedule, and budget, the project sponsor
signs off on these plans.
Then, the project manager establishes the project scope baseline, the schedule baseline,
and the cost baseline.
The term "baseline" indicates that the project sponsor and critical stakeholders
approve of the plan.
Next, the project manager begins the support planning stage, which is made up of several
planning elements.
The quality assurance (QA) and quality control planning activities ensure the project conforms
to quality requirements.
Resource planning ensures the correct number of resources are available when needed.
Resources primarily include personnel, materials, supplies, and equipment.
Communications planning ensures all team members are aware of their roles and responsibilities.
Project risk management planning ensures risks are known in advance.
Procurement management planning may be needed if third-party support from an external seller
is required to achieve the scope.
And stakeholder engagement planning ensures that stakeholder commitment and engagement
remains high.
The project manager presents the final project plan to the project sponsor.
Then the sponsor will either approve or request revisions to the program.
If the project manager has included the sponsor in the initial planning, it is more likely
that the sponsor will support the plan.
Once the sponsor signs off on the final project plan, the next step is to schedule a kick-off
meeting.
The goal of a kick-off meeting is to share the approved project management plan with
project stakeholders and the project team to gain their approval and commitment to move
the project to the executing phase.
There is no established method to conduct a kick-off meeting.
The PMI states that the meeting is to be scheduled before executing begins.
There are six topics to address in the kick-off meeting.
Project background: Why is the project necessary?  and What is the value of the project?
Project scope: The stakeholders should agree on what will be accomplished by the project,
The timeline,
The risk management plan,
The key roles and responsibilities, And defining the tools, templates, and standards
used in the project.


In this video, you learned that:
The planning phase is critical as it includes twenty-four out of the forty-nine steps to deliver a 
project.
The project manager guides the end-to-end planning process.
And the project management lifecycle plan includes:
The project charter approval, Defining the scope,
Defining schedule and budget, Completing the support plan,
Approving the project plan, Conducting the kick-off meeting,
And creating the project baseline.

Project Executing

Welcome to "Project Executing" After watching this video, you will be able to:
Summarize the importance of the project executing phase.
Examine roles and responsibilities of the project manager.
Identify skills essential to project executing phase success.
In the project executing phase, also called the implementation phase, the team completes
tasks identified during the previous planning phase.
The executing phase begins when the project management plan is approved by the sponsor
and accepted by key stakeholders.
During this phase, the team produces the product or service which is delivered to the customer.
Certain processes should be followed to ensure a successful executing phase.
The project manager implements the following nine processes during the executing phase:
Acquire resources laid out in the project plan to support the project management plan.
If resources are not acquired, the project schedule may change.
Send statements of work (or SOW) to eligible sellers to find the best fit and develop a contract.
If contracts are not finalized quickly, the schedule may change.
Implement the communications management plan and keep it up-to-date and working, as 
communication requirements will change through the process.
You will learn about the communications management plan in another lesson.
Ensure quality assurance activities are implemented.
Quality assurance (or QA) focuses on preventing issues and defects in the deliverables and
ensures key executing processes and standards are being followed.
And manage project knowledge via status reporting and lessons learned.
The remaining four execution process phases the project manager should follow are:
Assist team members to develop their skills and provide constructive feedback to improve 
performance.
Manage the team and address issues as they occur, and communicate effectively.
Implement risk responses and work with risk owners to recognize when risks occur or about 
to occur.
And finally, maintain stakeholder engagement by implementing strategies to keep 
stakeholders motivated.
The project manager plays a critical role during the executing phase.
The following roles and responsibilities should be followed by the project manager:
Be accessible to the team and meet with them often to be aware of any issues.
Manage effective meetings to ensure communication to the team.
Manage change via the integrated change management system and ensure stakeholders adhere to it
to avoid scope creep.
Conduct and share lessons learned to assist future project managers by recommending solutions
to problems encountered.
And monitor project support activities and ensure key quality, procurement, and risk management
activities are accommodated and completed.
Project management is most critical in the project executing phase for a successful completion.
The project management institute (or PMI) defines 11 key interpersonal skills essential
to success: Effective communication, leadership, motivation,
conflict management, negotiation, coaching, political and cultural awareness, influencing,
decision-making, team building, and trust-building.
In this video, you learned: The project executing phase begins after the
project management plan is approved.
The team produces the product, service, or deliverables during the executing phase.
The key processes of the executing phase.
The roles and responsibilities of the project manager.
And the 11 interpersonal skills identified by the PMI for a successful executing phase.

Project Monitoring and Controlling

Welcome to "Project Monitoring and Controlling" After watching this video, you will be able 
to:
Summarize the importance of the project monitoring
and controlling phase, Describe the integrated change control process,
Examine the roles and responsibilities of the project manager,
And identify essential skills to project monitoring and phase success.
Now, the monitoring and controlling phase begins when the team produces the first 
deliverable.
In this phase, the team verifies that all deliverables meet the specifications the project
manager documents in the project management plan.
In addition, the customer accepts the project deliverables.
Integrated change control is also a part of the monitoring and controlling phase.
Now, there are eight monitoring and controlling phase processes.
The quality control team inspects and verifies each deliverable the team produces.
And the team must correct deliverables with defects before transferring them to the customer.
The project team validates the scope.
The phrase, "The customer is always right," holds true in project management.
The deliverable is not complete until the customer accepts it.
The project manager and team control the scope, schedule, and cost to meet the baseline 
commitments
made in the project management plan.
And the project manager controls resources.
And resource requirements may change as the project progresses.
The project manager must communicate resource needs to the functional managers who oversee
the resources.
Let's now learn about the four remaining monitoring and controlling phase processes.
The project manager monitors communications via the communications management plan, which
is kept up to date throughout the project.
The project manager and team monitor risks.
And risks must be identified and acted upon if they occur.
The project manager controls procurements, communicates with vendors or sellers, and
monitors them to ensure they produce what is outlined in the contract.
And finally, the project manager monitors stakeholder engagement by implementing strategies
to keep stakeholder commitment throughout the project.
The project manager and team develop an integrated change control process to ensure project 
change
management.
If the team does not control change, scope creep may occur.
The integrated change control program is part of the project management plan.
Sponsors and stakeholders approve this plan, and the project manager enforces it.
Stakeholders should commit to following this process to ensure a quality end product.
So, according to the Project Management Institute (or PMI), any project's two primary quality
goals are to conform to requirements and provide a deliverable that is fit for use.
There are three components of an integrated change control program.
Process unique to the project,
Change log,
And change form.
The roles and responsibilities of the project manager during the monitoring and controlling
phase include: Being accessible to the team and meeting often
to stay on top of any issues or defects in the product.
Managing effective meetings to ensure communication.
Quality control and deliverable acceptance meetings are critical during this phase.
Managing change with the integrated management system to ensure all stakeholders adhere to
it.
Sharing periodic lessons learned whether the product is a success or if there are issues.
Ensuring defective deliverables are not given to the customer and identifying and correcting
defects as soon as possible.
To ensure a successful project monitoring and controlling phase, the project manager
must do the following: Perfect the 11 critical interpersonal skills the PMI defines as essential to 
success.
We cover these in another lesson, but as a review, these include effective communication,
leadership, motivation, conflict management, negotiation, coaching, political and cultural 
awareness, influencing, decision-making, team building, and trust-building.
The project manager must also understand and acknowledge external stakeholders' and customers'
needs and develop collaboration skills to ensure a successful interaction with both.
In this video, you learned that: The monitoring and controlling phase begins
when the team produces the first deliverable, The customer accepts deliverables that meet
the specifications in the project management plan.
The integrated change control program has three components:
Process unique to the project, Change log,
And change form.
The project manager and team develop an integrated change control process to ensure project 
change
management, And the project manager's roles and responsibilities
in this phase include the 11 PMI interpersonal skills and understanding stakeholders' and customers' 
needs.

Project Closing

The closing process begins when the project team produces a deliverable, the quality control 
team inspects the deliverable, and the project manager verifies the deliverable as meeting 
specifications from the project management plan.
The project team completes the closing phase input and outputs for all deliverables. The key inputs 
required to begin the closing phase are:
•	The project charter, which defines the objectives of the project. The objectives drive 
project planning and execution. Project managers evaluate deliverables against what the 
project charter describes to ensure no omissions or gaps.
•	Business documents such as the benefits management plan and business case which 
describe the project's anticipated benefits. The project manager assesses whether the final 
project has delivered the intended benefits.
•	The project manager ensures fulfillment of all contract deliverables and settlement of 
final payments, and no actions remain.
•	An authorized agent accepts the deliverables. Possible authorized agents include the 
sponsor, the manager, the client, the customer, or the user.
Once the project team fulfills the input requirements, the project manager focuses on the outputs of 
the phase, which include:
•	The final product transition, the most crucial product or service handoff. The customer 
accepts the product or service, which is now their responsibility.
•	The final report is an overview of what the project team plans to create versus what they 
produce. If there are gaps or omissions, the project manager must address them. This report 
is also an excellent opportunity to thank and praise the team.
•	Lessons learned are critical, as lessons learned provide information to help future projects 
succeed.
Key roles and responsibilities of the project manager
The roles and responsibilities of the project manager during the closing phase include:
•	Staying in constant contact with those who must accept the final product or service and 
identifying and addressing issues when they occur.
•	Being aware of what success looks like and constantly searching for deviations that may 
result in non-conformance and a lack of fitness for use.
•	Ensuring the capability of the subject matter experts who understand the nature of 
contract deliverables and can perform effective vendor management for the project.
•	Beginning to plan the product or service transition on day one of the project. The 
project manager should identify who will accept the transitioned product or service and 
ensure the acceptor is part of the project planning and execution phases.
•	Performing a variance analysis and knowing what the project means to produce. The 
project manager must have an inventory of what the project team produces and address any 
variances as the next steps.
•	Conducting lessons learned.
The Importance of Lessons Learned
The project manager should conduct and document lessons learned after each completed 
project phase or within implementation of a process when it makes sense. The Project 
Management Institute (PMI) states that the primary value of lessons learned is to provide 
information to help future projects be successful. History repeats itself. Lessons learned ensure 
that good history repeats itself or reduces the risk of bad history recurring.
The project manager leads lessons learned, and the project team and stakeholders respond to three 
questions:
1.	What went well?
2.	What could go better?
3.	How can we improve?
The PMI recommends that the organization create a lessons learned register, a document the 
project manager posts in a shared location such as Microsoft Teams or Microsoft SharePoint. The 
lessons learned from multiple projects are available to select managers and team members to 
review.
A second recommendation from the PMI is that the project manager assigns each improvement idea 
to a team member. This team member is responsible for executing the improvement idea. The 
project manager logs the responsible team member and improvement idea into the lessons learned 
register.
Conclusion
Project managers must be able to summarize the importance of the project closing phase, including 
the key inputs and outputs that occur. Project managers should communicate with those who 
accept the deliverables, be aware of what a successful finished project looks like, and conduct 
lessons learned with the project team after the project. Lessons learned prompt the stakeholders 
and project team to determine what went well, what could go better, and how they could improve to 
ensure the success of the future project.

Common Causes for Project Failure
A project manager is expected to see a project through from the beginning to a successful end. 
While no project manager will plan for failure, there are times when a project fails. This article 
describes expected losses and causes and recommends best practices to minimize failure.
Please note that the reasons are not in any specific order.
Scope Creep
Scope creeps a common reason for project failure. Scope creeps a failure to conform to 
requirements. For example, consider a scenario when the project team adds a functionality to a 
deliverable without formal approval from a sponsor or senior leadership. The addition of a new 
functionality can potentially impact the project schedule and budget.
To effectively limit the scope, maintain a well-documented Integrated Change Control system. 
Ensure all stakeholders adhere to the system. A project manager must ensure that the relevant 
stakeholder approves any change or addition to an existing requirement before the project team 
starts working on the need.
Poor Communications
Ineffective communication between team members, other stakeholders, and senior leadership is a 
significant cause of project failure. For example, a project team may not receive communication at 
the right time. Another example is where senior leadership may not receive the correct input. Both 
situations may occur because of team members not freely expressing their concerns.
To ensure effective communication, the project manager must ensure that the proper 
communication at the right time to the right people in the right amount. Also, having a 
Communications Management Plan is critical.
Poor Resource Management
Poor resource management leads to shortages, over-allocation of workload, cost overruns, and 
missed schedules.
To avoid resource issues, a project manager must identify resources essential to project success 
during the Planning process. A project manager must ensure that resources are available when 
required.
Inadequate Stakeholder Management
Far too often, a project manager does not understand different stakeholders' needs. The gap in 
understanding can lead to a shortfall in stakeholder management, which can cause multiple issues 
that can impact project success. As an example, consider a situation where a project has some 
changes to the HR process. Unfortunately, HR was not included in initial project planning and is 
now put into a reactive mode to accomplish their responsibilities.
Make sure to invest time and effort in people, as they are the essential resource on a project.


Poor Estimation
Many project managers estimate time and cost in the ideal time, which rarely materializes. There is 
usually an optimistic, most likely, and pessimistic estimate to consider. According to proven 
statistics, the optimistic estimate occurs on only one in six occasions.
When the estimate is not correct, the associated plan is inaccurate. The inaccuracies can result in 
project failure.
To ensure good estimation, a project manager can leverage various tools, such as three-point 
estimation and top-down estimation, using a work breakdown structure (WBS).
Poor Risk Management
Risk is any potential event that can impact a project. Risk can push a project to failure. Remember, 
"You can manage risk, or it will manage you." If the project team is not able to identify risks at the 
right time, they can become an issue from which the project cannot recover.
There are various strategies to respond to risks. We will cover this subject in detail later in this 
course.
Poor Planning
"If you fail to plan, you are planning to fail." - Benjamin Franklin
Planning is one of the most critical activities and can aid with the project's direction. As mentioned 
earlier, a poor estimation can result in inadequate planning. An incorrect understanding of the 
project deliverables can also result in insufficient planning. Many projects kick off with poorly 
defined objectives. Several times, a project manager may spend minimal time on planning during 
the initial stages of a project. Casual planning can result in issues as the project moves forward. For 
example, some critical tasks may not have been addressed during the initial planning phase. This 
will have a ripple effect on any task. 
A project manager must spend time planning to define SMART objectives in the project charter 
and ensure all stakeholders agree with the project objectives.
Poor Quality Management
Quality is an important aspect of any project. Quality problems can derail them. Most organizations 
have some form of a quality control system. The quality control system allows projects to detect 
quality problems. However, most times the quality problem detection happens towards end of the 
project. Discovering problems when after finalizing a deliverable can impact schedules and budgets 
negatively.
To reduce quality problems, make sure to document and monitor quality requirements. 
Implementing quality assurance can help with identifying problems before they occur.
Project Manager Role: Organization Models
Almost every project in an organization is bound to have a project manager. In some organization 
models, the project manager is part-time, or a technical member might take up project management 
as an additional role. In these scenarios, the overall project results tend to suffer.
For the project manager role to be effective and drive a project to success, organization models 
should encourage good project management. Organizations with formal project management 
methodologies can streamline project management activities and equip project managers with tools 
and best practices for success.
Incorrect Project Lifecycle Selection
Using predictive methods to execute a project when adaptive methods are the best fit, or vice-versa 
can lead to poor results.
For example, using predictive methods when the degree of change is high and the customer expects 
frequent deliveries is a mistake. On the other hand, using agile for a simple project where change is 
low and a single deliverable at the end of the project is expected to be "overkill."
To select the right lifecycle, an organization needs to analyze the project and determine which 
specific lifecycle type is the best fit. After selection, a project manager can plan and implement the 
project.

Module 1 Summary and Highlights: The 
Project Management Lifecycle
Congratulations! You have completed this module. At this point in the course, you know:
•	The different types of project lifecycles, including predictive and adaptive methods.
•	A brief overview of adaptive lifecycles and critical artifacts.
•	The Project Management Institute (PMI) employs crucial processes with each of the five 
phases or process groups in a predictive lifecycle.
•	The project manager's roles and responsibilities during the project management lifecycle's 
initiating, planning, executing, and monitoring and controlling phases.
•	Development of the project charter and a stakeholder register occurs during the initiating 
phase, and the project manager presents these documents to a project sponsor for approval.
•	In the project planning phase, the project manager develops a comprehensive project 
management plan and presents it to a sponsor for approval. Then the project manager 
schedules a kick-off meeting and gains stakeholder acceptance of the plan.
•	The development of the project deliverables occurs during the executing phase and the skills 
a project manager must have for a successful execution phase.
•	The project manager verifies that completed deliverables meet project management plan 
specifications during the monitoring and controlling phase. The project team presents the 
deliverables to a customer for acceptance.
•	In the project closing phase, the project manager ensures all deliverables meet 
specifications, attains final customer acceptance, and transitions the final product or service 
to the customer. The project manager also presents a final report during this phase, and the 
project team conducts and shares lessons learned.
