Communications Basics

Welcome to "Communications Basics."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Summarize the communications model, Define technology factors that can impact
effective communications, And define various communications methods.
The communications model illustrates the complexity of achieving effective communications.
It is essential that the project manager understands the communications model in order to reduce
the risk of poor or inadequate communications that can lead to project failure.
Let's look at four lessons we can learn from the communications model.
Lesson one is to encode each message so the receiver can understand it.
The project manager should ensure that the message sent is the message received.
This requires audience analysis and an understanding of how the receiver prefers to communicate.
Lesson two is to select the correct medium.
Some people prefer to communicate with email, others prefer texts, and some stakeholders
may not respond unless you meet face-to-face.
Lesson three is to ensure that all communications have a purpose.
The project manager should ensure ahead of time what type of feedback they require and
adjust the message as needed.
If no feedback is necessary, the project manager may reevaluate the purpose of the communications.
And finally, lesson four is to be aware of communication blockers.
This is the project manager's greatest communication challenge.
The project manager should identify blockers and plan to overcome them.
Some examples of blockers include culture, language, or the individual's readiness
to receive the communication.
The Project Management Institute (or PMI) identifies technology factors that can jeopardize
effective communications.
First, how urgent is the need to share information?
Project managers should try to avoid the "priority one" syndrome and instead focus on sending
the right information, at the right time, in the right amount, to the right person.
Every message does not need to be urgent.
Second, the availability and reliability of the technology are important.
For example, if the project team uses Microsoft SharePoint, the project manager should ensure
that all key stakeholders have access to this software and understand how to use it.
Third, the project environment plays a big part in effective communications.
The project manager should consider how the project team will accomplish communications.
Face-to-face communications are the most effective.
However, the team may be dispersed in different time zones.
In this case, virtual communications may be the only option.
And finally, project managers should understand sensitivity and confidentiality considerations
by safeguarding communications and ensuring the right audience is targeted.
The PMI identifies three primary communications methods that project managers should 
consider.
Each method requires communications planning and a situational approach.
The first primary communications method is interactive communication.
Interactive communication occurs between two parties and can be very challenging.
The project manager needs to understand the other individual's perspective, preferred
communication style, level of knowledge, attitude, and more.
The second method is push communications.
In this method the project manager sends communications to one or multiple parties without 
receiving
any acknowledgment that the communications were read or understood.
The manager should use this type of communication only after reaching a consensus with 
stakeholders that they understand the purpose of the communication and commit to the process.
And finally, the last primary communication method is pull communications.
Here, the project manager needs to determine and plan for stakeholder communications access
needs.
Pull communications involve access to information by stakeholders on an on-demand basis.
In this video, you learned that: The communications model illustrates four
lessons the project manager should understand to avoid project failure, encoding communications,
using the correct medium, having a purpose, and being aware of blockers
The PMI identifies four technology factors that can impact effective communications,
including urgency, availability and reliability, environment, and sensitivity and 
confidentiality,
And the three primary communications methods managers should consider using are 
interactive, push, and pull communications.

Communications Planning

Welcome to "Communications Planning."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Identify the importance of effective communications in a project,
Describe a three-step approach to managing communications,
Examine communications management planning techniques,
And identify key communications activities for project success.
Effective communications can make or break a project.
The greater the communications' effectiveness, the higher the potential for project success.
Let's look at the project manager's communication responsibilities throughout the Project 
Management
Institute's (or PMI) lifecycle.
First, project managers should ensure that all stakeholders understand the lifecycle
they will use in the project.
Then, managers should communicate the location of all critical documents and ensure the team
and stakeholders can access them.
Managers should also provide an understanding of project roles, responsibilities, and collaboration
strategies.
Managers are responsible for conducting problem-solving and decision-making communications 
when needed.
In addition, managers should communicate essential tasks to the team and explain the purpose
and value the project deliverables provide to the organization.
Finally, the project manager should ensure all stakeholders understand the current project
status and next steps.
It is important to note that the PMI states that communications impact 90% of a project
manager's job.
If they fail to communicate effectively, the project may fail.
The PMI has a simple but effective three-step process to manage project communications and
this process follows the Plan-Do-Check-Act (or PDCA) methodology.
The first step in this process is to plan communications.
The project manager develops a communications management plan which defines crucial activities,
assigns leads, determines audiences, documents media and timing, and describes the purpose
of the communications items.
The next step is to manage communications.
Once the project sponsor approves the communications management plan, the manager can then 
implement
the plan, and the team can communicate in accordance with the plan.
And the third step in this PDCA methodology is to monitor communications.
In this final step, the team monitors and adjusts communication methods as needed.
The project manager monitors and resolves issues and updates the communications management
plan as the project progresses.
They also assess work performance information and share it in a work performance report.
The communications management plan provides a roadmap and a rhythm to communication.
Let's examine the nine-step process to develop and approve a communications management plan.
In the first step, the project manager determines if the organization uses a standard communications
management plan template.
If so, the manager uses the template.
In step two, the manager and team brainstorm the project.
Since every project is different, the group should determine the essential communications
they must execute to ensure success.
For step three, the project manager must determine whom is included in communications.
A best practice is for the manager to review the project's stakeholder register as a
starting point.
In almost all cases, someone on this register has a role that requires communications.
In step four of developing a communications management plan, the manager documents and
defines the purpose of each communications item and its audience.
In step five, the project manager determines the best team member to manage the communications 
item.
After confirming the role and responsibilities of the item lead with the team member, the
manager adds the assignment details to the plan.
Step six requires the project manager to analyze the audience to determine the most appropriate
communications medium and enter this description into the plan.
Options of communications mediums include email, messenger, virtual, or face-to-face meetings.
For step seven, the project manager determines the ideal frequency for each communications
item and completes the frequency section of the plan.
In step eight, the manager shares a copy of the initial plan with all potential recipients,
confirming that they agree and support the communications items that impact them.
Finally, in step nine, the project manager shares the communications management plan
and ensures version control on past documents, as the plan will require updates throughout
the project.
While every project is different, there are common activities that the project manager
should document in the communications management plan.
Let's look at some examples.
Managers post status reports and identify when and where the project team will hold
meetings.
The sponsor and manager discuss the project status and issues in periodic sponsor one-on-ones.
An essential activity of building a team is team meetings.
The project manager must plan meetings to ensure this interaction happens.
Vendor and change management communications are essential to ensure how project managers
will accomplish vendor management and how they will review and approve change requests.
For larger projects, the team needs to meet periodically to perform risk reassessments,
monitor risks, and share issues that occur and the plans to resolve them.
Some projects require specific meetings to discuss financial status and resource needs.
And finally, resource requirements may change for a variety of reasons, so it's important
that the team periodically meets and validates the resource plan to address shortages and
over-allocations.
In this video, you learned that: The project manager's communications responsibilities
throughout the PMI lifecycle include ensuring stakeholder understanding of the project lifecycle,
communicating documents to the team, conducting problem-solving and decision-making 
communications,
and confirming stakeholder understanding of the next steps.
Communications impact 90% of a project manager's job,
The PMI's three-step process to manage project communications is planning, managing, and
monitoring communications.
There are nine steps a manager should follow to develop and approve a communications 
management
plan, And despite differences in projects, there
are common activities that the project manager should always document in the communications
management plan.

Welcome to expert viewpoints, communications planning.
In this video, we will hear from
project managers discussing
how to effectively communicate.
I'm going to talk about two key documents.
One of them is the stakeholder register.
A stakeholder register is a list of key stakeholders that
the project manager or the team should
develop very early in the project.
You identify all stakeholders early,
you assign roles and responsibilities.
The key to this document is to
gain their commitment to support the project.
The second aspect or
document that I want to go ahead and talk
to is what we refer to as
a communications management plan.
Once we get into the planning phase,
what we're going to do is we're going to
take a look at that stakeholder register,
and we're going to determine who
needs to be communicated with.
In the communications management plan,
we defined a number of things.
Number 1, what do we want to communicate?
Number 2, to whom are we going to communicate?
Number 3, when are we going to communicate?
Number 4, how are we going to communicate?
And very importantly, Number 5,
why are we going to communicate
this particular information to the stakeholders?
As a rule, anyone who's on
the stakeholder register should show
up in the communications management plan.
If they're important enough to
have a role and responsibility,
they're important enough to be
able to receive information.
To plan to effectively communicate
with key stakeholders in a project,
it's important to establish
what cadence you want to use first.
For example at the onset of a project,
I like to establish whether or not we'll
be talking in weekly or
bi-weekly or if they need a
larger check-in at any period of the month.
Basically establish what cadence
you want to be able to have.
Then how ingrained into
details and other stakeholders want to be.
At the start of any project.
I always create a communication plan
detailing key stakeholders,
their role, and how and when
they're being communicated to.
The time and the effort I spend on
this always matches the size of
the project and the needs and
the expectations of the stakeholders.
For example maybe a small project might require
just a quick table and
a PowerPoint slide as a communication plan.
But for a big project,
like a product launch moment,
it might require a RACI chart in Excel or in PM software.
That might need formal interviews
conducted across multiple stakeholder groups
to really understand how
your project reports are being
socialized and who depends on them.
Setting up a communication plan for
a project can be a little tricky
because each project may
demand a certain communication tools.
For each project you're working with a different set of
stakeholders and a different set
of people that are actually doing the work.
This is really about stakeholder communication
and really understanding
who your stakeholders are is going to be
an important factor in
figuring out how best to communicate.
Once again, I'm going to point you to
the stakeholder register and communications plan.
But more than just developing them,
you want to go ahead and
have the meeting before the meeting.
Pre coordinate these, makes sure
that anyone who's on the stakeholder register with
a role and responsibility or anyone who is in
the communications management plan realizes that
they have a role to play and there are certain aspects of
communications that they have to be aware of as well.
Have that standard stakeholder
register communications management plan,
and make sure that they are available
and accessible to all of
the different stakeholders as well.
In addition, I'm going to introduce
a new acronym to you, MBWAT.
I learned this a long time ago.
It stands for management by walking and talking.
While MBWAT management by
walking and talking may not necessarily be a tool.
It is a very strong technique.
You can have multiple issues impact you in a project.
If you do not get out and
see the people, visit the stakeholders,
build those relationships,
those issues may catch you by surprise.
In addition, some project managers will try to
manage issues via email. Don't get me wrong.
Email is a great methodology.
However, you can accomplish
more in one face-to-face meeting,
then you probably can through
a number of different emails as well.
I have used different types of software.
I have used Asana,

My preference for those types of

Those are some tools that I like.
It's really important to research and take a look

for your own project as well.
It's hard to recommend a specific tool or

so their needs are always going to be so

with a wide range of

For example I'm a visual person.
I love PowerPoint decks,

and so I cater to their needs.
It's critical to interview clients at the start of

What do they want to see,
what has worked well for them in the past and why?


Manage Communications - Part 1


Welcome to "Manage Communications - Part 1."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Describe key communication methods.
And identify key communication challenges.
Managing communications occurs after the communications management plan has been approved.
Note,
The communication plan is discussed in another video.
Communication activities must be effective as the project moves into the execution phase.
There are different communication methods a project manager might need to use on a project.
These include interpersonal communication, small group communication, and large or public
group communication.
The project manager is responsible for selecting methods that meet the needs of the project
and stakeholders.
Let's look at some tips to make these methods effective.
Interpersonal communication is necessary and is an exchange between two individuals.
It is critical to understand various communications styles and needs of all members of the project
team to ensure communications are satisfactory and yield results.
Some stakeholders are analytical and want to get to the point.
Others are structural and want to be organized.
Some may be social and go with the motto "Let's work together."
And some others may be conceptual and say, "Let's explore the opportunities."
Small group communication is also a common method to share information.
And in small group communication, the project manager:
determines who needs to be in a meeting or on a chat.
Invites only those who need to be at the meeting.
Shares an agenda, sets clear goals and objectives, and shares minutes and action items when the
meeting is complete.
Finally, A project manager may need to communicate with a large group or publicly.
Here, careful preparation is essential.
The project manager must ensure the communication portrays information that was reviewed and
serves the needs of the organization.
Methods that work for some stakeholders may not work for others.
They must understand the audience, understand their information needs, and plan communications
accordingly.
We reviewed different communication methods.
Now, let's discuss a few types of communication mediums.
The medium types include face-to-face conversations, instant messaging, emails, and video calls.
Select the medium that best meets the needs of stakeholders.
For example, if team members work remotely, face-to-face is not the best option.
Select a call or a video conference.
You also need to decide if the meeting is impromptu or scheduled.
Remember, a method or medium that works for some stakeholders may not work for others.
Share the right information with the right people using an appropriate medium.
Understand the audience, understand their information needs, and plan your communications
accordingly.
A "one size fits all" communication methodology will not always yield positive results.
While communication must be effective, it is arguably a difficult interpersonal skill
to perfect.
Anticipate communications challenges as the project progresses.
The most common challenges include insufficient competence in communication, inability to
comprehend communication styles and non-verbal communication, dealing with commitment 
issues,
and providing feedback to team members.
Communication competence includes: tailoring communication,
ensuring the purpose of communications is clear,
building effective relationships to enhance communications success,
And displaying proper leadership behavior to support communications.
Strive to improve your communication competence whenever possible.
Since different stakeholders have different communication styles, the PMI recommends that
all project managers consider completing an assessment of their communication style and
be aware of the styles of others.
Also, be aware that messages are not simply conveyed with words.
A project manager also communicates non-verbally through expressions, gestures, and tone of
voice.
Ensure you are aware of your non-verbal mannerisms and take the next step to self-manage them.
The high level of excitement present when a project is initiated often decreases over
time.
A project manager must detect when the team's commitment levels drop and take action to
motivate the impacted stakeholders and team.
A project manager needs to hold stakeholders accountable for commitments to achieve project
goals.
A project manager should provide feedback to the team.
Feedback mitigates the risk of poor performance and accentuates and rewards the positive.
When feedback is not provided, team members assume they are performing adequately when
perhaps performance is lacking.
Remember to provide positive feedback.
Positive feedback reinforces good behaviors and skills and is a great tool for motivating
team members.
In this video, you learned that: Managing communications occurs after the communications
management plan is approved.
Three types of communication methods include interpersonal, small group, and large group
communication.
And, five key communication challenges include communication competence, communication style
comprehension, non-verbal communication comprehension, commitment management, and 
providing feedback.


Manage Communications - Part 2

Welcome to "Manage Communications - Part 2."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Explain key communication skills essential to succeed.
There are various interpersonal and team skills that are essential to improve communication,
as shared by PMI.
These include conducting effective meetings, active listening, conflict management, 
networking,
and" cultural and political awareness."
Meetings are a constant for a project manager.
Numerous studies cited meetings as a huge time waster in the opinion of managers.
Project managers must learn how to mitigate this risk.
Ensure meetings are well planned, have an agenda with a well-defined outcome, and are
conducted in an organized and efficient manner.
Only have meetings when necessary, and ensure the right people are invited and available.
Active listening is another key to your success.
Techniques that help with active listening include acknowledging the conversation, clarifying,
and confirming that you understand.
Paraphrasing is a great tool to show understanding.
Perfecting your active listening skills will improve the quality of communication, enhance
relationships, and garner additional levels of respect.
Conflict occurs when two or more parties have differing opinions or ideas.
Conflict can be categorized as functional or dysfunctional.
Functional conflict occurs when there are conflicting ideas that, when discussed, lead
to a better solution.
Dysfunctional conflict occurs when conflicting ideas lead to anger, frustration, and lost
time.
Conflict will occur.
A project manager must establish a safe environment where all stakeholders feel free to share
ideas in a constructive manner.
Effective networking provides access to multiple information sources, such as establishing
cross-team collaboration and garnering expertise in the organization from outside the project
team.
Networking helps solve problems and influence stakeholder support.
Understanding the differences between individuals, groups, and organizations is critical.
In addition, recognition of the project environment and power dynamics, both formal and informal,
can impact success.
In this video, you learned that: Five key interpersonal and team skills essential
to effective communications, as shared by PMI, are:
conducting effective meetings, active listening,
conflict management, networking, and
"cultural and political awareness."


Manage Communications, Tools, and 
Techniques


Welcome to "Manage Communications, Tools, and Techniques."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Summarize active listening,
Explain the importance of effective conflict management,
And explain the concept of cultural and political awareness when sharing information.
Active listening is a critical skill essential to effective communication.
Let's look at seven steps that summarize active listening.
This is also a great guide to improve active listening skills.
1-Being attentive.
The project manager should give the other party their full, undivided attention.
2-Asking open-ended questions.
Active listening enables the project manager to learn about various subjects in depth.
3-Asking probing questions.
Understanding the basic premise of the conversation and asking follow-up questions ensures 
effective communication.
4-Requesting clarification.
The project manager should ensure that the message sent was the message received.
5-Paraphrasing.
By repeating what they understood, the project manager can ensure everyone is on the same page.
6-Being attuned to and reflecting feelings.
Project managers should watch the non-verbal cues, listen to voice tone, and reflect passion
where appropriate.
7-Summarizing.
Project managers reflect on the conversation and ensure mutual understanding of the next
steps discussed.
Conflicts will happen and may be caused by resource availability, scheduling, budget,
priorities, personal work styles, personalities, and more.
Proactively recognizing and dealing with conflict can lead to greater productivity and fewer
issues.
Conflict can be both functional and dysfunctional.
Ways to reduce the risk of dysfunctional conflict and encourage functional conflict include:
Setting ground rules and norms, Having a solid and agreed-upon communications
management plan, having well-defined roles and responsibilities, and having productive team 
meetings.
The Project Management Institute (or PMI) states five potential techniques for resolving
conflict.
1-Collaborate-Problem Solve.
With this favoured conflict method, also known as win-win, project managers incorporate multiple
viewpoints, show a cooperative attitude, and strive for consensus and commitment.
2-Compromise-Reconcile.
This technique is not preferred but is often necessary when the collaborate-problem solve
technique is not possible.
Also known as lose-lose, each party receives something with this technique but must also
give up something in return.
Then we have, 3-Force-Direct.
Also known as win-lose, in this technique, one viewpoint is pushed at the expense of
another so that the second party may not have a say in the matter.
This method is preferred during emergencies but should not be the default conflict management
mode.
4-Withdraw-Avoid.
This method is not preferred long-term as it involves retreating or postponing a decision.
This can sometimes be positive as it can reduce emotions and allow for better preparation
to move forward.
Then finally we have 5-Smooth-Accommodate.
The areas of agreement are emphasized rather than the differences.
Needs are postponed to maintain harmony and relationships.
While this technique may be effective in certain situations, it is not long-term.
Project managers should adapt communications to accommodate individual, group, and 
organizational differences and minimize misunderstandings and miscommunication.
The benefits of improving cultural awareness include:
Increasing communication, Increasing respect and understanding of the
advantages a diverse culture can provide, Enhancing the ability to lead effectively,
Improving the workspace environment, And ensuring successful globalization.
Now, a project manager can potentially possess many forms of power.
Some powers are based on position, while other powers must be earned.
This PMI area of focus includes five powers.
1-Formal Authority or Position power is based on the position.
A project manager has authority over the project charter to plan and execute the project and
may request resources for project planning.
2-Reward Power is the project manager's ability to gain support from the team and stakeholders
due to the project manager's ability to provide salary, promotions, or future work
assignments.
3-Penalty power is the project manager's ability to take punitive action when team members
or stakeholders do not perform satisfactorily.
This power should be used sparingly and with caution.
4-The project manager gains expert power when the team and stakeholders perceive the project
manager as knowledgeable.
The team must perceive this knowledge as functional expertise that they consider essential.
Project managers must earn expert power.
And finally, 5-referent power is the ability of the project manager to gain support because the team 
and  stakeholders feel personally attracted to the project manager or the project.
In this video, you learned that: Active listening is a skill essential to effective
communication.
Project managers can reduce dysfunctional conflict and encourage functional conflict.
The five techniques the PMI recognizes for resolving conflict are:
Collaborate-problem solve, Compromise-reconcile,
Force-direct, Withdraw-avoid,
And smooth-accommodate.
Project managers should be culturally and politically aware.
Project managers can possess powers, and we reviewed five powers the PMI emphasizes.


Monitor Communications

Welcome to "Monitor Communications."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Summarize communications monitoring responsibilities.
Summarize effective meeting management techniques.
Describe best practices in virtual communications.
Identify how the Project Management Institute (PMI) Code of Ethics impacts effective 
communications.
Communication requirements change as a project progresses.
The project manager has several responsibilities to maintain good communication practices 
throughout
the project.
We will look at seven responsibilities.
The first three are: Continuing to monitor work performance information
impacting the project and communicating important information out.
Ensuring stakeholders follow the integrated change control process, as all changes must
be approved before implementation to avoid scope creep.
And keeping the communications management plan up to date and ensuring version control
is maintained.
Let's now look at the last four project management communication responsibilities.
Updating the stakeholder register, especially if new stakeholders are identified to support
the project.
Stakeholders whose support is no longer needed should be thanked and removed from the plan.
Managing and updating the issue log and proactively addressing issues.
Issues may be project or personnel-related and include blockers, stakeholder questions,
or problems that need a solution.
Continuing to develop and manage the team with meetings and discussions.
While e-mail is convenient, it should not be the primary communications method.
Face-to-face communication is preferred.
Lastly, conveying the importance of conducting and documenting lessons learned to assist
future projects; communicating successes and disappointments with stakeholders.
Meetings are necessary, and the project manager should ensure all meetings are meaningful
and provide value to participants by following ten meeting rules.
Let's look at the first five meeting rules.
Rule 1: Meeting goals are clear and actionable.
Rule 2: An agenda should always be shared.
A best practice for agendas is the 48/24 rule, meaning the agenda should be sent out 48 hours
prior to the meeting, and the meeting minutes, or notes, should be sent out no later than
24 hours after the meeting.
Rule 3: Publish minutes to act as a reminder on the next steps, and so that action items
are defined.
Rule 4: Share the purpose of the meeting with attendees.
Evaluate who should be at the meeting and who does not need to be.
Some members may be able to review minutes for needed information.
Rule 5: Share materials and pre-work 48 hours before the meeting.
Many meetings fail to achieve objectives due to stakeholders guessing what the meeting
is about during the meeting.
Now, let's look at the remaining five meeting rules a project manager should employ to ensure
meetings are meaningful and valuable.
Rule 6: Provide opportunities to team members to facilitate certain meetings.
Rule 7: Hire a notetaker when comprehensive notes are required to ensure the project manager
can focus on the meeting.
Rule 8: Assign owners to action items and ensure that stakeholders leave the meeting
with an understanding and commitment to accomplishing their tasks.
Rule 9: Practice non-attribution.
A meeting environment should allow stakeholders to feel comfortable and safe sharing ideas
and opinions that may contradict others.
There may be times when stakeholders want to discuss issues not pertinent to the current
meeting.
When this occurs, use what is called a parking lot method to provide a space for comments,
discussions, or questions that are not related to the current meeting's agenda.
By placing these topics to the side, they are not being ignored but will be dealt with
later.
Rule 10: End the meeting early if the objectives are met.
Meet for purpose, not just to fill up time.
Virtual communication requirements are a necessity in today's global environment, where 
stakeholders
and team members may not be able to meet face-to-face.
The Project Management Institute (PMI) recognizes the following best practices for virtual 
communication.
Planning regular and clear communications to avoid communication gaps.
Defining roles and responsibilities early in the project.
Using best meeting practices, such as agendas, and publishing the minutes.
Developing meeting norms and ground rules and sticking with them.
Striving to have a shared vision, outcome, and sense of purpose.
Promoting an open team culture where all team members are listened to, respected, and comfortable
asking others for help.
Building relationships, rapport, and trust.
Understanding team members' perspectives and how they prefer to work.
Using familiar technology and providing technology training when necessary.
Requesting virtual meeting members activate their camera when speaking.
Promoting use of screen-sharing technology.
And finally, using a common repository that all can easily access.
PMI defines four values that drive effective communications in their Code of Ethics, which
are: responsibility, respect, fairness, and honesty.
PMI defines responsibility as "Duty to take ownership for the decisions we make or fail
to make, the actions we take or fail to take, and the consequences that result."
Project managers have a duty to set a positive example and to accept accountability for the
project.
PMI defines respect as "Duty to show a high regard for ourselves, others, and the resources
entrusted to us."
Project managers who show respect for others receive respect in return.
PMI defines fairness as "Duty to make decisions and act partially and objectively."
A project team is a close-knit group.
And project managers should strive to create an environment of fairness.
And finally, PMI defines honesty as "Duty to understand the truth and act in a truthful
manner both in our communication and in our conduct."
Project managers should be honest and truthful to the team.
In this video, you learned: The primary responsibilities of a project
manager when monitoring communications.
Ten meeting rules for effective meetings.
PMI's best virtual communication practices.
And, PMI's four values to drive communication.

Expert Viewpoints: Monitoring and 
Controlling Communications

Welcome to Expert Viewpoints: Monitoring and Controlling Communications.
In this video, we will hear from project managers discussing monitoring and controlling 
communications.
I could probably spend hours on this particular subject, but I'm going to narrow it down
to two key tips.
Tip number one: know your audience.
Not everybody is the same.
Different people have different communication styles.
You, as a project manager, need to understand what that communication style is, how people
are most comfortable communicating, and, whenever possible, try to adapt your style to fit the
needs of the audience.
In addition, adjust your media.
What is the definition of insanity?
You've probably heard this before.
It's doing the same thing over and over again and getting the same unsatisfactory
or poor results.
So, here's a case in point.
Say you send out three emails, and the stakeholder does not respond.
Don't send out that 4th email.
Try a different media to go ahead and reach them.
To ensure the quality of communication remains constant throughout a project, it's important
to establish what cadence of communication you're going to have at the beginning of
the project, whether that means scheduling daily stand-ups, weekly check-ins, larger
check-in meetings after having weekly check-ins.
It is up to you and the rest of the project stakeholders, but it's important to ultimately
establish what that cadence is going to be and stick through it and then in order to
make sure that that cadence is stuck through, it's helpful to have those reoccurring meetings
set from the beginning.
Just put it on the Google Calendar so that are recurring meeting time and it's there
and then with that, I also like to include writing meeting notes, so I use Google Docs,
and within that I'd like to have all of our meeting notes in there for every single
time that we meet with our vendors and stakeholders.
So we have a record of what we've discussed and then it also gives us a good template
to follow through for the rest of our meetings.
It's also really helpful to have weekly email check-ins as well.
I find.
It's good to send and end of the week recap that just runs through what the accomplishments
are, what any blockers are.
If there are any blockers, what are we doing to solve for those blockers and also, call
out if there's any piece of the project that needs to be escalated.
When you have a communication plan, it can be very easy to let that communication plan
slip as a project is, you know, well underway.
And people are doing their jobs and they get a sense of what's happening.
You might find yourself, particularly over a couple of milestones in a project repeating
the same information.
I'm going to send out the status report.
Nothing has really changed because our milestones are a couple of weeks out.
So we're having the same, essentially the same, information over and over again, and
that can get a little tedious, but what it does do, I think, is build discipline.
So, if you have a plan, I'm going to send out status twice a week.
You send.
You should send out status twice a week if you are going to do a daily recap of the day's
work.
Do a daily recap of the day's work and just be disciplined about it, and sometimes if
the information hasn't changed that much, you can copy and paste from the last status
report and then just make minor modifications as needed.
The other technique that I found that really helps is that as soon as I send out a status
report, I start the next one.
So I'll create a template if it's a Word document or even if it's a message you know
something in a message board.
I'll start something in a notepad in, a digital notepad, and I'll start my next
status report.
And as things change in that, whatever that cadence is for your communication.
As things change, I write them down, and then by the time it's, you know that the the
moment comes to send out the next status report, you've essentially created it because you've
been doing it over the course of a few days.
To make sure that everything is consistent with communication throughout a project, it's
great to already have processes in place.
This is where your PMO organization is super helpful for you.
First off, if you already have pre-planned out templates on what your status reports
will look like, your weekly reports, whatever it might be, or even presentations.
That way, everyone already knows what they're expecting.
When you have that expectation, they're able to easily reference it for a future,
and they know it's coming.
Be timely about your communications as well.
If I'm using data as part of my communications, I like to always make sure that I'm pulling
that data from the same place so that week after week, my data points don't look different.
I'm not reporting on man hours one week and team hours another week, or I'm not
reporting on number of tasks done versus number of project objectives met.
I'm always constantly communicating the same data and the same information to the
stakeholders.
So again, they know what to expect.
They know what to look for.
They can think through what questions that they want to ask.
And it just helps keep the quality of the communications consistent.
The stakeholder register and communications management plan.
As the project evolves, things are going to change.
Stakeholders are going to come, and they're going to go ahead and go.
The different communication requirements early in the project are going to change as the
project progresses.
Stay abreast of those changes, update your stakeholder register, update your communications
management plan, and make sure that all of the key stakeholders are aware of those adjustments
and updates.
In addition, people are people.
Sometimes, personal issues are going to occur.
As a project management manager, going back to MBWAT: management by walking and talking,
you need to get out and meet people.
If there is an issue, chances are pretty good that issue is not going to come to you.
Sometimes you have to go out and find it.
And in addition, if you suspect that there are going to be some personnel issues some
resource challenges, have a backup plan.
Do your best to go ahead and support your people, but also have a backup plan just in
case to go ahead and support your project.
Number one is a lack of commitment.
This is a huge risk.
You need to take time to determine the required levels of commitment from each particular
stakeholder and then determine a strategy to go ahead and get them to where they may
need to be.
There may be some stakeholders that only require support.
There may be others who need to be leading.
You need to identify what that level of commitment is, and those strategies that you employ need
to be effective in moving them in that right direction.
Number two: poor collaboration.
Again, develop that stakeholder register, develop that communications management plan.
Make sure that all of the key stakeholders understand their roles and responsibilities
and commit to these roles and responsibilities before you finalize that particular document.
[08:37] Make sure that they understand it.
And make sure that they're ready to go ahead and commit and follow through so that you
can meet the goals of the project, you can meet your needs, and you can meet their needs
as well.
I think it's worth saying that you don't want to do too much in a communication plan
because if you are going to remain consistent, the more you overburden your communications,
the more difficult it is going to be to do it regularly and consistently.
The more you overburden your communications, the more difficult it's going to be to do
regularly and consistently.
So if your communication plan always involves taking a number of screenshots or filling
out a spreadsheet and creating a Word doc and you're trying to do that multiple times
a week or even once a week.
The more friction that you put in front of yourself for your communication plan, the
less you're going to be inclined to do it.
So I would say, you know, you can also mitigate risk by keeping your plan fairly simple, fairly
succinct, and concise, and that will also help you remain consistent so that it's
easy to do if you can template things, whether it be a document or a slack message, or even
a spreadsheet.
Keep it templatized, and then you'll just easily fill in those lines in a spreadsheet
or fill in that template in a document.
To make sure communication is effective, it must be clear.
Unclear messages just cause miscommunication from there.
Also, we have a lack of transparency.
Give a responsible, reasonable timeline.
If you're saying it's going to be done next week, and it's really going to be done
about a month from now because there's potential risks that are involved, do not say it's
going to be next week just to make your boss happy.
Lack of responsiveness.
This is a huge one.
Communication has to be an open door, and it also has to be done timely.


Module 2 Summary and Highlights: 
Information Sharing: Communications
Congratulations! You have completed this module. At this point in the course, you know:
•	The basic communications model stresses the importance of ensuring that the project team 
receives messages as intended and introduces the concept of communication blockers, which 
are factors that can obstruct effective communication. It is crucial to identify these blockers 
before they impact the team. The Project Management Institute (PMI) also identifies 
technology factors the project manager should analyze and plan for, as these factors can 
affect communications. Finally, the project manager should consider different 
communication needs, such as pull, push, and interactive communications, when planning 
for effective communication in each project.
•	Communications planning emphasizes the significance of effective communications in 
achieving project success. You now know the three-step approach to managing 
communications and reviewing communications management planning techniques. The PMI 
states that communications are 90% the project manager's responsibility and should be a 
central focal point as you plan and execute a project. Every project should have a 
communications management plan, as a lack of communications planning will likely result 
in random and ineffective communications. The communications management plan should 
contain key communication activities crucial for project success.
•	How to implement a communications management plan. You now know the essential 
communication methods, challenges, and skills a project manager should possess. The PMI 
states communication is the most difficult interpersonal skill to perfect, so you should hone 
your skills whenever possible.
•	The key tools and techniques essential to effective communication include active listening, 
conflict management, and how political awareness is vital when sharing information.
•	Communications monitoring responsibilities include effective meeting management 
techniques, best practices in virtual communications, and how the PMI Code of Ethics 
impacts effective communications.

Identify Stakeholders

Welcome to "Identify Stakeholders."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Identify potential questions from a stakeholder perspective at the time of the project proposal.
Summarize the purpose of a stakeholder register.
Explain the structure of a stakeholder register.
Describe the key tools and techniques used to identify stakeholders.
And, explain the steps to effectively identify stakeholders and gain commitment.
After the initial project proposal phase, there are four questions on the minds of stakeholders.
These questions need to be answered in a logical order to move forward with the project.
Questions one and two are basic including, "What is the project?" and "Why does
the project matter?"
The project stakeholder can find answers to these questions in the project charter.
Question three is, "Who are the stakeholders?"
Stakeholders include customers, end-users, sponsor, team, subject matter experts (SMEs),
and so on.
A project stakeholder can find answers related to stakeholders in stakeholder register.
The final question is "How will we execute the project?"
A detailed response to this question can be found in the project plan that a project manager
creates during the planning phase.
Let's now understand the purpose of the stakeholder register.
A stakeholder register is a critical project document that includes stakeholder details,
such as name, role, areas of expertise, and so on.
The stakeholder register forms an input into various project activities including project
planning, communications, and project governance.
A project manager must create a stakeholder register at project initiation in conjunction
with the project charter.
When the sponsor and senior management approve the project charter, the project manager 
also finalizes the stakeholder register.
The project charter and stakeholder register enable the project manager to start with the
project planning phase.
Most project managers develop a stakeholder register using Microsoft Excel or Word and
can be in tabular format.
The stakeholder register captures several key pieces of information.
Let's review the required information.
Identify each stakeholder by name.
There might be times when the project manager may not know the name of the stakeholder.
For example, if the project manager has not been able to identify and assign a SME to
the project, leave the name blank.
Specify the organization name which is important when multiple organizations, including 
contracting
agencies, participate in the project.
Note, you can ignore this detail for small projects with one organization.
Provide a brief description of the role that the stakeholder plays in the project.
List the responsibilities using RACI designators.
Let's review the designators.
R indicates Responsible.
The stakeholder will take the responsibility of completing the specified project work or
tasks.
A represents Accountable.
The stakeholder will be held accountable for certain work on the project.
Accountable implies that the stakeholder needs to ensure the work is accomplished, though
they may not necessarily perform the work.
C indicates Consult.
The stakeholder must be available to provide expertise and guidance.
And I indicates Inform.
The stakeholder will be informed about the specified work as the project progresses.
And the final key piece of information on the stakeholder register is Comments.
Document additional information, references, or clarification, which are helpful to the
project.
There are a number of tools and techniques used to identify stakeholders.
Here are a few recommended by the Project Management Institute, or PMI.
Expert judgment is a technique where the project manager consults with experts who can 
share the stakeholder requirements for the project.
Identification meetings are another technique. Invite all stakeholders that might be impacted by or 
interested in the project. Strive to have a representative for each stakeholder group.
Stakeholder mapping is a technique to identify stakeholders based on their relative power
and interest in the project.
The stakeholder mapping technique places each stakeholder into one of four quadrants and
provides management guidance for each.
Note, if you plan to attempt the CAPM exam, you must know this model.
Document analysis is another PMI recommended technique.
Review initial project documents, such as business case, contracts, and Service Level
Agreements. You will discover stakeholders in these documents.
PMI recommends using brainstorming as a technique to identify stakeholders.
Use brainstorming to pose a question and facilitate the free flow of ideas.
We discussed the tools and techniques that PMI recommends for identifying stakeholders.
Let's now review the steps to develop and communicate the stakeholder register to all
stakeholders.
The first step is to determine stakeholders by using PMI recommended tools and techniques.
Next, complete the initial stakeholder register.
Document the key components, such as name, organization, and role.
Then, analyze each role in terms of responsibilities using RACI designators.
Some stakeholders may have a single responsibility, such as "R" or "C" while other stakeholders
may have multiple responsibilities, such as "RC"
The next step is to have the "meeting before the meeting."
Collaborate with each stakeholder to determine if they can satisfy the role and responsibilities
assigned.
Document any issues, such as limited capacity, in the Comments section.
After documenting the details, share the stakeholder register with the sponsor.
Make sure to get confirmation from the sponsor on the stakeholder details before moving to
the planning phase.
If what, why, and who questions are answered, and the project remains feasible, move to
the planning phase.
In this video, you learned that: Questions asked after project proposal include:
"What is the project?"
"Why does this project matter?"
"Who are the stakeholders?"
And, "How will we execute the project?"
The purpose of a stakeholder register is to capture stakeholder information.
The stakeholder register captures several key stakeholder details including name, 
organization,
role, responsibility, and comments.
Responsibility is captured using RACI designators: Responsible
Accountable Consult
And Inform PMI recommends using various tools and techniques
to identify stakeholders including: Expert judgement
Identification meetings Stakeholder mapping
Document analysis And Brainstorming
And finally, follow the recommended process to develop and communicate the stakeholder
register.
Plan Stakeholder Engagement

Welcome to "Plan Stakeholder Engagement."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Summarize the purpose of a stakeholder engagement plan.
Explain the structure of a stakeholder engagement plan.
Describe key strategies to receive desired stakeholder commitment.
And explain why a stakeholder engagement plan is a close-hold plan.
Planning stakeholder engagement is essential for project success.
The stakeholder engagement plan documents current and desired levels of engagement for
key stakeholders identified in the stakeholder register.
In addition to engagement levels, the stakeholder engagement plan outlines strategies to help
sustain positive levels and move other stakeholders to expected levels.
Project managers develop a stakeholder engagement plan using Microsoft Excel, Microsoft Word,
or Microsoft PowerPoint.
A stakeholder engagement plan should be in tabular format, and captures key information,
like the following.
A key entry is the stakeholder name or position.
Remember that not all stakeholders on the stakeholder register need to be annotated
in the stakeholder engagement plan.
The stakeholder engagement plan targets critical stakeholders who are generally external or
not directly associated with project planning.
Another key piece of information is the current level of commitment.
The Project Management Institute, or PMI, provides recommended commitment levels.
Five commitment levels include Unaware, Resistant, Neutral, Supportive, and Leading, as 
documented in the Stakeholder Engagement Assessment Matrix tool from PMI.
The project manager maps the current commitment levels of key stakeholders in each phase 
of the project management lifecycle.
For example, if the stakeholder is not open to committing to the project work, map them
to commitment level, Resistant.
Or if a stakeholder must influence others to commit, map the stakeholder to commitment
level, Supporting.
Also include the desired commitment level from the stakeholder to support project objectives.
Finally add strategies to sustain or achieve desired levels of commitment in the stakeholder 
engagement plan.
Now, let's look at some strategies recommended by PMI to engage stakeholders and gain 
commitment.
Influencing is a critical interpersonal skill to engage stakeholders.
For example, if a project manager is able to influence a resistant stakeholder with
project values, there is a greater possibility of that stakeholder becoming supportive.
Engage stakeholders early.
The project manager should engage with stakeholders as soon as the stakeholder register is 
approved.
Late identification often leads to frustration, anger, or lost support.
Another strategy is to share and discuss the project charter with stakeholders.
Ensure all key stakeholders review the project charter.
When stakeholders understand project objectives and value, commitment often increases.
Asking questions is another strategy.
Ask relevant questions and try to understand the perspective of other stakeholders.
Use active listening skills.
Some inputs may be valuable, while others may not.
Be open to suggestions and improvements.
Getting stakeholders to collaborate is another good strategy.
Collaboration helps address issues as early as possible.
For example, capacity issues may be discovered through a simple conversation or meeting,
Integrity is another strong strategy.
Lead with integrity.
Commitment may follow.
For example, if you set a positive example, others may follow.
Include stakeholders in planning.
Share scope, schedule, and budget recommendations before the project management plan is 
presented.
Keep people informed and avoid surprises.
Surprises can lower commitment levels.
Build the team.
An effective project manager works with the team to identify issues and lagging commitment
levels.
For example, a team member will disclose more in a simple conversation than in numerous
e-mails.
Manage expectations.
Clearly defined roles and responsibilities and well-defined and value-added project objectives
go a long way to help gain commitment.
Look for triggers early that may lead to lowered commitment.
Rewards matter.
Recognize stakeholders who perform at a high level.
If your budget is limited, at minimum, say "Thank You."
And finally, communicate effectively.
Remember, communication is 90% of a project manager's job.
Effective communication is often the difference between sustained or lost commitment.
The stakeholder engagement plan is a unique document that must be accomplished.
At the same time, the stakeholder engagement plan is only shared with select stakeholders.
Why only select stakeholders?
The answer is that many stakeholders might take offence if they are publicly documented
as resistant or neutral.
Hard feelings can develop, and bridges may be burned that can never be repaired.
The stakeholder engagement plan, therefore, needs to be close-hold and only used by the
project manager and core project team.
In this video, you learned that: The stakeholder engagement plan contains key
stakeholder engagement details including current and desired commitment levels and 
engagement strategies for key stakeholders.
The stakeholder engagement plan can be in tabular format using Microsoft Excel, Word,
or PowerPoint Strategies for engagement include:
Influencing Direct impact on stakeholders
Engage early Share and discuss
Ask questions Collaborate
Integrity Involvement
Build a team Manage expectations
Rewards Effective communication
The stakeholder engagement plan is a close-hold document and is only shared with select 
stakeholders.


Manage Stakeholder Engagement
This article will teach you the importance of managing stakeholders and why stakeholder 
commitment levels may be low.
The importance of effectively managing stakeholders
The Project Management Institute (PMI) identifies critical success factors that underscore the 
importance of effective stakeholder management.
•	Defining roles and responsibilities and sharing and confirming expectations with the 
stakeholders as early as possible in the project is critical. The earlier you onboard and set 
expectations with stakeholders, the more effectively they will perform.
•	Sharing the project's values and benefits with stakeholders can help overcome 
resistance and encourage project commitment. It would be best if you showed how the 
project would benefit the individual stakeholders and the organization.
•	Planning effective meetings to collaborate and lead brainstorming, focus groups, 
problem-solving, decision-making, and other key communications. Meetings should 
achieve value-driven outcomes and be purposeful for all attendees.
•	Using the most appropriate communication channels to conduct stakeholder 
communications. Try to use channels that accommodate the needs of the audience.
•	Practicing active listening to understand stakeholder perspectives and motivational 
factors better.
•	Understanding different stakeholders have distinct communications. Adapt your 
communications approach to meet stakeholder needs whenever possible.
Reasons why stakeholder commitment levels are low
There are a few pitfalls to avoid that may reduce project stakeholders' commitment levels:
•	Failure to identify stakeholders early in the project. Project managers must understand 
the importance of all stakeholders and the role each stakeholder plays in the project. Work as 
a team to identify all key stakeholders and engage with them as early as possible.
•	Not meeting the stakeholder's needs and expectations. Communication is a two-way 
street. A project manager should set expectations. However, the project manager must also 
understand and meet the expectations of stakeholders as well. Communicate the project's 
purpose, be transparent, and accept accountability for your actions. Ensure stakeholders do 
not feel ignored.
•	Failure to acknowledge stakeholders' powers and interests and underestimating their 
influence and impact. Avoid a one-size-fits-all engagement methodology. Treat each 
stakeholder as unique and use a situational engagement strategy.
•	Inadequate issues management. Project managers define issues at the stakeholder level as 
problems, blockers, or questions impacting the successful completion of commitments. A 
project manager must proactively identify issues before they drastically impact the project.
•	Poor communication leads to misinformation and uncertainty. When the message sent is 
not the message the stakeholder receives, it can damage the relationship and jeopardize 
project success.

Monitor Stakeholder Engagement

Welcome to "Monitor Stakeholder Engagement and Ground Rules."

After watching this video, you will be able to:
Summarize methods to maintain stakeholder support,
Describe the Tuckman Ladder and situational leadership model,
And recognize key motivation theories to shape stakeholder engagement strategies.
Maintaining stakeholder support and commitment through the planning and execution of a project
can be difficult.
The project manager should always collaborate effectively to keep stakeholders moving in
a positive direction.
A project manager must be able to organize the project, be an effective communicator,
be a positive influencer, and be accessible to the team and stakeholders.
In 1965 Bruce Tuckman developed the Tuckman Ladder and this ladder shares a four-step
process for team development.
Then, Paul Hersey and Ken Blanchard developed the Situational Leadership Model in 1982.
And this model shares strategies to gain commitment and support depending on an 
individual's readiness state.
We combine these two models to adopt a successful approach to building a team.
When a team first comes together, productivity is low and it takes time to move the team
to a state where productivity is high.
Let's look at the stages the team moves through and how the project manager can guide the
team to success.
First, the team comes together in the form stage of the Tuckman Ladder.
Project managers should use a tell strategy (of the Situational Leadership Model) by telling
the team what the project is, why it's important, and explaining the roles and responsibilities
of each team member.
Next, In the storm stage of the ladder, team members may begin to have doubts and feel
the project is not a good fit for them.
They may have reservations about their skills, roles, and responsibilities and questions
about the project itself.
Productivity is low during the storm stage.
Here, a project manager should employ a sell strategy of the Situational Leadership Model
by selling the team on the project and selling the team on themselves.
By addressing areas of doubt, answering questions, and assuring team members that they 
have value and belong, a team can weather the storm stage.
In the norm stage of the ladder, the team begins to focus on project work, and productivity 
increases.
Now the team may still have questions and some reservations.
The project manager should cease using the telling and selling strategies and switch
to a participate strategy by being available, accessible, and ready to support the team.
Finally, productivity peaks in the perform stage of the ladder.
The team can now self-organize and self-direct themselves.
The project manager should use a delegate strategy and allow the team to work independently
and self-correct.
If an issue occurs, the project manager can repeat any of the rungs on the Tuckman Ladder.
The Project Management Institute (or PMI) shares four motivational theories that a project
manager should understand and leverage to motivate their team.
The first of the four motivational theories is the Expectancy Theory.
The team evaluates the work depending on the level of effort it will require to accomplish it.
If the potential reward justifies the level of effort, the team member performs at a high
level.
However, if the reward does not justify the level of effort, the team member's performance
may not be adequate.
The second theory is the Hertzberg Hygiene and Motivational Factors theory.
This theory was developed by Frederick Hertzberg, who categorizes motivation as hygiene and
motivational factors.
Hygiene factors, such as company policies, salary, and the work environment, decrease
motivation if they are absent.
Motivational factors, such as achievement, growth, and advancement opportunities, increase
motivation when they are present.
Now, the third theory is Intrinsic versus Extrinsic Motivation.
Daniel Pink developed this theory in which he categorizes motivational factors as being
either extrinsic or intrinsic.
Extrinsic motivators are short-term and diminish over time, such as salary.
Intrinsic motivators are broken into three categories:
Autonomy, which is the desire to direct one's own life,
Mastery which is the ability to improve, learn, and excel,
And purpose, which is the need and desire to make a difference.
And the fourth theory is the Theory of Needs.
David McClelland states that people are generally motivated by three needs: achievement, power,
and affiliation.
The strength of these three needs in an individual varies depending on the individual's experiences,
values, and culture.
In this video, you learned that: A project manager must be able to organize
the project, be an effective communicator, be a positive influencer, and be accessible
to the team and stakeholders.
The Tuckman Ladder Model states that teams move through the form, storm, norm, and 
perform stages.
A project manager employs the Situational Leadership Model - tell, sell, participate,
and delegate strategies through each ladder stage to keep their team on task.
The four motivational theories are:
1-The Expectancy Theory,
2-The Hertzberg Hygiene and Motivational Factors Theory,
3-The Intrinsic versus Extrinsic Motivation Theory
4-The Theory of Needs.

Expert Viewpoints: Ground Rules and Norms

Welcome to Expert Viewpoints: Ground Rules and Norms.

In this video, we will hear from Project Managers discussing Ground Rules and Norms. They 
explain when using ground rules is most beneficial, examples of successful implementation of 
ground rules and norms, and advice for when stakeholders fail to follow ground rules and norms.
Well, the Project Management Institute came up with a tool called a team charter. And within
this team charter, they define six different areas where ground rules and norms are probably
quite important. I want to go ahead and pick the two that I think are really important.
Number one, meeting norms. Let's be honest. Meetings are a huge time waster.
Try to get with your team and determine what are norms and ground rules that will ensure that
your team applies effective meeting management.Here's a couple of quick examples.
Number one, publish an agenda. A meeting without an agenda is like a journey without a road 
map. And publish the minutes. Ensure there is a record of discussions and action items. Without 
minutes,
you may very well encounter a term that I like to refer to as "selective amnesia."
What does "selective amnesia" mean? It means that the next day the individual who made
commitments at the meeting has no understanding or remembrance of the commitments that they 
made.
I want to go ahead and close out meeting ground rules with a rule that I was informed of that I
really think is good. It's the rule of 48/24. Get the agenda out 48 hours ahead of time. Why
48 hours? It gives people enough time to go ahead and do the pre-work and to try
to understand what this meeting is all about. And get the minutes out within 24 hours of the
end of the meeting to avoid that "selective amnesia" that I just shared a moment ago.
The second area: team values. I like to refer to team values sometimes as the elephant in the room.
Ensure you treat each other with respect, and here's the key. Respect may mean
different things to different people. When you're determining what those ground rules and norms 
are, define what respect means to the team. What does it mean to the group? Come up with a 
standard definition that everyone can agree upon.
Avoid hurtful and derogatory language. Some people may think they're very funny, but 
sometimes language can be very, very painful. Try to determine what those boundaries are and 
where you 'don't want to cross those particular boundaries.
Be inclusive and treat everyone equitably. And embrace diversity, 'don't fight it.
These are very important ground rules, meetings, and team values that I think
if you hammer out and everyone can come up with an agreement on the team, I think you'll
progress very, very well through the project. Whenever I start a project, I like to really
make sure to set the expectations and to be clear at the very beginning and to prevent any ambiguity 
34 00:03:22,980 --&gt; 00:03:28,980 so I will typically go ahead and have one-on-ones with each 
individual. Preset expectations, especially with communication and then redo that again as a whole 
team just to make sure everybody understands and gives them the opportunity for Q and A as well.
Well, I mentioned that team charter document just a couple of minutes ago.
A team charter is a document that defines ground rules and norms in six key areas. So now, I'll
give you the Project Management Institute's six areas. Those six areas that you want to consider
having ground rules and norms in are, 1-team values, which we talked about a second ago.
2-Communications guidelines. What's an example of that? Perhaps for emails, if it is urgent, we 
will
put "Urgent" in the subject line, and everyone will agree to get back within 24 hours.
3-Decision making process and criteria. How are decisions going to be made?
Is there a process and how can you be inclusive in that particular process?
4-Conflict resolution process. Conflict means people have a different idea,
different thoughts, different opinions. When that occurs, how do we resolve them?
We talked just a minute ago about 5-meeting guidelines. Definitely,
that rule of 48/24 is one of my favorites.
And 6-team agreements. What do we agree to do in terms of supporting each other?

Sometimes we'll have stakeholders who say, "Yeah, yeah, I'll do it" or "I totally agree
with everything" and all of a sudden you see that they're not really participating
or they're not agreeing to your ground rules.What you need to do first is have a one-on-one
with them reset those expectations and to find out why they're not agreeing to it or
what is going on. Is there something else in the background? For example, they don't have
enough training or something like that.Find out the why, in addition to resetting
those expectations. If that doesn't work out. And you have taken the time to really
push those ground rules and make sure that they understand they have all the training.
Then you need to go to management. Sometimes you actually do need to escalate as well.

Management

•	The stakeholder register is a guide for critical communications which the project 
manager creates in conjunction with the project charter during the initiation phase of

•	The purpose of the stakeholder engagement plan is to list key stakeholders in the 
stakeholder register. We reviewed key strategies to attain desired levels of stakeholder 
engagement. The stakeholder engagement plan is a close-hold plan; all stakeholders 
are different. The project manager should analyze each stakeholder to determine their 
motivations and adapt strategies to each.
•	The importance of effectively managing stakeholders and why project managers may reduce 
levels of stakeholder commitment. 
•	The benefits of setting ground rules and norms can eliminate many issues in the long term. 
We introduced a team charter concept.
•	Methods for a project manager to maintain stakeholder support throughout the project and 
how to strategize with the team via the Tuckman Ladder model. You reviewed motivation 
theories that can help shake stakeholder engagement strategies.
