Project Risk Management Overview

Welcome to "Project Risk Management Overview."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Identify the need for effective project risk management.
Describe the steps in the project risk management lifecycle.
List five primary reasons that lead to project failure.
And explain key project risk management roles and their responsibilities.
Risk is any event that can impact a project.
For example, miscommunication among team members might introduce a project delay.
Recent productive project management statistics reveal that over 50% of projects fail.
A prominent reason for project failure is allowing risk to manage you rather than you
managing the risk.
The project manager and team must be aware of impacts on the project.
Now, every project has a level of uncertainty.
These uncertainties can lead to five primary reasons that may cause a project to fail.
They include: failure to achieve an on-time product or service
delivery, cost overruns that negate project value,
inability to achieve project objectives developed when the project was approved,
failure to satisfy requirements as stated by customers and key stakeholders, and
delivering products or services with little or no value at project end.
The Project Management Institute, or (r) PMI, states, "an effective risk management program
can increase chances of a successful project by 90%."
PMI shares a five-step approach, or lifecycle, to manage project risk:
Plan Risk, Identify Risk, Analyze, Respond, and Control.
In this approach, the first step is
1-Plan Risk. In this step, the project manager creates a Risk Management Plan.
This plan provides an overview of how risk management will be accomplished for the project.
Note, that another video covers the Risk Management Plan in detail.
The next step is 2-Identify Risk. The project manager and team develop a "risk register."
The risk register documents all risks identified using a method called risk metalanguage.
Risk metalanguage provides a three-part structured description of a risk, which includes 
cause, risk, and effect.
Again, a different video covers risk metalanguage in more detail.
The third step in the project risk management lifecycle is 3-Analyse.
Each risk must be analysed in a qualitative and quantitative manner.
Analysis is essential as all risks do not have a similar impact potential.
After Analyse comes 4-Respond.
The project manager and team develop risk responses.
Some responses may be implemented before a risk occurs, while others may be implemented
after the fact.
Finally, 5-Control.
Risks must be continually reviewed and controlled through project end.
Remember, risk is not a one-time occurrence.
Successful project risk management depends on establishing a team.
This team should be comprised of different roles, including a project manager, risk owner,
sponsor, and subject matter expert or SME.
Let's look at responsibilities for each role.
The project manager must be part of the risk management team.
The project manager is responsible for managing project risk management program activities
including planning, implementing, monitoring, and controlling.
The risk owner is responsible for managing an identified risk.
A risk owner analyses the risk, determines risk priority, develops and manages responses,
and monitors and controls the risk.
A sponsor approves the risk management plan for the project.
A sponsor also approves, designates, and authorizes reserves.
Reserves refer to the contingency funds that may be used if a risk response requires funding.
The SME is a stakeholder who can be consulted for any technical aspects of a risk.
In this video, you learned that: Effective risk management can help with preventing
project failure.
Five reasons a project may fail include failure to meet schedule, cost overruns, inability
to achieve objectives, failure to satisfy requirements, and delivering little or no value.
The five steps in the project risk management lifecycle include Plan Risk, Identify Risk,
Analyze, Respond, and Control.
A project risk management team should include a project manager, risk owner, sponsor, and 
SME.

Risk Defined

Welcome to "Risk Defined."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Describe key takeaways from PMI's Uncertainty Performance Domain.
Explain risk categories.
Describe risk types.
And define the term "issue."
As discussed in another video, risk is defined as "any potential event that can impact
a project positively or negatively."
For example, every person on the project uses a computer.
There is a possibility that some computers may not have all the required software loaded.
This will limit accessibility.
This is a risk, a potential event.
PMI added the Uncertainty Performance Domain in the Project Management Body of 
Knowledge (r) (PMBOK) to address activities and functions associated with risk and uncertainty.
Here are some key takeaways.
The current business environment is filled with uncertainty.
Technical, social, political, market and economic events can impact a project.
A project manager and team must proactively identify potential events that can impact
a project and plan accordingly.
There are multiple variables in a project.
Every action you take may have an impact on different aspects of the project.
You must identify cause-and-effect variables for every aspect.
All risks are not equal.
Some risks have greater potential than others to impact the project.
Constant analysis and prioritization are key.
Conditions impacting a project will likely change.
Effective risk management is critical from project beginning to end.
Remember, effective risk management identifies BOTH positive and negative events.
And risk can impact both schedules and budget.
Closely monitor the plan, schedule, and budget reserve.
Based on their impact on the project, we can broadly categorize risks into threats and
opportunities.
A risk with a negative impact is referred to as a threat.
When a threat occurs, it can have a negative impact on scope, schedule, and budget.
The project manager and team need to identify and plan for potential threats to ensure minimal
impact on the project.
When a risk has a positive impact, it is called an "opportunity."
There may be potential events that can lead to positive impacts, such as the ability to
add product functionality, accelerate schedules, or cost savings.
Effective risk management looks for potential opportunities to improve project performance.
Risks can be divided into two types, known and unknown.
"Known risks" are risks the project management team and stakeholders have identified.
If a threat or an opportunity has been identified by the team, it will be a known risk.
"Unknown risks" are those yet to be identified.
Any unidentified threat or opportunity is an "unknown risk."
A key goal of project risk management is to identify as many risks as you can before they
occur. This includes both threats and opportunities.
The sooner you identify a risk and make it known, the sooner you can develop appropriate
responses to address it.
Managing risks is critical to the success of a project.
Risk management begins on Day 1 of the project.
Risks are identified and documented as Planning progresses and are initially identified during
the Project Charter development process.
Additional risks are identified during scope, schedule, and budget planning.
Support planning will also likely lead to additional risk identification.
Another video covers the end-to-end risk planning process and associated activities.
All identified risks must be added to a risk register.
The risk register is a document used to add and track risks.
The risk register also includes information, such as the likelihood of the risk occurring
and risk impact.
The risk register should be updated every time a risk is identified.
If a risk becomes an actual event, it is referred to as an "issue."
The project manager must keep track of issues in an issue log.
An issue log is a document containing a list of issues along with details required to track
the issue, such as issue description, current status, and priority.
Note that another video covers issue logs in detail.
In this video, you learned that: Risk is an inherent part of any project that
is impacted by many variables.
Project managers should identify positive and negative risks and prioritize how to handle
them based on their potential impact on budget and schedule.
Two categories of risk include: Threat, which has a negative impact on the
project, and Opportunity, which has a positive impact on
the project.
Two types of risk include: Known risks, which have been identified by
the project manager, and Unknown risks, which have not yet been identified.
And, if a risk becomes an actual event, it is called an issue.

Risk Metalanguage

Welcome to "Risk Metalanguage."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Explain the need for a risk metalanguage statement.
Identify parts of the risk metalanguage statement.
And describe parts of the risk metalanguage statement.
Documenting risks is mandatory.
The quality of the risk statement is equally important.
For example, consider the risk statement, "Weather is unpredictable."
This risk statement is ambiguous as it does not provide a clear view of why the unpredictability
is a risk or what will happen if the weather changes.
An ambiguous statement can be difficult to decipher.
This can result in a project manager taking an incorrect action to manage the risk.
Risk metalanguage is an industry best practice that helps with writing unambiguous and accurate 
risk statements.
The risk metalanguage breaks the risk statement into three parts: cause, event, and impact.
The Project Management Institute (PMI) does not define risk metalanguage by name.
However, PMI states that the initial risk entries in a Risk Register should include
risk cause and effect statements.
Part one of the risk metalanguage maps to cause.
Parts two and three constitute the effect and subsequent impact.
The metalanguage structure has three parts.
Let's understand each part in detail.
The first part of the structure is 1-"risk cause."
Risk cause is a situation or condition that exists.
"Bad weather" and "Good weather" are two examples of risk cause.
2-Event is the second part.
Event defines what can potentially occur due to the cause.
For example, bad weather could result in rain.
In this example, "rain" is the event.
Similarly, good weather may result in sunshine.
"Sunshine" is the event.
The last part of risk metalanguage is 3-impact.
Impact answers the question, "Why does the event matter?"
Using the weather example, the impact of rain may result in a delay in external work, and
schedules may slip.
The impact of sunshine, however, may allow the team to work longer and make up for any
lost time due to the rain.
Let's rewrite the statement, "Weather is unpredictable," in a way that it will
appear in the risk register.
In this video, you learned that: Ambiguous risk statements can result in confusion
and chaos.
Risk metalanguage provides a structure to develop risk statements.
Risk metalanguage breaks the risk statement into three parts:
Cause, which is a situation or condition that exists.
Event, which defines what can potentially occur due to the cause.
And impact, which provides a response to the question, "Why does the event matter?"

Demo: SWOT Analysis

Hello everyone, and welcome to a quick demonstration on a SWOT analysis.
SWOT stands for strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats.
A SWOT analysis is a very commonly used risk identification tool.
Let's begin with a quick definition of strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats.
Let's begin with strengths and opportunities.
A strength in SWOT refers to internally controlled features that are positive.
Opportunities in SWOT result from existing strengths and document external events that
may occur as a result.
Turning our attention to weaknesses and threats.
Weaknesses in SWOT refer to internally controlled factors that are negative.
And threats in SWOT result from existing weaknesses and document external events that may 
occur as a result.
Today, for this SWOT analysis demonstration, we're going to feature a process improvement
project.
A team gathered together and identified two strengths and associated opportunities and
two weaknesses and associated threats.
Let's take a look at what they identified.
The first strength that the team identified was a reliable supply chain.
Now you may be asking yourself, how is this an internal consideration?
You're the organization; you determine who is going to partner with you in the supply chain.
If the supply chain is satisfactory, you are empowered to go ahead and maintain these partnerships.
If the supply chain is not satisfactory, you are empowered to go ahead and change.
The second strength that was identified by the team was high customer satisfaction.
So, we had two strengths.
The next step was to take a look and determine: what are the external opportunities that may
result from these two strengths?
So, we take a look first of all at the reliable supply chain.
The teams determine that with this reliable supply chain, there was a high potential for
supplier willingness to adapt to any improvements and changes that were made.
The high customer satisfaction was analysed, and the team determined that based on this
high customer satisfaction, the customers may be willing to partner with us and hopefully
expedite the implementation of any improvements.
A win-win situation for the organization and the customer.
However, there were two weaknesses that were identified by the team as well.
The first weakness that was identified was there were many manual operations in the current
process, and the second was there was employee complacency.
Their employees had learned to live with a very ineffective and very inefficient process.
The next step was to evaluate the threats.
They took a look once again at many manual operations and determined that the primary
threat was limited improvement opportunities.
As a result of the manual operations, many of the improvement solutions may not be able
to be implemented.
And for employee complacency, they took a look and determined that there might be some
resistance to change.
They completed their SWOT analysis and then went to the next step.
They took their strengths and opportunities, weaknesses, and threats, and they completed
their risk register.
After they documented the information that they had attained during the SWOT analysis,
they defined the impact of each of the opportunities and impact of each of the threats.
They assigned probability and impact numbers to each opportunity and each threat and 
calculated a risk score.
This concludes our brief overview of SWOT analysis.
Hopefully, you have gained a better understanding of SWOT analysis, its purpose, and the 
methodology to go ahead and complete this analysis.
Thank you for your attention, and we look forward to seeing you in future demos.


The Risk Management Plan

Welcome to "The Risk Management Plan." After watching this video, you will be able to:
Define the purpose of a risk management plan.
And describe the different sections of a risk management plan.
A risk management plan describes how risk management activities will be structured and performed 
for the project.
The risk management plan provides instructions and a roadmap for how risk
management for a project will be conducted. After the risk management plan is approved,
it becomes part of the overall project management plan.
The risk management plan contains different sections.
These include:
1-Risk management team,
2-Definitions of probability and impact,
3-Probability and impact matrix,
4-Risk reassessment schedule,
5-Risk contingency reserves, and
6-Clarification and comments.

Let's look at each of these in detail.
The risk management plan should have details about the risk management team.
This list should includes responsibilities for different roles including,
project manager, risk owner, Subject matter experts (SME), and any other stakeholder 
involved in overall project risk management.
The risk management plan should also contain definitions for probability and impact ratings.
These ratings are used to score the project risks, which helps the project manager prioritize 
and monitor risks.
Note: PMI recommends using a simple Likert scale from 1-5.
Once definitions are complete, the project manager can determine the risk score by multiplying 
the probability score times the impact score. The higher the risk score, the more a risk
should be monitored. This table displays an example of probability and impact ratings.
Depending on the risk score, the project manager will need to take different actions.
To ensure a common structure is followed by all members of the project team, the project manager
must define the probability and impact matrix. This matrix contains the risk score
ranges along with associated actions. Here is a table displaying a sample matrix.
The project manager should also document the risk assessment schedule in the risk 
management plan.
As part of the schedule, document when project risks will be reviewed.
And include status meeting requirements, status reporting requirements, and management 
reporting requirements.
Detailed schedules should reflect in the project communications plan.
Another video covers the project communications plan in detail.
A risk management plan should contain the definition for contingency reserves
or funds required to respond to known risks. In addition, the risk management plan should
contain details about how reserves are maintained and distributed.
The risk management plan must share the amount of reserves available and the process to 
access them.
Note that in most cases, the project manager does not control contingency reserves or funds.
In addition to contingency reserves, a project should also have a management reserve.
Management reserves are funds set aside to support unknown risks, which can be caused due 
to various reasons, such as information gaps. The higher the project complexity,
the more management reserves should be set aside.
The risk management plan can also contain an optional section for clarifications and comments. 
This section can be used to provide references, policy, links, and so on that impact risk management 
planning.
The project manager can also reference a "risk breakdown structure," if available.
A risk breakdown structure is a list of potential risks that may impact projects broken out by 
category. The project manager can derive the risk breakdown structure by using the lessons 
learned on risks from other projects.
This table displays an example of the risk breakdown structure.

In this video, you learned that: A risk management plan describes
how risk management activities will be structured and performed for the project.
The risk management plan should contain the following sections:
Risk management team, which defines the risk management team and their roles.
Definitions of probability and impact, which defines probability and impact ratings to be applied 
to qualify all risks.
Probability and impact matrix, which determines the relative priority of all risks by risk score. 
Risk reassessment schedule to provide a schedule for risk reassessment and status 
analysis/reporting.
Risk contingency reserves that define reserves required to respond to risk, in addition to
how reserves are maintained and distributed.
And a clarification and comments section to
provide clarifying information, links, references, and so on as required.


Expert Viewpoints: Risk Planning

Welcome to Expert Viewpoints: Risk Planning.

In this video, we will hear from Project Managers discussing Risk Planning. They explain how they 
normally conduct risk planning, why risk management planning is necessary, how they plan for risk 
management, and tools and techniques that are critical to planning success. The best piece of advice 
that I can give you is three words: Make it real. Try to go ahead and share past lessons learned
where risks occurred that impacted the project negatively. In addition, try to share examples of 
opportunities that were lost. There's an old saying that an ounce of prevention is worth a pound of 
cure. If you can provide concrete examples of how risk impacted a project, then chances are pretty 
good that you may be able to catch those stakeholders' attention.
Pretty easy response: Begin on day number one of the project. As you're developing the project
charter, which defines what the project is, why it's important, and who needs to be involved,
do a brainstorming session with whatever stakeholders are available. What are those
potential risks to this particular project? The first thing that you want to do is to define
those potential risks in the project charter. Next, identify risks as you plan. Identification
of risks is a very iterative process. Once you get through the project charter, you're
going to begin planning scope, then you begin planning your schedule, you'll begin planning
your budget. As you complete each major planning section, make sure that you spend a little bit of
time before you move forward and ask yourself, "What were some risks that were identified?"
and continually add those to your risk register. The first thing people need to know about risk
management planning is why it's important, how it affects the organization, how it affects the
outcome of the project, and what the implications are for them personally by not doing this or not
doing it well enough. Therefore, you need to explain why we do risk management planning.
And if it's not supported by the organization, if it's not something that's
part of the process of running a project or implementing something new, development, then
people are really not going to understand why, and they're not going to be committed to doing it.
So, I think if people know personally how it affects them if their job, for example,
is an engineering and they know that the outcome of not planning for a risk could be a failure of
the product. Then they're going to have more incentive to pay attention and do this risk
planning. So, I think you need to make it part of the organizational process. It really needs
to be part of everything that we do whenever there's a project, whenever there is a new
product implemented, then it should be done across the board, across the organization. It
should be something that is part of the standard process. If management doesn't support it, then
nobody else will. So, if you really want to get people interested in doing this, you have to have
management support. You have to have a process and people you understand why it's important
When it comes to planning risk management and how you do it, you have to have the team
involved from day one. They have to be part of that process. They have to be there when
you're just brainstorming what the risks are, right? Because if you don't, then you're going
to either have to go back later on and do a bunch of reworks, or you're going to miss it altogether.
And then the risk occurs, it's triggered, and then you have no plan in place for mitigating
that risk or responding to it. The second thing is you have to have a quantitative system for
identifying the risks, and normally you want to look for things like detectability,
severity, likelihood, right? Because we want to know how. If it's going to happen,
we don't know how bad it's going to be, and we want to know if we can detect it at all.
And the other thing is you have to be diligent about auditing these. This risk management plan
and that involves having something which you may call a control plan, which is a formal plan that
lays out all of the risks and how you respond, who's responsible, you know when we do it by
there's a couple ways to do it, but normally you want to look at those things.
And if you don't have any of that, then you're going to know that you're going to have a problem,
And also, if you if you have a system of auditing in place periodically,
you can go in and evaluate whether our risk, uh, measures are still valid. If the everything need,
to be updated, right? Because these are living documents that we should be updating regularly.
I'm going to go ahead and share three of them very briefly. Number one is a risk management plan,
and in a future interview, we're going to delve a little bit deeper into this risk management
plan. But in essence, it's an overview of how overall risk management will be conducted. Have
a plan. Plan it before you do it. Secondly, the risk register. This is a very common tool; it
is a place where you list the risks. You begin by filling out the risks that you identify during the
project charter. As you plan scope, you add risks to this risk register or list. As you do schedule
and budget planning, you add risks. By the time you've completed all of your planning, you're
probably going to have a pretty long list of risks to go ahead and manage. And the risk register is
that primary document that you use to go ahead and document those risks. Last but not least, and
again, we'll go ahead and explain this a little bit more in a future interview. There's another
tool called a risk matrix. It's a very simple visual overview of the top risks that impact
the project. You want to use this risk matrix for stakeholder and leadership presentations.
And again, we'll talk to this a little bit more, but as they say, a picture is worth 1000 words.
Appreciate the opportunity to answer these first three questions, and I'll
see you again in the next risk-focused subject matter expert interview session.

Customer & Stakeholder Interaction
This article will teach you about project managers' challenges in implementing an effective risk 
program, risk appetite, risk thresholds, and how they impact risk planning.
Challenges project managers encounter in implementing an 
effective risk program
Project managers may encounter many challenges when managing an effective risk management 
program. The Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK) identifies the following 
challenges:
•	Uncertainty. The organization may not have a solid awareness of issues, events, paths to 
follow, or solutions to pursue. A project manager should understand the project and ensure 
there are Subject Matter Experts (SMEs) available to provide guidance.
•	Ambiguity. Risks can be unclear, and there are challenges in identifying event causes and 
determining response options. Ensure you enlist the support of risk owners and SMEs who 
are experts in their fields.
•	Complexity. Many manage programs and projects in various environments that are difficult 
to manage. The project manager and team must recognize human behaviours and 
motivation, system behaviours, and ambiguity as a team.
•	Volatility. The pace of change is rapid. A solid project risk management program is 
proactive - not reactive. It looks head and plans for change. It analyzes both current and 
future conditions.
•	Flexibility. Gather credible information and prepare for multiple outcomes. Explore various 
designs to respond to risk events. Be adaptive and resilient.
How risk appetite and risk thresholds impact risk planning
Risk appetite is "the degree of uncertainty an organization is willing to accept in anticipation 
of a reward." The project manager and team must know the organizational risk appetite and plan 
accordingly. For example, an organization may have rigid funding limits. In this case, the project 
manager must guard the budget, even at the expense of the scope and schedules. On the other hand, 
an organization may be willing to stretch budget limits to achieve a valued outcome. If this is the 
case, the project can accept more risk.
Risk thresholds are a "measure of acceptable variation around an objective that reflects the 
risk appetite of the organization or stakeholders." The Project Management Institute (PMI) is 
relatively rigid in assessing project success. For example, if a project budget is approved for 
$100,000 and the final costs are $100,001 - this is a failed project. The project manager establishes 
thresholds when budgets and/or schedules are approved. Using the budget example, if a more 
flexible threshold of plus or minus 5% had been approved, success would have been defined 
between $95,000 to $105,000. The project is a success.

Module 4 Summary and Highlights: 
Introduction to Project Risk Management
Congratulations! You have completed this module. At this point in the course, you know:
•	The need for an effective project risk management lifecycle and the roles and 
responsibilities essential to project risk management success.
•	The definition of risk and uncertainty in projects. We defined known versus unknown risks 
and the difference between risks and issues. The project manager should identify both 
opportunities and threats. Threats can impact the project baseline negatively, while 
opportunities can enhance project baseline performance. Effective risk management 
requires attention to both risk categories.
•	Model risk metalanguage to document risks and how to distinguish between a cause, 
event, and impact. Risk metalanguage tells a story, is easy to understand, and allows for 
actionable responses.
•	The purpose of SWOT analysis and how a project manager can use a SWOT analysis 
to identify opportunities and threats. SWOT is a proven method to identify risk causes 
and potential events and impacts that follow.
•	The purpose and contents of a risk management plan, and you can explain traditional 
ratings for probability and impact. You can describe contingency reserves and 
management reserves.
•	How to illustrate an example of a risk register and describe a risk trigger and a risk 
breakdown structure (RBS). We summarized qualitative risk analysis and explained the 
concept of risk exposure and risk score. The risk register is the primary tool project 
managers use to identify and manage risks by analysing each risk and understanding how it 
impacts the project.

Respond to Risk

Welcome to "Responding to Risk."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Identify risk response categories.
Describe responses to threats.
Explain responses to opportunities.
And describe responses to both threats and opportunities.
Every risk should have a response strategy.
The Project Management Institute (PMI) categorizes risk responses into eight distinct strategies,
including: Three strategies to respond to threats,
Three strategies to respond to opportunities, And two strategies that can respond to either
threats or opportunities.
Every risk owner should use these strategies when creating risk responses.
The response strategy you choose is tied to risk metalanguage.
Remember, "Every risk has a cause that leads to a potential event, which leads to a potential
impact."
Strategies are dependent upon whether or not the team can control the cause of the risk.
If the cause can be controlled, certain strategies are appropriate.
If not, other strategies are required.
There are three response strategies for negative risks or threats.
These include avoid, transfer, and mitigate.
Avoid a cause that can be controlled.
For example, the project manager, risk owner, or team can easily identify and control causes,
such as: An ineffective team member,
Lack of training, Or manual processes.
Transferring a risk to a third-party is another strategy to manage threats.
This strategy can be used when the project team does not have the required expertise.
Then the third-party will be accountable to manage the risk.
Examples could be: Life insurance,
or a contract SME.
The third strategy is to Mitigate.
The project manager will use the mitigation strategy if the team feels they do not have
any control over the cause.
If a threat is identified, look at ways to reduce the probability and impact of the risk
if it occurs.
Examples of mitigation as a strategy include: Planning indoor work in the event of rain,
and Developing workarounds to reduce the impact of new regulatory guidance.
We discussed the response strategies for threats.
Next, let's look at response strategies for opportunities.
There are three recommended strategies, including exploit, share, and enhance.
Exploit, or take advantage of, the cause that can be controlled.
For example, you may be able to leverage a motivated team member or a highly trained
team to improve the probability of high productivity.
Sharing an opportunity with a third-party is another strategy.
The third-party will be accountable for partnering with the project risk management team to achieve
an opportunity.
Examples where sharing the opportunity is beneficial could be:
Combining orders to receive a discount, or Sharing expertise to achieve a mutual goal.
There may be times when the project risk management team might not have any control over 
the risk cause.
In this case, the only responses are to increase the probability of the opportunity occurring,
increase the impact of the opportunity occurring, or increase both the probability and impact
of the opportunity occurring.
Let's look at some examples for responses.
Consider the scenario where the schedule is fixed and you have no control to change it.
In this case, you should look for ways to increase the probability of an early finish.
One such strategy is to provide incentives to accelerate the schedule.
Here's another situation.
The team composition has been decided and cannot be changed.
To increase the probability of high productivity, you can provide growth opportunities to increase
motivation.
Finally, response strategies that can be used for both threats and opportunities include
acceptance and escalation.
The acceptance strategy can be used in two scenarios.
The first scenario is where the risk probability and impact are low.
In this scenario, accept that the risk might occur.
If it occurs, respond.
The second scenario is where the risk probability and impact are not clear.
In this case, the project risk management team does not have a clear acceptable response
for a risk.
If probability and impact are low, this is not a large problem.
If probability and impact are high, the project may need to be reassessed.
The escalation strategy can be used when the project manager needs to gain high-level approval
for a response, normally from the sponsor.
The escalation strategy can be used if a response is either controversial or requires additional
funding or reserves.
In this video, you learned that: The Project Management Institute (PMI) categorizes
risk responses into eight distinct strategies, including:
Three strategies to respond to threats, Three strategies to respond to opportunities,
And two strategies that can respond to either threats or opportunities.
Three response strategies for threats include Avoiding risk when the cause can be controlled,
Transferring risk to a third-party when the team does not have the expertise, and
Mitigating when the cause cannot be controlled.
Three responses for opportunities include: Exploiting or taking advantage of the opportunity,
Sharing the opportunity, and Enhancing the impact of the opportunity.
And, two response strategies for threats and opportunities include acceptance and escalation.

Demo: Risk Report
Hello everyone.
I'd like to go ahead and take a few moments to walk through another key risk management
tool called the risk report.
We're going to go ahead and take a look at the template, review the instructions to complete
the risk report, and hopefully enable you to use this tool in your everyday risk management
efforts.
We always begin by defining the project name, the project manager, and the date.
The reason for this is that the risk report is going to be unique to your particular project.
Define the project purpose, a brief description of the project, and the purpose.
Why is this project in existence?
The next category that is recommended is to list the urgent risks.
Now, what do we mean by urgent?
On your risk register, you're going to have a number of risks.
Normally an urgent risk is one that scores probability times impact greater than sixteen.
Do not include every risk.
Embed a table, as you can see in this particular illustration.
List the risk by cause, event, and impact, the response, and the risk score.
The purpose of a risk report is not to provide status of every risk; it is to provide status
of the key risks or the urgent risks.
Remember that risks come in two categories: threats and opportunities.
Part of your risk management duties is to look for opportunities as much as identify
those threats.
The same rule applies.
List your opportunities by cause-event-impact, your proposed response, and the risk score.
Any new risks that were identified since the last report, and if there were a lot of risks
that were identified, remember the rule of urgency.
If it is probability times impact sixteen or greater, then you may want to list it.
You may want to list a risk by exception if you feel that this risk is pertinent, even
if it does not score sixteen or higher.
The next category recommended in a risk report is project risk exposure, and we will go ahead
and cover that a little bit later in this demonstration.
A key aspect of the risk report is help needed.
This risk report is not for your team; it's not for you.
This risk report is provided to your sponsor and other executive stakeholders.
And it is meant to provide a quick overview of how risk management is progressing for
the project.
But a key area is help needed.
Do you need additional contingency reserves, dollars in case of risk?
Do you need response approval for some of the responses that you are proposing?
Coming back to risk exposure, the definition of risk exposure: an aggregate measure of
the potential impact of all risks at a given point in a project.
A key note: a risk score for a threat is a positive number.
Risk scores for opportunities are subtracted.
So, let's say hypothetically; we had three risks.
Two were threats, and one was an opportunity.
The threat would be four times four or a risk score of sixteen.
The opportunity, potentially 3 x 3 = 9.
But we subtract this.
Why?
Because risk exposure is how much negative risk you are being exposed to.
If there is an opportunity and opportunity can mitigate the impact of negative risks
and reduce the overall risk exposure.
We have another one which is a threat of twelve.
So, if we add these up, our risk exposure is nineteen.
To summarize this demo, here is an overview of a project.
In week one, the risk score was sixty for all of the risks.
It dropped to fifty-eight.
On week number two, fifty-four.
On week number three.
But then it began climbing again from week number four.
Risk exposure shows how the overall risk score for all risks in the project is either increasing,
decreasing, or staying the same.
This is a great tool to determine how well your risk management program is working.
If the exposure is going down, then chances are quite good that you and your team are
doing a wonderful job mitigating the potential of risks or enhancing the opportunities that
are out there.
If the risk score is going up, that is a red flag that states we may have some problems.
Maybe we want to go ahead and review this project at greater depth.
Perhaps there are some risks that we may have missed, or perhaps some responses that we
need to go ahead and implement.
This concludes a quick overview of a risk report and, in addition, a brief explanation
of the risk exposure portion of this report.
We hope that you have a better understanding of the risk report, and we do hope that this
is something, a tool that you can use as you move forward.
Thank you very much for your attention.
Have a great day, and we look forward to seeing you again in future demos.


Risk Reassessment (Review)
	
Welcome to "Risk Reassessment."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Recognize the importance of timely risk response implementation.
Describe characteristics of risk audits, including audit objectives, frequency, and process.
Explain the difference between residual and secondary risks.
And describe the contents of an "issue log."
Any risk has the potential to become an issue and impact project success.
A negative risk may impact scope, schedules, and budget.
An opportunity may be lost.
Remember, a single risk occurrence may lead to project failure.
It is essential the project risk management team recognize and implement a response in
case a risk does occur.
The risk register needs to be regularly updated to include response strategies.
Risk scores might change.
Some risks may no longer be applicable.
Such risks must be removed from the risk register.
Risk reassessment includes risk register updates, risk audits, documenting secondary and 
residual risks, and managing issues logs.
Next, let's look at risk audits.
Risk audits are an integral part of overall project risk management.
Here are the objectives of a risk audit.
Review the overall project risk monitoring process and determine the overall effectiveness
of the risk management plan.
Review the effectiveness of risk response strategies to make adjustments as required
for the remaining project.
Also, determine if risk responses were appropriate or if further action is required.
Remember, always document the audit and relevant conclusions.
Risk audits should be scheduled at an appropriate frequency based on the needs of the project.
Project scope is a key factor that helps in deciding the frequency and quantity of audits.
Medium and large projects may require more frequent risk audits.
Smaller projects may have a risk audit only at the end of all work.
Risk audit frequency and processes are defined in the risk management plan.
Let's briefly look at the risk audit process.
A risk audit is triggered based on the frequency specified in the risk management plan.
During the audit, the overall effectiveness of risk management monitoring is evaluated.
If any changes are identified, the project risk management team will make the required
changes.
The risk audit also evaluates risk response effectiveness.
The risk register is updated if the response was adequate and results are documented in
lessons learned.
If a risk response was not adequate, residual risks are identified and documented in the
risk register for further action.
Let's understand residual risks in more detail.
When a risk occurs, a response is initiated.
In some cases, the response is adequate.
However, in some cases, the risk may still be present in an altered state.
This is referred to as a residual risk.
Here is an example.
Consider this scenario.
The primary risk, "Snowfall resulted in limited parking," occurred.
The identified response, "Use a commercial company to plow the parking lot and remove
the snow," was implemented.
Later, an ice coating was found in the parking lot under the snow.
This is a residual risk.
The ice became an issue when the snow cover was removed.
The risk owner needs to identify and document the new residual risk and implement the response
to de-ice the parking lot.
Residual risks are added to the risk register when discovered.
The project risk management team may also encounter secondary risks.
Many high-probability and impact risks require multiple risk response options.
In some cases, a primary and fallback response is generated.
If the primary response does not yield desired results, the fallback response is initiated.
There may be times when a primary or fallback response generates a new risk.
This is referred to as a secondary risk.
Here is an example.
The primary risk response is to increase safety inventory levels to mitigate the risk of material
shortages.
However, there is a secondary risk.
If the team increases safety stock levels, they may not have adequate storage space.
The team's response is to lease adequate storage space.
However, this response has cost impacts.
In this situation, check if the cost outweighs the benefits of increasing safety stock.
Another way to look at the risk might be to check if the costs of leasing more storage
space outweigh the risks of project delays due to material shortages.
If a secondary risk presents greater challenges than the primary risk, then the primary risk
response should be adjusted.
Finally, let's look issues and issue logs.
An issue is defined as a risk that occurred.
The project team must identify issues as soon as possible and implement planned risk responses.
Any residual risks should also be documented.
A best practice is to create an issue log with all relevant information about the issue
and resolution.
An example of headings that might be captured in an issue log are displayed.
The contents of an issue log should include Accurate and actionable description of the
issue.
The issue log should also include issue priority, such as High, Moderate, or Low.
Remember, all issues are not equal.
You can also include the issue category, such as, operations and finance.
Ensure the issue log captures the details about the issue reporter and issue resolver.
This will help establish the required communication to efficiently resolve the issue.
Issue status is another important information that you must capture.
Examples of issue status include active, deferred, or resolved.
Finally, the issue log must contain the date of issue resolution, which will be documented
after the issue is successfully resolved.
Note that PMI does not provide any recommendations on the contents of an issue log.
In this video, you learned that: Timely response to a risk is important as
a single risk occurrence may lead to project failure
Risk audits help determine the effectiveness of the risk management plan and response 
strategy.
Frequency of risk audits will vary based on project scope.
Risk audits may result in updating the risk management plan and residual risks.
A residual risk is identified when a response uncovers an altered risk state.
A secondary risk is identified when a fallback response is implemented.
An issue log should contain all relevant information about the issue and resolution.

Demo: Risk Matrix

Hello everyone.
Today I would like to go ahead and do a brief demonstration on a tool and technique that
is used quite often in project risk management.
This tool is called a risk matrix.
The primary tool that is used to identify and document risks by the project team is
the risk register.
However, a risk register often has more information than is needed by all of the project 
stakeholders.
There may be times when you need to provide risk status to perhaps the sponsor or other
key stakeholders.
When that is the case, the risk matrix is your best choice.
A risk matrix is meant to be a visual tool.
A risk matrix also provides very quick status.
The status is meant to be impactful, and in addition, by using this risk matrix, you can
oftentimes share your proposed responses and gain input on the validity of those responses
as well.
So, let's go ahead and share how a project manager and team would fill out or complete
a risk matrix.
We have a project called the Company Picnic, and two risks were previously identified.
Remember, a risk is documented using cause, event, and impact nomenclature.
It's called risk metalanguage.
A risk should tell a story.
So, our first risk or story, if you will, is: there is the potential for insects to
come and bite our participants, and if they bite our participants, that could result in
illness and discomfort.
So, we develop a response.
Our response is: we're going to go ahead and provide repellant to all of our participants.
The next thing we do is we go back to our risk register and we review the probability
and impact ratings.
In this particular case, you'll notice on the grid we have probability three and impact
three.
We put down R1, which stands for risk one, and now we have a compelling visual of where
risk number one fits on the impact and probability scale.
Our next risk that we identified was: there is a potential for bad weather.
And bad weather could bring with it rain.
And if we do have rain, we may have to reduce our events.
So, what is a applicable response?
Let's go ahead and create a few tents so that people can take cover if it rains and still
enjoy the picnic.
We go back to our risk register, and we see that bad weather was a probability of two
and an impact of four, so we go to our risk matrix grid and we put down risk number two.
Let's go ahead and identify a third risk.
Unfortunately, we have a lot of illness that is going around our particular community,
and if the illness occurs, we may end up with unfortunately reduced participation.
And what is the impact of reduced participation?
That would be reduced team interaction.
So, what can we do as a response to this?
What we may want to do is we may want to allow virtual participation.
Allow those who may be ill or unable to attend the event to at least look in, hear the keynote
speakers, and see some of the fun that the team is having at the picnic.
Remember that risk comes in two categories.
Risks can be negative, or threats, or positive, or opportunities.
And part of good effective risk management is looking for opportunities as well.
But before we move forward, we still have one task.
We take a look at this new risk, and we determine what is the probability and what is the impact.
So, our team gets together, and they determined that the probability is probably three, but
the impact is going to be five.
So, in this particular case, we put down our three.
And now we have a risk that's in the red area, and normally risks that are coated red on
the risk matrix get a lot of attention from the individuals who are receiving the status
update.
Let's take a look at a second type of risk, the opportunity.
We already have one in place.
The cause is good weather, and if we have good weather, we may have an abundance of
sunshine, and if we have an abundance of sunshine, maybe we can plan some more events.
So, what is the response?
Well, if we do achieve this good weather and sunshine, let's add a 1K trail walk.
If it rains, we will not have that trail walk.
But if it does, this is just another event that will be fun and help the team to come
together.
We identified a second opportunity.
The CEO is supporting this project, and as a result of this wonderful level of CEO support,
we can potentially expect some increased funding.
And what is the impact of increased funding?
Well, we can increase the benefits to the team.
So, what would be a response to ensure that we increase these team benefits?
What we can do is say: why don't we open this picnic up for family members as well?
Now we go to our probability and impact for this particular risk, we determine that the
probability is four and the impact is four, and we put down R2 in the grid.
Notice that this is now in a green area.
What does this mean?
It means that this is a high-probability, high-impact risk.
And if we are able to achieve this response by inviting family members, we're going to
benefit really greatly if we're able to go ahead and achieve this particular opportunity.
This ends my overview of the risk matrix.
Hopefully, this was helpful to you to gain a greater understanding of this powerful risk
management tool, and I look forward to seeing you in future demos.


Module 5 Summary and Highlights: Respond 
and Monitor Risk
Congratulations! You have completed this module. At this point in the course, you know:
•	The different response types to consider when planning for risk include response to threats 
such as avoid, transfer, and mitigate. This also includes responding to exploiting, 
sharing, and enhancing opportunities. You also learned how to respond to threats and 
opportunities, such as acceptance and escalation. Remember to think through your risk 
responses and develop the appropriate strategy to meet the risk response need.
•	Tips from a Subject Matter Expert (SME) panel on developing a solid risk response and how 
to identify risk triggers. Remember the guidance the SMEs shared: risk triggers and 
responses are critical to ensure the project is not derailed by risk.
•	The importance and contents of a risk report. Use the risk report to your advantage, as it 
is a great way to communicate risk status, maintain levels of stakeholder support, and solicit 
help to address the needs and issues stemming from risks.
•	Common risk management tools to include in document reviews include brain storming, 
brainwriting, the Delphi Technique, interviewing, root cause analysis, checklist 
analysis, assumption analysis, and lessons learned. You also learned the value of using a 
risk matrix to share risk status with key stakeholders.
•	The importance of timely risk response implementation, identifying the purse and 
outputs of a risk audit, and explaining the difference between secondary and residual risks. 
Risk is not a one-time activity. Risk exposure on a project will change as the project 
continues through closure. Use every method you can to maintain the lowest risk exposure 
possible.
•	The importance of ensuring that the project manager accomplishes risk reassessments 
promptly and some critical success factors to remember when reassessing risks. Project risk 
management begins at the start of a project and continues through closure. One risk the 
project manager does not manage well can lead to failure.

Key Takeaways
Effective information sharing and risk management along with a good understanding of the project 
lifecycle are critical to a project manager's success.
The key takeaways from this course include:
•	The different types of project lifecycles include predictive and adaptive methods.
•	The Project Management Institute (PMI) describes a total of 49 crucial processes within 
each of the five phases or process groups in a predictive lifecycle.
•	The project manager's roles and responsibilities during the project management lifecycle's 
encompass initiating, planning, executing, monitoring and controlling, and closing phases.
•	Development of the project charter and a stakeholder register occurs during the initiating 
phase, and the project manager presents these documents to a project sponsor for approval.
•	In the project planning phase, the project manager develops a comprehensive project 
management plan and presents it to a sponsor for approval. Then the project manager 
schedules a kick-off meeting and gains stakeholder acceptance of the plan.
•	The development of the project deliverables occurs during the executing phase. The skills a 
project manager must have for a successful execution phase are critical.
•	The project manager verifies that completed deliverables meet project management plan 
specifications during the monitoring and controlling phase. The project team presents the 
deliverables to a customer for acceptance.
•	In the project closing phase, the project manager ensures all deliverables meet 
specifications, attains final customer acceptance, and transitions the final product or service 
to the customer. The project manager also presents a final report during this phase, and the 
project team conducts and shares lessons learned.
•	The basic communications model stresses the importance of ensuring that the project team 
receives messages as intended and introduces the concept of communication blockers, which 
are factors that can obstruct effective communication. It is crucial to identify these blockers 
before they impact the team. The Project Management Institute (PMI) also identifies 
technology factors the project manager should analyze and plan for, as these factors can 
affect communications. Finally, the project manager should consider different 
communication needs, such as pull, push, and interactive communications, when planning 
for effective communication in each project.
•	Communications planning emphasizes the significance of effective communications in 
achieving project success. You now know the three-step approach to managing 
communications and reviewing communications management planning techniques. PMI 
states that communications are 90% the project manager's responsibility and should be a 
central focal point as you plan and execute a project. Every project should have a 
communications management plan, as a lack of communications planning will likely result 
in random and ineffective communications. The communications management plan should 
contain key communication activities crucial for project success.
•	How to implement a communications management plan. You now know the essential 
communication methods, challenges, and skills a project manager should possess. PMI 
states communication is the most difficult interpersonal skill to perfect, so you should hone 
your skills whenever possible.
•	The key tools and techniques essential to effective communication include active listening, 
conflict management, and how political awareness is vital when sharing information.
•	Communications monitoring responsibilities include effective meeting management 
techniques, best practices in virtual communications, and how the PMI Code of Ethics 
impacts effective communications.
•	The stakeholder register is a guide for critical communications which the project manager 
creates in conjunction with the project charter during the initiation phase of the project 
management lifecycle. You learned what PMI recommends as tools and techniques to 
identify stakeholders and gain commitment. You should identify stakeholders as early in the 
project as possible to enhance maximum participation and commitment.
•	The purpose of the stakeholder engagement plan is to list key stakeholders in the stakeholder 
register in terms of their current and desired levels of commitment. We reviewed key 
strategies to attain desired levels of stakeholder engagement. The stakeholder engagement 
plan is a close-hold plan; all stakeholders are different. The project manager should analyse 
each stakeholder to determine their motivations and adapt strategies to each.
•	The importance of effectively managing stakeholders and how project managers may 
increase or reduce levels of stakeholder commitment was shared.
•	The benefits of setting ground rules and norms eliminate many issues in the long term. We 
introduced a team charter concept.
•	Methods for a project manager to maintain stakeholder support throughout the project and 
how to strategise with the team via the Tuckman Ladder model. You reviewed motivation 
theories that can help shape stakeholder engagement strategies.
•	The need for an effective project risk management lifecycle and the roles and 
responsibilities essential to project risk management success were highlighted.
•	The definition of risk and uncertainty in projects. We defined known versus unknown risks 
and the difference between risks and issues. The project manager should identify both 
opportunities and threats. Threats can impact the project baseline negatively, while 
opportunities can enhance project baseline performance. Effective risk management requires 
attention to both risk categories.
•	Modelled risk metalanguage to document risks and how to distinguish between a cause, 
event, and impact. Risk metalanguage tells a story, is easy to understand, and allows for 
actionable responses.
•	The purpose of SWOT analysis and how a project manager can use a SWOT analysis to 
identify opportunities and threats. SWOT is a proven method to identify risk causes and 
potential events and impacts that follow.
•	The purpose and contents of a risk management plan are where you define ratings for 
probability and impact and distinguish between urgent and non-urgent risks. You also 
describe contingency reserves and management reserves.
•	The risk register is the primary tool project managers use to identify and manage risks by 
analysing each risk and understanding how it impacts the project.
•	The different response types to consider when planning for risk include response to threats 
such as avoid, transfer, and mitigate. This also includes responding to exploiting, sharing, 
and enhancing opportunities. You also learned how to respond to threats and opportunities, 
such as acceptance and escalation. Remember to think through your risk responses and 
develop the appropriate strategy to meet the risk response need.
•	Risk triggers and responses are critical to ensure the project is not derailed by risk.
•	Use the risk report to your advantage, as it is a great way to communicate risk status, 
maintain levels of stakeholder support, and solicit help to address the needs and issues 
stemming from risks.
•	Common risk management tools to use when documenting reviews include brain storming, 
brainwriting, the Delphi Technique, interviewing, root cause analysis, checklist analysis, 
assumption analysis, and lessons learned. You also learned the value of using a risk matrix to 
share risk status with key stakeholders.
•	Risk is not a one-time activity. Risk exposure on a project will change as the project 
continues through closure. Use every method you can to maintain the lowest risk exposure 
possible.
•	Project risk management begins at the start of a project and continues through closure. One 
risk the project manager does not manage well can lead to failure.



Welcome to the Course

Welcome to the Project Management Communications, Stakeholders, and Leadership course.
This course is ideal for beginners or professionals with business experience who want to sharpen
their business skills or even transition into a project management role.
This course provides information and best practices in the key areas of project management,
including • creating a healthy project foundation,
• effective communications building blocks, • effective communications planning,
• leadership fundamentals • and effectively manage and lead stakeholders.
Concepts related to these areas are presented in five modules.
The last module will provide you with an opportunity to apply your newly acquired skills in a 
graded
project.
Module 1 provides guidance on how a project manager must put their people first, create
a healthy project environment, and embody the virtues of a servant leader.
Effective communication can make or break a project.
Module 2 provides an inventory of effective communication building blocks a project manager
must assemble to ensure project success.
Key communication skills required include communication mediums, when to use them, and
proven engagement tactics.
In addition, the module provides some tips on cross-cultural communications.
You will also learn how to fail fast in a way that benefits the project, along with
using the RACI tool to identify key project roles.
Ensuring communication reaches the right audience in a timely manner is critical to project
success.
Module 3 highlights communications planning.
You will learn how to plan and communicate schedules effectively.
The module also introduces a tool called a communications management plan.
This plan ensures that all project communications are organized and the right information is
available to all stakeholders when needed.
You will also learn about work performance reports, focusing on status reporting.
The module will help you to determine your communication style, and those of your team
are explored.
Module 4 introduces key leadership topics.
You will understand why a project manager must be a good leader.
The module will emphasize how a leader must know their strengths and weaknesses.
You will also be introduced to situational leadership and a leader's involvement in
team formation.
The module completes with a brief overview of a leader's knowledge management duties
and a summary on how making decisions using "gut calls" plays a role in effective
leadership.
Module 5 discusses a key leadership responsibility- resource management.
You will be introduced to a resource planning and management tool called resource breakdown
structure (RBS).
The module also covers tips to effectively acquire resources and build trust with the
team.
The module also provides some guidance on how you can improve your Emotional Intelligence
(EQ).
You will also learn about some ways to effectively manage up, such as your manager and client.
Finally, the module will introduce a critical leadership trait-adaptability and resilience.
Finally, in module 6, you will have the opportunity to apply the concepts you learned in the course
into a project.
You will submit your work and grade your peers.
This is followed by a final assessment quiz.
This course will be an aid if you plan to attain any PMI certifications, including:
• Certified Associate in Project Management, or PMI-CAPM,
• Project Management Professional, or PMI-PMP, and
• Review the opportunity to qualify and attain these certifications at pmi.org.

and leaders.
