Put Your People First

Welcome to "Put Your People First."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Discuss ways to foster a healthy environment for team members.
And explain effects of empowering team members.
As important as schedules, deliverables, and tools to manage the project are to success,
the people that do the work of the project matter most. Ensuring that the people involved in the
project are motivated and clearly understand what they're working on sets a project up for 
success.
Project managers, many times, don't directly manage the people or even
the work that is being done. But they can greatly impact morale
and productivity by serving the team with clear schedules, goals, and deliverables.
One way project managers can help a team to function well is to ensure people are
working on tasks that match or slightly exceed their skillset and disposition. For example,
software developers shouldn't be expected to write marketing copy. Project managers
can work with people managers to ensure there is proper alignment for workers and tasks by:
Clearly defining each team member's tasks
and responsibilities and ensuring they understand their role in the project.
Assigning tasks to team members based on their skills, experience,
and abilities. This maximizes the use of the team's strengths.
Regularly monitoring the progress of each team member and the project as a whole.
This helps identify areas where team members may need additional
support or where tasks may need to be reallocated.
Providing team members with training and development opportunities to enhance
their skills and abilities. This helps to develop a highly skilled and motivated team.
Another way project managers can focus on people is by empowering them to keep
the project moving forward. Empowerment is the process of giving team members the 
authority, resources, and support they need to complete their tasks effectively and achieve 
their project goals. It involves creating an environment where team members feel
valued and appreciated and are encouraged to take ownership of their tasks and use
their skills, experience, and creativity to contribute to the project's success.
Project managers can empower their team by matching tasks to team members based on their
skills, experience, and abilities. Matching skill sets with the appropriate team members 
empowers them to complete each task to the highest standard and maximizes the team's 
strengths.
Project managers also empower their teams by creating a positive and
supportive work environment where team members feel valued and appreciated.
Encouraging open and regular communication also empowers
team members and stakeholders. Open communication can help identify issues
or concerns and allow for effective collaboration and problem-solving.
When team members feel empowered, they are more likely to be motivated and committed
to the project. This can lead to higher levels of productivity and a more positive work environment.
Empowerment can help build morale and motivation and improve team dynamics.
Empowering team members invites new ideas and innovative solutions to the
project and can lead to improved ways of working.
By empowering team members to take ownership of their tasks, they are more likely to identify
and solve problems as they arise, which can help to keep the project on track.
Similarly, an empowered team is one that knows they can work on any open
task on which they are skilled to keep the project moving forward.
This can reduce friction and delays, and creates a more collaborative environment.
Since many people spend a good portion of their day working on projects,
project managers should help people enjoy what they're doing.
Promoting open communication and fostering a sense of teamwork creates a positive and
supportive work environment. This can help build morale and motivation and improve team 
dynamics.
Recognize and reward the efforts and successes of team members. This can help to build 
motivation and also improve team morale.
Know which things are important and urgent and which aren't. Not everything requires
urgent language, and some things don't need to be addressed. Knowing how to weigh
things will help keep the important things important, build trust, and reduce stress.
Encourage team members to maintain a healthy work-life balance. This can help reduce stress 
and burnout and improve overall job satisfaction.
As a project manager, your primary focus should be on timelines, deliverables, and ensuring 
stakeholders are getting what they need.
People are the key to success, and, as a project manager, you play a crucial role in that 
success.

In this video, you learned that:
Ways to foster a healthy environment for team members include:
Empowering team members
Builds morale
Improves team dynamics
Invites innovation
Reduces friction
Prevents delays

Maximizing team strengths by serving the team with clear schedules, goals, and deliverables.
Regularly monitoring the progress of each team member and the project as a whole to identify 
areas where team members may need additional support or where tasks may need to be 
reallocated.
Providing team members with training and development opportunities to enhance their skills 
and abilities.
Empowering team members to keep the project moving forward by giving team members the 
authority, resources, and support they need to complete their tasks effectively and achieve 
their project goals. This can be achieved by:
-Creating an environment where team members feel valued and appreciated and are 
encouraged to take ownership of their tasks and use their skills, experience, and creativity to 
contribute to the project's success.
- Matching tasks to team members based on their skills, experience, and abilities.
-Matching skill sets with the appropriate team members empowers them to complete each 
task to the highest standard and maximizes the team's strengths.
- Creating a positive and supportive work environment where team members feel valued and 
appreciated by encouraging open and regular communication also empowers team members 
and stakeholders. Open communication can help identify issues or concerns and allow for 
effective collaboration and problem-solving. This can reduce friction and delays, and creates a 
more collaborative environment.
- Promoting open communication and fostering a sense of teamwork creates a positive and 
supportive work environment. This can help build morale and motivation and improve team 
dynamics.
- Recognize and reward the efforts and successes of team members. This can help to build 
motivation and also improve team morale.
- Encourage team members to maintain a healthy work-life balance. This can help reduce 
stress and burnout and improve overall job satisfaction.

Communicating Clear Project Objectives

Welcome to "Communicating Clear Project Objectives."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
explain the importance of project objectives,
discuss the project manager's responsibilities regarding the project objectives, and
explain how project objectives prevent scope creep.
Project managers are generally responsible for clearly communicating and often setting 
project objectives. These objectives, as a foundational element of any project, are the "north 
star."
Project objectives are specific, measurable, and time-bound outcomes that a project team 
works towards achieving. Objectives define what the project aims to accomplish and provide 
a clear direction for the project team. They are typically set at the beginning of the project during
the planning phase and are critical to guide decision-making throughout the project lifecycle.
Part of the project manager's responsibility in leading the team is communicating clear,
actionable project objectives early and often.
If a company is running a marketing campaign project for a new product, some of its project 
objectives might include:
-Increase brand awareness by boosting website traffic by 50% month-over-month
for three months before the product launches.
-Attract new customers by establishing partnerships with 10 micro-influencers and co-develop 3 
sharable assets.
-Reach and maintain a 3% conversion rate for three months after launch by A/B testing the 
product's marketing messaging.
A project manager can document and communicate project objectives in the project charter 
or the project scope statement. These documents outline what work will be done for the project 
and act as a tool to help project managers, project teams, and project stakeholders align on project 
objectives. Also, by formally documenting and communicating project objectives in a project 
charter or project scope statement, project managers set clear expectations for the team and 
protect against under or over-delivering.
A project manager should also communicate the project objectives during the project kick-off
meeting. During a project kick-off meeting, all relevant stakeholders, such as the project sponsor 
and project team, gather to discuss the objectives, deliverables, risks, and roles.
This meeting is the perfect time for a project manager to communicate project objectives because 
the meeting sets the tone for the project, ensures that all stakeholders are aligned, and creates 
an opportunity for high-level stakeholders to reinforce the importance of achieving the project 
objectives.
During the life of the project, a project manager should communicate the project objectives 
regularly to continue to keep all stakeholders aligned.
Project managers can do this during daily stand-ups or weekly status meetings by tying the work 
that has been done, is in progress, or that is yet to be completed to one or more of the project 
objectives.
They can also include the project objectives in weekly reporting dashboards or documents.
Communicating project objectives clearly is crucial to ensuring that everyone involved in the 
project understands what they are working towards. Whether using verbal or written 
communication, there are some ways to ensure that project objectives are communicated clearly. 
When communicating objectives, you should:
-use clear and concise language to explain the project objectives, avoid using technical jargon 
or complex language that may confuse stakeholders
-adjust the communication of project objectives depending on the audience.
Different stakeholders may have different levels of knowledge and interest in the project, so it is 
important to tailor the message to meet their needs.
-use visual aids, such as graphs, diagrams, and charts, that can help clarify the objectives and 
make them more memorable.
-help stakeholders understand how the team is going to measure the objectives.
-Finally, encourage the questions and feedback from the audience to ensure
that they understand the project objectives. Answering questions and addressing concerns can 
help to clarify any confusion or misunderstandings.
Project managers may have the responsibility of writing the project objectives. Since project 
objectives are so important to the lifecycle of the project, there are a few characteristics that project 
managers must keep in mind when developing them:
-Project objectives should be clear and unambiguous, defining exactly what the project aims 
to achieve.
-They should be quantifiable so that progress towards achieving them can be tracked and 
measured.
-And they should be realistic and attainable, given the project's constraints and available 
resources.
It is also important for project managers to remember that what is left out of project objectives is 
as important as what is put in. Project managers may find it difficult to say no, especially to key 
stakeholders. But learning to say no helps prevent scope creep and reduces the risk of 
overworked teams.
Scope creep is when project objectives, requirements, and tasks expand throughout the life of 
the project, but budget and resource constraints stay the same. A small amount of scope creep 
is generally understandable, but eventually, scope creep can lead to missed deadlines and 
increased expenses.
Saying no as a project manager can be challenging, but it is an important skill to have to 
maintain control over the project scope and ensure that the project remains on track. Here are some 
tips on how to say no as a project manager:
-When saying no, be clear and firm in your response. Use a confident and assertive tone
to communicate that you are not willing to accept a request that is outside of the project 
scope.
-Provide an explanation for why the request cannot be accommodated, including risks and 
constraints the team is working within.
When saying no, it's important to keep the big picture in mind.
-Explain how the request may impact the project timeline, budget, or overall success.
Saying no doesn't have to be confrontational.
-Be collaborative in your response and show that you are willing to work with stakeholders to 
find a solution that meets everyone's needs. Offer alternatives that may help to address the 
underlying need or concern.
Finally, document the decision. It's important to document the decision to say no and why in 
case questions or challenges arise in the future.

In this video, you learned that:
-Project objectives provide direction of the project
-Project managers should communicate clear, actionable project objectives early and often
-Document project objectives in the project charter and communicate them during the project 
kick-off meeting
-Effectively communicate project objectives by using clear and concise language
-Tailor their message and delivery to their audience, and encourage questions and feedback
-Saying no as a project manager can be challenging, but it is an important skill to have in 
order to
maintain control over the project scope and ensure that the project remains on track.
Servant Leadership

Participating in the Work

Welcome to "Participating in the Work."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
-Define servant leadership.
-Discuss the benefits of "participating in the work" as a servant leader.
-And identify best practices that help "participating in the work" as a servant leader.

Project managers, or PMs, who adopt a servant leader approach can create an environment 
more conducive to successful project outcomes. Their teams often feel empowered, are more 
collaborative, and have high morale, which sets the stage for successful projects.
Robert K. Greenleaf, credited with popularizing the concept of servant leadership, says servant
leadership is "a philosophy and set of practices that enriches the lives of individuals, builds 
better organizations, and ultimately creates a more just and caring world."
But how do project managers put servant leadership into practice?
The most effective PMs can set schedules, learn appropriate project vocabulary, and 
understand nuances of project details.
Participating in the team's work and collaborating with them can help you to learn these skills.
When project managers participate in the work that their teams are doing, they better understand the 
tasks involved in the project and the challenges that team members may face. This helps project
managers make decisions and provide more effective guidance and support to team members.
By participating in their teams' work, project managers demonstrate their willingness to get
their hands dirty and work alongside their team members. Their actions build trust and 
rapport and create a camaraderie that can improve team dynamics and morale.
While participating in the work, project managers can also observe the processes and procedures 
in action and identify areas for improvement. Then project managers can streamline workflows, 
eliminate inefficiencies, and optimize project outcomes.
Finally, when project managers participate in their teams' work, they lead by example, 
demonstrating the behaviours and attitudes they expect from their team members.
This creates a culture of collaboration, accountability, and continuous improvement.
As a project manager, you and your team may already have full schedules, which may make 
participating in the work seem difficult. Some strategies that can help make participating in the 
work easier include:
-Find thirty minutes to an hour in your calendar and schedule time to work with the team.
You can work on part of the project independently. Or, it may be time you already have scheduled 
with a team member where you can co-work on the part of the project.
-Communicate your intentions and explain why you are participating in the work before you 
jump in. This will help team members understand your perspective and avoid confusion or 
misunderstandings.
While it is important to participate in the work, it is also important to set clear boundaries and 
avoid micromanaging. Make it clear that you are there to support and assist but that you trust your 
team members to do their jobs and make their own decisions.
-Be open to learning and trying new things when participating in the work. Your team 
members may have different perspectives or approaches that can help you improve your skills and 
knowledge.
By participating in the work as a project manager, you can build stronger relationships with your 
team members, better understand the project, and model the behaviours and attitudes you 
expect from your team.

In this video, you learned that:
-Servant leadership emphasizes serving the team by focusing on their needs while also 
empowering and supporting them to reach their full potential.
-Participating in team member's work can help stay connected to the project, build 
relationships with team members, and identify opportunities for improvement that can 
enhance project outcomes.
-And project managers can participate in the work by budgeting their time for work, 
communicating their intentions, setting boundaries, and being open to learning.
