Effective Conversations

Welcome to "Effective Conversations"
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Describe methods for having effective conversations.
Explain key communication skills to effectively manage a program.
And describe communication techniques and the technologies you can use to implement
them.
When managing a project, you will have ongoing conversations with the team and stakeholders.
Specifically, there are seven conversational areas you'll have regularly.
1-Plan the project with the team, stakeholders, and sponsors to define the scope, goals, and
timeline of the project.
2-Discuss resource allocation with the team to identify required resources (human, financial,
and material) and ensure their availability.
3-Talk about project risks with the team and stakeholders to identify potential risks,
assess their impact, and develop contingency plans.
4-Work with the team to track the project's progress, identify any deviations from the
plan, and adjust the plan as necessary.
5-Talk regularly with stakeholders to manage expectations, address concerns, and ensure
their engagement and support throughout the project.
6-Have planned and ongoing conversations with the teams, stakeholders, and sponsors to 
ensure regular, transparent, and effective communication about the project.
7-Throughout the project, talk with the team to assess their performance, identify areas
for improvement, and provide feedback
By having effective conversations, you can discover potential risks before they become
issues.
Managing resources can be challenging on any project.
Talking with your key stakeholders can help you determine the resources they have available
and the capacity they will have for the project.
Many times, projects overlap.
When teams use the same people to work on multiple projects, workloads can become overbearing.
Discussing this with other PMs can help prevent burnout.
Project managers can help prevent issues that may block progress on the project both before
the project starts and during production.
By clarifying expectations and identifying risks early, stakeholders will know what the
project will entail.
During the project, the PM will help resolve conflicts and maintain transparency on all
aspects of the project.
These help keep the project running smoothly.
These types of conversations will help you understand what stakeholders may be concerned
about.
Creating an environment of trust and transparency will help stakeholders voice their concerns
before and during the project.
Project managers also get to share in and promote success stories.
Effective conversations help people find the success in a project, and project managers
get to amplify those success stories across the team.
Amplifying success is self-perpetuating and can have a positive effect on a project.
Planning is essential to have effective conversations.
While it may seem odd to plan for an activity we do on a regular basis, planning will help
you get the most out of your conversations.
Before you start a conversation, think about what you want to achieve from it.
This will help you focus the conversation and keep it on track.
Prepare a clear and concise agenda for the conversation.
This will ensure that all the important topics are covered and that everyone has a shared
understanding of what will be discussed.
Include the topics you want to discuss and what data or information you need from the
conversation, and be sure to address any assumptions you have about the topics.
Consider the type of conversation you are having and choose an appropriate mode for
the type of conversation you are having.
For example, face-to-face, synchronous conversations may be more effective for sensitive or 
complex topics, while email or chat may be more appropriate for routine updates.
Encourage all participants to effectively listen to one another and engage in a two-way
dialogue.
This will help build trust and foster a positive and productive environment.
Conflicts are inevitable in any project, but as a project manager, you should be prepared
to handle them effectively.
Encourage open and honest communication, listen to both sides of the argument, and work towards
finding a mutually acceptable solution.
After the conversation, make sure to follow up on any action items or decisions that were
made.
This will help keep everyone accountable and ensure that the conversation remains productive.
Project managers should continually remind the team of the importance of having effective
conversations early in the project that continue through the project's end.
Effective conversations at the beginning of a project help clarify expectations and ensure
everyone is on the same page.
This includes defining project goals, expectations for team members, and the roles and 
responsibilities of each stakeholder.
Through effective communication, project managers can build trust with their team members and
stakeholders.
This helps to foster a positive and productive working environment, which is essential for
the success of a project.
Conversations throughout the project allow project managers to identify and resolve any
issues that may arise.
This includes addressing any roadblocks or challenges and finding ways to overcome them.
Effective communication helps keep everyone informed about the progress of the project,
changes in scope, and any other important updates.
This helps to maintain transparency and keep everyone aligned on the project's objectives.
By engaging in open and honest conversations, project managers can gather valuable insights
and feedback from their team members and stakeholders.
This helps to improve decision-making and ultimately leads to better project outcomes.

In this video, you learned that:
During every project, you may have key conversations about project planning, resource 
allocation,
risk management, progress monitoring, stakeholder management, communications, and 
performance evaluation.
Planning is essential to have effective conversations, as it will help you get the most out of 
your
conversations.
Effective conversations are important for the entire team, and project managers should
continually remind the team of their importance from the beginning of the project until the
end


Project Management Communications Skills

Welcome to "Project Management Communications Skills."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Describe why effective communication is important for project managers,
Identify key communication skills essential to the success of project managers,
And explain best practices for different types of communication
Communication skills are essential for project managers because they are responsible for
ensuring that they inform and engage all stakeholders throughout the project.
Effective communication enables project managers to build trust, resolve conflicts, provide
clear direction, and keep everyone aligned during the lifecycle of a project.
Poor communication can lead to misunderstandings, delays, and even project failure.
Hence, strong communication skills are crucial for project managers to be successful in their
role.
Communication includes more than just the ability to have a conversation.
Some key communication skills that project managers should have include:
Active listening, Oral communication , Written communication, Interpersonal communication
And Presentations.
Active listening is a communication technique that involves giving your full attention to the 
speaker, avoiding distractions and interruptions, and using verbal and non-verbal cues to 
show that you are engaged in the conversation.
Active listening is important because it helps project managers understand their stakeholders'
perspectives, needs, and concerns, including team members and clients.
By actively listening, project managers can build trust, resolve conflicts, identify potential
problems early on, and make informed decisions in the project's best interest.
Some ways that project managers can practice active listening include restating what the
speaker has said, listening to understand, and asking open-ended questions to show you
are interested in the conversation.
Oral communication is the use of spoken language to convey information, ideas, and opinions.
This form of communication is direct, immediate, and personal.
Project managers use oral communication in various settings, including one-on-one conversations,
meetings, and presentations.
Oral communication is crucial for project managers because it allows them to quickly
and effectively convey information and ideas and respond to questions and concerns in real
time.
Oral communication is particularly important for project managers because it allows them
to build relationships, motivate team members, and negotiate with stakeholders.
Additionally, oral communication can help project managers clarify complex concepts
and provide context for written or visual communications.
For effective oral communication, project managers should use clear and concise language,
adapt their communication styles based on the audience, and adjust their tone so that
it is appropriate for the conversation.
Written communication is the use of written language to document information, provide 
instructions, and to communicate with people who are not in the same physical location.
Examples of written communication in a project management context include emails, direct
messaging, reports, and presentations.
Written communication is important for project managers because it provides a record of 
information
and decisions and allows for clear and consistent communication with stakeholders who may not
be available for oral communication.
Written communication can also help project managers clarify complex concepts, (86present
data and information, and document project processes and decisions.
Effective written communication skills are essential for project managers to ensure they
are efficiently sharing accurate information and to promote transparency and accountability
in project management.
To communicate effectively through written communication, project managers should write
for clarity, be consistent in formatting and terminology, tailor their writing style for
the audience, and include graphics and visuals to communicate data.
Interpersonal communication is the process of exchanging information, ideas, and emotions
between two or more people.
Interpersonal communication can be oral or written but is used to motivate, negotiate,
and facilitate collaboration.
Strong interpersonal communication skills allow project managers to understand the perspectives
and needs of their stakeholders and to communicate effectively to ensure that everyone is aligned
with the project goals.
Interpersonal communication also helps project managers to gain the trust and cooperation
of their stakeholders, manage and resolve conflicts, as well as negotiate and make decisions
which is essential for successful project outcomes.
Effective interpersonal communication involves practicing active listening skills, employing
empathy, use appropriate body language, and reinforcing messages with non-verbal cues.

Presentation skills are the ability to effectively communicate information, ideas, and opinions
through presentations, such as speeches, slide presentations, and workshops.
This form of communication requires the use of active listening, oral, written, and interpersonal
communication to engage an audience and convey complex information clearly and concisely.
Project managers with strong presentation skills can effectively communicate important
project information, such as goals, progress, and outcomes, to stakeholders.
They can also engage and motivate their audience and clarify complex concepts.
This allows them to secure buy-in and support from stakeholders and to build trust and credibility.
Effective presentations include employing best practices from other types of communication.
For presentations, it is also highly important to use visuals to effectively communicate
key points to your audience.
Jorge is a program manager at a large tech company, and his team just completed part
of their program and launched a brand-new product.
Jorge's manager asked him to give a presentation to the entire group of stakeholders.
Jorge wants to effectively communicate the successful launch of the new product and motivate
the team to continue the rest of the program.
He also needs to communicate the risks of the next phase of the project to the stakeholders.
Jorge begins by greeting the audience, introduces himself, and clearly states the purpose of
the presentation.
He uses clear and concise language and maintains eye contact to engage the audience.
He utilizes written communication skills by using slides and visual aids to support his
oral communication.
The written information is concise, relevant, and is relevant to what he is saying.
He is aware of his audience and adapts his communication style to meet the audience's
needs.
He uses personal anecdotes to create a connection and motivate his team.
He also responds to questions and feedback from the audience, demonstrating an openness
to dialogue and a willingness to work together.
Throughout the presentation, he actively listens to the audience's feedback and concerns, asking
questions, clarifying misunderstandings, and incorporating suggestions into the presentation
as appropriate.

In this video, you learned that: Effective communication enables project
managers to build trust, resolve conflicts, provide clear direction, and keep everyone
aligned during the lifecycle of a project.
Key communication skills for project managers include active listening, verbal and written
communication, interpersonal communication, and presentations.
Project managers should always aim to use clear and concise language and tailor
their message and delivery to their audience Effective presentations include employing
best practices from each of the other types of communication skills.


Project Communications Overview

Welcome to "Project Communications Overview."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Describe the key strategies to ensure effective communication across different project 
processes.
And explain the skills a project manager must have, to design and implement effective 
communication.
Communication begins when the project starts and continues through the project end.
Ensuring smooth communication throughout the project is critical to the success of the
project.
The Project Management Institute, or PMI, recommends using three processes to ensure
effective communication with all project stakeholders throughout the project.
The processes include:
1-Plan Communications Management
2-Manage Communications, and
3-Monitor Communications
Each process provides certain key strategies to aid in effective communication.  
Let's take a look.

Plan Communications Management is about planning the management of communication.
Key strategies outlined in this first step include:
-Review the project charter, project management plan, and all pertinent project 
documentation.
-Consult with subject matter experts (SMEs) and analyse project communications 
requirements essential to success.
The consulting strategy includes:
	Understanding communications technology needs and challenges.
	And utilizing different communications methods to evaluate the team's interpersonal 
	skills to communicate effectively and meaningfully.
Step 1 ends with developing and distributing a comprehensive communications management
plan.
This plan becomes part of the formally approved and accepted project management plan and 
provides a road map to execute the project's communications strategy.
Remember, the goal is to ensure the proper communications get to the right stakeholders
in the right amounts at the right time.

After the planning is complete, the next step is to Manage Communications.
During this process, some key strategies that a project manager must follow to ensure success
include:
-Implementing the communications management plan,
-Documenting issues and developing a plan to address them,
-Ensuring technology works in their favour for all project communication,
-Using the potential from Work Performance Reports to their advantage,
S-haring information that is pertinent and valuable,
-Asking for help and support when required,
-Avoiding doing the same thing repeatedly and expecting a different result,
-And proactively identifying what is not working in your process and proposing a plan to fix
it.

As you manage communications for the project, you should also monitor communications.
Monitor Communications is PMI's final communications process.
Some key communication effectiveness strategies essential to success include:
-Continually monitor Work Performance Data, or WPD.
This is defined as "raw" data by PMI.
WPD is informal communication from:
	Conversations, Emails, and Text messages.
New stakeholders will be needed as the project progresses.
Prior stakeholders may no longer be required on the project.
-Continually update the communications management plan to reflect where the project is in 
the lifecycle accurately.
-Ensure the formal change control system is working.
-Make sure the project is not overcome with scope creep.
-Continue to communicate effectively until the final project closure.
We discussed the key strategies for effective communication that apply to the three-step
process.
Next, let's look at some skills that a project manager must have to design and implement
effective communication.
A project manager must possess a good understanding of the different mechanisms by which 
information is exchange.
This will help the project manager to select the right mechanism to meet the stakeholder's
needs.
Common mechanisms include:
Written, which can be through physical or electronic communication.
Spoken via face-to-face or remote communication.
Gestures using facial expressions or hand gestures.
Media via pictures, actions, or even the choice of words.
Choice of words to relay a message.
There are many ways to relay a similar message through oral or written communication.
Another essential skill project managers must possess is understanding the difference between
formal and informal communication.
Formal and informal communication can be further divided into verbal and non-verbal 
communication.
Formal communication follows the rules of an organization in a respectful manner.
An example of formal communication is how you would talk to your co-workers or manager
at work.
Informal communication happens outside of an organization.
An example of informal communication is how you would talk to your friends or family.
Project managers must also understand the stakeholder's position in the project team
and adjust their content accordingly.
Key stakeholder categories include:
Upward, including senior management stakeholders.
Downward, which can be through the team or other members who contribute to the work of
the project.
And horizontal through peers of the project manager or team.
Knowledge of how to apply the 5 Cs of communication using the PMI model is also a 
mandatory skill for project managers.
Let's understand the 5 Cs.
The first C represents correct.
Ensure grammar and spelling are accurate, and the intent of the message is well-stated.
Next comes concise.
A well-crafted message reduces the chances of misunderstanding the intent.
The third C represents clear.
Ensure the needs of the stakeholders or audiences are factored into the message.
The fourth C of communication is coherent.
Ensure the flow of ideas is logical.
Use introductions and summaries.
Finally, control.
Control the flow of words using graphics or summaries.

In this video, you learned that:
Define and implement different strategies for effective communication during the plan
communications management, manage communications, and monitor communications project 
processes.
A project manager must possess different skills to design and implement effective 
communication, including:

	An understanding of when to use which communication mechanism,
	Ability to distinguish between formal and informal communication,
	And the ability to apply the 5 Cs of communication using the PMI model.


Synchronous vs Asynchronous 
Communications

Welcome to "Synchronous and Asynchronous Communication"
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Differentiate synchronous from asynchronous communication
Compare and contrast situations in which synchronous vs asynchronous
communication would be most appropriate.
There are a number of mediums of communication that you can use to communicate with your 
team, such as video conferencing, a phone call, or email. Mediums of communication fall into two 
categories, synchronous and asynchronous. Mediums of communication will be discussed in further 
detail in another video.
Synchronous communication means you're communicating with one or more people
in real time. In-person communication is the most common type of synchronous communication.
Other synchronous mediums include the telephone, voice chat, and video chat.
With asynchronous communication, the communication is not in real-time. There
is a time lapse between when a message is sent, when it is received, and when it is responded to.
Examples of asynchronous communication include voice, video, and text messages, as well as 
email.
Direct messaging can be synchronous or asynchronous and often even toggles quickly
between the two. Think about how many times you have been messaging back and forth with
someone in real-time and then all of a sudden you don't hear back, often with no notice that the
person on the other end of the conversation got sidetracked and the conversation abruptly stops.
The conversation started as synchronous but then suddenly switched to asynchronous.
Understanding the differences between these two types of communication can help you select the
right communication method for a given situation.
For instance, synchronous communication would be preferable when working on a project that 
requires real-time decision-making, while asynchronous communication might be better for tasks 
that require thought and reflection. Knowing the differences can help you better manage your 
stakeholder's time and avoid miscommunications.
In general, synchronous communication is a better option when dealing with a complex
and sensitive topic that requires interpersonal skills to navigate, such as conflict management.
Synchronous communication enables the receiver to ask clarifying questions or restate the message 
in their own words to ensure they interpreted the message correctly.
Synchronous communication is also better to build rapport. As a project manager, you will need to 
gain your team members' and your stakeholders' trust. This can best be accomplished with real-time 
conversations, both project related and more casual, informal conversations to get to know each 
other on a little more personal level.
Asynchronous communication is preferred though, if you wish to have more time to think about, 
craft, and edit your message. It is also preferred for the receiver if you wish for them to have
the time to think about and digest your message before responding. For instance, a project report
that addresses several key points containing statistics is better delivered asynchronously.
Asynchronous communication is often a better choice when you need to deliver the same message 
to a group, especially if you are working across time zones.
Coordinating schedules can be challenging and time consuming. There are certainly times when
you will need to meet at the same time as a group when you wish to have a discussion but if you are 
trying to get the same message to multiple people, asynchronous is often prudent.

In this video, you learned that:
Synchronous communication is communication that happens in real-time
Asynchronous communication is communication when there is a time lag in sending,
receiving, and responding to the communication
Synchronous communication is better when building trust or dealing with
sensitive topics such as conflict management
Asynchronous communication is a good choice when
the message needs to be carefully crafted or when communicating with a larger group .


Communications Mediums

Welcome to "Communication Mediums"
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Identify different communication mediums and
Describe the advantages and disadvantages of different communication mediums.
In this video, we will discuss several communication mediums that project
managers can use to communicate with their teams, including:
In-person meetings that allow for real-time interaction and collaboration Email and direct 
messaging are simple and direct ways of sending messages to team members.
Video- and audio-conferencing tools like Zoom, Skype, and Google Meet for face-to-face 
interactions, and Mobile phones can be handy when you need to contact a team member 
urgently.
The choice of communication mediums depends on the nature of the communication required, 
based on the team's location, availability, and urgency of the message. Project managers should 
choose the
most appropriate medium to ensure effective and efficient communication with their team.
Traditionally, in-person communication has been a preferred mode of communication for project 
managers.
Let's discuss some advantages of in-person communication.
Participants can gauge the reactions and feedback of other team members, making it easier to 
understand their needs and concerns.
Real-time interaction, like meetings, allows team members to work together synchronously and 
collaborate effectively.
Project managers receive immediate input and feedback from team members, making it easy to 
reach a consensus and make informed decisions.
In-person interactions can help build better relationships with team members by building rapport 
and trust, leading to a positive and productive work environment.
There can be challenges with in-person meetings as well.
These meetings can be time-consuming and expensive, especially if team members are in various 
parts of the world.
Coordinating the schedules of multiple team members can be challenging, leading to delays and 
rescheduling.
Environmental factors such as noise, distractions, and lack of privacy can also negatively impact the 
effectiveness of meetings.
Let's discuss the benefits of using electronic messaging, such as email and direct messaging.
Email programs like Outlook and Gmail and direct messaging such as Slack, Microsoft Teams, and
WhatsApp provide a record of communication that any stakeholder can refer to at a later point.
Electronic messaging can be sent and received from any location on multiple devices and are low-
cost.
Both email and direct messaging allow for swift and easy communication, making them ideal for
sending quick updates, asking questions, and receiving responses in close to real time.
Electronic messaging can free up time for more important tasks rather than wasting it while trying 
to coordinate in-person or face-to-face synchronous meetings.
On the downside of these applications, project managers should be careful not to overuse these 
tools.
Direct messages can distract team members from deep work, leading to reduced focus and 
decreased productivity.
Both applications can lead to miscommunication because it is difficult to indicate tone and body 
language.
If you start to notice misunderstandings during conversations using these mediums,
find another synchronous medium, such as a video conference or phone call to clarify.
The Covid-19 pandemic brought video and audio conferencing to the front and centre of 
communication tools for many businesses. This type of communication is called face-to-face and is 
also utilized for video-on remote meetings.
Face-to-face is the optimal method of communicating. Face-to-face allows project teams to better 
schedule and participate real-time in synchronous meets from any location. Synchronous
meets may also be virtual. Video and audio conferencing also can reduce travel costs.
While video and audio conferencing are great options, there are some downsides.
Technical issues such as poor internet connectivity, equipment problems, and software compatibility 
can impact the quality of communication.
Virtual conferencing, particularly audio-only, can lack in-person communication's personal 
connection and cues. External environmental distractions can impact the effectiveness of 
communication and collaboration.
Mobile phones can be handy when you need to contact a team member urgently. However, phone 
calls and text messaging should be used judiciously during off hours and reserved only for truly 
urgent needs.
Regarding all types of communication, it is also important to note that project managers must be 
aware of their team's work-life balance. They should know team member locations, work hours, 
and paid time off.
Let's consider the case of Jordyn and how she chooses to use different communication mediums
with her team. Her team's locations encompass several time zones. She uses Outlook calendars,
which show all of her team members availabilities. She often uses
face-to-face meetings with Zoom to share her screen and display information for the team. She 
emails the team the meeting materials to preview before a meeting. She asks her team members to 
collaborate synchronously on needs basis.

In this video, you learned that:
Mediums available to project managers include in-person,
electronic messaging, virtual conferencing, and mobile phones.
Each medium has advantages and disadvantages, and PMs should use the medium that 
maximizes its benefit and minimizes its challenges.
Project managers should be aware of their team's work-life balance.


Expert Viewpoints: What's the Most Effective 
Communication Media

Welcome to Expert Viewpoints: What's the Most Effective Communication Media?
In this video, experts and leaders will discuss their most effective communication media,
including their choice of when to use synchronous and asynchronous communications.
How do you decide when to use synchronous versus asynchronous communication mediums?
So, with asynchronous and synchronous different types of communication mediums,
it really depends if you need something to be done quickly, and it has to be in order.
So, during my project syncs, I only have 15 minutes with my team.
So, I want to make sure, I'm synchronous, and I'm just going through A, B, C, D:
"Is this done? Do we have any updates? Great! What's our next steps?"
Versus asynchronous, when we have a project call, and it's a working session,
then we want to allow for a lot more wiggle room, and it doesn't have to all be in order.
Synchronous and asynchronous communication. Got a lot to say on this one, folks.
So, I believe that synchronous and asynchronous communication
both definitely have their place,
but I do have a mug that says "This meeting could have been an e-mail"
and I try to take that very seriously when I'm deciding whether or not to set up a meeting.
And as project managers, when you're deciding to set up a meeting,
one of the things that you need to think about, as a good steward of the organization,
a good steward of your team's time, is that a one-hour meeting isn't just one hour.
If you have a team of 6 or a team of 10, and you call a one-hour meeting,
that's really costing your organization 6 to 10 man-hours of time
that somebody could be doing other work.
So, it's really important, again, as a steward of the organization, as steward of your team's time,
in protecting your team, to really analyse and see, "Does this situation require a meeting?"
Do I really need to call a meeting? If I do, how long does that meeting need to be?
Can we get things done in 15 minutes or half an hour instead of calling a full hour-long meeting?
And when I'm thinking about whether or not that's true, there's a couple questions that I ask myself.
So, is the matter extremely urgent?
I have a boundary and a practice where I will only respond to e-mails...
I will respond to e-mails within 24 hours.
Sometimes I respond sooner. But I respond to e-mails within 24 hours
and when I'm working on a team, I expect that same boundary from my team.
I don't expect instant replies back and forth.
Whether that's chat, e-mail, text I have a 24-hour rule.
so if a certain matter is extremely important, and it needs to be addressed
more quickly than 24 hours, then I think having synchronous communication methods:
So having a meeting, having a one-on-one, doing a quick phone call is very critical,
but if it's not that important or it's
not that urgent, and it can be responded to within 24 hours, then, of course, you can
use asynchronous methods of communication.
The other thing that I ask is, is the meeting extremely sensitive?
Is the matter extremely sensitive?
If you're dealing with a conflict, you're dealing with personnel issues or performance issues,
having an in-person conversation, or at least a video meeting, is probably your best option.
I use both synchronous and asynchronous communication every day.
Deciding which to use has actually become easier the further along I've gotten in my career.
Initially in my career, I did not have a lot of meetings,
and so I was in my inbox or in a chat system for most of the day.
Now, as I'm further in my career, I'm in meetings most of my day,
and I try to balance my early morning or late afternoon / early evening,
balance the meetings throughout the day with e-mail or chat during those times.
I am very particular about my e-mail inbox and my chats; and so,
I will have read every e-mail by the end of the day and I'll have responded where I need to.
I may not know the answer, but I'll say, "I've read your e-mail,
I should be able to get back to you tomorrow or when I know more."
Same with chats. Chats usually are a little bit more important,
and so I do try to reply to every chat during the day
with some sort of response other than, "I've seen this, and I'm thinking about it."
My nature is to learn more towards asynchronous
and so if I do find myself not having a lot of meetings
then I know that I may be defaulting to an asynchronous behaviour
when I should be getting meetings scheduled or getting on the phone and talking to people.
And then another good rule of thumb is
if you are in chat or if you are in e-mail and the threads have gone back and forth
a number of times; some people say three, some people say five
you'll want to pay attention to when;
but when the thread has gone back and forth without resolution,
or you can tell that there's confusion,
great time to pick up the phone and get people in a quick ad-hoc meeting,
talk it through and get to the decision or the answer that you need.


Effective Engagement

Welcome to "Effective Engagement."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Summarize the best practices for effective stakeholder engagement.
Understand the stakeholder mapping scenarios with power and interest.
Describe the gulf of execution and evaluation.
And explain the tailoring considerations for stakeholder engagement.
A critical component for the success of a project is stakeholder engagement.
A project manager can keep stakeholders engaged and involved by frequently communicating 
project
updates and new information to ensure everyone is on the same page.
A project manager must ensure the right stakeholders receive the appropriate engagement level.
Identifying and leveraging existing relationships and interests between stakeholders can be
used to establish communication.
Let's review some stakeholder engagement best practices, including:
Selecting the right communication medium, and
Categorizing stakeholders.
A best practice is to select the right communication medium.
For example, if a project manager sends emails to a stakeholder who prefers face-to-face
conversations, the engagement will not be effective.
Ensure to evaluate the communication medium preferences for all key stakeholders early
in the project.
Another best practice is to categorize stakeholders.
The Project Management Institute, or PMI, provides the power and interest model for
optimal engagement strategies for stakeholders in two categories.
PMI refers to this method as stakeholder mapping.
In the stakeholder mapping method, the two categories are:
Power is defined as the ability to influence the project, and
Interest is defined as the project's impact on the stakeholder engagement.
Let's review common stakeholder power and interest scenarios.
High Power/High Interest is a scenario where the project manager must manage stakeholders
closely and clearly define the project's information and benefits.
Stakeholders in this category may be sponsors or senior management.
In a High Power/Low Interest scenario, stakeholder satisfaction is essential to project success.
Ensure to provide periodic information and updates.
Examples of stakeholders in this scenario are high-level executives who are not deeply
involved in the project.
Low Power/High Interest is a scenario where stakeholders with responsibilities must be
satisfied and informed for the project's success.
For example, customers, operations, or end users who cannot necessarily influence the
project, but need to be heard are Low Power/High Interest stakeholders.
The Low Power/Low Interest scenario requires a project manager to frequently monitor 
stakeholders.
Be aware of stakeholders and look for any changes in behaviour or status.
We looked at a few power and interest scenarios.
Let's now look at a concept called gulf of execution and evaluation.
The gulf of execution and evaluation, or cognitive gulf, was described by Donald Norman in 
his 1988 book The Design of Everyday Things.
Norman referred to it as "the difference between people's intentions and their ability
to execute them."
Imagine this. A project manager may have confidence that what they want to accomplish can be 
accomplished via a certain communication medium, such as email.
However, email communication is not taken well as the stakeholder prefers face-to-face
meetings.
In this situation, a gap is created between the project manager's expectations and the
actual results they achieve.
This gap is referred to as the gulf.
The "gulf of execution" is the gap between what the user wanted to accomplish and the
results they achieved.
The "gulf of evaluation" differs between a system's response and the user's expectation.
The "gulf of evaluation" requires the project manager to evaluate why email was
ineffective and determine better execution moving forward.
A gap in the understanding of stakeholder preferences can create challenges for successful
engagement.
For a successful engagement, the project manager should understand the preferences.
For example, different people have different preferences.
A project manager must keep the audience in mind.
Another example is the right selection of communication medium.
Choose the communication medium based on the audience preference.
After understanding the audience preferences, make sure to tailor the engagement with 
stakeholders.
Tailoring stakeholder engagement is essential.
There are three critical tailoring considerations that the PMI lists including:
1-Make sure to evaluate the skills and capabilities of the project team.
2-Determine the level of empowerment team members will have based on the project, 
environment, and organization.
3-Implement external stakeholders into the team as projects may include external 
stakeholders such as vendors, partners, or consultants.

In this video, you learned that:
Best practices in stakeholder engagement are selecting the right communications medium
and categorizing stakeholders.
Stakeholder mapping scenarios based on power and interest include:
High Power/High Interest
High Power/Low Interest
Low Power/High Interest
Low Power/Low Interest
The "gulf of execution" is the gap between what the user wanted to accomplish and the
results they achieved.
The "gulf of evaluation" differs between a system's response and the user's expectation.


For a successful engagement:
Understand the preferences, and Tailor stakeholder engagement in terms of people, 
empowerment, and integration.


Cross Cultural Communications and 
Communications Channels

Welcome to "Cross Cultural Communications and Communications Channels."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Describe the impact of cultures on effective communications.
Explain how communication channels help in effective communication.
And describe the "grapevine."
Diversity is becoming predominant in any workforce. With diversity comes cultural differences, 
which can amplify communication differences.
A project manager needs to understand the challenges posed by culture and reduce the risk of 
ineffective project communications.
The Project Management Body of Knowledge acknowledges that culture can impact effective 
communications and references the "Browaeys and Price Cross-Cultural Communications 
Model."
The Browaeys and Price Cross-Cultural Communications Model divides the communication 
into two components:
frames of reference and communication blockers. Let's look at the components in detail.
Different individuals have naturally different frames of reference. An individual's frame of 
reference is impacted by their knowledge, experience, norms and values, and assumptions about 
business, people, and life. Cultural differences can amplify the differences in the natural frame 
of reference.
The second component in the "Browaeys and Price Cross-Cultural Communications Model" is 
cultural blockers, which can affect communication. There are several cultural blockers.
Language is a cultural blocker as it requires translation. There are times when the primary 
language of the individuals communicating is different.
Another cultural blocker is communication styles. Different people have different 
communication styles despite their cultures.
Stereotypes are another cultural blocker. Different cultures tend to stereotype others and 
assume everyone fits a single mould. Stereotypes can be damaging because they can lead to 
prejudice, ecological fallacies, and discrimination.
Another cultural blocker specified in the "Browaeys and Price Cross-Cultural Communications 
Model" is relationships. The level of your relationship can impact communications.
In some cultures, relationships and trust must be established before communications can be open.
To summarize the "Browaeys and Price Cross-Cultural Communications Model," different 
people have a diverse frame of reference. Compound this reality with the cultural realities of 
language, styles, stereotypes, and relationship factors, and you have a challenge.
The intended message sent may very well not be the message received.
Next, let's understand the concept of communication channels. PMI defines communications 
channels as the number of potential conversations that can occur.
There are four team members. In all, six potential conversations can take place.
Here is the formula to calculate the six channels for a four-person team.  
Stakeholder((Stakeholder-1)/2) =Channels.
Notice that the number of channels increases dramatically with only six team members.
Understanding the communication channels and how to calculate them will help project 
managers communicate effectively in a project.
Communication channel details are documented in the communications management plan,
which defines critical project communications items, and promptly provides information 
about using suitable mediums. The communications management plan helps the project manager 
ensure all stakeholders have the correct information about the project. The plan also ensures all 
channel members share accurate information.
A project manager must also be aware of the grapevine effect, which can be a potential risk to 
the project. "Grapevine" is how rumours spread. For example, rumours may spread if 
stakeholders and project team members do not have access to accurate and timely 
information. Again, a communications management plan mitigates the risk of the grapevine 
effect.

In this video, you learned that:
The message intended may not be the message received;
cultural blockers can affect communication.
PMI defines communications channels as the number of potential conversations that can 
occur.
The communications management plan must document the number of effective 
communication channels.
The "grapevine" is a term that shares how rumours spread.
A communications management plan mitigates the risk of misinformation.



 
Introduction to Failing Fast
Many people know Thomas Edison as the famous inventor of the modern light bulb. But did you 
know he also invented an electronic vote recorder, an electric pen, and an early home projector for 
viewing movies? Thomas Edison was a prolific inventor, but many were failures (at least at their 
onset). When he took the electronic vote recorder to congress, they told him they didn't want it. It is 
also believed that he failed many times when advancing the design of the lightbulb.
In traditional project management methodologies, project managers spend much time at the 
beginning of the project developing a project plan and defining a project scope that the team rigidly 
follows throughout the project's life. Modern project management methodologies follow an 
approach that is more focused on failing and learning fast. In this reading, you will explore what 
failing fast means, when you should take a fail-fast approach as a project manager, and what 
benefits a fail-fast approach can provide for your projects.
Failing and learning fast
As a project manager, you deliver high-quality projects that meet project objectives quickly. One 
strategy is to learn and change course as soon as you know something isn't working. In other words, 
fail fast. "Failing fast" is a concept that is often associated with agile software development, 
but it has broader applicability to many areas of business and life. At its core, "failing fast" 
means identifying failures and problems as early as possible in a project or process so that you 
can quickly pivot and adjust the course. The idea of failing fast is partially based on iterative 
development, which requires you to break projects down into small, manageable iterations. At 
the end of each iteration, the team evaluates progress and then adjusts plans as necessary. A project 
could shift or pivot completely depending on what is learned, and when implementing a fail-fast 
mindset, those pivots are encouraged. When working on a project as a project manager, you 
always manage time, resources, and budget constraints. The longer it takes you to realize that the 
feature your team is working on isn't one the customers want, that the materials that you are using 
cannot be used, or that the marketing strategy you're implementing isn't meeting objectives, the 
harder it is for you to manage those constraints. But the faster you can validate the features your 
team is building, start using a more durable material, or test your marketing message quickly, 
the easier it is to manage those constraints and see a return on investment.
Complex, uncertain, and fast-moving
A fail-fast approach is perfect for every project, and while all projects may find some benefit in 
failing fast and learning early, there are specific projects where a fail-fast approach would 
produce the most benefits.
Complex projects
Projects that involve multiple stakeholders, complex requirements, or dependencies on other 
projects or systems can benefit from a fail-fast approach. By breaking the project down into 
smaller, more manageable pieces, you can identify and address issues early and reduce the risk of 
project failure.
For example, developing a large-scale software application or platform, such as a social media 
platform or an e-commerce website, is complex. These projects involve multiple stakeholders, 
including software developers, user experience designers, product managers, and quality 
assurance specialists. Developing a large-scale software application or platform involves several 
stages, including requirements gathering, software design, development, testing, and deployment. 
These sorts of projects are perfect for a fail-fast approach where project managers and teams 
break the work into smaller iterations and aim to gather feedback from stakeholders and 
potential customers as early as possible during the project.
Uncertain projects
If a project has a high level of risk or uncertainty, a fail-fast approach can help you identify 
issues early and avoid costly mistakes. By building a minimum viable product (MVP) or 
conducting smaller experiments or pilots, you can test assumptions, identify risks, and validate 
solutions before investing too much time and resources.
A company expanding into a new country or market is an example of a high-risk project. Entering a 
new market often involves navigating cultural differences that can impact how a product or 
service is received, which may affect product features and marketing. There are also new legal 
and regulatory considerations and an established competitive landscape to manage. Using a fail-
fast approach when expanding into a new market allows project managers to develop and run 
tests to validate their product offering and messaging in a new market, quickly adapt to 
compliance and regulatory concerns, and see how established competitors react.
Fast-moving projects
Projects with tight timelines or deadlines or operating in rapidly changing environments can also 
benefit from failing fast. By being open to experimentation, breaking the project down into small 
parts, and pivoting based on feedback, you can adapt to changing conditions and increase the 
likelihood of project success.
Fast-moving projects may find a fail-fast approach beneficial, such as a company's shift to new 
artificial intelligence software to keep up with current trends. These projects often involve 
competitive and regulatory environments that change rapidly, and organizations may need to pivot 
quickly to keep up with new laws or customer requirements. Project managers can react quickly to 
these changes by using a fail-fast approach.
How to fail fast and learn
A fail-fast mentality is as much about learning as it is about failing. Here are some strategies that 
project managers can implement to fail fast while learning as much as possible.
•	Define clear objectives and metrics: Before beginning the project, define clear objectives 
and metrics for success to help the project team to stay focused on what matters and make 
data-driven decisions about which experiments and approaches to pursue.
•	Create a culture of experimentation: Encourage the project team to experiment and take 
risks. Celebrate failures as learning opportunities and encourage the team to share what they 
learned with others.
•	Test early and often: Begin testing early in the project and continue to test frequently 
throughout the project.
•	Measure and analyse results: Collect and analyse data on the results of each experiment 
and test. Data should be collected to provide insight into the defined objectives and metrics.
•	Focus on speed and efficiency: A fail-fast approach is about speed and efficiency. 
Encourage the project team to work quickly and efficiently and to focus on delivering results 
as soon as possible.
•	Encourage collaboration and communication: A failing fast approach requires 
collaboration and communication among the project team and with stakeholders. Encourage 
open and honest communication and foster a culture of transparency and trust.
•	Embrace feedback: A failing fast approach requires being open to feedback and using it to 
inform decisions and adjust the project plan and strategy. Encourage the project team to seek 
input from customers, partners, and other stakeholders and use this feedback to improve the 
project and its outcomes.
Conclusion
Project managers, and the organizations they work for, can benefit in many ways from taking a fail-
fast approach to their projects. They can identify failures and problems early on by failing fast and 
pivoting quickly to correct the course. While not the best for all projects, this approach is excellent 
for fast-moving, complex, and uncertain tasks. Project managers with a fail-fast mindset should 
make learning a top priority. To do this, they must define and measure clear objectives and 
metrics, embrace a culture of experimentation and testing early and often, and encourage 
collaboration, communication, and feedback.


When is Failing Fast Good?

Welcome to "When Is Failing Fast Good?"
After watching this video, you will be able to:
identify signs of a failing project,
and describe how failing fast can be an opportunity.
Over 60% of projects fail. The Project Management Institute, or PMI,
conducted a study concluding the five crucial areas where project failures occur, including:
Poor project selection and planning, when deadlines, budgets,
and resource limits are decided without consideration of reality.
Inconsistent sponsorship results from a lack of
engagement from the sponsor even after being informed.
Lack of scope definition awareness results in stakeholders adding elements to the scope.
Code green mentality, which is the situation when team leaders and members
only acknowledge or address problems and issues only once it is too late.
Lack of team commitment to support the project.
But how can a project manager identify if a project is moving
toward failure? Here are some warning signs to look out for.
One sign is that a project has several missed milestones and the project schedule is slipping.
Another sign is when the project is over budget.
A customer showing dissatisfaction or disinterest with the quality of
deliverables is also a warning sign.
Another warning sign that helps a project manager understand that
the project is moving towards failure is when team members and other stakeholders
exhibit burnout symptoms or a lack of commitment.
The project team losing confidence in the sponsor or vice versa is also a clear warning sign.
In addition, a warning sign is when there is a trend of
failed promises and a reduction in deliverables.
Small failures that seem to multiply into more significant ones are also something to look for.
The "failing fast" concept can help change a failing
project to a successful one before it is too late.
The failing fast approach can be implemented in certain situations,
such as when stakeholder agreements on deliverables is low,
project technical complexity is high, or the need for innovation is high.
Failing fast can be a learning opportunity. At the end of a project phase, identify what went well,
what can be improved, and the actions to take for improvement. Ensure the team shares their
experiences and uses the learning in the next phase of the project or in the next project.
Remember, effective communication can lead to real-time feedback that allows a project manager
to identify "fail fast" opportunities before they become major losses.

In this video, you learned that:
There are five crucial areas where project failures occur, including:
Poor project selection and planning,
Inconsistent sponsorship,
Lack of scope definition awareness
Code green mentality, and
Lack of team commitment.
There are different warning signs of a failing project, including:
Missed milestones and a slipping schedule
Project is over budget,
Customer dissatisfaction and disinterest in deliverables,
Team members and stakeholders exhibiting burnout symptoms,
Project team or sponsor losing confidence,
Failed promises, and
Increase in small failures.
Failing fast is a concept that helps projects go from failure to success.
Lessons learned should be conducted at the end of each project phase.


Key Project Roles
Many projects include individuals from several different roles, and each of these individuals may 
have a different communication style. As a project manager, part of your role will be to ensure that 
these different roles are able to communicate and collaborate effectively for the life of the project. 
In this reading, you'll briefly review some common project roles, learn about tools you can use to 
determine different communication styles, gain insight into some common communication styles, 
and learn how acknowledging other's communication styles can impact project success.
Review of Project Roles
Successful project managers understand that each role in a project plays a unique and important part 
in the project's success. To encourage collaboration and communication between stakeholders, it is 
important for project managers to understand the different responsibilities of each role. Some 
of the most common roles in projects include:
•	Sponsor
The sponsor is the person or group that provides the funding for the project. They are 
responsible for ensuring that the project aligns with the organization's goals and that it is completed 
within the allocated budget.
•	Product Owner
The product owner is responsible for defining the product vision and ensuring that it aligns 
with the organization's goals. They work closely with the development team to prioritize features 
and ensure that the product meets the needs of the stakeholders.
•	Scrum Master (Team Facilitator)
The scrum master is responsible for ensuring that the development team follows the agile 
methodology and scrum framework. They facilitate the daily scrum meetings, remove any 
obstacles that may be blocking progress, and ensure that the team is staying on track. Note: PMI 
refers to a Scrum Master as a Team Facilitator.
•	Business Analyst
The business analyst is responsible for analyzing the organization's needs and identifying 
areas where the project can help to meet those needs. They work closely with the product owner 
and the development team to ensure that the product meets the business requirements.
•	Core Team Members The core team members are the individuals who are responsible 
for completing the project. They include developers, designers, testers, and other 
specialists who are needed to build and deliver the product.
As a project manager, it is important to ensure that all of these roles are working together 
effectively, and managing the collaboration and communication of the different roles involved 
in a project is crucial to its success.
In a predictive project, the "Project Team" consists of the project manager, core team, and 
extended team. In an adaptive project, the team consists of the product owner, scrum master, 
and development team.
How to determine communications styles
People communicate in different ways, and understanding these communication styles is essential 
for effective collaboration. One way to determine communication styles is by using surveys, 
such as I-speak, MBTI, Emergenetics, and Insights. Look at each of these surveys and how they 
can help identify communications styles.
I-Speak Survey
The I-speak survey is a tool that helps individuals understand their communication style by 
measuring four components: Thinker, Senser, Feeler, and Intuitor.
MBTI
The Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI) is a personality assessment tool that helps 
individuals understand their preferences and tendencies. The tool identifies four different 
dichotomies that describe a person's preferences, including extraversion vs. introversion, sensing 
vs. intuition, thinking vs. feeling, and judging vs. perceiving.
Emergenetics
Emergenetics is a tool that helps individuals understand their thinking and behavioural 
preferences. The survey identifies four different thinking attributes and three behavioural 
attributes, which can help individuals understand how they communicate and interact with others.
Insights
Insights is a tool that helps individuals understand their communication style and how to 
communicate effectively with others. The survey identifies four colour energies that represent 
different communication styles: fiery red, sunshine yellow, earth green, and cool blue.
By taking these surveys, individuals can identify their strengths and weaknesses and learn how 
to adapt their communication style to better communicate with others.
Different types of communication styles
Since understanding the communication styles of team members can help you communicate more 
effectively with the team and improve collaboration, it is important for you to understand some 
common communication types. In each of the surveys above, the names of the communication 
styles differ, but the concepts are similar.
Thinking vs. Feeling
The thinking and feeling dimensions refer to how individuals make decisions and judgments. 
People who score high on the thinking dimension tend to make decisions based on logical analysis 
and objective facts. On the other hand, people who score high on the feeling dimension tend to 
make decisions based on their personal values and emotional responses. These dimensions can 
also be known as analytical vs. social.
Sensing vs. Intuiting
The sensing and intuition dimensions refer to how individuals perceive and process information. 
People who fall on the sensing dimension tend to process information through their five senses and 
rely on concrete, tangible information. On the other hand, people who are strong intuits tend to 
process information through patterns and connections and rely on abstract concepts and 
ideas.
Assertiveness
All of these communication styles surveys measure assertiveness as a component of 
communication. Assertiveness refers to the degree to which individuals express their opinions 
and ideas. Some individuals may be more assertive and direct, while others may be more reserved 
and indirect in their communication style.
Flexibility
Flexibility refers to the degree to which individuals can adjust their communication style to fit 
the situation and the person they are communicating with. All of these surveys measure 
flexibility, or versatility, as a component of communication. Some individuals may be more 
versatile and adaptable in their communication style, while others may be more rigid and inflexible.
It is important to note that no communication style or personality type is better than another. 
Depending on the project, or situation, some communication styles may be more preferred than 
others. It is also important to note that these characteristics exist on a spectrum, and many people 
fall somewhere in between. For example, this can mean that while typically, a person may be more 
intuitive, in certain circumstances they may process information using their senses and the data that 
is available to them.
How to acknowledge other's communication styles for maximum impact
As a project manager, understanding the communication styles of team members can help you 
communicate more effectively with the team and improve collaboration. The following are some 
ways that a project manager can use the results from communication styles surveys to communicate 
more effectively and improve collaboration:
Adjust Your Communication Style
By understanding the communication styles of team members, project managers can adjust their 
communication style to better fit the preferences of team members. For example, if a 
stakeholder prefers more data to make a decision, you may need to present more data to reach 
a decision.
Adapt Your Leadership Style
Different communication styles may require different leadership styles. Some team members may 
require more detailed instructions, while others may prefer more autonomy. Understanding the 
communication styles of team members can help project managers adapt their leadership style to 
better suit the team's needs.
Encourage Open Communication
Encourage open communication by creating an environment where team members feel comfortable 
expressing their thoughts and ideas, no matter what their communication style is. Project managers 
can create an inclusive space where team members feel heard and valued. This is especially 
important for team members who may be less assertive, particularly during meetings. As a 
project manager, you can invite them to participate during the conversation, or you can encourage 
them to participate in other ways after the meeting.
Foster Team Collaboration
Understanding the communication styles of team members can also help project managers foster 
team collaboration. By understanding the strengths and weaknesses of team members, project 
managers can assign tasks that align with each team member's strengths.
Provide Communication Training
Communication styles surveys can also identify areas where team members may need additional 
communication training. Project managers can provide training to team members to help them 
communicate more effectively with each other. Understanding communication styles can also 
help when you are giving reviews.
Conclusion
When you understand the roles and responsibilities of the people on your projects and their 
unique communication styles, you can foster effective communication and collaboration. By 
using communication style and personality type surveys, you can learn more about the team 
and your stakeholders and acknowledge those communication preferences for maximum 
impact on your projects.

Project Role Identification: RACI
A project manager must ensure each team member has assigned roles and responsibilities that meet 
their skill sets and disposition whenever possible. A best practice is to develop a condensed 
stakeholder register for the team. RACI, which is an abbreviation for Responsible, Accountable, 
Consult, and Inform is a tool that helps with assigning responsibilities to team members. The table 
below is an example of a condensed stakeholder register.
Team Member Name
Assigned Role
RACI
Ram
Project Manager
RACI
Priya
Core Team Budget Lead
RACI
Sam
Core Team Budget Support
RC
Maurice
IT Technical Liaison
C
Hideki
Sponsor
AI
The project manager sets the level of responsibility using the RACI designators. These include:
R: Responsible
Any team member who has assigned tasks should be assigned an "R" role.
A: Accountable
The Accountable team member is responsible for the quality of the product regardless of their 
responsibility to create it.
Note: There should be only one accountable individual per role. For example, in the table above, 
while Priya and Sam are core team members working on the project budget, only Priya is 
Accountable for the core budget. There can only be one lead.
C: Consult
Any team member who is a technical advisor to the project can be assigned "C."
Note: The team members may or may not have additional responsibilities.
I: Inform
Any team member who needs to be informed on certain communications does not need to be 
assigned an "I" responsibility. Limit the information flow.
The project manager must ensure the team participates in RACI planning and agrees on their roles. 
People and positions may change on a project. It is, therefore, important that the project manager 
must update the RACI as the project progresses.

Expert Viewpoints: Working Together as a 
Team

Welcome to Expert Viewpoints: Working Together as a Team.
In this video, we experts and leaders will share their insights into how project managers gain the
cooperation of multiple roles and responsibilities and encourage people to work together.
In order to have order, technically, with all stakeholders and team members, we need to make sure 
to really grab their cooperation at the beginning of a project. So, of course, we set the expectation 
this is what your weeks are going to look like.
If you pre-schedule, it'll actually help them out to understand what the expectations are and plan 
around your meetings, with that, have successful team meetings. So, when you go to meet with 
everyone, whether it's an actual sync or working session, make sure they are organized, and 
everybody knows what they're going to be doing during those. Have successful follow-ups along 
with next steps. When you have consistency like that, you have a great, organized team.

So there's three things that come to mind right away. One is really work on your communication
skills. Clear, concise communication of facts, of accurate information, of accurate requests.
Don't ask questions that you already know the answer to to prove that you know the answer. That 
can be a real turn-off for some people in your project team.
Also, look and pay attention to what you're taking on. I think there can be a tendency for project 
managers to take on too much and sometimes tasks that somebody else in the project should be 
doing. And you don't want to be in a situation where you over-promise and then under-deliver. That 
may happen just through the nature of the project, but if you start getting a reputation for over-
promising and under-delivering then people are going to avoid wanting--people are going to avoid 
hearing your commitments, or they're not going to trust that you'll actually deliver on what it is that 
you're committing to.
Another tip for building rapport is, ask for feedback. It doesn't have to be on every project. It doesn't 
have to be on every task within a project. Somewhere in between.
You know you don't want to bug people all the time saying, "tell me how I can be better. Tell me 
how I'm going to do better." But when you do ask for feedback, be sincere about it. Be willing to 
improve based on the information that you're hearing. It should be constructive feedback that you're 
receiving, and you should be willing to listen to it, internalize it, reflect on it, and then decide if 
there's any changes that you need to make.
Hearing how other people perceive you through their feedback helps you build a relationship
with those people because then you can kind of tailor your style to better meet their needs.

First of all, define the roles and responsibilities based on the project's needs. As the project manager, 
ask the team, "Who do we need? What do we need? What skill sets are required? What subject 
matter expertise is going to be required?"
Come up with a list of personal resources or personnel resources that you require.
Time is close to that frame time.
Step number two, take this list of these are the people that I need to the sponsor.
Try to fill each position with a name. Step number three. We have our names now assigned to the 
roles and responsibilities. Try to meet with each individual. Face-to-face is wonderful. However, it's 
2023, a virtual environment sometimes is required. Ensure each individual understands their role 
and responsibilities. Make sure that they are willing to commit to support the project, and make sure 
that they have the capacity to do so.
So, if, for whatever reason, step number four, some personnel assignments may not work out, then 
identify the disconnects from the prior step. Share with the sponsor, with the key stakeholders,
with the managers that, unfortunately, your suggestion for this individual for this role may not work 
out. Negotiate. Do whatever you can to perhaps find someone new. Someone who can support this 
particular role and responsibility and then move forward.
Once you have all of the faces committed and you have all of the positions filled, finalize your 
stakeholder register and your resource management plan.
Periodically check in and address issues.
The final question in this segment that I want to address is how do you encourage people in various 
roles to work together? Well, first and foremost, ensure all of the stakeholders understand the value 
of the project, no matter how dedicated, no matter how motivated a stakeholder may be, if they 
don't see value in a project, the chances are pretty good that their motivational level is going to be 
very, very low. Secondly, ensure everyone has a clear understanding of their roles and 
responsibilities. Avoid duplication of effort. One of the worst things that you can do,
is to assign one stakeholder one role and then duplicate that with another. They're going to
be bumping into each other. There's going to be friction. There's going to be problems.
There's going to be chaos. There's going to be frustration. There's going to be unhappiness.
Thirdly, make sure that you develop a vision for your team, and at your first meeting, develop a tool 
called a team charter. This is where the team gets together, they brainstorm, document, and you gain 
consensus on ground rules, norms, and acceptable behavior that the team will commit to follow and 
hold others accountable to.

Module 2 Summary: Effective 
Communications Building Blocks

At this point in the course, you know:
•	Planning is essential to have effective conversations. It will help you get the most out of 
your conversations. Effective conversations are important for the entire team. Project 
managers should continually remind the team of their importance from the beginning of the 
project until the end.
•	Effective communication enables project managers to build trust, resolve conflicts, 
provide clear direction, and keep everyone aligned during the lifecycle of a project. Be 
it any form of communication, a project manager must learn to use clear and concise 
language and tailor conversation to different audiences.
•	A project manager must possess and practice different skills to design and implement 
effective communication.
•	Use synchronous communication for real-time conversations and asynchronous 
communication when the message needs to be carefully crafted when communicating 
with a larger group or if an immediate reply is not necessary.
•	Communication mediums available to project managers include in-person, electronic 
messaging, virtual conferencing, and mobile phones. A project manager should assess the 
pros and cons of each medium and select the medium that best suits a scenario.
•	Make sure to select the right communications medium and categorize stakeholders 
accurately. Different communication strategies must be implemented based on different 
power/interest scenarios. The gulf of execution and gulf of evaluation help understand 
the gaps in execution and measure the level of accomplishment. Effectively use 
communication channels and ensure the "grapevine" does not become the norm.
•	Failing fast is an approach that can help turn projects from failure to success. A key 
strategy in this approach is to conduct lessons-learned meetings at the end of each phase and 
the project.

project to fit the specific needs and 
conditions of the project

communication

information, provide instructions, and
