Project Management 
Communication Skills


 
Key Tool - Critical Path Method
A project manager's main goal is to successfully complete a project. To accomplish the goal, a 
project manager must address various aspects of the project, including resources, people 
skills, budgets, and different expectations. A project manager can use different tools and 
techniques to plan a project with all aspects in mind successfully. One such technique is the critical 
path method.
Several activities or tasks in a project together form the longest sequence that a project team must 
complete on time to ensure the successful completion of the project. The longest sequence is 
referred to as the critical path. A delay in any activity in the critical path can result in an 
overall delay in the project.
Using the critical path method, the project manager can determine the potential early start and 
early finish days and the potential late start and late finish days for a project. In this method, a 
project manager creates a visual of the different activities or tasks in the project. The project 
manager aims to determine the longest sequence of tasks along with the latest finish day. Here 
is an illustration of a completed Critical Path analysis.
 
 
Figure 1 Project Network Diagram
Key Terms Associated with Critical Path Method
The critical path method uses the following symbol to calculate a critical path for a project.
  
Let's look at the definitions for each of the terms.
•	Early Start (ES): The earliest time that a task can be started in the project. Make sure to 
understand the dependencies before adding this time.
•	Late Start (LS): The very last minute in which the project manager can start a task before it 
threatens to delay the project schedule.
•	Early Finish (EF): The earliest time when a task can be finished, depending on the duration 
and the earliest time when the task can start.
•	Late Finish (LF): The latest time when a task can be completed, based on its duration and 
its latest start time.
•	Slack/Float: A term that describes how long the project task can be delayed before it 
impacts other activities in the sequence and the project schedule. Note that any task on the 
critical path will have zero float because the task cannot be delayed.
Benefits of using the critical path method
•	The critical path method allows the project manager to determine work packages on 
the critical path. A project manager must manage these packages carefully. Any schedule 
slip on any critical path work package will result in a project schedule slip.
•	Work packages on non-critical paths have built-in flexibility. If hard-pressed, we can 
delay completion or borrow or "crash" resources from the non-critical path to keep the 
critical path on schedule.
•	Be careful when you crash. If you use too much slack or float, the non-critical path may 
become a new critical one.

Demo: Critical Path Method

Hello everyone and welcome to a demonstration on the Critical Path method.
Let's begin by defining the purpose of the critical path method.
Critical Path Method is a popular project management scheduling technique.
It determines the theoretical early start and early finish days and/or the theoretical late start and late 
finish days for a project.
Critical path is defined as the path of the longest duration in a project network diagram.
Here is a symbol that you want to familiarize yourself with if you are going to conduct a critical 
path analysis.
Let's begin with an overview of key acronyms that you want to understand.
ES stands for Early Start.
This is the earliest that the work package can begin.
EF stands for early finish.
This is the earliest that the work package can finish.
A work package is similar to an activity;
I'll use the term "work package" throughout this demonstration.
The duration is the time that is going to be required between the early start and the early finish.
The late start is the latest that a work package can begin and the late finish is the latest that it can 
finish.
If there is a difference between the early finish and the late finish, we have something called slack 
or float.
If there is no difference between the early finish, late finish or the early start and late start, then we 
have no slack or float.
There are two processes that need to be completed to complete a critical path analysis.
The first is called a forward pass.
For a forward pass, we're going to determine the early start and the early finish for each work 
package.
We're going to move left to right, from the early start to the early finish, for each particular work 
package in sequence.
We will complete all of the paths.
Once we do this, we can determine the path of the longest duration, which is the critical path.
The second procedure we're going to perform is a backwards pass.
The backwards pass helps us to determine the late start and the late finish.
In this particular case, we're going to move from back to front, right to left.
We're going to begin with each work package's late finish, and we're going to move to the late start.
Very important, complete the critical path first.
If you do not create, if you do not complete the critical path first, then your results may be 
erroneous.
Once we complete the critical path, then we're going to complete the non-critical path, from the 
longest path to the shortest.
So with that, let's go ahead and take a look at an example.
And we're going to begin with a forward pass.
Again, a forward pass; we're going to determine the early start and the early finish for each of our 
work packages.
Let's begin with Path A, D, and G.
We begin with day number one.
This is a three-day duration work package.
So, what is the early finish? 1, 2, 3.
We go to work package D and we add one day.
We begin work package D the following day.
We ended A on day three; we begin D on day four.
This is three days in duration: 4, 5 and 6.
So, now we have our early finish of day number six.
We're completing PATH A-D-G, so we move forward to work package G and we go to the next day 
for the early start, day number seven.
This is four days in duration: 7, 8, 9, 10.
And now, we have the time frame required to complete A, D, and G: ten days.
Now we still have A, D, and E.
We've already calculated A and D.
However, E follows D, so therefore,
we ended D the early finish on day six. So, the early start is going to be day seven.
This is a five-day duration work package 7, 8, 9, 10, and 11.
So now we have the early finish for Path A, D, and E; 11 days.
A little bit longer than A, D, and G, which was ten days.
We now have one final forward pass to complete; Path B, C, and F.
So, we're going to begin on day number one with our early start for the first work package, B.
three days in duration one, two, and three for our early finish.
We begin the next day for our early start for our work package C, day number four.
This is a longer duration work package; Seven days, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9 and 10. So, our early finish is 
day number ten.
The next in sequence is work package F, we add one day for the early start: day number 11. Six day 
duration: 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, and 16.
We now know that Path B, C and F is going to require 16 days.
And we've learned something very important: which is the path of the longest duration?
Which is the critical path?
The critical path is BCF, 16 days.
This project is going to require 16 days.
Now we need to go ahead and perform a backwards pass.
So, to perform a backwards pass, the first thing you need to do is to put the critical path duration
as the late finish for all of the final work packages in each particular path.
For ADG, we're going to go ahead and put the late finish at 16
For ADE we're going to put the late finish at 16.
And we're going to do the same for BCF.
Now, remember, for a backwards pass, the rule is we always begin with the critical path,
and we determined through our forward pass that BCF is the critical path, 16 days.
So, we begin with day number 16 and the late finish, but now we're going to work backwards.
This is six days in duration, so we have to subtract: 16, 15, 14, 13, 12 and 11.
We put the number 11 for 11 days in the late start.
Now, we're going to go backwards one day.
This is a backwards pass.
So, for work package C in the late finish, we put in ten.
This is seven days in duration; we count back seven days. 10, 9, 8, 7, 6, 5, and 4
And we place four in the late start.
Minus one day as we move backwards to work package B, Day number three, three days in 
duration. Countdown three, two and one.
Now, let's take a look at what we have completed for BCF. Every box is filled.
We want to compare the early finish and the late finish and see if there is a difference, in this 
particular case, there is no difference.
The early finish is 16 days. The late finish is 16 days.
When we subtract this, we end up with zero.
Let's validate by doing the same for the early start and the late start.
Is there any difference between 11 and 11?
The answer is no; we put zero in this box, which is the slack or the flow.
What do we mean by that?
It means that the early finish and late finish are the same as the early start and the late start;
We have no slack. We have no flow. This is the critical path.
We validate work package C: 10, 10. 4, 4. No difference. Zero flow and slack.
Work package B: 3, 3. 1, 1. No flow, no slack, zero.
Now, very important, which is the path of the next-longest duration?
That is A, D, and E.
So now we're going to do the same methodology.
We put 16 days, which is our critical path, in the late finish,
and we're going to subtract backwards five days, which is the duration,16, 15, 14, 13, and 12.
We put the 12 in the late start.
But now let's notice something very important:
There is a difference between the early finish and late finish of five days.
There is a difference between the early start and late start
of five days.
We put the five in this particular box; the slack and the flow.
What do we mean by that?
It means the earliest we can start work package E is day 7. The latest we can start it is day 12.
We have a little bit of leeway in terms of when we need to start this work package
for it to be completed by day number 16,
ADE are connected on a singular path.
We go day number 12 and then we go to D, which is the work package which precedes E
and we subtract one day, day number 11, subtract three, 11, 10 and 9.
Again, we have that difference.
6 compared to 11, 4 compared to 9.
We have float/slack of five days.
We subtract one day from D to calculate work package A, that's day number eight.
Subtract three, 8, 7, 6.
Again, we have that difference of five
between the late finish and early finish and the late start and the early start; we have float and slack 
of five days.
This leaves us with one final activity for the backwards pass--and why do we save it for last?
Because 10 is less than 11 and far less than 16.
So, we do the same methodology. The late finish gets 16 days. This is four days in duration.
Let's count backwards four days. 16, 15, 14, 13.
And now we can go ahead and take a look at the difference between the early finish and the late 
finish and the early start and the late start, and this is six days.
So, for our work package, G, we have the most flow and the most slack.
We have a six-day window in which we can go ahead and plan our early start or late start
to still complete this worst case scenario, by 16 days, which is our critical path.
This concludes our overview of this demo.
Hopefully, critical path analysis makes a little bit more sense to you.
We hope that you're able to go ahead and apply what you learned in a lab that we have planned for 
you, where you will take a look at a scenario and develop and perform a critical path analysis.
Thank you for your attention. Have a great rest of your day, and we look forward to seeing you 
again in future presentations and demos.

Critical Chain Method

Welcome to "Critical Chain Method."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Define critical chain method.
Describe the steps involved in developing a schedule using critical chain method.
Define differences between critical chain and critical path methods.
And identify when to use critical chain method.
Imagine this: You're part of a 4 by 200 meter relay race.
The exercise is simple:
Run the 200 meters, pass the baton to the next person, and
follow the process till the last person completes their 200 meters.
During this time, several things might happen.
For example, a runner may fall, slow down, or increase their speed.
The goal is to continue to hand off the baton until every runner has reached the end line.
At the beginning of the race, the team may take the time
to select the runners and understand their dependencies during the race, such as the track, weather, 
shoes, and so on.
In addition, a runner only runs or passes the baton at a given point in time.
They cannot perform both actions at the same time.
The team plans for resource shortages; they have an extra runner on board, just in case.
The team also plans for time delays.
They practice the baton exchange and allocate extra time for the exchanges in case of an exchange 
issue.
They never lose sight of their goal.
They want to finish the race as quickly as possible and win.
The critical chain method is similar to a relay race.
The critical chain method is a project management technique that emphasizes the resources such as 
as people, equipment, supplies, materials, and physical space required to execute project tasks.
Critical chain was developed as an alternative to the critical path method.
When using the critical chain method, project managers plan project schedules with a focus 
on resource and time constraints.
The project manager identifies the longest sequence of resource-dependent activities.
The sequence is referred to as the critical chain.
The project manager includes buffers to protect the critical chain from resource shortages 
and delays and to ensure that the project is completed on time.
At a high level, developing a critical chain can be divided into four steps.
The first step is identifying the different activities and creating a network diagram.
Identify the paths, including the critical path.
In the network diagram displayed, path EFG is the critical path.
Paths AB and CD are required activities to complete the project, But they're not on the critical path.
The second step is determining the potential for resource shortages or issues on the non-critical 
paths.
Add extra resources in anticipation of resource risks materializing.
Ensure resource issues do not delay the non-critical paths to the point where the critical path is 
jeopardized.
These are called resource buffers.
The next step is to add feeding buffers, which add extra time to the non-critical paths.
Feeding buffers assume that extra time or float will likely disappear.
For example, let's say the critical path EFG is 14 days.
Path AB is scheduled for ten days.
A feeding buffer is placed on path AB to plan for 12 days.
If the work is completed in 10 days, great!
However, there is a possibility of risks occurring.
Therefore, plan for 12 days.
Remember, resource buffers also help in ensuring delays are minimal.
This step is performed with each path.
The last step is to plan for the worst-case scenario.
In this example, the critical path EFG will take 14 days.
Resources and time have been added to the non-critical paths
to ensure they are not delayed to the point where the critical path is impacted.
But what if the critical path activities are delayed?
To address this scenario, add a project buffer at the end of the project.
Let's say this is 2 days.
In this case, at a worst-case scenario, the project will complete in 16 days.
This completes the overview of the steps in the critical chain method.
Critical chain method is similar to critical path method However, there are a few key differences 
between critical path methodology and critical chain methodology; these include:
Critical path methodology assumes that the length of tasks and their dependencies are the major 
constraints, while critical chain methodology assumes that resources are a project's major 
constraint.
Critical path methodology simply defines the amount of slack or float for each activity, while 
critical chain methodology adds resource buffers between tasks and adds additional time buffers at 
the end of a project if needed.
Because of these differences, when using critical path methodology, project teams can be working 
on multiple project tasks at a time, whereas with critical chain methodology, project teams focus on 
one critical task at a time before they're able to move onto another.
Critical path methodology and critical chain methodology are both project management planning 
techniques, but they have different approaches and applications.
You should use critical path methodology when the project is well-defined, there's a high level of 
certainty in the task duration and resource availability, and the project is relatively simple, with a 
straightforward sequence of tasks.
For example, planning an event with a clear sequence of tasks and a fixed timeline.
You should use critical chain methodology when the project is complex and uncertain, there are 
significant risks and variability, and the availability of resources is limited, or resources are shared 
across multiple projects.
For example, researching and developing a new pharmaceutical drug.
In this video, you learned that:
Critical chain method adds the availability of resources and their dependencies while determining 
the minimum time required to complete the project.
There are four key steps in the critical chain method.
Critical path methodology is best for well-defined projects, while critical chain methodology is best 
for uncertain projects.

Key Tool - Communications Management Plan

Welcome to "Key Tool: Communications Management Plan."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Summarize the purpose of a communications management plan.
Describe the components of a communications management plan.
Project Management Institute, or PMI, states that communications impact 90% of all project
management activities. This shows effective communication is key to project success.
The PMI recommends using a communications management plan to ensure communication for the 
project is organized and effective.
A communications management plan provides the overall strategy to describe how best to 
communicate with each other and communicate responsibilities based on project requirements.
The project manager must create the communications management plan during project planning and 
frequently update the plan as the project progresses.
The PMI provides some input into the process of a communications management plan. Let's look at 
some of the purposes.
Every project has its communication requirements. For example, a software development 
project may have very different communication requirements than a job modernization project from 
the HR department. The project manager will need to develop and tailor the communications 
management plan to support the information needs of each stakeholder or group of stakeholders and 
the overall project.
Creating a communications management plan gives the overall communication process a 
documented structure. A communications management plan aids in creating a positive 
communication rhythm for the project. For example, when a team member knows precisely where 
to find a report and when to publish the report, communication is more efficient and effective 
communication.
A communications management plan provides guidance on communication at different levels. This 
guidance helps each stakeholder to identify the right people, the right time, and the right content 
level for communication.
The result of this understanding is that each project stakeholder can effectively and efficiently 
engage with other stakeholders by promptly presenting relevant information.
For example, during an internal status meeting, a project manager may need to go into all the 
minute details of the project. However, with a sponsor, the level of detail may need to be at a macro 
level focusing only on the completion percentage.
We discussed the purpose of having a communications management plan. A communications
management plan template is normally available in either Microsoft Word or Excel.
The PMI states that a communications management plan should have certain components. 
Let's see the components of a communications management plan.
The communications management plan must have a project name to map the plan with the 
correct project title.
You can add different communications items. A communications item represents a type of
communication. Examples include status meetings, budget meetings, change boards, and so on.
Each communications item must have an associated:
Owner: Identifies the project team member responsible for managing the communications item.
Audience: Describes the project team members and stakeholders who will receive the 
communication. Ensure to select the right people.
Timing: Sets a schedule for the communications item. For example, weekly status meetings will
occur every Wednesday from 11:00 AM to 11:30 AM. Manage exceptions on need basis.
Format or Medium: Determines how the team needs to conduct the communications item. For 
example, face-to-face meetings, virtual meetings, emails, and so on.
Purpose: Identifies the need for the communications item. For example, a weekly status meeting 
aims to review the current project status, understand potential issues, and answer any open 
questions.
The communications management plan is frequently updated. It is a good idea to maintain the 
version number and date of change to maintain version control.

In this video, you learned that:
A communications management plan:
Is created during project planning and frequently updated, supports the information needs of a 
project, provides communication strategy for the project, aids in positive communications rhythm,
and helps identify the right people, time, and content level for communication. The components of 
a communication management plan include the project name, communications item details, 
version, and date.
The communications items details include item description, owner, audience, timing, format or 
medium, and purpose.


Business Analyst Communication 
Requirements
Objective
•	Differentiate between the communications requirements of a Business Analyst compared to 
a Project Manager
Communication requirements for a Business Analyst 
vs. Project Manager
The Business Analyst and the project manager must work closely together to plan and implement 
the project to benefit the organization. The Communications Management Plan should include the 
Business Analyst as a key stakeholder, and in some cases, may lead communications item activities.
A Business Analyst focuses on ensuring that the right requirements are defined before the Project 
Charter is developed. The project manager is presented with requirements by the Business Analyst 
and communicates with stakeholders to execute the solution.
The Business Analyst has specific communication responsibilities. These include:
•	Lead collaboration with key stakeholders to identify problems and opportunities, assess the 
current product state, determine an acceptable future state, and brainstorm viable options. 
The project manager is often a participant in these conversations.
•	Facilitate the development of product roadmaps and business cases that will drive future 
programs and projects.
•	Assist the project manager in developing project charters and preparing pre-baseline 
presentations to sponsors to gain approval.
•	Assist the project manager in identifying and analysing stakeholders to determine an optimal 
communications approach.
•	Lead business analysis planning activities and assist the project manager in developing a 
project transition plan.
•	Determine the best requirements elicitation approach, prepare for and conduct elicitation, 
and confirm elicitation results.
•	Determine requirements analysis approaches and applicable models to use, support the 
project manager during requirements prioritization activities, and assist in risk identification 
and management.
•	Develop a Traceability Matrix that defines the product development stages and allows the 
project manager to ensure they communicate effectively with all key stakeholders.
•	Assist the project manager in developing a change management process to manage changes 
to requirements and other products.
•	Assist the project manager in determining project performance evaluation and acceptance 
criteria.
Conclusion
Business Analysts and project managers work as a team to ensure project success. Together they 
ensure that the right products are identified, planned, executed, and delivered to address 
organizational problems and achieve opportunities.


Demo: Communications Management Plan

Hello, everyone.
I'd like to go ahead and take a few moments and present a brief demo on a communications
management plan.
A communications management plan is a formal part of a project management plan,
and the intent of a communications management plan is to provide a roadmap for all project
communications,
to ensure that communications gets to the right person at the right time in the right
amount.
According to the Project Management Institute, a communications management plan should have
an introduction. As you can see,
we have the communications plan for a two-day all hands event.
This is just an example.
Always try to define the project, because there may be multiple projects and multiple 
communications
management plans.
A communication management plan has six areas that need to be populated.
The first area is what we refer to as the communications item, sometimes called the
forum.
This is what you are communicating.
As you can see on this particular example, we have three that are highlighted: the weekly
project status meeting,
the sponsor one-on-one meeting and the Weekly Project Status Report.
We have some others as well:
A Change Control Board, Vendor Source Selection, Conference Room Presentation.
So, the first step in developing the communications plan is step number one, define the required
communication items. As the project manager,
enlist the support of your core team and try to determine what needs to be communicated
and populate this first column.
The second step is to determine the owners.
Every communication item should have a specific owner who is responsible for planning and
implementing that particular line item.
In this particular case, the weekly project status meeting is going to be owned by Sanjay
Randall.
Sanjay is going to be the individual who is empowered to go ahead and plan and implement
and ensure that the weekly project status meeting happens.
We have others as well.
We have Roger Jones, who is going to be the sponsor one-on-one meeting the weekly project
status report.
By the way, a sponsor one on one meeting is a best practice.
It is a very, very good thing for the project manager to meet periodically with the sponsor
and have conversations about status and other key areas as well.
The third step in developing the communication plan, as you can see over in my green column
here, is to determine the audience.
Here's a little bit of a tip.
Everyone who's on the stakeholder register should be included in this communications
plan.
If you have someone on the stakeholder register who was identified having a role and responsibility
and they're not on this plan,
you may want to question why you have them on the stakeholder register and why you are
assigning them a role and responsibility if you're not going to communicate with them.
Not communicating with people on the stakeholder register,
to use a colloquialism, is an accident waiting for a place to happen.
Step number four determine the timing.
When are we going to go ahead and implement this particular communications item?
Some may be weekly.
Some may be two times each week.
Some may be just a one time, such as the vendor source selection.
Ensure that you understand how often this communications line item needs to occur and
document it in the fourth column.
The next is to complete the medium.
What medium are we going to go ahead and use?
And in terms of where are we going to meet?
As you can see, in some cases, we have a location, the main conference room, Sarah's office.
In other cases, we may actually have a technology such as SharePoint as well.
So sometimes we don't meet individually or in an office.
We meet electronically using SharePoint.
Always and with a purpose as well.
It's very, very important that all of the individuals who are going to be receiving
information as part of this communications plan have an understanding of the purpose,
why this is important as well.
So, once you have completed all six of these items and you have defined the project title
on the top of the plan, go to step number five,
validate the plan with the audience, have a meeting with all of these audience members.
Let them know what the expectations are.
Don't surprise them by sending them communications items without some kind of a heads up as 
well.
Ensure you get some kind of verbal signoff from each one in the audience, that they understand
what the communication line item is.
They understand the purpose of it, and they're willing to go ahead and support that particular
communications line item.
Once you gain that validation, publish it and follow the plan.
One of the worst things you can do as a project manager is to develop this plan, put it in
the project management plan, and then conduct communications in a random manner.
The last step in communications planning is update as needed.
You'll notice on the bottom we have version and date.
This plan is going to change as the project is initiated.
There are going to be certain communications items that are required.
But as the project progresses, more and more communications will be required and some of
the prior communication items may no longer be required as well.
In addition, the audience may very well change as the project progresses.
Individuals who needed and required communications early in the project may no longer require
these communications,
toward the middle and end of the project.
So be consistent and keep this plan accurate.
You will have an opportunity to read a scenario and develop a communications management plan
based on that scenario.
I highly encourage you to do your best in that lab and try to understand how this plan
is developed and appreciate the overall value proposition of this plan.
It's a very, very important planning activity in project planning.
And again, if you develop this communications management plan, it will act as a road map
and help guide effective communications.
Thank you very much for your time listening to this demo, and we look forward to seeing
you and future demo videos.
Have a great rest of your day.

Some may be weekly.
Some may be two times each week.
Some may be just a one time, such as the vendor source selection.
Ensure that you understand how often this communications line item needs to occur and
document it in the fourth column.
The next is to complete the medium.
What medium are we going to go ahead and use?
And in terms of where are we going to meet?
As you can see, in some cases, we have a location, the main conference room, Sarah's office.
In other cases, we may actually have a technology such as SharePoint as well.
So sometimes we don't meet individually or in an office.
We meet electronically using SharePoint.
Always and with a purpose as well.
It's very, very important that all of the individuals who are going to be receiving
information as part of this communications plan have an understanding of the purpose,
why this is important as well.
So, once you have completed all six of these items and you have defined the project title
on the top of the plan, go to step number five, validate the plan with the audience, have a meeting 
with all of these audience members.
Let them know what the expectations are.
Don't surprise them by sending them communications items without some kind of a heads up as 
well.
Ensure you get some kind of verbal sign-off from each one in the audience, that they understand
what the communication line item is.
They understand the purpose of it, and they're willing to go ahead and support that particular
communications line item.
Once you gain that validation, publish it and follow the plan.
One of the worst things you can do as a project manager is to develop this plan, put it in the project 
management plan, and then conduct communications in a random manner.
The last step in communications planning is update as needed.
You'll notice on the bottom we have version and date.
This plan is going to change as the project is initiated.
There are going to be certain communications items that are required.
But as the project progresses, more and more communications will be required and some of the 
prior communication items may no longer be required as well.
In addition, the audience may very well change as the project progresses.
Individuals who needed and required communications early in the project may no longer require
these communications, toward the middle and end of the project.
So be consistent and keep this plan accurate.
You will have an opportunity to read a scenario and develop a communications management plan
based on that scenario.
I highly encourage you to do your best in that lab and try to understand how this plan is developed 
and appreciate the overall value proposition of this plan.
It's a very, very important planning activity in project planning.
And again, if you develop this communications management plan, it will act as a road map and help 
guide effective communications.
Thank you very much for your time listening to this demo, and we look forward to seeing you and 
future demo videos.
Have a great rest of your day.

Expert Viewpoints: Planning for Effective 
Virtual and In Person Communications

Welcome to "Expert Viewpoints: Planning for Effective Virtual and In-Person Communications."
In this video, experts and leaders will provide tips for effective communications planning,
particularly in a virtual environment.
What tips can you provide for effective communications planning,
particularly in a virtual environment?
Tips for effective communication planning.
I wrote this first one on my cheat sheet in all uppercase letters:
"Look at people's calendars for their busy and free time."
One of my biggest pet peeves is when I receive a calendar appointment.
And the person who sends it is double- if not triple-booking me.
I am a fiend about keeping my calendar current, and so when people who are scheduling meetings
don't take the time to look at my calendar for free/busy, and I'm a required member or participant in 
the meeting, it just makes me nuts.
And I know that I can propose a new time that works in my calendar, but I'm not the organizer of 
the meeting, and so I shouldn't have to look through calendars to find that for me plus all the other 
participants.
So, that's my big one is look at calendar availability when you're booking.
Second tip for effective communication.
Know the time zones that your project team is in, especially if you're a global team and you have 
people around the world.
understand that they're going to be working in their mornings, afternoons, and evenings, and then to 
plan your meetings and plan your connections with them accordingly.
Being sensitive to their working hours will help them be sensitive to your working hours, so also 
establish your own boundaries as far as, as far as working hours go.
And then make sure that you find out team holidays; different countries, of course, have different 
holidays.
And then also personal time away, if people are going to take vacations.
That also helps you plan for your timeline, how you're going to manage when people are out,
and more.
And then last, of course, I think you've probably already heard this, but when you are in meetings,
if one person turns their video on, everyone should turn their video on.
If people are sensitive to the room that they're in, go ahead and blur your background.
But do take advantage of the video, take advantage of earbuds and headsets to block out noise from 
other places in the house, and then also if you hear dogs barking, make sure that you can, try to get 
your dog settled down so they don't interrupt your video recording For effective communications 
planning, I like to get a sense, before I plan the communications, of each of my stakeholder's 
communication needs and preferences.
So, I like to spend a little bit of time, either one-on-one with a stakeholder or the team, or even just 
through an e-mail, gathering the communication preferences of those people.
And I like to put, you know, all of that information in a singular place that I can go back and refer to
when I'm doing communications planning.
And that helps me, as I'm building my communications plan, think through what communications 
methods am I going to use, what tools am I going to use? Those sorts of things.
Another thing that I am a really big fan of is, I always have a communications plan template. I think 
it just makes, having a template and always starting from that template and always following the 
same process because you're using a template really helps you not have to think "am I forgetting 
something?" Am I forgetting a key stakeholder? Am I forgetting a type of communication that I 
need to possibly include in this communications plan? but having a template just really makes 
things a lot easier and it makes you much more effective as you're planning those communications.
When it comes to planning in a virtual environment, I think understanding the tools that are at your 
disposal and really understanding what features they have.
So, if you're, you know having a virtual call, a virtual video call, are people going to be able to view 
a recording? Is there a transcription service available that transcribes that recording?
Where are those videos going to be saved? Are you going to need to communicate where those 
videos are saved after each meeting so that people can actually access them ?
But really kind of understanding the technology that you're using:
How do you actually set up the meetings?
What things do people maybe need to download onto their computers
before they join the first meeting?
To be able to access that meeting and to be able to get on the meeting?
All of those things are really important. The technology piece is really important.
and adding those things to your communication plan, so if, for example, you need to send out a link 
to the meeting recording after every meeting.
It's important for you to plan for that communication in your communications plan and then 
potentially build a template: build a template that says,
"Hi team, here is the link to our meeting recording from today. You can access it here."
and then you can go back to that template, and you already have it written, it's already done.
And then when you're in your communications plan, you can send it off very quickly and be done 
with it.
So having templates, understanding the technology, and really understanding the needs of your 
team, communication needs of your team and stakeholders is very important for effective 
communications planning.

First off, make sure that you have all the right stakeholders involved.
Not everybody needs to attend every meeting needs to be on every type of email or something like 
that.
Different types of tools that you can use:
I love Slack, to be honest. A lot of companies use different things, like Teams have a great support 
system as far as a storage box they can put documentations into. That makes it a lot easier for your 
team members to find information. Email, phone call--a lot of people don't call any more;
That's a great opportunity for a one-on-one session.

Project teams should always have a discussion on preferred communication style, how 
frequently, what method, what has worked for them in the past, what hasn't.
And even though your team will collectively decide on a communication plan, every project 
manager is smart enough to know that you need to learn your team members' individual 
preferences.
For example, you don't want to upset someone by calling them unannounced at 3:30 when you 
know that they pick up their child every day from school during that time.
Get to know your team and adapt to their styles.

Planning Virtual Communications

Welcome to "Planning Virtual Communications.
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Explain the key indicators that measure the effectiveness of virtual meetings.
And summarize communications planning tips to accommodate a virtual environment.
The PMI defines virtual meetings as opportunities to interact using communication 
technology.
Virtual meetings are essential in today's work environment, such as making decisions, solving 
problems, responding to stakeholder requests, and providing information.
Let's look at some key parameters that can help measure the effectiveness of virtual meetings.
A key parameter to measure virtual meeting effectiveness is attendance. Typically, a poorly run 
virtual meeting tends to have fewer participants, which may often point to a lack of perceived value 
from the meeting and no accountability for not attending.
Participants may also need help to connect to a meeting or other technology challenges.
Another parameter is the level of participant interaction. When people are engaged, they are 
attentive, contributing, and maximizing the value of the meeting or event.
Participation in polls is another parameter to measure the effectiveness of virtual meetings. Lower 
participation may indicate a lack of focus or interest.
Make sure to conduct periodic polls. Strive to attain 100% participation.
The most important parameter to measure the effectiveness of a virtual meeting is the outcome. It is 
important to validate if the meeting achieved its intended purpose. If not, it is important to 
understand why the purpose was not achieved and continuously improve.
We discussed the measurement parameters for the effectiveness of virtual meetings. Next, let's look 
at some tips on improving the effectiveness of virtual meetings.
The first tip to improve virtual meeting effectiveness is to establish ground rules. Ground rules 
help project teams to communicate effectively, collaborate, and make decisions during a virtual 
meeting.
Some examples of ground rules include:
Be punctual,
Keep cameras on,
Start and end on time,
Ask relevant questions, and
Mute when others speak.
Every participant must be well-conversant with using the technology or software for the meeting.
Conduct technology training, if required.
Another tip to improve the effectiveness of virtual meetings is to ensure that every meeting has a 
well-defined agenda.
Make sure to publish the meeting agenda to all participants. The agenda should have clear 
objectives stated to help align all participants. At the end of the meeting, the project manager must 
publish the meeting minutes.
Here is an example of a clearly defined agenda.
Having the right people in a meeting is essential to be effective. Determine who needs to attend the 
meeting and ensure the participant understands why their attendance is critical.
For example, when setting up a weekly project status meeting, the project manager must invite the 
team members. However, the project sponsor or senior leadership may be optional.
Only invite participants who need to be at the meeting.
When selecting the right participants, ensure backup participants in case a key participant cannot 
attend. Also, ensure that the proxy identified is empowered to make decisions.
Another tip to make the virtual meetings effective is to involve participants. Here are some 
examples to involve participants.
Divide responsibility for presenting topics among the participants. This will increase overall 
engagement.
Encourage participants to share ideas and thoughts via the chat function. This will bring openness 
and engage the participants.
Schedule periodic check-ins with key participants. This will help solicit feedback throughout the 
meeting.
Leverage technology. Introducing periodic break-out room discussions may increase interaction and 
help break the monotony of the meeting.

In this video, you learned that:
Parameters to measure the effectiveness of virtual meetings include attendance, level of 
participant interaction, polls, and outcomes.
Tips to improve the effectiveness of virtual meetings include:
Establish ground rules
Technology awareness
Meeting agenda
Participant selection
Proxy participant identification
Involve participants


Status Reporting

Welcome to "Effective Status Reporting."
After watching this video, d for periodic work performance reports.
Explain the significance of status reporting.
And, describe the attributes of a good status report.
The Project Management Institute (PMI) discusses the need for periodic work performance reports.
These reports include status reports, memos, justifications, dashboards, and more.
Periodic work performance reports support the following:
better decision-making, identifying and raising issues, defining required actions, and creating 
awareness in the team and other stakeholders.
Status reports are one of the most frequently used categories of periodic work performance 
reports.
According to PMI, a status report provides the status of a project.
The report may include information on progress since the last report and forecasts for cost and 
schedule performance.
Typically, a status report is created weekly.
However, the frequency may increase or decrease depending on the project requirement.
It is important to document the definition and need for status reporting and its frequency in 
the communications management plan, during the project planning phase.
The project manager is responsible for establishing status reporting formats and submission 
schedules.
In most cases, organizations use a standard status report template across projects.
For the status report to be effective, it should have some attributes. Let's look at these attributes.
The status report should have an audience focus.
Ensure to tailor content according to the audience.
For example, a weekly status report may contain several line items for development
as the audience is all project team members.
At the same time, a monthly project report to senior management
may contain high-level milestone details.
Another key attribute of an effective status report is that it is short.
Ensure that the status report is one page or shorter.
Use links to review details, if needed.
It is also important to format a status report for better readability.
Share the essential information first, followed by secondary information.
For example, a milestone achieved or a requirement change may be something to highlight at the 
start of the report.
You can also add a high-level summary of the project areas.
Adding factual data to the status report is important.
However, make sure you only add information stakeholders require.
For example, summarize the development status instead of providing a line-by-line detail.
Use graphs or visuals to improve readability.
Varied audiences, such as technical, non-technical, senior or junior, will use the status report.
Keep the language simple to enable varied audiences to understand the status report.
Limit the use of technical jargon.
Add a glossary at the end of the status report.
Use this section to add definitions for technical jargon.
Also, add legend descriptions for any graphs or visual aids.
A project team and stakeholders may include people with disabilities, such as colour-blindness;
make the report inclusive.
Ensure to use symbols along with colours to improve readability for all audiences.
Putting a status report together takes time.
Make sure to set realistic expectations with team members to receive all information.
Similarly, set realistic expectations with stakeholders for sharing the reports.
Ensure the author takes accountability.
The project manager may delegate status report collection and distribution responsibility
to a project core team member.
However, the project manager remains accountable for the quality of the report.
Here is an example of a status report.

In this video, you learned that:
Periodic work performance reports help in various aspects of project management, including 
decision-making and issue identification and resolution.
The status report is a frequently used periodic work report
to provide a project's current status.
The attributes of a good status report include the following:
Focuses on the right audience It is short and to the point
Starts with the essential information Contains factual data
Uses simple language Sets realistic expectations
Adheres to accessibility norms Contains a glossary, if needed
And ensures report credibility.



 
Defining Communication Styles
The Project Management Institute (PMI) encourages using assessments to determine personal 
communication styles, work styles, and individual motivations. Some common assessments include 
Meyers-Briggs, Insights, I-Speak, and Emergenetics. There are many more.
Let's look at the four Emergenetics communications styles to understand how different people 
communicate and how to use that knowledge to improve the effectiveness of our communications.
Note: Different models use different labels for each style. However, there is consistency across all 
models, which are based on the same scientific principles.
Common Communication Styles
There are four common styles of communication. The table below provides an overview of all the 
styles with communication preferences and the questions that will help you design the 
communication content.
Communication 
Style
Communication Preferences
Burning Questions
Analytical
Key Focus: Why
•	Need to have facts to 
support points made
•	Direct and to-the-point 
communications
•	Leave time for thinking 
and analysis
•	Get results and solve the 
problem
•	Do I have the pertinent 
facts?
•	What provides the most 
value?
•	Will this solution fully 
resolve the problem?
Structural
Key Focus: How
•	Ask what, when, where, 
and how questions
•	Speak in complete 
sentences/paragraphs
•	Very deliberate and clear
•	Meticulous
•	How can I get this done?
•	What is the implementation 
process and timeline?
•	Will I be in control?
Conceptual
Key Focus: What
•	Asks questions that lead to 
other questions
•	Stop in mid-sentence, 
assuming others know
•	Use metaphors to make a 
point
•	Very abstract in speaking
•	Have I seen the 
possibilities?
•	What is the big picture?
•	How can we take this to a 
new level?
Social
Key Focus: Who
•	Use stories/experiences to 
illustrate
•	Prefer face-to-face 
communications
•	Caring and compassionate
•	Empathetic
•	How will I affect others?
•	How can we do it together?
•	Are the right people 
involved?
According to statistics, 6% of people have a singular preference, 58% have two preferences, 36% 
have three preferences, and less than 1% have all four styles. However, while an individual may 
have multiple styles and preferences, one style stands out.
Tips for Adapting Your Communication Style
A "one size fits all" communication style is not affected. Try to adapt your communication style to 
meet the needs of the individual you are communicating with. Here are some tips.
Communication Style
How to Plan and Manage Each Style
Analytical
•	Be brief
•	Provide executive summaries
•	Provide credible data
•	Present information logically
•	Allow time to digest
Structural
•	Provide all facts and details
•	Give specifics and clear direction
•	Leave them alone to get the job done
•	No surprises
•	Allow time for questions and clarification
Conceptual
•	Allow time to brainstorm
•	Give freedom to reach the goal their way
•	Give the big picture and skip the details
•	Allow time to think outside of the box
•	Allow time to use creativity
Social
•	Allow some non-work conversation to break the ice
•	Watch your non-verbal's
•	Be sincere
•	Ask for and value their input
•	Give more than just the facts

Leadership Essentials

Welcome to "Leadership Essentials."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Define the key attributes and skills of a good leader.
Explain the attributes of a servant leader.
And describe specific leadership competencies that can give your project an advantage.
A project has different leadership roles, such as management and leadership.
Management focuses on ways to meet project objectives.
Some ways include implementing effective processes, planning, coordinating, measuring, and 
monitoring
Leadership focuses on people.
This position includes influencing, motivating, listening, enabling, and other activities
dealing with the team.
As you have seen, a project manager plays a management role because they must be a good
leader.
The Project Management Institute, or PMI, provides a list of key traits and activities
of a successful leader.
Every project manager must develop these traits to be successful.
Let's look at the traits and activities of a successful leader.
One trait of successful leaders is that they create and maintain a vision and motivate others.
For example, a project manager must ensure a clear project goal.
In addition, the project manager must create a healthy work environment filled with 
empowerment
and skill proficiency, which motivates the team.
Another key trait of successful leadership is identifying, addressing, and solving challenges.
A project manager must be a problem solver.
For example, if the client complains about a team member, the project manager must fully
understand and assess the situation before providing a solution.
Leaders uphold levels of commitment by collaborating with team members.
For example, a project manager must facilitate collaboration between team members and steer
everyone toward a common goal.
The PMI prescribes some key interpersonal skills as traits of a successful leader, including:
emotional intelligence, decision-making, and conflict management.
Let's review these traits.
Emotional intelligence, or EQ, is a leadership trait that increases social awareness, improves
social skills, aids in self-improvement, and increases empathy.
For example, a project manager with high emotional intelligence acts after a thoughtful situation
assessment.
This behaviour makes it easy for the project manager to establish trust and build better relationships 
with the team and stakeholders.
Decision-making is a crucial leadership trait.
A leader must clearly define their decisions and plans and include the team in decision-making.
For example, a project manager determines that the skills required to complete the project are 
unavailable in the existing team.
In this situation, the project manager asks the team for their input and may decide that training the 
current team is a good option as timelines are flexible and the option aligns with the vision of the 
larger organization.
Finally, conflict management keeps communications respectful and focused.
Leaders always encourage dialogue that will move the project forward and intervene when conflict 
turns negative.
Consider this scenario.
The project deliverable is due next Monday.
Alex needs Julia's input to complete the task to complete the deliverable.
Julia has not responded to any of Alex's messages or emails.
Alex is annoyed but continues with other tasks.
The project manager, Chris, notices this and objectively lists the tasks to complete and assigns them 
to the respective team members.
Further, Chris encourages Alex and Julia to have a conversation to sort out their differences.
Another leadership trait is the ability to tailor a leadership style.
For example, at the start of a project, the project manager may need to be a visionary to set and 
communicate the project goal to the team.
However, when working with a junior team member, the project manager may need to be directive.
Next, let's understand servant leadership.
Servant leadership allows teams to self-organize, empowering the team to make their own 
decisions.
There are three leadership behaviours specific to a servant leader.
1: Obstacle removal.
Servant leaders encourage open communication to help identify blockers or impediments.
If the team lacks resources, address the shortage immediately.
2: Diversion shield.
Servant leaders protect the project team from internal and external distractions to help the team 
remain productive and focused.
Interface with stakeholders who have questions so the team can focus on the job.
3: Encouragement and development opportunities. Servant leaders provide tools, rewards, and
encouragement to maintain team satisfaction and productivity.
The project manager must never take the team for granted.
A leader must possess at least some competencies.
These competencies include:
Transparency.
A project manager must be transparent in their actions and thought processes.
Integrity.
A project manager must be ethical and honest.
The project manager must always share accurate and timely information.
Respect.
A project manager must respect others' skills, thinking, and expertise.
The team is more effective than the individual when they work together and share.
Positive discourse.
A project manager must create solutions that work for everyone and be inclusive.
Share the decision and the rationale behind it.
Support.
A project manager must build team trust and proactively identify and remove impediments.
Trust leads to open and honest conversation and collaboration.
Courage: A project manager must show courage and conviction and be willing to take the
lead when needed or follow when it makes sense.
Celebrate success.
A project manager must recognize and acknowledge team contributions in real time and never
take credit for the contributions of others.

In this video, you learned that:
Management focuses on meeting project objectives, and Leadership focuses on people.
Key leader traits and activities include:
Vision and motivation
Problem-solving
Commitment and collaboration
Interpersonal skills, including emotional intelligence, decision-making, and conflict
management
Ability to tailor leadership style
Servant leadership behaviours include obstacle removal, being a diversion encouraging, and
developing team member skills.

Leader competencies include:
Transparency
Integrity
Respect
Positive discourse
Support
Courage
And celebrate success

Expert Viewpoints: Why Leadership?

Welcome to Expert Viewpoints: Why Leadership?
In this video, we will hear leaders and experts discuss the benefits of good leadership.
What are the benefits of good leadership?
I think one of the big benefits of good leadership is increased productivity.
You see increased productivity when you set goals, when you set clear expectations,
and when you give feedback--and you give valid feedback that's constructive and to the point,
it's not overly critical and not personal.
So, by providing clear expectations and the goals of what needs to get done,
you're really setting your team up for success.
You're enabling them to be as efficient as possible
to get things done in a possibly faster timeline than what you originally anticipated.
and that's going to produce better outcomes for your organization.
The other good thing, the other benefit of good leadership, is improved morale.
So, the clearer you are, the more concise you are, the more open you are
about what your expectations are as a leader and as a leader of team members,
the higher the morale is going to be.
there's not going to be surprises when you have feedback that they may need to change something,
and the feedback would be given in good faith.
And so, the more open you are, the more honest you are,
and the more you set expectations about what's good, better, best,
the higher the morale in your company and your organization is going to be.
And then a third one is those two combined, so:
Setting expectations, being clear about that, leading to better productivity, increased morale
You're also just going to be able to build better relationships.
Trust is something that you have to earn,
and so by being open, by being clear about what your expectations are,
you're gonna start building trust within your project team,
and then your client is going to see that as well, because you'll have a happy team,
a happy team is going to produce great results,
and then that's going to give you a happy client.
I think that the benefits of great leadership, particularly in project management, are
high performing teams and projects that are completed successfully.
So, a successful project being a project that's completed
on time, on budget, and with high-quality deliverables,
where it meets the project objectives,
and I think that great leadership does this because
great leaders are able to really bring people together in a way that
just enhances the strengths of each of the members on the team and minimizes
the weaknesses of members on the team.
Great leaders help the whole team be greater than the sum of its individual parts,
and they're able to bring out the best in people
and help teams communicate effectively about challenges and issues that they're facing
or work that needs to be done.
And that is one of the benefits of great leadership-- and, I think, those high performing teams.
As well as a leader's, a great leader's, ability to really manage stakeholders well,
to have a high overarching view of an entire project
while also being able to really understand and see the details,
helps teams get projects done on time, on budget, and in a high quality way
and really meet the project objectives in a way that makes the project successful.
In my opinion, the number one benefit of effective leadership
is the ability to motivate the team.
As a leader, you need to understand that intrinsic motivation
must come from within or inside the individual.
Successful leadership allows all stakeholders and team members
to believe they will achieve something of value by being part of the project.
It allows the individual to feel positively challenged,
believe in the work that they are doing, and strive to make a difference.
It allows for self direction,
acceptance of responsibility, and personal growth.
Question 2, what distinguishes a good leader from a poor leader?
In a word, focus.
A good--let me say, great leader,
focuses on the needs and success of others over self.
The great leader identifies and removes obstacles to success
before they impact the project and the individual.
They eliminate factors that may prevent the individual
from successfully accomplishing the work of the project.
And finally, they provide encouragement and opportunities for each member of the team
to develop their skills and ultimately thrive.
Benefits of good leadership can add value to a team's communication, productivity,
and create a better and more motivating work environment.
