Impact of a Good Leader on Team Dynamics 
and Productivity

Welcome to "Impact of a Good Leader on Team Dynamics and Productivity."
After watching this video, you will be able to: Summarize the Tuckman ladder.
And define how being a good project leader impacts a project team.
The dynamics of a project team vary over the project lifecycle.
For example, when team members meet for the first time, the trust levels may be minimal.
Trust may grow as the project progresses.
Conflicts may arise due to differences of opinion as the team starts working together.
All these can impact overall productivity.
A project manager must recognize, prepare, and manage the dynamics of a team throughout the 
project lifecycle, ultimately geared towards creating a high-productivity team.
The Tuckman ladder, developed by Bruce Tuckman in 1965, is a model for project team 
development throughout the project lifecycle.
The Tuckman ladder guides the project manager and prescribes leadership strategies
to achieve maximum team productivity.
The Tuckman ladder shares four stages of team development, including:
form, storm, norm, and perform.
At each stage, the Tuckman model prescribes distinct leadership strategies.
Let's look at each stage and practical leadership strategies in detail.
Consider this scenario. At the start of a new project,
individuals from different departments come together to work on the project.
Being a new project, some individuals are excited, some are confused, and others are curious.
This is the form stage of the Tuckman ladder, where the team needs general information on 
the project, such as purpose, value to the organization/themselves, and who's involved.
The project manager should be a leader who directs and tells the team what they need to know.
For example, the project manager must set clear goals and objectives, address questions and issues, 
and orient the team to the project.
Remember, failure to "tell" leads to confusion, lack of commitment, questions, and blockers.
The storm stage is when individuals start working on the project on their tasks.
For example, after the project manager provides project details to the team, each individual 
starts working on project tasks.
Different working styles can lead to conflicts and questioning each other's capabilities and working 
styles.
There may even be some [resistance] to starting any work.
This is an essential stage, as many teams fail beyond recovery.
In the storm stage, the project manager must be a leader who can "sell"
the project value to a team member and spell out the value the team member brings.
The project manager must address reservations, provide assurances, and answer questions.
Most importantly, the project manager must look for opportunities to build relationships with 
team members.
A failure to "sell" will leave the team member in a state where they are not productive and unable to 
focus on the project's work.
Next comes the norm stage, where the team has overcome the storm, they are beginning to work 
together, and their focus shifts from self to the project.
For example, individuals gradually start resolving their differences, appreciating each other's 
strengths and skills, and working as a team.
In the norm stage, the project manager must be a leader who "participates."
The project manager must encourage team members to take responsibility for the project's progress.
The project manager must also promote collaboration and effective interpersonal communication.
A failure to "participate" can lead to the team rolling back to the storm stage.
Throughout this time, the team is motivated and starts working towards a common goal.
For example, if a team member is on leave, another team member picks up the work and takes it to 
closure.
This is the perform stage of the Tuckman ladder, where the team shows commitment and motivation 
and requires minimal support.
In the perform stage, the project manager must be a leader who "delegates."
The project manager must delegate tasks to team members and let the team take responsibility.
The project manager should focus on status updates and check-ins regularly.
A failure to "delegate" displays a lack of trust and confidence in the team.
Micromanagement and team demotivation go together.

In this video, you learned that: The Tuckman Ladder is a team-building model.
There are four stages of the Tuckman Ladder: In this video, you learned that: The Tuckman Ladder 
is a team-building model.
There are four stages of the Tuckman Ladder:
Form stage, where a project manager must be a leader who "directs."
Storm stage, where a project manager must be a leader who "sells" project value.
Norm stage, where a project manager must be a leader who "participates."
Perform stage, where a project manager must be a leader who "delegates."

 
Techniques for Improving Leadership Skills
The range of leadership skills is vast. A project manager must strive to become a strong leader, 
which requires continuous learning to acquire new knowledge and skills or improve their 
shortcomings.
Objectives
After completing this reading, you will be able to:
•	Describe proven techniques to improve leadership skills
•	Summarize leadership best practices
Techniques to Improve Leadership Skills
PMI shares several tools, techniques, and skills essential to leadership success.
•	Apply Critical Thinking: Recognize your personal biases. Use disciplined, rational, logical, 
and evidence-based thinking. Avoid being swayed by false premises, analogies, emotional 
appeals, and other faulty logic.
•	Improve Your Emotional Intelligence: Work to increase self-awareness and self-
management skills. Strive to become more socially aware and improve your social skills.
•	Decision-Making: Understand the consequence of decisions that must be made. Determine 
the right method and tools to reach decisions based on the situation and severity of the 
consequences.
•	Conflict Management: Work to create a culture and environment where fear of conflict is 
not a factor. Understand different conflict management techniques to match the situation. 
Differentiate between functional and dysfunctional conflict.
Leadership Best Practices
PMI shares several tips and best practices essential to leadership success. Here is a summary of 
their guidance.
•	Establish and maintain a vision: Share the project purpose and benefits. This will often act 
as a catalyst for the team to commit their time and energy in the right direction to achieve 
the project's purpose.
•	Understand motivation: Take time to understand what motivates the team and individual 
team members. Individualize conversations to provide reasons for the team to commit and 
perform. Understand diversity and that everyone's motivational triggers are different.
•	Tailor your leadership style: Understand situational leadership and how it is applied. Work 
smartly to determine each stakeholder's state of readiness to support the project and adjust 
your leadership approach accordingly.
•	Set the example: Provide guidance and direction for the team. Be willing to practice the 
behaviors that you are asking the team to embrace.
•	Be accessible: Be available when the team needs your guidance. Recognize and reward high 
performers.

Leadership Factors and Styles

Welcome to "Leadership Factors and Styles."
After watching this video,
you'll be able to: Compare manager and leader.
Identify the different types of leadership styles.
List the factors that impact a leader's style.
And describe the Hershey Blanchard situational leadership model.
Manager and leader, as terms, are used interchangeably.
However, while managers and leaders share common attributes, there are several differences.
Project Management Institute (PMI) lists eleven distinctions between managers and leaders.
Let's look at these.


A manager uses their position to direct the work; a leader guides, influences, and collaborates using 
relational power.
A manager maintains the current state; a leader develops a new and improved state.
A manager is an administrator; a leader is an innovator.
Managers focus on systems and structures; leaders focus on relationships with people.
Managers rely on control; Leaders inspire trust.
A manager focuses on achieving short-term goals: a leader focuses on a long-range vision.
The manager asks how and when; the leader asks what and why.
Managers focus on the bottom line; leaders focus on the horizon.
Managers accept the status quo; leaders challenge the status quo.
Managers do things right; leaders do the right things.
Managers focus on operational issues and problem-solving.
Leaders focus on vision, alignment, motivation, and inspiration.
A project manager needs to strive to be both a manager and a leader.


Let's now move the focus to leadership styles and look at some distinct styles.
Laissez-Faire, or "hands-off" style, is where a leader allows the team members to work 
independently and make decisions on their own.
Transactional is a leadership style focused on accomplishments, such as completing tasks, providing 
feedback, meeting goals and objectives, and determining the rewards based on accomplishments.
Another leadership style is servant leadership.
A servant leader focuses on serving the people and always puts their people first.
Transformational leadership style focuses on empowering, inspiring, and encouraging innovation.
Charismatic leadership is a style where leaders are high energy, enthusiastic, inspirational, and have 
a strong conviction.
Interactional leadership style is a combination of transactional, transformational, and charismatic 
leadership styles.
A project manager may have one of the above leadership styles to be dominant.
However, they will need to mix or swap styles based on different situations.
One approach to select the best leadership style is influenced by the four factors.
Project manager characteristics, which include their attitude, moods, needs, values, and ethics.
Team member characteristics are their attitudes, moods, needs, values, and ethics.
Organizational characteristics, which includes the purpose and structure of the organization.
The nature of work also influences the leadership style.
Environmental characteristics, such as the current social situation, economic state,
and even internal and external political elements, can influence leadership style.
Another approach to selecting a leadership style is the Hershey Blanchard situational leadership 
model.
The model defines four specific performance-readiness levels for each team member or stakeholder.
The model suggests that project managers adapt their leadership styles to tasks and relationships in 
the workplace that map to the individual's or team member's readiness level.
Readiness Level 4 is the highest state of readiness.
The team member is highly skilled and capable of performing at a high level.
They also have the confidence to do what is required and are self-directed to take the initiative 
without being directed.
At this level, the optimal strategy is to delegate.
Readiness Level 3 is similar to Readiness Level 4 with one big exception.
The team member has the necessary skills to perform at a high level.
They also require minimal direction.
The exception is confidence:
Something's preventing this team member from taking the initiative to perform.
We classify Readiness Level 3 as a state of moderate readiness.
At this level, the optimal strategy is to participate.
Readiness Level 2 is a state where the team member has the confidence and motivation to perform;
they are anxious to move forward.
The problem is that they lack the skills to be successful.
We also classify Readiness Level 2 as a state of moderate readiness.
These team members must be leader directed; at this level, the optimal strategy is to sell.
Readiness Level 1 is the lowest state of readiness.
The team member lacks the skills necessary to perform.
In addition, they lack the confidence needed to be self-directed.
These team members must be leader directed.
At this level, the optimal strategy is to tell.
The table summarizes the association between leadership styles and readiness levels.


In this video, you learned that:
Management and leadership do intersect and have shared attributes.
There are eleven distinctions between a manager and a leader, as defined by PMI.
Some leadership styles include Laissez-Fair, transactional, transformational, servant leadership,
charismatic, and interactional.
There are four main characteristics to consider when choosing a leadership style
including leader characteristics, team characteristics, organizational characteristics, and 
environmental characteristics.
The Hershey Blanchard situational leadership model defines four specific performance readiness 
levels for each team member or stakeholder.


Expert Viewpoints: Leadership Competencies, 
Skills, and Mindset


Welcome to Expert Viewpoints: Leadership Competencies, Skills, and Mindset.
What are some leadership challenges you encountered, and how did you overcome them?
I've encountered a lot of leadership challenges over the years, having been a leader and then 
obviously having been led by many leaders.
I've got to see it from both sides of the coin. I'm delivering, you know, leadership skills to
other people and then being the recipient of other people's leadership abilities and skills.
So, I've had many, many challenges.
I think if I were to kind of call out, one of the biggest challenges that I've had to face as a leader and 
then overcome is the ability to be honest with bad news.
Early on in my career, I hated delivering bad news, absolutely hated it.
Whether it be performance challenges or telling upper management that a project was going to be 
late, it didn't matter.
I just hated delivering bad news, and I don't think most people like delivering bad news.
But in leadership, in project management, it's always something that you have to do.
Things rarely go perfectly, and there's always some bad news that you have to deliver.
So, earlier on in my career, I would find ways either to avoid delivering the bad news.
I would try to solve certain problems myself so that I didn't have to deliver the bad news, or I 
would try to couch the bad news in vocabulary that made it, didn't make it sound as bad as it was.
So, one big mistake I made a lot in my career is that I wasn't clear on what I wanted my team to do 
or what I wanted a specific team member to do, or I wasn't clear to upper management on how bad 
things were because I was trying to, I was trying to minimize the impact of my bad news that I was 
delivering.
And I can say, obviously, recollection isn't always perfect, but I can say with a lot of confidence 
that in almost every situation where I did that, I ended up regretting it.
Here's an example.
When I was, you know, managing teams early in my career, there was always people on the team 
that needed to have their performance improved.
They needed to do a better job than they were doing, and we would give year end and mid year 
reviews, and I would have to tell them, you're not performing at the level you need to perform to 
get a good bonus or whatever, and I would not want to deliver that message because people never 
wanted to hear that they weren't performing well.
And so I would try to, I would couch it, I would focus on the things they were doing well, and then 
I would say, oh, and here's a couple of things you should probably work on.
But I was never really super clear on, you know, you're not performing, and these are the things that 
you need to get better at in order to get up to that top performer level, and then six months later, or a 
year later, whenever the next review was, they didn't really--so, at their next performance review,
they didn't really respond to the feedback I gave them because I wasn't clear in my feedback,
and their situation would be worse, and then I'd have to deliver even more bad news.
But I didn't want to deliver the worse news the six months or a year later.
And so that problem would continue to exacerbate until it came up, it came to a really big problem 
that my manager would have to step in and deliver the bad news.
So, I had to learn to be an effective leader.
It's better to deliver hard news and sometimes bad news very, very honestly, and very clearly 
upfront rather than letting it, you know, just grow bigger and bigger until a project blows up. Now 
obviously, there's ways to deliver bad news or tough news in a way that doesn't demoralize the 
people that you're delivering it to or that doesn't, you know, that reduces confidence in leadership if 
you have to deliver bad news to leadership.
But I have found that being extremely clear and not soft soaping your bad messages, and then 
always trying to provide a mitigation--
So, if you have to deliver a bad message to one of your, the people on your team, you can say 
"Here's what's happening; here's what it means if you don't improve."
"But now let's talk about ways that we can turn this around."
Or if you have a project that is behind schedule, you can say to your team that the project is behind 
schedule, things aren't going well.
Here's the impact if we don't turn this around, and here are some ideas that I'm going to bring to 
the table to help us get this back on track.
So it's not just delivering bad news and kind of letting the team flounder.
It's providing a path forward so that that can be improved, and then the team has a very good sense 
of what they need to do, or the individual you're talking to has a good sense of what they need to do
in order to get the project or their career or whatever it is back on track.
So, I think those two components go together.
For a large number of years, I've been a remote worker and so I--even when people were in the 
office before COVID--I was not there.
You know, people would, project team members would have hallway conversations, they would 
discuss something, maybe they'd decide something.
Maybe they would take the project a different way and I'm not there to be part of that conversation.
Not every conversation can be had in a meeting with a remote person as part of that meeting
or be documented as notes and sent out later.
You're not going to get people who run into each other in your little kitchen area at work, getting a 
cup of coffee, having a conversation, they're not going to go back to their desk and ping you and 
say, "hey, I just talked to this person, and here's what we talked about, and I thought you should 
know."
So what I've done, what I did to overcome that, what I still do, is I just have frequent touch points,
almost like a Sprint, in order to stay informed.
And so maybe it's a 15-minute connect at the end of the day or noon or whatever.
Maybe it's a coffee chat in the morning, but I just touch base with key people that I have a really 
good relationship with and say, hey, what's going on?
Who have you talked to lately?
Anything I need to know about that you're hearing around the office? Or wherever they are,
you know, and around--I think of "around the office" as in air quotes.
That has really been one of the critical things that I've done to to work past being a remote leader to 
where I can't be there.
The other issue or the other leadership challenge that I have faced in the last few years is having a 
global team And my team, I'm in Fargo, North Dakota, and my team is in India.
I cannot be feet on the ground for them.
I can't be there to react in the moment to provide decisional direction on hot items.
And so again, frequent connections, frequent conversations, and then also different chat apps, 
WhatsApp on my cell phone if they need to get a hold of me, or texts or something like that.
They are really critical.
And then then surrounding myself with people that I trust.
That's really a big one, and there's probably different quotes of people saying that.
I think Presidents have said that, US Presidents, but, where I can't be feet on the ground, where I 
can't be available for crucial in-the-moment conversations, I need to trust the person who is having 
that conversation. And I do.
And my team in India is an excellent team and they run a really tight ship.
And so finding those trusted people that you can have on your team that keep you informed, that 
engage you when you need to be engaged, is super critical.
I am a firm believer in the Emotional Intelligence model.
Unfortunately, I often encounter many stakeholders who have severe self-awareness issues.
They have no idea how their actions impact the team.
In addition, they have limited control over how the team affects them.
I often share the top five self-awareness challenges and ask the team members to honestly evaluate 
themselves.
If they are lacking, I give them a challenge to address the challenge they see as the biggest one 
impacting them.
So let me go ahead and include the top five areas of self-awareness challenges you may encounter.
Challenge number 1.
Do you accurately perceive your own emotions in the moment and understand your tendencies 
across situations?
Do you know how you're going to react?
Number 2.
Are you willing to tolerate the discomfort of focusing on feelings that are negative?
Unfortunately, in project management, not everything is positive, and sometimes, you have to have 
the difficult discussions.
Number 3 is my favourite:
Do you have a straightforward and honest understanding of why you do the things you do?
Do you know how people push your buttons and how you're going to react?
Do you have a clear understanding of what you do well, what motivates and satisfies you,
and again, which people or situations can lead you into actions that perhaps, you may not be happy 
with in retrospect?
Finally, are you afraid of your emotional mistakes?
Or can you recognize the beauty and the blemishes of who you are?
I'm going to take this as the approach of other managers that I've worked with and my own 
leadership as far as things that we had encountered.
So, for example, the first one is lack of communication.
When you don't understand exactly how they like to communicate and they don't look to see how 
you would like to communicate, there's that barrier.
With open communication, you also understand more of the expectations that they're looking for.
When you have no expectations, it can be a very stressful environment--for both sides,
because you're not getting the information you need from your manager, and the manager doesn't 
know what's going on either.
So, really having that open communication, setting expectations, makes a huge difference.

Situational Leadership with Your Team

Welcome to "Situational Leadership with Your Team."
After watching this video, you'll be able to:
Summarize key leadership tailoring considerations
Explain the OSCAR coaching and mentoring model.
There are different types of leadership styles, including tell, sell, participate, and delegate.
Another video explains the leadership styles in detail.
The project manager cannot rely on one or the other and must be able to determine the most 
appropriate leadership style based on the situation.
For example: A project manager has to manage the completion of a project.
The team has been working together for a long time and understands the project processes
and deliverables.
The project manager has full confidence in them.
Therefore, they can use the "delegate" leadership style with the team.
A project manager must understand how to tailor the leadership style in different scenarios.
To help the project manager with tailoring or adapting the leadership styles, the Project 
Management Institute, or PMI, provides four key variables.
Let's dive into the variables.
One variable to consider is the team member's expertise.
A project manager must determine the level of expertise each team member possesses.
The project manager must also determine how well a team member's skill-set matches the project's 
requirements.
A good understanding of the skill levels and capability to perform the required tasks in a project is 
crucial to select the proper leadership style.
For example, consider a team member with minimal skills and low confidence.
In this case, a project manager needs to provide direction.
Hence the project manager will use the "direct" leadership style.
An example of selling is encouraging the team member to apply new skills learned in a training 
session.
Another variable to consider is the maturity of team members.
While a team member may have the expertise in a certain skill, experience working in the area of 
expertise can bring other advanced skills, such as problem-solving, adaptability, and resilience.
The third variable to consider when selecting the appropriate leadership style in a given 
situation is governance.
The level of governance drives the levels of empowerment and delegation that a project 
manager can give the team.
For example, on a highly data-sensitive project, the project manager may need to direct all team 
members to work from an onsite location rather than a remote location.
The project manager might even need to use the "sell" leadership style to help team members 
understand the importance of the project for the organization while highlighting the skill 
additions for the team members.
The fourth variable to be considered when selecting the leadership style is the nature of the 
team setup: co-located or distributed.
For example, consider a team of experienced individuals that works in from the same location.
It's likely to be easy for a project manager to assess the team's maturity and delegate work as 
necessary.
At the same time, in a newly set up distributed environment, irrespective of the levels of expertise 
in the team, the project may need to use "direct" leadership style until the team settles.
With an understanding of the variables in leadership styles, a project manager can use the OSCAR 
coaching and mentoring model.
Developed by Karen Whitworth and Andrew Gilbert, the OSCAR model is a five-step process 
to help leaders better adapt their styles and approaches by providing an action plan for 
personal development.
The OSCAR model refers to five contributing factors.
The Outcome can be summarized as the expectations you have for the individual in the long run.
What is the expected result from the conversation?
The Situation is, in essence, a gap analysis.
Where is the individual in terms of skills, abilities, and knowledge, and where do they need to be?
Choices and consequences objectively analyse the gaps and determine the best way to improve the 
individual's performance and outcomes.
The Action is a well-planned step-by-step approach to reach the level of success required of the 
individual.
Finally, Reviews at each step along the way are essential to provide feedback and ensure the 
individual stays on track.
Let's review an example of using the OSCAR model. Consider a scenario:
A new developer has been assigned to the project team.
One: the project manager defines the outcomes.
The outcome is that the new team member must integrate into the team and be self-directed 
by the next iteration.
Next, the project manager defines the situation and performs a gap analysis.
The situation with gap analysis is:
The new team member is deficient in three key skills and must attend a training class.
The consequence is explained in terms of choices.
In this example, the new team member must score at least an 80% on the final training course exam
and be evaluated by a senior team member for competence.
The action plan is developed, and the new team member signs off.
In the end, the team member's progress is reviewed and ready for being self-directed.

In this video, you learned that:
The Project Management Institute, or PMI, has four key variables
when determining the most appropriate leadership style:
experience, maturity, governance, and distributed teams.
Developed by Karen Whitworth and Andrew Gilbert, the OSCAR model is a five-step process
to help leaders better adapt their styles and approaches by providing an action plan for 
personal development.


 
Mapping Situational Leadership Model to the 
Tuckman Ladder
An understanding of the development stage of a team can help a project manager adopt the 
appropriate leadership style.
Objectives
In this reading, you will:
•	Review the Tuckman Ladder
•	Review the Hersey Blanchard situational leadership model
•	Map the Tuckman Ladder with the Hersey Blanchard situational leadership model and 
determine the appropriate situational leadership style
Tuckman Ladder Review
The Tuckman Ladder is a step-by-step overview of team development stages developed by Bruce 
Tuckman in 1965. The model shares four steps a team must complete to enter a high-performance 
development stage.
The table below summarizes the four stages of the Tuckman Ladder.
Step
Stage
Stage Characteristics
Level of 
Productivity
1
Form
•	The team is coming together
•	The goal is to create a clear structure, goals, 
direction, and roles
•	Team members need guidance
•	Productivity is low
Low
2
Storm
•	Characterized by turbulence
•	The team begins work
•	There are high levels of disagreement and 
discontent
•	Little work is being accomplished
Lower
3
Norm
•	The team begins to work together. Productivity 
increases. The turbulence begins to calm
•	Collaboration increases, and individual focus 
decreases
•	Reconciliation, reduced anxiety, and 
cooperation are evident
•	The team is beginning to trust each other
Moderate
4
Perform
•	The team evolves into a cohesive unit
•	Everyone works well with others
•	The team is both efficient and effective
•	Productivity is high
•	Team members are self-directed and committed
Moderate
Hershey Blanchard Situational Leadership Model: Review
Paul Hersey and Ken Blanchard created the Situational leadership(r) model in the 1970s.
The model defines four specific readiness performance readiness levels for each team member or 
stakeholder.The model suggests that project managers adapt their leadership style to tasks and 
relationships in the workplace that map to the individual's or team member's readiness level.
Readiness level R4 indicates that the team member is self-directed. They are able, confident, and 
willing to perform at a high level.
At R3, the team member is still self-directed. However, they are insecure or unwilling to perform.
An R2 team member requires leadership direction. They are unable to perform their assigned tasks. 
However, the team member is confident, willing to learn, and ready to try.
At R1, the team member also requires leadership direction. They cannot perform their assigned 
tasks and are insecure or unwilling to learn and try.
The table summarizes how the different levels map with the strategies.
Situational Leadership Readiness Level
Situational Leadership Style
R1
Tell or Direct
R2
Sell or Coach
R3
Participate or Support
R4
Delegate or Monitor
Mapping the Models and Leadership Styles
The stages in the Tuckman Ladder map perfectly with the readiness levels in the Hersey Blanchard 
situational leadership model. The project manager can determine the situational leadership style to 
implement depending on the level.
Tuckman Ladder Phase
Situational Leadership Readiness 
Level
Situational Leadership Style
Form
R1
Tell or Direct
Storm
R2
Sell or Coach
Norm
R3
Participate or Support
Perform
R4
Delegate or Monitor
R1: The team needs task support. Create ground rules, communicate roles and responsibilities, 
answer questions, and discuss what the project is and why it is important.
R2: The team needs both task and relational support. Effectively facilitate discussions. Listen and 
advise. Manage dysfunctional conflict. Coach the team to build their skills while maintaining 
motivational levels.
R3: The team still needs relational support. Stop telling and selling. Empower the team to work 
together to accomplish the goals of the project. Continue to build trust within the group. Be 
accessible and provide support as needed. Avoid the tendency to micromanage.
R4: Let the team manage conflicts and plan the work internally. Stay out of the way. Check-in with 
the group occasionally to ensure everything is tracking as planned. Periodically provide rewards and 
recognitions to maintain high motivational levels.
Conclusion
Team members will be in different stages of development. As a project manager, treat each team 
member individually. Determine where they are on the ladder and apply situational leadership 
accordingly.

 
The Knowledge Sharing Hierarchy
A key project management responsibility is effective knowledge management. Knowledge 
management can ensure critical information is distributed to all stakeholders promptly and also 
facilitate efficient and effective project planning and execution.
Objective
•	Define work performance data (WPD), work performance information (WPI), and 
work performance reports (WPR)
•	Apply the knowledge-sharing hierarchy to project management leadership
•	Revisit the importance of Lessons Learned
Introduction to Knowledge Sharing Hierarchy
The Project Management Institute (PMI) categorizes data and information into three 
categories. The illustration shares the knowledge-sharing hierarchy.
 
 
Work performance data (WPD) is "raw" observations and measurements identified during 
activities to carry out the project work. WPD is commonly acquired from conversations, emails, 
or routine project correspondence. Typically, WPD has limited value. However, WPD needs to 
be received, acknowledged and understood. Occasionally, WPD contains information critical to 
project success. WPD is received during the executing process group. WPD can take the form of an 
e-mail from a team member expressing reservations about a milestone. It may be a customer 
conversation where they share ideas to save resource dollars. Or as simple as a user stating they 
want to ensure instructions on how to use a new product are easy to understand.
Work performance information (WPI) is derived from WPD. WPI is performance data collected 
during the monitoring and controlling process group. WPI usually is more consequential than 
WPD. Examples include the status of deliverables, implementation status, and forecast estimates to 
complete. WPI is analyzed to develop work performance reports (WPR).
WPRs are distributed during the monitoring and controlling process groups. WPR extracts 
critical WPI data and shares information to generate decisions, raise issues, report status, 
request assistance, or address problems and solutions.
Applying the Knowledge-Sharing Hierarchy to Project 
Management Leadership
The effective use of WPRs can aid the team and stakeholders in two areas essential to leadership 
success. The team's readiness to perform at a high level is tied to their understanding, abilities, 
confidence, and motivation.
Actively listening to the team and processing WPD presents an impression that the project manager 
is concerned and receptive to the team's inputs, which builds trust and increases motivation and 
commitment.
Working closely with the team to identify WPI required to share and distribute details in the 
WPR provides critical task-related details that can increase team effectiveness. In addition, the 
knowledge-sharing hierarchy can be used to share essential project benefits and values to increase 
commitment, confidence, and willingness to support the project.
Importance of Lessons Learned in Knowledge Sharing
Lessons learned are one of the greatest sources of knowledge for a project manager. Optimally 
lessons learned are accomplished at the completion of each project phase and at the end of the 
project. Discussions during lessons learned provide a wealth of WPD that, in many cases, can 
be used to identify consequential WPI. This new WPI can then be used to provide critical 
knowledge in WPR.
Lessons learned address three key questions.
 What went well in a project,
what could have gone better,
and what can be improved the next time?
Lessons learned address vital skills and task-related information that can improve the 
efficiency and effectiveness of the team on the next project. In addition, lessons learned share 
key risks, issues that were addressed and overcome, and discovered opportunities.
Lessons learned have little impact on the current project. However, they can assist all organization 
project managers by providing information to help better lead future projects.

 
Intuitive Decision-Making
One of the challenges for a project manager is making decisions that can significantly impact the 
success or failure of the project. While data and analysis help a project manager make informed 
decisions, there are times when the project manager may need to rely on intuition to make 
decisions because not enough data is available.
In today's business landscape, where it may not be easy to meet with team members and 
stakeholders in person, trusting one's intuition can be invaluable.
Objectives
After completing this reading, you will be able to:
•	Describe the need for intuitive decision-making when managing projects
•	Explain how to use four types of thought patterns to validate decisions made based on one's 
intuition
Need for Intuitive Decision-Making
Sometimes in high-pressure or time-dependent situations, a project manager doesn't have enough 
time to analyse all available data. Yet, when a project manager must make an immediate decision, 
the project manager must make decisions based on their intuition. A project manager relies on 
things like their past experiences and emotional intelligence. In part, emotional intelligence is 
the ability to interpret the emotions of others effectively. Sometimes, it is necessary to gauge 
others' feelings and incorporate that understanding into the decision-making process. Also, a 
project manager may need to depend on their emotions, which are automated reactions based 
on experience, because otherwise, the project manager doesn't have enough explicit 
information. Learn to trust your intuitive reaction.
A project manager may have to make quick decisions to reduce the impact of various issues on the 
project. In these situations, relying on one's instincts can help make quick decisions that can be 
critical to the success of the situation. The more knowledge and experience a project manager 
has, the more the intuitive instincts come from sound reasoning and informed decision-
making.
To help a project manager feel comfortable with their intuition-based decisions, knowing one's 
thinking patterns and preferences can be helpful. What kind of evidence do you need to trust your 
intuition?
Ned Hermann's whole brain model
According to Ned Hermann's whole brain model, there are four categories of thought patterns: 
analytical, practical, relational, and experimental. Knowing your thought patterns when making 
decisions will help you trust your judgment when relying on your intuition.
If an individual is an analytical thinker, they will feel most comfortable taking a logical approach 
to decision-making. Ask yourself such questions as, "What factors will indicate the solution is on 
track?" "What are the possible root causes of the problem?" "What aspects indicate a need for 
change?" and "Are those indicators subjective or objective?"
If an individual is a practical thinker, their thinking is organized, detailed, and structured. 
They focus on a method to solve a problem. Practical thinkers feel most comfortable following a 
plan in problem-solving and avoiding pitfalls. They effectively manage their feelings when making 
decisions to ensure the actions are focused.
Relational thinkers will trust their intuition when solving problems by getting a sense of the 
problem through the eyes of the people the issue affects the most. They carefully gauge choices and 
decisions by listening to the tone of interactions and reactions of the people involved.
Finally, experimental thinkers will trust their intuition when making innovative and creative 
choices. They like to understand how their decisions affect the big picture. They prefer to explore 
and consider possibilities before making a choice. A project manager will also find times when 
they must trust someone else's intuition. Understanding their thought pattern preferences according 
to the whole brain model may also help you evaluate their decisions when you have little else to go 
on.
A project manager must assess the potential risks and benefits of the decision based on the 
thought patterns as a basis for evaluation. A project manager must ask questions, express 
concerns, and try to understand others' perspectives. If their thought pattern preference is 
different, it may be helpful to justify their decision by asking them questions based on one's 
preferred thought pattern category.
Conclusion
The need for decision-making based on intuition arises in time-dependent situations when 
there is not enough time to gather all the relevant data. It is helpful to understand the four 
categories of thought patterns when justifying intuitive decisions. The categories include analytical, 
practical, relational, and experimental thinking.


Expert Viewpoints: Using your Intuition

Welcome to Expert Viewpoints: Using your Intuition.
In this video, we will hear from leaders and experts discussing the importance of using
your intuition to make decisions and share their real-world experiences.
When a project goes off course, there are tiny little hints that many people might not
notice, but a good project manager will pick up on it right away.
Maybe it's silence on a call.
Maybe it's a client's communication style that has shifted, and their sentences are a little bit shorter 
with a small hint of negativity.
It's important to not shy away from this and start checking in with your teammates and clients one-
on-one.
"Say, hey, how are you feeling about this project?
I've noticed this ___."
This will help you get to the root of the problem faster and change course.

Intuition, for me, is the ability to use your background knowledge, your natural skills, as well as all 
the training and experience that you've gained to bring that to the
table to help make decisions.  So, for example, if you're presented with a problem, let's say that a 
stakeholder has just told you that they thought they were going to have time to work on your 
project, but now they have to pull out because the previous project that they were working on
is running over.
Now, without intuition, you may not have any sense of what that's going to mean, and if you're a 
junior project manager, that may seem like the world's going to end, right?
"This is now no longer something I can handle.
We have a major stakeholder that can't do their work and so we need to push out the timelines and 
all the rest of it," right?
If you have some intuitions around that, you may say, "OK.
This has happened before.
I've experienced this problem before.
Then there's a number of things I can do.
I can go to the person's manager and ask for that person's time back or see if the manager has 
another person on their team that can step in and fill in the gap."
There's things that you can do to maybe share time so the person works a little bit on the previous 
project and then works on your project.
You may even evaluate, "Do I need this stakeholder?
Is this something that I can do without for at least the time being.
Or can I push the stakeholder out so they can join later and then still not impact the project 
timelines?"
So, what I think intuition does there is it gives you a sense of 'What does this information
that I've just received, what does it mean for this project?
And how do I incorporate that information now to make a good decision or to make a decision 
that's right for the team or a decision that is going to help ensure that this project continues to move 
forward?"
And intuitions can help with that because they do bring that past experience to the table as well as 
kind of your natural dispositions for dealing with complicated issues in a project.
And every project has those complicated issues for sure.
I think part of the problem with intuition is that it is very... It can be very difficult to define, and 
understanding what your own intuitions, what you're good at intuitively, and what you actually 
need data for can also be very tricky.
So, for example, a project manager might think that they have some really good intuitions
on how long something is going to take to accomplish, whereas you know most people need
a little bit of data.
So, if you're developing a product and there's a certain aspect of that product that is critical for 
getting the project done, having some data so that you say in the past this has taken developers this 
much time to put this piece of the project together.
I'm going to use that information and then add my intuition on top of that.
I think you can use data and then add intuition to that data to make better decisions.
If you if you just use data.
If you say it's taken this long in the past and it's going to take this long for this project without 
bringing your intuitions to the table, I think you miss and miss out on something very critical there.
I think you miss out on a very important aspect of using raw data without intuition, that adding 
intuition to that data can definitely help you make better decisions.

Intuition can be very useful when you're in situations where there's incomplete information,
ambiguity, maybe a crisis situation, or you just need to make a decision really fast in the moment.
Trusting your gut, going with what you think is right in that moment in time, is very acceptable
in my book.
But always going with your gut and not looking for data, facts, and taking the time to analyse it and 
really make an informed decision is not the right way to go.
You really need to balance out, as a successful leader, your gut decisions together with your
very well-informed decisions.
Of course, you want to lean towards the side of a well-informed decision.
But in those moments when you need to make it a gut decision or use your intuition to make a 
decision when you don't have the complete facts, feel empowered to do that.
The more you do, you will get more competent in the outcome and in making those decisions,
but early on, I know it is tough to to feel confident that you can take a chance and go with it.
I think as long as you're trying your best in my book and you're making the decision, or you're 
using your intuition and making your gut decision based on the best of your abilities, I'm not going 
to fault anybody for that.
There may be some people who do, but in my book, you're trying your best and trying to keep 
things moving forward.


 
Module 4 Summary: Leadership 
Fundamentals
Congratulations! You have completed this module. At this point in the course, you know that:
•	Management focuses on meeting project objectives, while leadership focuses on people. 
Some key leader traits and activities include vision and motivation, problem-solving, 
commitment and collaboration, interpersonal skills, including emotional intelligence, 
decision-making, and conflict management, and the ability to tailor leadership style. Servant 
leadership behaviors include obstacle removal, being a diversion encouraging, and 
developing team member skills. Leader competencies include transparency, integrity, 
respect, positive discourse, support, courage, and celebrate success.
•	The Tuckman Ladder is a team-building model with four stages including:
•	Form stage, where a project manager must be a leader who "directs."
•	Storm stage, where a project manager must be a leader who "sells" project value.
•	Norm stage, where a project manager must be a leader who "participates."
•	Perform stage, where a project manager must be a leader who "delegates."
•	To improve their leadership skills, project managers can apply critical thinking, increase 
emotional intelligence, improve decision-making, and enhance conflict management. As a 
leader, make sure to establish and maintaina vision, understand motivation, tailor your 
leadership style, lead by example, and be accessible.
•	There are eleven distinctions between a manager and a leader, as defined by PMI. Some 
leadership styles include Laissez-Fair, transactional, transformational, servant leadership, 
charismatic, and interactional. There are four main characteristics to consider when choosing 
a leadership style, including leader characteristics, team characteristics, organizational 
characteristics, and environmental characteristics. The Hershey Blanchard situational 
leadership model defines four specific performance readiness levels for each team member 
or stakeholder.
•	The Project Management Institute, or PMI, has four key variables when determining the 
most appropriate leadership style: experience, maturity, governance, and distributed 
teams. Developed by Karen Whitworth and Andrew Gilbert, the OSCAR model is a five-
step process to help leaders better adapt their styles and approaches by providing an action 
plan for personal development.
•	The stages in the Tuckman Ladder map perfectly with the readiness levels in the Hersey 
Blanchard situational leadership model. The project manager can determine the situational 
leadership style to implement depending on the level. Some team members will be in 
different stages of development. As a project manager, treat each team member individually. 
Determine where they are on the ladder and apply situational leadership accordingly.
•	PMI categorizes data and information into three categories, including work performance 
data (WPD) at the lowest, followed by work performance information (WPI), and finally, 
work performance. Knowledge-sharing hierarchy can be used to share essential project 
benefits and values to increase commitment, confidence, and willingness to support the 
project. Discussions during lessons learned provide a wealth of WPD that, in many cases, 
can be used to identify consequential WPI. This new WPI can then be used to provide 
critical knowledge in WPR.
•	The need for decision-making based on intuition arises in time-dependent situations when 
there is not enough time to gather all the relevant data. It is helpful to understand the four 
categories of thought patterns when justifying intuitive decisions. These categories include 
analytical, practical, relational, and experimental thinking.

Effective Resource Management

 
Effective Resource Planning
Resources are critical to a project's success. Therefore, ensuring that the right resources are 
available at the right time is critical. Further, resource planning is a critical activity in project 
management, which aids the project manager in managing resources effectively.
Objectives
After completing this reading, you will be able to:
•	Define resource planning
•	Explain the benefits of resource planning
•	Identify areas project managers should consider when assigning resources to tasks
What is effective resource planning?
Effective resource planning involves identifying and estimating the resources needed for a 
project, including personnel, equipment, materials, and budget. The project manager also needs 
to allocate the resources appropriately across the project's tasks and timelines to ensure effective use 
of the resources.
Effective resource planning involves identifying each deliverable for the project and creating a 
work breakdown structure (WBS) for the overall project. The WBS list all the project tasks 
sequentially to the lowest level. The WBS will help the project manager identify what and when 
resources are required to complete different tasks.
Note: Another video covers details about WBS.
Resource planning considerations
After the project manager creates the WBS, they must assign different tasks to resources. Before 
resource assignment in the resource plan, project managers must consider various considerations.
•	Availability of resources: Project managers need to ensure that resources are available 
when required. In addition, the project manager must consider team members' workload, 
equipment, and materials when assigning resources to tasks.
•	Skills and expertise: Project managers must consider the skills and expertise required to 
complete each task. For the plan to be effective, the project manager must assign resources 
with the necessary skills and training to complete the tasks.
•	Prioritization of tasks: Project managers should review and identify critical tasks and 
assign resources accordingly.
•	Interdependencies: A project manager must consider interdependencies between tasks 
when assigning resources. The project manager must assign tasks dependent on each other to 
the appropriate resources and completed in the right sequence.
•	Budget: Project managers must ensure resources assigned to tasks are within the allocated 
project budget.
What are the benefits of resource planning?
While it may seem a cumbersome process, resource planning is highly beneficial. Some benefits of 
effective resource planning include:
Better estimation of timelines and deadlines
Resource planning helps a project manager look ahead at a project's resource requirements and 
create a detailed plan for the types of resources needed, how much is required, and when each 
resource is needed. With a clear understanding of available resources and their capacities, project 
managers can better estimate project timelines and deadlines.
Better risk management
Resource planning is a proactive activity that helps project teams proactively manage risks and 
mitigate potential issues before they arise. For example, resource planning helps with a clear picture 
of resource requirements. By mapping the requirement with resource availability, project managers 
can identify potential bottlenecks or resource constraints that may impact project timelines before 
they become an issue.
Better cost management
With clear visibility of tasks, resource availability, and requirement, project managers can allocate 
resources efficiently and minimize unnecessary expenses.
Increased stakeholder satisfaction
By optimizing resource allocation and avoiding delays or cost overruns, project managers can 
demonstrate their ability to deliver high-quality results, enhancing stakeholder satisfaction.
Improved efficiency
Resource planning helps ensure the right resources are available at the right time, which can 
improve overall efficiency and productivity. In addition, it helps to avoid situations where resources 
are underutilized or overburdened.
Avoids overallocation
Overallocation occurs when a project manager assigns more work to a resource than they can 
realistically complete within a given time. With efficient resource planning, a project manager can 
avoid overallocation. Avoiding overallocation can help with:
•	Increased team morale
•	High energy and increased project involvement
•	Superior quality output
•	Reduction in delays
How to do resource planning
Project managers can use the resource breakdown structure (RBS) document to plan resources and 
avoid overallocation effectively. The Project Management Institute defines the resource breakdown 
structure as "a chart that is a hierarchical representation of resources by category and type."
Project managers create a resource breakdown structure during the planning phase of a 
project to identify all the necessary project resources, including human resources, software 
and tools, equipment, and more.
Conclusion
Resource planning is a crucial activity in project management that helps project managers 
manage resources effectively. Effective resource planning involves identifying and estimating the 
resources needed for a project and allocating them appropriately across tasks and timelines to 
ensure effective use. Project managers must consider several factors such as availability, skills, 
prioritization, interdependencies, and budget before assigning resources to tasks. Effective resource 
planning offers several benefits, including better estimation of timelines and deadlines, risk 
management, cost management, increased stakeholder satisfaction, and improved efficiency. The 
use of a resource breakdown structure document is a tool that project managers can use to plan 
resources effectively and avoid overallocation.

Acquiring Resources

Welcome to "Acquiring Resources."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Recognize the common challenges that project managers face when acquiring resources.
Explain why effective negotiation skills are important for project managers when acquiring
resources.
Identify the key principles of effective negotiation.
And describe how the key principles of effective negotiation can be applied to the challenges
of resource acquisition.
Acquiring resources needed to complete the project successfully is also a project manager's
responsibility.
However, acquiring resources can be a complex and challenging process.
Let's explore the most common challenges that project managers face when acquiring
resources.
One of the biggest challenges project managers face when acquiring resources is having a
limited budget to work with.
A limited budget can make it difficult to obtain the resources needed to complete the
project successfully.
Another common challenge is the limited availability of resources, including personnel, equipment,
or materials.
Sometimes, there may be conflicting priorities making it difficult to obtain a resource.
For example, consider a team member shared among multiple projects, making it challenging
to obtain the resource.
Lack of effective communication can lead to misunderstandings or confusion about resource
needs and availability.
The project manager can implement a few actionable resource acquisition strategies to mitigate
the challenges.
Let's look at the strategies.
Build a strong network of colleagues and potential resource providers, such as vendors, suppliers,
and subcontractors, to increase the likelihood of finding the necessary resources when they
are needed.
Build relationships with other department heads and project managers to identify potential
conflicts and proactively address them.
Ensure clear and effective communication with stakeholders and resource providers, including
concise documentation on timelines, budgets, and deliverables.
Conduct a cost-benefit analysis to determine which resources are critical to the project's
success and prioritize their acquisition.
While a project manager may implement one or more resource acquisition strategies, they
may still struggle to acquire the required resources.
Effective negotiation can help project managers to overcome some challenges by finding mutually
beneficial solutions that satisfy both the project's needs and the resource provider's
needs.
According to the PMBOK, negotiation is a process of communicating, collaborating, and 
compromising to reach a mutually acceptable agreement.
There are six key principles to effective negotiation, including:
Be prepared.
Build relationships.
Listen actively.
Communicate clearly.
Creatively solve problems.
Manage emotions.
Let's look at each principle in detail.
Be prepared.
Before the negotiation begins, the project manager should understand the negotiation
process, identify key issues, define objectives, and aim to understand the other party's interests.
The project manager must understand if there are any competing priorities or challenges
the other party may face regarding resources.
Build relationships.
When the negotiation begins, attempt to build a relationship and trust with the other party,
which can create a positive negotiation environment.
You can do this by expressing your willingness to work with the other person and identifying
areas of common interest.
Be sure to listen actively.
Active listening lets negotiators understand the other party's interests, concerns, and
needs.
If necessary, repeat back the other party's concerns or objections, and ask questions
to clarify.
Communicate clearly and assertively to avoid misunderstandings and ensure that both parties
understand each other's needs and expectations.
Be sure to state your resourcing needs and position clearly.
Think creatively to come up with possible solutions.
Be willing to explore alternative options and make concessions when necessary.
Finally, managing your emotions and maintaining a professional demeanour throughout the 
negotiation process is important.
Negotiation can be a stressful and emotional process, but following the key principles of effective 
negotiation can help you acquire resources even if you face many challenges.

In this video, you learned that:
Project managers face budget, availability, prioritization, and communication challenges
when acquiring resources.
Project managers can mitigate these challenges by networking, building relationships, clearly
communicating, and doing cost-benefit analysis.
Effective negotiation is a process of communicating, collaborating, and compromising with 
other parties to come to a mutually beneficial solution.
Project managers can effectively negotiate by following six key principles, including
preparing for the negotiation, building rapport, actively listening during negotiations,
clearly and assertively communicating needs, creatively problem-solving with other parties,
and managing their emotions.


Building Trust




Welcome to "Building Trust."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Summarize Lencioni's 5 dysfunctions of a team.
Identify methods to build trust.
Trust is a key factor that helps the project manager, team, and stakeholders ensure the project is 
successfully delivered on time and on budget.
When a team lacks trust, part of the project manager's role is to determine reasons for the trust 
deficit.
Lencioni's five dysfunctions of a team model describes five common dysfunctions that can 
occur within a team, which can impede trust and collaboration.
The dysfunctions build upon one another.
The first or the bottom-most layer of dysfunction is the absence of trust.
When team members are unwilling to be vulnerable and open up to each other, it creates a lack of 
trust within the team.
The next layer is fear of conflict.
Healthy debate and conflict are good for a team's growth.
When team members fear voicing their opinions and ideas, it can result in poor decision-making.
The third layer is a lack of commitment.
Team members may lack motivation and commitment when they don't align with project goals and 
objectives.
The fourth layer is avoidance of accountability.
Team members may not feel accountable or responsible for the project outcomes.
This can result from a lack of commitment or motivation.
The final layer is inattention to results.
When team members prioritize their individual goals over the project goals, it can lead to a lack of 
focus on achieving the desired outcomes.
Lencioni's dysfunction model shows that the absence of trust makes up the bottom layer.
Lencioni defines trust as the confidence among team members that their peers' intentions are 
good, and that there is no reason to be protective and careful around the group.
He describes trust as the willingness of team members to be vulnerable with each other and to 
admit their weaknesses and mistakes without fear of judgment or reprisal.
In other words, team members trust each other when they feel safe enough to be open and 
honest about their thoughts, feelings, and intentions.
According to Lencioni, trust is critical because it sets the tone for the rest of the team's interactions.
Without trust, team members are more likely to avoid conflict, withhold their opinions, and 
prioritize their individual goals over the project outcomes.
Trust is essential for building strong relationships and effective collaboration, and it requires 
a commitment from all team members to be open and honest with each other.
How do you, as a project manager, help a team build trust?
Building trust is not an easy exercise.
Building trust often requires teams to spend ample time together.
It also requires team members to have a deep understanding of others' unique skills, abilities, 
and personalities.
It requires team members to fulfil their commitments and complete tasks as promised consistently.
Finally, trust is earned through a track record of honesty, transparency, and accountability.
There are also a few team exercises you can leverage to help build trust more quickly.
For example, imagine a small digital marketing agency that has just been acquired by a more 
prominent, more traditional marketing firm.
The project manager believes there's a lack of trust in the team due to different personalities, 
communication styles, focus areas, and approaches.
One way the project manager can help the team gain a deeper understanding of other team members 
to build trust is to do an exercise where team members share information about themselves.
The exercises don't need to be incredibly personal in nature but should provide some interesting or 
unique information about each member.
Some examples include Two truths and a lie:
In this game, each team member shares three statements about themselves, two of which are true 
and one that's false.
The other team members must guess which statement is the lie
Human bingo:
Create a bingo card with different personal characteristics, such as "plays an instrument,"
"has travelled to a foreign country," or "speaks more than one language."
Team members must talk to each other and find someone who fits each characteristic until they 
have a full bingo card Life-mapping: Have each team member create a short visual timeline of the 
most important, impactful events of their life and share key points with the team.
You can ask team members to keep the timeline professional in nature and focus on things like 
educational milestones, career milestones, and inflection points where they learned a new skill
or had a life-changing conversation with a mentor.
Now, imagine the new marketing team is working on a complex project with tight deadlines and 
multiple dependencies.
The team members do not communicate regularly with each other or with the project 
manager, and they avoid sharing their progress, challenges, or ideas.
They also do not give or receive constructive feedback on their work.
When the team does communicate, conversations quickly turn into heated debates.
To build trust in this scenario, a project manager may have the team take a personality 
assessment and share their results with key members of their team.
Understanding different personality types and preferences can help team members understand their 
own strengths and weaknesses and communicate more effectively with others who have different 
preferences.
A few of the most popular assessments include:
Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI):
This assessment measures personality preferences based on four dichotomies:
extraversion/introversion, sensing/intuition, thinking/feeling, and judging/perceiving.
DiSC: This assessment measures behavioural styles based on four dimensions:
dominance, influence, steadiness, and conscientiousness.
Strengths Finder: This assessment measures individual strengths across 34 talent themes.
Insights and Emergenetics: Breaks out an individual's thinking attributes into four styles to 
determine work preferences, communications styles, and more.
By applying some of these strategies, the project manager of the newly created marketing team
can begin to build trust in the team.
Over time, as the team members fulfil their commitments and continue to be more transparent,
trust will continue to grow.

In this video, you learned that:
Lencioni's 5 dysfunctions of a team include: absence of trust, fear of conflict, lack of 
commitment, avoidance of accountability, and inattention to results.
Trust is the confidence among team members that their peer's intentions are good
and that there's no reason to be protective and careful around the group.
Building trust is not easy, and it requires time, credibility, and an understanding of team 
members' unique attributes.
Project managers can leverage exercises such as unique attributes exercises and personality 
assessments to build trust more quickly.

Environment
