Emotional Intelligence

Welcome to "Emotional Intelligence."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Define the five components of the emotional intelligence (EQ) theory.
Summarize how project managers can use EQ and identify methods to improve EQ.
Project managers often need to use their emotional skills to inspire team confidence and 
commitment.
Since project managers interact and influence many individuals in an organization, they
can have a large impact.
Imagine two people interacting and then imagine the interaction cascading into project teams,
groups, and the whole organization.
That is the power of influence.
Emotional intelligence, or EQ, determines how well a project manager can form and maintain
relationships, as their decisions can impact many relationships in a complex network.

The Project Management Institute, or PMI, defines emotional intelligence as "the ability
to identify, assess, and manage the emotions of oneself and other people, as well as the 
collective emotions of groups of people."
The emotional intelligence model, which is used globally, includes five components:
Self-awareness, which is the act of knowing your own emotions and how they affect your
thoughts and behavior.
Self-regulation, which involves managing your emotions and impulses so that you can respond
appropriately to situations.
Motivation, which is the ability to motivate yourself and others to achieve goals.
Empathy, which is the understanding other people's emotions and being able to respond
appropriately.
And social skills include the ability to communicate effectively with others, resolve conflicts,
and build relationships.
Let's understand how a project manager can make use of the components of EQ.
Having knowledge about emotional intelligence can help a project manager in many ways,
such as Managing stakeholders, Fostering trust, Making decisions, Leading teams.
Let's look at an example of EQ at work.
Rose is a project manager managing a project to replace city-wide streetlights.
As the project progresses, there is a disagreement between the city officials and the lighting
vendors regarding the delay in project timelines.
The lighting vendors have had an unforeseen issue causing a delay in material supply.
Rose listens to the perspectives of both parties and understands their challenges.
Without being judgmental or biased, Rose focuses on the problem at hand.
This helps her foster trust with both parties.
Further, Rose is able to manage both parties to help them agree to a new acceptable timeline.
A strong EQ is an asset for any project manager.
Every project manager should test their current EQ level and work toward improvement if required.
There are many emotional intelligence assessments that you can take to test EQ levels.
These include tests such as the Emotional and Social Competency Inventory, the Six Seconds
Emotional Intelligence Assessment, and Team Emotional Intelligence.
Some techniques to improve EQ include:
Self-reflection, engaging with your own emotions, and getting feedback from leaders and 
peers to better understand how you are perceived.
In this video, you learned that:
Emotional intelligence, or EQ, is "the ability to identify, assess and manage the emotions
of oneself and other people, as well as the collective emotions of groups of people."
The EQ model includes the five components of self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation,
empathy, and social skills.
EQ helps project managers foster trust, make more rational decisions, manage stakeholders,
become better leaders, and improve project outcomes.
Project managers assess their EQ with a number of assessments and use techniques such as
self-reflection and gathering feedback to improve their EQ.


 
Managing Up
Project managers frequently interact with stakeholders who are in higher-level positions or hold 
influence over a project. In such cases, a project manager may need to manage up.
Objectives
After completing this reading, you will be able to:
•	Define managing up.
•	Identify common stakeholders project managers may need to manage up.
•	Explore tips for managing up.
•	Describe the benefits of managing up.
What is managing up?
Managing up refers to the process of building a productive working relationship with one's 
manager and senior stakeholders to achieve common goals and objectives. It involves 
proactively and strategically communicating with the reporting manager and senior stakeholders, 
anticipating their needs and priorities, and aligning one's work with their expectations.
Successful project managers understand that each role in a project plays a unique and important part 
in the project's success. To effectively manage up, it is important for project managers to 
understand the types of stakeholders that may need to be managed. Some of the most 
common roles that need managed up include:
Reporting manager
The reporting manager is one of the first stakeholders that a project manager will manage up. 
Helping the reporting manager in different ways to help improve their efficiency and efficacy is a 
good strategy.
Senior management
Senior management includes executives, department heads, and other senior leaders within the 
organization who hold decision-making authority over the project. As a project manager, helping 
senior managers understand how project objectives align with organizational goals and 
providing information can help them make more informed decisions.
Clients
Project managers may need to manage up client stakeholders who have contracted the organization 
for the project. Proactively communicating project progress, risks, and issues, helps avoid surprises 
and builds a trusting relationship with clients.
Vendors or Contractors
If the project involves working with external vendors or contractors, project managers may need to 
manage up vendors and contractors to ensure that they are meeting the organization's standards 
and contributing effectively to the project.
As a project manager, it is important to ensure that all these roles are working together effectively, 
and managing up is crucial to the project's success.
How to manage up
Managing up can feel uncomfortable at first. However, it is an important skill for a project manager. 
Here are some tips for effectively managing up.
Build a relationship
Building a positive relationship is key to managing up with managers or colleagues who hold 
influence over a project manager's work. The project manager must get to know them and their 
work style and establish a rapport based on trust and mutual respect.
Communicate effectively
Clear communication is crucial when managing up. The project manager must make sure to 
articulate their goals and priorities clearly and be proactive in communicating updates and progress.
Anticipate their needs
The project manager must try to anticipate the needs and preferences of the stakeholder being 
managed up and tailor work accordingly. For example, a project manager may need to adjust 
their work style and prioritize the stakeholder's requests while providing timely updates.
Show initiative
The project manager should proactively take on tasks or responsibilities that will help the 
stakeholder or the project succeed. This can help demonstrate your value and build trust.
Be collaborative
Rather than seeing the stakeholder as a potential obstacle, the project manager should view them as 
a partner in achieving shared goals. Look for ways to collaborate and work together effectively.
Be respectful
Even when managing up, the project manager must maintain respect for the stakeholder's 
position and authority. The project manager must never undermine a stakeholder's authority or act 
in a way that could be seen as insubordination.
The benefits of managing up
Project managers who successfully manage up can benefit in several ways.
Improved communication
When project managers effectively manage up, they establish clear lines of communication with 
their superiors and stakeholders, which helps ensure that expectations and priorities are aligned. 
This can reduce misunderstandings and delays and ensure that the project runs more smoothly.
Increased support
By building positive working relationships with their manager and senior stakeholders, project 
managers can gain greater support for their project. This can include access to additional resources, 
buy-in from stakeholders, and increased visibility within the organization.
Greater autonomy
When project managers effectively manage up, they may be given more autonomy to make 
decisions and take action. This can help them be more efficient and effective in their work and build 
their confidence and sense of ownership over the project.
Career advancement
Successfully managing up can demonstrate a project manager's leadership and communication 
skills, which can be valuable for career advancement opportunities within the organization. It can 
also increase the likelihood of being entrusted with more complex and high-profile projects in the 
future.
Conclusion
In conclusion, managing up is a crucial skill for project managers to have, especially when 
dealing with stakeholders who hold higher-level positions or have influence over a project. By 
building positive relationships, communicating effectively, anticipating needs, showing initiative, 
being collaborative, and maintaining respect, project managers can successfully manage up to 
achieve shared goals and objectives. The benefits of managing up include improved 
communication, increased support, greater autonomy, and career advancement opportunities. 
By mastering the art of managing up, project managers can ensure the success of their projects and 
advance their careers within their organization.
Adaptability and Resilience

Welcome to "Adaptability and Resilience."
After watching this video, you will be able to:
Define adaptability and resilience.
Discuss examples of adaptability and resilience.
Implement adaptability and resilience traits to effective communications and leadership.
Netflix started as a DVD rental-by-mail service. Customers could order DVDs online and receive 
them in the mail.
Ten years later Netflix, powered by new streaming technologies, launched its online streaming 
service, allowing customers to watch movies and TV shows directly on their computers.
Since then, video streaming has become one of the primary ways that people consume media.
But, even with the challenge of increased competition, Netflix has continued to evolve and is 
considered a leading streaming platform.
This example illustrates the leadership characteristics of adaptability and resilience.
Netflix has adapted over the years to stay relevant.
And they have shown resilience by continually moving forward despite challenges, such as a 
heavily competitive market.
Adaptability and resilience are two essential qualities necessary for effective leadership.
Adaptability refers to the ability to adjust to changing circumstances and situations.
Let's look at some of the benefits of being adaptable.
Adaptable leaders can quickly assess new situations, make necessary changes to their plans,
and effectively navigate unexpected challenges.
For example, during COVID-19, organizations had to adapt quickly to the idea of a remote 
workforce and make the required adjustments to technology and behaviours.
Those who struggled perished.
Resilience, however, refers to recovering quickly from setbacks and failures.
Resilient leaders can maintain their focus and motivation even when things don't go as 
planned.
A resilient leader might face a significant setback such as losing a key employee or a failed product 
launch.
Rather than giving up, they can use the experience as a learning opportunity and develop a new 
plan.
They maintain their focus and motivation and can inspire their team to do the same.
Adaptability and resilience are good traits for a project manager to have.
Some common ways that project managers need to apply adaptability and resilience are the 
following:
Adjusting communication style
Being open to feedback
Embracing change
Staying focused.
Let's look at some examples to understand adaptability and resilience better.
When many companies shifted to remote work during COVID-19, there was a huge impact on 
communication between team members and stakeholders.
Short hallway conversations and mid-day coffee brainstorms were no longer possible.
And asynchronous communication methods, like team chats, became even more popular.
In this scenario, project managers had to quickly study and adapt to their team members' 
communication styles and preferences.
Amidst all this, the project managers had to ensure everyone followed the organization's work 
policies.
The project managers tried to adapt their communication approaches to different communication 
preferences, which helped keep teams engaged and motivated to work towards project goals.
In the end, success came to project managers who could adapt to change.
Here's another example.
Imagine a project manager leading a construction project to build a new office block.
The project manager receives news of supply shortages for a special type of wood and steel 
specified in the development plans.
Changing the material will require changing the building permits.
In this scenario, the project manager should not make a rash decision.
Instead, the project manager can contact team members, stakeholders, and other project leaders for 
feedback and ideas.
For example, construction contractors can provide feedback on alternative materials.
Local officials and regulators can provide feedback on how to expedite the permit process and 
suggest alternative solutions to meet any regulatory requirements.
Resilience is key.
As a good leader, a project manager should constantly look for solutions and never give up.

In this video, you learned that:
Adaptability and resilience are two important qualities
that are necessary for effective leadership.
Adaptability refers to the ability to adjust to changing circumstances and situations.
Resilience refers to the ability to recover quickly from setbacks and failures.
Project managers can apply adaptability and resilience
by adjusting their communication styles, being open to feedback, embracing change, and 
staying focused.

Expert Viewpoints: Overcoming Resource 
Planning Challenges

Welcome to Expert Viewpoints: Overcoming Resource Challenges.
In this video, we will hear experts and leaders discuss overcoming resource challenges.
How did you overcome resource planning challenges you have encountered?
Resource planning challenges can be very real and very critical,
and when you get to a larger size company or you start having multiple projects running in parallel 
of competing priority, resource management and capacity planning becomes more difficult.
So one, you need to have a clear understanding as a resource planner of what the tasks are,
how long they're going to take in general, and when your projects are gonna wrap up
so that you can start the synchronized conducting of resourcing.
Second is, once you've come up with good resourcing plans you see the ebb and flow of the 
projects, you begin to identify peaks and valleys.
For us, July and September tend to be slower months and so "How can I take advantage as a 
resource planner of slower months, when December and through April is a just insane race to get 
work done?"
So I look for trends as far as our projects. I look for resource alignment.
Are there project teams that work really well together on specific projects?
Are there others where it just doesn't work out? We have to rematch.
I look for that. And then I also bring in other people.
So, within our organization at Skill-Up, each team is responsible for their own resources, but 
managing and prioritizing projects across the entire company is my responsibility.
And so I have to understand everybody's schedules almost and commitments and
project commitments so that I can advise swaps:
"We need more instructional designers here," or "I've got a high priority there."
How can I send people over to the right spots at the right time and not completely derail other 
projects that need to continue?
So to do that, I meet with all my leads, all my managers, and then all of our supporting teams as 
well. And understand workloads, capacity challenges, and then I can make those decisions
better informed in the moment-- I don't get them all right, but I try to be as informed as I can.

I would say the greatest resource challenge I encounter is a failure to plan and manage resource 
risks.
A project requires a defined number of personnel, equipment, supplies, materials and potentially 
other miscellaneous resources such as licenses or permits.
Unfortunately, many project managers assume that resources will be available when needed.
and find this assumption was erroneous as the project progresses.
Planning is the key--So the logical follow-up question is, "How do you overcome them?"
Well, let's share a step-by-step approach and see if we can answer this question.
Step number one.
Break out the project into phases and chronological activities that must be accomplished.
The best tool to accomplish this is referred to as a Work Breakdown Structure or WBS.
Step number two.
Assign core team members who are knowledgeable on each activity in that work breakdown 
structure.
It is their job to define all resource requirements for that particular activity.
Step number three.
Document all activities and resource requirements on a tool called the Resource Breakdown 
Structure.
This tool defines each resource required, by activity, and defines when the resource will be required.
And finally, determine who manages and distributes the resources you need.
Share your time-phased resource breakdown structure with these individuals.
Identify any risks upfront and begin working those responses ahead of time.

I was working on a project a few years ago with a company that I was with and I was leading a team 
to redo the website of a major tech company.
And my team was responsible for creating content for about 30 pages of the website, and we only 
had one content writer at the time.
and as we were looking at the project schedule and trying to figure out how we were going to get 
everything done, we realized there was no way that we would be able to complete the project with 
just one resource.
So, I was facing some resourcing challenges.
There was not anyone else that was available, on different teams, or other teams to support my 
content writer, and we really just needed some folks to write content for the website.
So, I actually had to go to the manager that was above me to let her know, first of all, that we were 
going to have resourcing issues, and that we had resourcing issues, and that the timeline was going 
to be impacted if we didn't get any more resources, and in working with her, we discussed that there 
was potentially a budget to bring on some more resources, but it also wasn't *her* decision.
So, her and I had to come up with a plan:
"How many resources did we actually think that we were going to need?"
"How long did we think that we were going to need those resources for?"
"What skills did those resources need to have?" and then, "What was the available budget that we 
had to spend on those resources?" and then we actually took that to our VP, that plan to our VP, and 
requested that we get some contracting resources just for the duration of the project.
So, her and I had to put together this plan and then we pitched it to the VP of our department who 
approved the use of contractors and approved our plan.
But then I was stuck because I needed... the resources!
I had the *money* for the resources now, I was approved to get the resources, but I still didn't have 
those resources.
so I actually had to-- and I needed them very quickly-- so I actually had to tap some people in my 
network to ask them
a) If they wanted to do this work, if they were available to work, and if they wanted to do this work.
And if they didn't, if they knew anyone who would be available to do that work and have the skill 
set that we needed.
And so within a few days of getting the budget and the plan approved,
I was doing interviews and talking to some people that we could use as contracting resources.
And we were really able to find just two or three people who could work for a short amount of time,
they were were willing to do the role, they had the skills that we needed, and we were able to get 
those people within our budget.


 
Module 5 Summary: Managing and Leading 
Stakeholders
Congratulations! You have completed this module. At this point in the course, you know that:
•	Resource planning is an important activity in project management that helps project 
managers manage resources effectively.
•	Effective resource planning involves identifying and estimating the resources needed for a 
project and allocating them appropriately across tasks and timelines to ensure effective use.
•	Project managers face budget, availability, prioritization, and communication challenges 
when acquiring resources. Project managers can mitigate these challenges by networking, 
building relationships, clearly communicating, and doing a cost-benefit analysis.
•	Project managers can effectively negotiate by following six key principles:
•	Preparing for the negotiation
•	Building rapport
•	Actively listening during negotiations
•	Clearly and assertively communicating needs
•	Creatively problem-solving with other parties
•	Managing their emotions
•	Lencioni's five dysfunctions of a team include:
•	Absence of trust
•	Fear of conflict
•	Lack of commitment
•	Avoidance of accountability
•	Inattention to results
•	Trust is the confidence among team members that their peers' intentions are good and that 
there is no reason to be protective and careful around the group.
•	Building trust is not easy, and it requires time, credibility, and an understanding of team 
members' unique attributes.
•	Project managers can leverage exercises, such as unique attributes exercises and personality 
assessments, to build trust more quickly.
•	Emotional intelligence is "the ability to identify, assess and manage the emotions of oneself 
and other people, as well as the collective emotions of groups of people."
•	The EQ model includes the five components of self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation, 
empathy, and social skills.
•	Project managers assess their EQ with several assessments and use techniques such as self-
reflection and gathering feedback to improve their EQ.
•	Project managers can successfully achieve shared goals and objectives by:
•	Building positive relationships
•	Communicating effectively
•	Anticipating needs
•	Showing initiative
•	Being collaborative
•	Maintaining respect
•	Adaptability and resilience are two essential qualities that are necessary for effective 
leadership:
•	Adaptability refers to the ability to adjust to changing circumstances and situations.
•	Resilience refers to the ability to recover quickly from setbacks and failures.
•	Project managers can apply adaptability and resilience by adjusting their communication 
styles, being open to feedback, embracing change, and staying focused.

Key Takeaways
Effective communications, stakeholder management, and leadership can be the difference between 
project success or failure. Effective communications, stakeholder management, and leadership can 
be the difference between project success or failure. This course provided guidance and examples 
on how to create a healthy project foundation-the course then dove into effective communications 
building blocks.
The key takeaways from this course include:
•	The best project managers always put their people first. They place the right people in the 
right roles. Fostering an empowering and problem-solving mindset.
•	Communicate project objectives that are crisp, understandable, and actionable. They ensure 
a common understanding of what the project will and will not produce and avoid scope 
creep.
•	Strive to be a servant leader. Work alongside your team and put them first. This will build 
trust and help you better understand project details, discover issues, and succeed.
•	Understand the criticality of having effective conversations early and throughout the project. 
Practice key communication skills essential to project success. Examine areas such as 
written, oral, public speaking, presentation skills, teamwork, collaboration, and negotiation.
•	Develop a process for managing end-to-end project communications. Identify challenges 
and potential solutions to ensure effective communications.
•	Understand various media options available and the advantages and disadvantages of each. 
Research and select the most appropriate media. Understand the difference between 
synchronous and asynchronous communications and select the media that matches the need.
•	Understand the impact of culture on effective communications. Avoid allowing project 
communications to be dependent upon the grapevine.
•	Understand and practice the concept of failing fast. Know when a failing fast mindset can be 
advantageous. Understand potential areas where a project may fail.
•	Know the key roles required for the project to be successful. Assign roles and 
responsibilities using common RACI methodology. Ensure the team commits to their role.
•	Critical Path method is a scheduling technique that estimates the minimum project duration 
and allows you to determine how much scheduling flexibility you have on all schedule 
paths. Critical Chain is another scheduling methodology that adds resource and time buffers 
to all schedule paths to guard against potential resource shortages and delays. Use both 
methods to your advantage.
•	Develop and implement a Communications Management Plan. This plan defines all critical 
communications items, ensures information gets to the right stakeholders in a timely manner 
and enhances efficient and effective communications. Key communications items covered 
include virtual meetings and status reporting.
•	All stakeholders communicate differently. There are four basic communication styles. Adapt 
your message as much as possible to meet the audience's style and needs to improve 
communications effectiveness.
•	Attributes of a good leader were shared. You had an opportunity to assess your leadership 
strengths and weaknesses and develop an initial action plan to improve your leadership 
skills.
•	The Tuckman Ladder is a popular model that shares the steps a team must take to become 
highly productive. The model discusses readiness levels of an individual in each stage and 
provides a recommended leadership approach. Good leaders understand that each individual 
has different levels of ability and confidence and adapts their leadership situationally to meet 
those needs.
•	The difference between a manager and a leader was highlighted. A successful project 
manager should excel in both roles. We discussed the importance of knowledge sharing. 
Understand various categories of information you receive and use it to your advantage.
•	There may be times when you don't have all the information you need or adequate time to 
make an objective decision. Intuitive decision-making is a skill you need to develop and 
apply on those occasions.
•	A project manager must identify all required resources. Once identified, develop a plan that 
shares when resources are needed and in what quantity. Finally, the project manager must 
manage and control the resources provided wisely. A resource breakdown structure (RBS) is 
a great tool to accomplish these goals.
•	A project manager should strive to establish a culture of trust. In addition, a successful 
project manager displays high levels of Emotional Intelligence. Begin with self-awareness 
and learn to self-manage. From there, social awareness will increase, and relationships will 
gel.
•	The ability to effectively manage up is critical. In addition, adaptability and resilience are 
skills to work on and improve.
•	There are many reasons why projects fail. At the top of the list are poor communications, 
inadequate stakeholder management, and a lack of effective leadership. Use tools and 
techniques provided in this course to move your project management skills to the next level.



Course Introduction


Are you interested in pursuing a career in the IT industry, such as Product Manager,
IT Marketing Manager, or any role that involves interacting with IT practitioners such as
a Developer?
If so, this course is designed to meet your needs!
You will learn a solid foundation of IT fundamentals, enabling you to understand and speak the 
same language as IT professionals.
Whether you are new to the field or simply want to enhance your existing knowledge, this
course will equip you with the essential skills and insights to excel in the IT industry.
This course introduces you to key areas of Information Technology (or IT), including:
Computer hardware and operating systems, Software, programming, and databases, Networking and
storage, Cybersecurity, and cloud computing.
Concepts related to these areas are presented in five modules.
The sixth module will allow you to apply your newly acquired skills in a graded exam.
The sixth module also has bonus lessons you may complete to learn about IT support and
operations.
Module 1 introduces what a computer and an operating system are and the characteristics of 
different types of each.
It is crucial to understand what a computer is and how it is classified by size and usage.
You'll also learn about internal and external computer components, such as ports, connectors, and 
peripheral devices, which enhance their functionality.
In Module 2, you will learn about the differences between commercial and open-source software, 
software licenses, and common types of software.
You will gain familiarity with basic programming concepts and database fundamentals.
Computer networks form the backbone of modern communication, enabling devices to connect and 
share information.
Module 3 introduces you to computer networks, common cable types used in networking, and the 
differences between wired and wireless connection types.
You will explore the location of common network resources and network storage types in Microsoft
Windows, allowing for seamless navigation and utilization of shared network services.
In Module 4, you will learn how to ensure the security and protection of sensitive information on 
your computer.
Understanding the CIA Triad Model, consisting of confidentiality, integrity, and availability, 
provides a framework for addressing security concerns.
You will also learn about intellectual property, different types of security threats, and how to 
address security concerns related to public browsing.
You will explore password management best practices and learn about authentication factors.
Cloud computing has revolutionized how businesses and individuals access and use computing 
resources.
In Module 5, you will learn the five essential characteristics of cloud computing and explore its 
benefits.
You will also learn about the cloud infrastructure layer, storage options, and networking 
infrastructure,
providing insights into the underlying components that power cloud computing.
You will learn to identify types of virtual machines on cloud computing and explore virtual machine 
configurations for different workloads.
You will discover emerging technologies and trends around cloud computing, such as containers,
microservices, DevOps, and Cloud Native.
Finally, in Module 6, you will have the opportunity to apply the concepts you have learned in the 
course in a final assessment quiz.
You may choose to complete bonus lessons in module 6, which covers IT support and operations.
In these lessons you will have the opportunity to learn the importance of troubleshooting, the tiered 
support process, and service-level agreements.
You will explore features of ticketing systems, including how tickets are tagged and routed and why 
automation is critical in a ticketing system.
How you will learn: Guided instructional videos walk you through the key concepts with essential 
need-to-know facts.
Interactive activities reinforce what you've learned in videos, and virtual hands-on labs allow you to 
apply new knowledge and skills as you learn.
Practice assessments help you gauge your knowledge.
And graded assessments prove what you've learned, leading to a shareable badge and certificate 
you can show prospective employers.
As you take the course, if you struggle with a concept or have a question about an assignment,
please contact us in the discussion forum.
We're here to support your success and are excited you're here.
Let's get started!
