Module 1 Overview

This module defines the Scrum Master role and summarizes the Scrum Framework and the Scrum 
Master's involvement. It also describes how the role benefits the organization. In addition, the 
module also sums up the key skills required to be a successful Scrum Master. You will also discover 
the critical tasks the Scrum Master performs daily. Then, you can go through a reading on the 
Adaptive Methodologies where the Scrum Master role is essential. A hands-on activity will reiterate 
your learning on the role and skills of the Scrum Master.


Scrum Master Role and Benefits

Hello and welcome to this module on what is the role of the scrum master and the benefits of the 
role.
After watching this video, you'll be able to define the scrum master role, summarize the scrum 
framework and the scrum masters involvement, and explain how the scrum master role benefits the 
organization.
A scrum master is not a project manager.
In contrast, they act as coaches, facilitators and team members.
Unlike project managers, a scrum master does not plan the overall project from start to finish.
Manage budgets, control risks or procure material.
Nevertheless, some of their tasks are associated with those performed by project managers.
scrum masters lead teams, remove roadblocks, participate in the planning process for the team's 
work.
Lead meetings and scrum events, improve processes, reports to the management, support product 
owner and other stakeholders and help the team work together.
As a coach, a scrum master removes impediments and to promote a healthy team environment.
As a facilitator, they lead the scrum process, plan activities, track and collect data, and to help bring 
work to completion.
Traditional project managers execute a predetermined plan to produce deliverables.
While scrum masters utilize an iterative and incremental approach to complete work.
A scrum master must navigate through the complexities of aligning and realigning the team to the 
vision of the product owner and ensure the team provides value as planned.
Let's look at the steps in the scrum process.
During sprint planning part one-step, the team selects requirements or user stories from the product 
backlog they believe they can accomplish during the sprint.
The scrum master schedules this event and ensures everyone on the team participates.
In addition, the scrum master ensures that the team commits to what they can achieve in the plan 
timeline.
Scrum master works closely with the product owner to ensure the user stories selected are
well-defined in the terms of the role, need, value and acceptance criteria.
The product owner is responsible for the development and upkeep of the product backlog.
However, the quality of the user stories in the product backlog directly impacts the scrum master 
and the team.
In Sprint planning part 2 the team must complete a sprint backlog.
This is a breakout of all requirements into tasks.
The scrum master again ensures that the entire team participates.
They also facilitate, ensuring the team self organizes and assigns roles to each task.
During the sprint, the scrum master facilitates a daily scrum meeting.
They ensure everyone participates in the meeting.
They also ascertain that the sprint Kanban board is updated and then any burndown charts
being used are current.
If there are blockers, the scrum master acts to have them removed.
If there's a conflict, the scrum master manages it.
The goal of the sprint is to develop a minimal viable product MVP by the end of the sprint that
satisfies user story done criteria.
In the review or demo step, the scrum master ensures that all accomplished work during the sprint is 
ready for presentation on the sprint's final day.
They work closely with the team to present functionality and attain feedback.
In many cases, the scrum master prepares the product owner to present the functionality at the 
meeting.
The scrum master facilitates a retrospective at the end of the sprint.
At this meeting, every member of the team shares what went well, what can be improved and
their ideas for one big improvement.
The scrum master ensures that there is consensus on the improvement items selected and
works towards adopting it in the newsprint.
According to the scrum alliance, a scrum master provides immeasurable value to an 
organization.
Scrum masters ensure that the team is doing the right thing.
Scrum masters inspire the team and others to follow the scrum process and adhere to the 
scrum values without wavering.
Scrum masters or coaches and teachers.
They are servant leaders who put others before themselves.
They ascertain that the team has the skills and tools needed to succeed.
The scrum master ensures that the entire organization understands the value of scrum and
ensures the team's work is recognized.
The scrum master proactively identifies and addresses blockers and impediments and
paves the way for the team success.
Let's discuss other benefits of the scrum master role.
Scrum masters constantly search for improved ways to serve the team and organization.
They ensure retrospectives are accomplished and all team members must participate and most 
importantly, positive changes are implemented.
A solid scrum master is also known as a waste buster.
Scrum masters work with other scrum masters in the organization and share their expertise and 
insights.
In doing so, they gain additional knowledge and insights that help them improve their effectiveness.
Scrum masters are master problem-solvers, who help the organization achieve value-driven 
solutions.
In addition, they are always one step ahead of the rest of the team and planning for a better 
tomorrow.

In this video, you learned that unlike project managers, a scrum master does not plan the overall 
project from start to finish, manage budgets, control risks or procure material.
Scrum masters lead teams, remove roadblocks, participate in the planning process for the team's 
work and help the team work together.
The various steps in the sprint process are Sprint planning 1 and 2, sprint, review or demo and 
retrospective.
Scrum masters have various benefits.
They are coaches and servant leaders who lead by example.

Expert Viewpoints: What does the Scrum 
Master Do?

Welcome to Expert Viewpoints.
In this video, we will hear Agile and
Scrum experts describe the role of the Scrum Master.
Its unique functions and  to its success.
In my opinion, the role of the Scrum Master is the facilitator and
the servant leader.
Your job is to ensure that the team understands and is following the Scrum principles, practices and 
values.
The way I like to think about it is the product owner focuses on building the right thing.
The development team focuses on building the thing right, and the Scrum Master focuses on 
building the thing efficiently.
So what are the aspects of the Scrum Master role that are most critical to success?
I believe that the aspects of the Scrum Master role that are most critical to the success of a Scrum 
Master is that of being a servant leader, being a coach and being a mentor.
These are crucial in your ability to help the team understand and follow Scrum.

My opinion, the overall role of a Scrum Master is to facilitate
the effective implementation of his Scrum principles and practices.
Promote collaboration, remove impediments, and foster continuous improvement.
Unlike other roles, the Scrum Master does not have authority over the team, but serves as a servant 
leader and facilitator.
A Scrum Master has a unique role in many ways.
A Scrum Master is responsible for ensuring that the team and organization understand Scrum theory 
and practice.
In a sense, they need to sell the value of Scrum.
So, they are not solely accountable for the team's effectiveness alone, but they are accountable to 
the entire organization as a whole.
A Scrum Master must epitomize servant leadership to be effective.
This service takes the form of, number one, coaching the team.
Number two, the Scrum Master guides the team and positions them to create high value increments.
Number three, one of the key roles of the Scrum Master is to remove impediments or blockers.
And finally, a Scrum Master is a master organizer and facilitator.
A Scrum Master differs from most other management roles.
A Scrum Master is not necessarily responsible for doing the work, but they are tasked to pave the 
way for the team to accomplish its goals.
Rather, they prepare the team to self-organize, determine what needs to be done, and work 
together to accomplish what is referred to in Scrum as done.

Being a Scrum Master is multifaceted.
It's not one dimensional at all.
You are a coach, a leader, a guide, an expert in the Scrum framework process.
Your goal is the team's success.
That's why you're there.
Notice that I didn't say anything about completing tasks, project management.
That's because this is what makes the Scrum Master a little
bit different from other roles.
You're not even a manager in the hierarchical sense.
In fact, you're trying to put yourself as far behind the scenes as you can.
You are a servant leader, you are the person that is there to support the team and however you can 
make that successful, that's your job.
You need to help them get to the finish line.

The main role of the Scrum Master is to facilitate the Scrum processes and ceremonies.
And to act as a coach to the team through their adoption of the Scrum framework.
Unlike the product owner, they are not involved with the product strategy, the why of the product.
Nor are they like the development team in determining how the work is done.
They are the conduit between the two and fostering that communication is one of their 
responsibilities that is most critical to success.

First and foremost, understand the Scrum process and ensure it is understood and followed.
A Scrum Master is in a sense a process manager.
Next, the Scrum Master is also a facilitator and a coach.
They must facilitate all required events and ensure the right people are present and contribute.
As a coach, ensure the team is empowered to self direct and excel on the job.
The Scrum Master is also a conflict manager.
If a conflict surfaces, the Scrum Master collaborates with all involved to reach a satisfactory 
resolution.
In addition, the Scrum Master engages stakeholders to recognize and leverage different ways of 
thinking.
And ensures all stakeholders are working together to achieve the goals of the project.
And finally, the Scrum Master is a status manager.
They ensure the Kanban board is up to date, develop and maintain burn down charts.
Collaborate with the product manager to ensure the backlog of requirements is current and refined 
as needed.

A Scrum Master is a servant leader, a facilitator, a coach, a good communicator, a liaison, a good 
observer.
The most important role, the most vital aspect of a Scrum Master is removing impediments and also 
being that binding agent, that agent that binds the entire team together.
That way, the team is able to meet its prints goal and at the end of the day, the customer is going to 
be satisfied with all the work that has been done during the sprint.

You're focused on the team's success.
It's not really about your success.
You're not successful if the team is not successful.
It's not just about finishing tasks or success is defined by the customers needs.
And you're there to help the team get there because there's going to be challenges, there's going to 
be roadblocks.
And you're going to be the one to help them clear a path to the success that is defined by your 
customer or your product owner.
And you're going to help them get better along the way.
You're going to do process improvement and you're going to show them how they can be 
successful.


Scrum Master Skill Inventory


Welcome to this module on the skills necessary to be a successful Scrum Master.
After watching this video, you'll be able to, summarize skills necessary to be a successful Scrum 
Master, and explain the need for each skill.
There are a number of key skills a Scrum Master must learn and become proficient at to be 
effective.
Much of the information shared is extracted from a document called the Scrum Guide.
This document provides a blueprint to effectively implement Scrum and was originally created and
updated by some of the founders of the original Scrum methodology.
First and foremost, the Scrum Master must be an expert in the Scrum framework.
This person must possess a thorough understanding of Scrum methodology.
The team in the organization expect the Scrum Master to know how to guide the organization.
In some cases, you may be expected to lead an organization through a transformation from 
traditional project management methodology to Scrum.
A Scrum Master must have the skills necessary to be an effective servant leader.
To be effective, the following servant leadership skills are essential, manage relationships, 
encourage and create development opportunities, build effective communications with the team and 
across the organization.
Effective communication builds trust and credibility and increases the team's motivation to commit 
to doing the work that needs to be done, encourage the team to embrace success and provide 
development opportunities to grow, facilitate collaboration and act as a diversion shield.
Support everyone to be creative and innovative, encourage the team's participation, understanding, 
and creativity, and create a sense of shared responsibility.
A team can generally accomplish far more together than a single individual.
In addition, shield the team from external distractions as much as possible so they can concentrate 
on the work at hand, remove organizational impediments and obstacles, look for issues, blockers 
existing processes, and out-of-date practices that limit the team's effectiveness and pave the way to 
process improvements and improve performance.
The Scrum Master facilitates end of sprint retrospectives and can help achieve this goal.
Educate all stakeholders on both the value of Scrum and how effective implementation can provide 
value.
The Scrum Master must act as a change agent to move the organization forward.
As a Scrum Master, develop your coaching skills.
A Scrum Master is expected to coach team members to become self-directing, self-organizing, and 
skilled in cross-functional communication.
A key goal is to enable any and all team members to assume the role of a Scrum Master.
Help the Scrum team focus on creating high-value increments that meet the definition of 
Done.
An increment is a deliverable from a sprint that provides value to a customer.
Done indicates that the team was able to accomplish all solution criteria for a user story and 
gain sign off from the customer.
General management skills are also needed to ensure that the team stays focused and doesn't deviate 
from what needs to be done.
The goal of each sprint is to create and deliver a Minimum Viable Product, or MVP.
A Scrum Master needs to understand the purpose and desired outcomes of all scrum events and 
ceremonies.
They must ensure all Scrum events take place and are positive, productive, and kept within the 
timebox.
These include sprint planning, the daily stand-up meeting, demos, and retrospectives.
A Scrum Master also needs to be an effective process manager.
A Scrum Master must be able to identify and address sources of conflict.
This includes promoting functional conflict that may move the sprint forward, or mitigating 
dysfunctional conflict which can get quickly out of hand and impact a sprint negatively.
Scrum Masters must be skilled negotiators and problem-solvers.
Without these skills, it is impossible to help the team achieve success.
This may involve negotiation with stockholders, the product owner, other managers, and anyone 
who influences the team's success.
They should know how to create opportunities to collaborate and how to facilitate a team to stay on 
track.
For example, a Scrum Master may need to bring in a different Scrum team to collaborate if there is 
an intersection between the work that these teams are doing.
If the only way to get increments to meet the definition of Done is through collaboration and 
problem-solving, the Scrum Master must facilitate that process.
Scrum Masters need to be effective in facilitating the estimation process and ensuring expert input 
is received as needed from the right sources.
The Scrum Master assists in ensuring that the team understands its velocity.
Velocity is defined as a measure of how much work a team can successfully accomplish in a sprint.
Do not overpromise and underdeliver.
The Scrum Master needs to understand the role of the Product Owner and assist this individual to be 
successful.
This includes assisting the Product Owner in product goal definition and product backlog 
development and management, ensuring all stakeholders understand and agree with all the user 
stories in the backlog, and facilitating stakeholder collaboration as requested or needed.
The Product Owner has distinct responsibilities.
However, a good Scrum Master ensures the success of the Product Owner.
The product owner is responsible for developing user stories, creating and managing the 
product backlog, prioritizing user stories, and working with the team to determine which 
stories can be accomplished in a given sprint.
The Product Owner also needs to refine the backlog to ensure user stories in the queue are 
ready to implement in the next sprint.
The quality of the backlog directly impacts the Scrum Master and the team.
The Scrum Master assists in the refinement process.
In Scrum, decisions are made on an observation and experimentation rather than a detailed upfront 
planning.
Empirical process control is a concept that must be understood and embraced by a Scrum 
Master.
It relies on the three main ideas of transparency, inspection, and adaptation.
Transparency, transparency allows all facets from any Scrum process to be observed by anyone.
There are no secrets in Scrum.
This provides an easy and transparent flow of information through the organization and creates an 
open work culture.
A Scrum Master must be transparent.
Inspection, the Scrum Master needs to ensure that the information is shared with all key 
stakeholders.
This includes access to user stories and the product backlog, accessibility to information radiators 
such as the kanban board and sprint burndown chart, and invitations to product demos and reviews.
Adaptation, adaptation is the ability to learn and improve through transparency and information 
sharing noted in the first two ideas of transparency and inspection.
In this video, you learned that a Scrum Master may not have all of the answers.
However, they do lead the way to find them.
This requires knowing how to set realistic goals and achieve them, understanding the capabilities of 
your team, and knowing how to drill down when clarity is needed.
Arguably, the most important skill a Scrum Master must pursue is to become an effective 
communicator.
Strong communication skills impact every key skill we define in this skill set inventory.

Expert Viewpoints: Scrum Master Skills

Welcome to Expert Viewpoints: Scrum Master skills.
In this video, we will hear Agile and Scrum experts discuss Scrum Master skills, share tips for new 
Scrum Masters and describe a Scrum Masters typical day.
A few skills required to be a Scrum Master include understanding Agile principles in the Scrum 
framework, facilitation skills and metrics and reporting skills.
Part of your role will include assessing the health of the sprint and that will most likely include 
common metrics like velocity, cycle time, and burn down charts.
To a new Scrum Master looking to improve their skills, I would suggest seeking me abundance of 
training there is out there, whether it'd be free training and webinars or articles, and take little 
nuggets from each of these and continuously improve.
Describe a typical day as a Scrum Master.
A Scrum Master's typical day is spent facilitating the daily scrum and other scrum ceremonies 
depending on where you're at in the sprint, problem-solving and removing impediments, coating the 
team, and supporting the product owner.
You should have at least some experience managing projects of some sort.
Now, that's a very broad range of potential projects that you could manage.
But there should be some experience of coordinating things.
Remember, none of these people who report directly to you.
You are coordinating people over whom you really don't have any real authority.
Your authority is by your example, by the support that you bring to the team.
You should have some understanding of the industry that you're working in, the product.
A lot of times people crossover to Scrum from being an expert in another area and it's just a natural 
development.
For example, if you have a system that you're building, you could naturally crossover and offer that 
expertise as a Scrum Master and it will also help you because the team will know that you have that 
expertise in your background.
You don't need to be an expert, but you should be good at removing roadblocks.
Get to know the organization.
A lot of the work of the Scrum Master is not so much a technical skill as much as people skills and 
getting to the point where you can help the group.
You want to get to know the players involved, you want to get to know the appetite for Scrum in the 
organization.
A lot of times this is a new thing for an organization to adopt.
You want to be able to help them be successful and spend time understanding what it means to be a 
coach and a servant leader.
If you miss those things, then you probably will not have as much success as you want as a Scrum 
Master.
Know the framework of the Scrum cold.
This is your job, You are the expert in the organization, and if people have questions about scrum,
you are the person that should be able to facilitate those answers.
Well, one of the great things about being a Scrum Master is that it's never the same.
Your day may be completely different from the last and very different from the next.
You may spend your day facilitating meetings.
During a sprint, you may do a daily standup, depending on where you're at in the development 
process, you may be facilitating a retrospective sprint review and working with the product owner,
working with the team, removing roadblocks.
So there's just no telling what your day could bring, it really just depends on how the project goes.
There may be days where you find that the team is not performing at a very high level and your job 
is going to be to figure out why, and how to help them to get back on track.
Maybe a team member needs assistance from you, you may spend your whole day working with 
that team member to clear that path so that they can complete their work.

To become a Scrum Master, one needs a combination of technical and soft skills.
Technical skills include a deep understanding of a gentle methodologies, a Scrum framework,
and relevant tools such as JIRA, Confluence. Soft skills include strong communication,
facilitation, coaching, problem-solving, conflict resolution, leadership, and the ability to trust
and foster collaboration within the team.
To improve as a new Scrum Master, continuously learn and stay updated on a gel practices,
seek mentorship or coaching from experienced Scrum Masters, actively participate in Agile 
communities and forums, reflect on your experiences, seek feedback, and iterate on your approach.
Embrace a growth mindset and be open to learning from both successes and failures.
A typical day as a Scrum Master involves facilitating daily stand-up meetings, coaching the team on 
a giant practices, helping deemed to remove impediments, assisting product owner in backlog 
refinement, conducting retrospectives, collaborating with the stakeholders, and ensuring the teams 
adherence for Scrum principles and goals.

One thing is to make sure you have a thorough understanding of the Scrum pillars and values as 
coaching the team is a big part of your job.
You'll need excellent communication and facilitation skills, get to know Agile management tools 
like JIRA. Every day you'll be facilitating Scrum ceremonies.
I'm working with a team and the product owner on the work being delivered during the sprint.
To develop your skills, consider shadowing other Scrum Masters in your organization or take a 
certification class or join a community of practice .

A Day in the Life of a Scrum Master

Welcome to this module on a day in the life of a Scrum Master.
After watching this video, you'll be able to summarize critical tasks a Scrum Master must perform 
on a daily basis and to find challenges the Scrum Master may encounter and how to overcome them.
A Scrum Master has various responsibilities.
While each day brings new challenges, there are standard tasks a Scrum Master must accomplish in 
a day.
Let us review some of these key duties.
The Scrum Master facilitates the daily stand up meeting.
This is often referred to as a daily scrum meeting as well.
This is normally done first thing in the morning.
The three questions asked are what each team member did yesterday, what they will do today, and 
are there any blockers or impediments?
The Scrum Master must ensure that every team member participates in response to the three 
questions.
During the meeting, the Scrum Master tries to ensure that all team members have worked to 
perform.
In addition, the Scrum Master must take action in a variety of areas based on the result of this 
meeting.
During the stand-up meeting, the Scrum Master encouraged as each team member to update
their portion of the Kanban board, all burn down charts must be maintained for the sprint and are 
updated at the conclusion of the meeting as well to show progress and determine how the team is 
progressing.
If the sprint has issues, the Scrum Master works to resolve them.
If there are conflicts or issues, the Scrum Master immediately ensures the impact of team members 
work together to resolve them.
The Scrum Master tries to encourage the team to self-correct and resolve all conflicts internally
to the greatest extent possible.
If the Scrum Master support is needed, they get involved.
It is important to note that conflicts are not resolved during the daily stand up meeting.
The Scrum Master than addresses any blockers.
The goal is to resolve the blockers as quickly as possible.
This may entail working closely with the product donor or other key stakeholders in the 
organization.
The Scrum Master also act as a coach whenever possible, the Scrum Master shares information, 
guidance, and provide support to any and all members of the team.
The Scrum Master is a servant leader.
They put the needs of others ahead of self.
Every Scrum Master takes pride in preparing junior team members to both understand and assume 
the role in the future.
The Scrum Master is also a master event planner.
They make the team ready for any ceremonies planned in the near term.
Along with the daily stand-up key ceremonies including sprint planning, demos, and retrospectives.
The Scrum Master may need to spend time assisting the product owner to refine the product 
backlog and ensure it is ready for the next iteration or sprint.
A best practice is to have all user stories for the next two sprints ready for implementation.
The scrum master has a number of challenges to overcome.
A Scrum Master has critical responsibilities and often minimal authority to accomplish them.
A Scrum Master needs to establish themselves as a subject matter expert within the organization,
along with the trust and credibility with the team.
They have to wield influence on the team without much authority.
A sprint is time-bound.
Unlike a traditional project, the length of the sprint is set and cannot be extended.
They must work closely with the team to ensure all tasks are completed on time.
There may be times when the team is virtual.
This makes coordination and time management even more difficult.
Keeping senior management happy can be a real challenge.
Many managers are used to traditional project management methods and do not understand Scrum.
This can lead to potential interference and push back.
A Scrum Master needs to be capable of sharing the scrum process with the management
in a way that emphasizes the benefits and leads to acceptance by them.
Many stakeholders do not understand the role of a Scrum Master.
They assume a Scrum Master has the same job description roles as their traditional project manager,
education than patients are needed at times to be successful.
Finally, there may be times when stakeholders want to change direction in mid sprint.
When this occurs, the Scrum Master needs to be flexible, acknowledged the change, and update
the product backlog in conjunction with the product owner.
While at the same time doing all day cannot to disrupt the currents sprint and stay the course is 
planned.

In this video, you learned that scrum masters roles are very diverse.
Ensure that team stays organized, focused, and on track to satisfy the goals of the sprint, acts as a 
bridge between management and the team ensuring the team has not distracted from its primary 
tasks, ensures impediments and blockers are identified early and do all they can to and motivate 
them to perform at the highest levels.




Adaptive Methodologies
By the end of this Reading, you will be able to define various adaptive methodologies where the 
Scrum Master role is essential.
Scrum Masters serve in a number of adaptive methodologies to include Scrum. In some 
methodologies, a Scrum Master may be referred to as a Team Facilitator.
In a 2022 "State of Agile" report, Scrum or a hybrid of Scrum is used by 81% of all Agile or 
adaptive practitioners. However, there are other adaptive methods worth being aware of.
•	Extreme Programming (XP): XP is a software development methodology intended to 
improve software quality and responsiveness to changing customer requirements. XP 
advocates frequent releases in short development cycles intended to improve productivity 
and introduce checkpoints at which new customer requirements can be adopted.
•	Scaled Agile Framework (SAFe): Scaled Agile Framework (SAFe) is a set of organization 
and workflow patterns intended to guide enterprises in scaling Lean and Agile practices. 
SAFe is one of a growing number of frameworks that seek to address the problems 
encountered when scaling beyond a single team.
•	Kanban: Kanban is a methodology that uses many Scrum methods. Requirements are 
placed on a Kanban board and flow across the board from start to finish until completed. 
Each requirement begins in the Backlog or "To Do" column. When work begins, the 
requirement moves to "In-Progress." When the requirement is completed, it moves 
across the board to "Peer Review," "In Test," and ultimately, "Done." If a requirement 
is blocked, it is placed on the Kanban board accordingly until the blocker is resolved. A key 
feature of Kanban is "Work in Progress" limitations. There can only be so many 
requirements in each category on the Kanban board. This ensures that work is evenly 
distributed and that the team has adequate capacity to complete each requirement during 
each column or phase.
•	Dynamic Systems Development Method (DSDM): An Agile project delivery framework 
initially used as a software development method. It features an iterative and incremental 
approach and prioritizes deliveries.
•	Crystal: The Crystal Agile methodology is an agile framework which puts focus on the 
interaction among individuals rather than on the processes and tools used. It empowers 
teams to find their own solutions to problems instead of being confined by rigid 
methodologies of performing tasks. Crystal was derived from values stated in the original 
Agile Manifesto.
•	Lean Software Development: Lean Software Development (LSD) is an Agile framework 
based on optimizing development time and resources, eliminating waste, and ultimately 
delivering only what the product needs. Lean methodology was originally created by 
Toyota Corporation.


Module 1 Summary: The Role of the Scrum 
Master
Congratulations! You have completed this module. At this point in the course, you know: 
•	Unlike project managers, a Scrum Master does not plan the overall project from start to 
finish, manage budgets, control risks, or procure material.
•	Scrum Masters lead teams, remove roadblocks, participate in the planning process for the 
team's work, and help the team work together.
•	The various steps in the Sprint process are Sprint Planning I and II, Sprint, Review or Demo, 
and Retrospective.
•	Scrum Masters are coaches and Servant Leaders who lead by example.
•	A Scrum Master knows how to set realistic goals and achieve them, understands the 
capabilities of the team, and knows how to drill down when clarity is needed.
•	The most important skill a Scrum Master must pursue is to become an effective 
communicator.
•	Scrum Masters ensure the team stays organized, focused, and on-track to satisfy the goals of 
the Sprint.
•	Scrum Masters act as a bridge between management and the team, ensuring the team is not 
distracted from its primary tasks.
•	Scrum Masters ensure impediments and blockers are identified early and do all they can to 
resolve them.
•	Scrum Masters support the teams and motivate them to perform at the highest levels.
•	Scrum Masters serve in a number of adaptive methodologies to include Scrum like Extreme 
Programming (XP), Scaled Agile Framework (SAFe), Kanban, Dynamic Systems 
Development Method (DSDM), Crystal, and Lean Software Development.
Module 1 Glossary: The Role of the Scrum 
Master
Term
Definition
Agile
Optimal lifecycle when deliverable frequency is high and anticipated 
change is high.
Blockers
Issues or problems preventing a development team from progressing in a 
Sprint.
Burndown Chart
Information Radiator that graphically shows team progress to complete 
User Stories.
Ceremonies
Events to include sprint planning, the Sprint, reviews and retrospectives.
Coach
Process conducted to improve team member performance and confidence.
Crystal
An agile methodology that is an agile framework which puts focus on the 
interaction among individuals rather than on the processes and tools used.
Daily Scrum/Daily 
Stand-up meeting
A Scrum ceremony conducted for 15-minutes each day to ensure the 
Sprint is progressing and identify any potential blockers.
Done
Done is realized when all solution criteria for a User Story is 
accomplished to the customer's satisfaction.
Development Team
Team members committed to creating useable increments during each 
Sprint.
Diversion Shield
Shield the team from external distractions. Create an environment where 
the team can focus on the job at hand.
DSDM
Dynamic Systems Development Method. An agile project delivery 
framework initially used as a software development method.
Dysfunctional Conflict
Conflict that can lead to negative feelings and results.
Empirical Process 
Control
Promote transparency, ensure inspections occur as needed, and work with 
the team to adapt to change.
Extreme 
Programming (XP)
A software development methodology intended to improve software 
quality and responsiveness to changing customer requirements.
Facilitate
Lead communications and collaboration to achieve an outcome.
Functional Conflict
Conflict that can lead to positive feelings and results.
Impediments
Issues or problems preventing a development team from progressing in a 
Sprint.
Information Radiators
Forms of agile communications that are transparent and available to all 
stakeholders.
Kanban Board
A tool used to display all backlog tasks in a Sprint and status.
Lean Software 
Development (LSD)
An agile framework based on optimizing development time and resources, 
eliminating waste, and ultimately delivering only what the product needs.
MVP
Minimum Viable Product. The product increment developed during a 
given Sprint. The increment must have value to the customer.
Predictive
Lifecycle where project scope, schedules, and budgets are determined 
early in a project. Best if delivery requirements are low and change is low.
Product Backlog
A repository of prioritized User Stories developed and managed by a 
Product Owner.
Product Owner
Adaptive role. Maintains Product Backlog, develops User Stories, and 
acts as Voice of the Customer.
Project Manager
Person assigned by organization to lead the team.  Accountable for project 
objectives.
Quality
Provide a product or service that conforms to requirements and is fit for 
use.
Refinement
The act of updating the Product Backlog based on changing product 
requirements.
Retrospective
Ceremony conducted at end of each Sprint to determine what went well, 
what should the team change, and what is one change the team will pursue 
during the next Sprint.
SAFe
Scaled Agile Framework. A set of organization and workflow patterns 
intended to guide enterprises in scaling lean and agile practices.
Scrum
A popular form of agile used by the majority of agile practitioners.
Scrum Master
Adaptive role. Trains and coaches development team.  Ensures all agile 
processes are adhered to.
Self-Organize
Ability of a team to organize and take the right actions without the need 
for management direction.
Sprint/Iteration
A timed period where an adaptive or agile project is implemented. 
Generally, time boxed at 15 or 30 days.  
Sprint Backlog
A list of tasks to support a User Story developed by a Scrum development 
team.
Sprint Demo/Review
Ceremony where the Product owner presents the functionality developed 
by the team during a Sprint and receives feedback and acceptance.
Sprint Planning
The Scrum team determines which user Stories will be accomplished 
during a Sprint. Sprint backlog is developed to execute the User stories.
User Stories
A requirement defined by role, need, and value developed by a Product 
Owner.
Velocity
The amount of work a team can complete in a given Sprint.

Scrum Master and Traditional Project 
Manager Comparison 


Welcome to this module on comparison between scrum master and a traditional project manager.
After watching this video, you'll be able to compare scrum master and traditional project manager 
roles and contrast scrum master and traditional project manager roles.

A project manager and scrum master have roles that in many cases require the same set of skills.
However, the focus and definitions differ greatly.
A project manager is accountable for defining requirements, building a scope, creating a Work 
Breakdown Structure or WBS, and gaining approval of the scope baseline.
They manage predictive projects.
A scrum master confirms requirements with the team that are shared in the form of a user story by a 
product owner.
The product owner is responsible for generating the initial user story.
The scrum master enables a sprint backlog, which breaks out each user story into assignable tasks 
produced by the team.
They support adaptive products.


Project managers build a comprehensive schedule that must be approved by the sponsor and 
accepted by stakeholders.
A scrum master, however, helps manage a sprint.
This is a timebox iteration to produce a minimum viable product or MVP, in a time-boxed 15 or 30 
day iteration or period.
Scrum masters also help the team apply relative estimation techniques to classify user stories 
by complexity in the form of story points.
The higher the story points, the more complex and involved in the user story is.


Project managers must build a project budget.
A scrum master may assist the product owner with budgeting matters.
The product owner is responsible for the budget.


Both project managers and scrum masters ensure quality is built into a product.
The project manager develops a quality management plan.
The scrum master ensures that the team understands the definition of done and works to achieve it.
Project managers identify and procure resources.


They also assign roles and responsibilities.
A scrum master ensures that the team self-organizes and identifies who will perform what tasks in 
the sprint backlog.


Project managers control communication through a comprehensive communication management 
plan.
A scrum master ensures open communication through the use of Kanban boards, burndown charts, 
and other documents available to anyone on the team.


Project managers develop a comprehensive risk management plan and stakeholder register to 
manage risk.
A scrum master helps the team assess user story risks to determine the complexity of the work.
The scrum master needs to be capable of performing roles that differ from traditional project 
management roles.
Let's share a few examples.


Project definition is critical.
A project manager leads the effort to develop a project charter and project management plan
that provides a roadmap for the project.
This plan is provided to the team and drives execution.
The plan defined specific team roles and responsibilities that the project manager ensures are 
accomplished.
A scrum master on the other hand, provides direction to the team to determine what the project will 
deliver.
The scrum master helps the team define the project deliverables through the validation of
user stories developed by a product owner.
They do not dictate the plan.
Rather, they act as a coach and facilitator to ensure that the team self organizes and develops the 
plan in the form of a sprint backlog.


The project manager is the voice of the customer.
They work closely with customers and key stakeholders to determine the executed product or 
service state.
The project manager leads the team's efforts to develop the project scope, schedule, and cost 
baselines.
The scrum master works with a product owner who determines the requirements.
The scrum master is focused on ensuring the team understands the requirements and is
able to get the work committed to done.
A scrum master will ensure that the selected user stories are accomplished within the timeframe of 
the sprint.
Launch planning is normally accomplished by the product owner.


Both the project manager and scrum master perform issue management functions.
The project manager solicit status, identifies issues, and ensures that they are addressed in a timely 
manner.
The scrum master identifies issues or blockers on a daily basis, normally through the facilitation of
daily stand-up or scrum meetings, and ensures that they are addressed as quickly as possible.


Both the project manager and scrum master needs to be skilled in facilitation.
A project manager must facilitate status reviews, change meetings, pre-baseline and
baseline presentations, and more.
A scrum master needs to facilitate and ensure that the team participates in sprint planning,
the sprint, demos, and retrospectives.
These are classified as ceremonies and scrum.


A final contrast regard to the perception of the role. Project managers are normally
recognized as essential to the success of the business.
Sponsors provide authority to plan and execute the product.
A scrum master role may not be understood or recognized as critical.
A scrum master often needs to be capable of influencing the team without authority
to perform their required tasks.

In this video, you learned that project managers and scrum masters are similar in
the way that they define requirements, manage schedule, budget, ensure quality, manage roles and 
responsibilities, communication, and risks.
determination of scope, issue management, facilitation, and role perception

Expert Viewpoints: Traditional Project 
Management and the Scrum Master

Welcome to Expert Viewpoints.
Scrum Master opportunities.
In this video, we will hear agile and Scrum experts describe how someone who does not have a 
Project Management background can become an effective Scrum Master.
And compare the role of a Scrum Master to the role of a traditional Project Manager.
>> No, you don't have to have a traditional project management background to be a Scrum Master, 
and in some ways that could be better.
As Project Managers and Scrum Masters are distinct roles, there are similar soft skills used like 
communication and organization.
But Project Managers are about process control, managing work, scope, and cost.
Whereas a Scrum Master is an enabler role, more of a coach and facilitator, removing impediments, 
working with the team and product owner on the delivery of the sprint.
>> Yes, of course, someone without a project management experience can become an effective 
Scrum Master.
I have seen technical and functional team members evolving into Scrum Master roles.
While project management experience can be helpful, but it's not the must.
The key qualities of a Scrum Master such as facilitation, collaboration, coaching, and leadership can 
be developed and improved through training and practice.
The Scrum Master and traditional Project Manager roles have similarities such as focusing on 
successful project delivery and working with stakeholders.
In addition, they both require communication and problem-solving skills.
However, they differ in authority, approach, team empowerment, and focus.
A Project Manager role has more formal authority, follows a structured approach, may have a more 
directive role, and focus on managing constraints.
A Scrum Master serves as a servant leader, embraces an iterative approach, empowers, self-
organizing teams, and focuses on removing impediments and facilitating collaboration within the 
Agile framework.
>> While it will help that you have had project management experience, it certainly doesn't 
preclude anybody from becoming a Scrum Master.
Being a Scrum Master is more than just technical skills.
It takes the right type of person who has the right type of attitude and goals and interests in working 
with people to make them a successful Scrum Master.
If you are the type of person that would rather elevate the team and let the team take the credit and 
not look for your own glory, then this is really where you fit in.
Scrum Masters are servants, they're servant leaders.
And so if your motive is to get the spotlight or be the hero or anything like that, then really being a 
Scrum Master may not work out so well for you.
Your one job is to get the team to success.
Now that doesn't mean that you won't get credit for the work you've done, of course, you will.
But if you're motivated by helping others, then that's the type of person that succeeds as a Scrum 
Master.
Scrum Masters are just not there to help the team complete tasks.
The Scrum Master's focus is the success of the team and that may mean getting the team to work 
well together.
Teaching them how to work well together, reminding them of the goals, reminding them
of why they are there, supporting them, getting them to think about different ways of doing things, 
all for the goal of success.
Now, the Scrum Master facilitates the process and the process that they're facilitating is the Scrum 
framework.
That is a really key component, what makes it different than a traditional Project Manager.
Now, there's some similarities, of course, you want to help the team to get their work done, that's 
kind of the point.
But where the difference really lies is people over process.
And that is straight out of the Agile Manifesto, which is really the foundation of Scrum.
>> Yes, someone with no project management background can still become an effective Scrum 
Master.
Though it is easier for someone with project management background to become a Scrum Master 
because most of the work that they need to do is detach themselves from the traditional mindset and 
be in the Agile mindset.
Now, if you have no project management knowledge, you can still be an effective Scrum Master.
All you need to do is go down to the basis of learning the software development lifecycle, put in the 
work and you can still do very great.
A traditional Project Manager is usually involved from the initiation process, budgeting, 
implementation, and all that.
While as a Scrum Master, you are typically involved in the development part of it.
So as a Scrum Master you're making sure that an MVP, which is a most viable product, is being 
constantly delivered. So that's the main difference.
Developing Scrum Master Skills

Hello and welcome to this module on how to develop Scrum Master skills.
After watching this video, you'll be able to, define desired levels of project management knowledge
and expertise required to transition to the Scrum Master role, and summarize the benefits of 
becoming a Scrum Master compared to a traditional project management role.
A Scrum Master requires a certain amount of prior project management knowledge to improve their 
chances of success.
Some Scrum Master skills can be acquired with past project management experience.
However, project management skills, knowledge and expertise give a Scrum Master a decided 
advantage.
A Scrum Master needs to be an effective coach, facilitator, issues manager, and a servant leader,
you do not have to have project management experience to develop these skills.
However, time spent as a project manager makes it easier to attain these skills.
A Scrum Master needs to be a great organizer, understand the business environment and effectively 
interface with customers.
The product owner is the voice of the customer and elicits customer requirements.
The product owner is responsible for developing and managing the product backlog.
Customers share their available budget and desired time-frames for the launch.
The Scrum Master, however, often interfaces with customers to remove blockers and share 
information.
They must also foster good communication and teamwork within the team.
These skills can also be developed without being a project manager.
However, as stated earlier, time spent as a project manager allows you to develop these skills.
There are some project management skills, however, that a Scrum Master should possess to be 
successful.
Key project management skills such as requirements development, project planning, and 
scheduling, resource management, and risk management are essential to success.
Project scope management skills are required to facilitate the development of a sprint backlog.
The development team develops the sprint backlog, the Scrum Master ensures
Projects schedule management skills are necessary to manage the sprint and ensure all tasks are 
planned and completed on time.
Project quality management skills are necessary to ensure inspection and adaptation needs are met.
Project resource management skills allow the Scrum Master to ensure everyone is contributing
to achieve the overall goal of done.
Project communication skills are essential to ensure transparent and effective 
communications.
Scrum advocates osmotic communications.
The term was coined by Alistair Cock-burn, one of the signers of the Agile manifesto.
''Osmotic communication means the information flows into the background hearing of the 
team members so that they pick up relevant information as through by osmosis."
The Scrum Master ensures that the environment is conducive to osmotic communications.
Project risk management skills are necessary to ensure risk is factored into user story point 
estimates.
As a review, a story point is a measure of the complexity of a user story that determines
the amount of time and effort needed to complete it.
A user story with a story points up eight will take more effort and is more complex than a user story
scored at five story points.
In addition, a Scrum Master will likely need to work with project managers as many projects are 
hybrids that both use Scrum and traditional project management methods.
In such cases, some preliminary project management training and experience will allow
the Scrum Master to be effective in that role.
The traditional project manager role is rewarding and beneficial in many ways.
You are able to turn great ideas into reality and help move the organization forward.
However, more and more traditional project managers are transitioning into adaptive or Scrum 
related positions, such as product owner and Scrum Master.
Let's understand what the benefits are of becoming a Scrum Master.
The project management environment is becoming more complex.
The need for new innovative products delivered quickly to an increasing demanding market is 
growing.
There is a significant shift in project management to leveraging adaptive or agile life cycles.
Scrum remains the most widely used adaptive methodology.
This equates to a significant and growing demand for experienced Scrum Masters.
According to a number of studies, the need for Scrum Master is increasing,
demand for Scrum Masters will continue to grow, which itself leads to job security.
Here's a quote from braintrust.com. With Agile becoming more popular across a wide variety of 
industries, the need for Certified Scrum Master is only increasing.
On average, Scrum Masters earn more than non-qualified counterparts, with the experienced Scrum 
Master earning around $100,000 per year in the US.
Financial rewards are high.
A recent study by scrum.org in 2022, surveys Scrum Masters and calculated the average Scrum 
Master salary at approximately $84,000 annually.
As you gain experience, average salary increases.
The field is growing and the salary is very competitive.
Most people agree that salary and job opportunities are important, however, being a Scrum Master
is not all about the money.
The Scrum Master role can be highly rewarding in many other ways.
Scrum Masters assume a servant leader role and help other people achieve success, this is hugely 
rewarding in and of itself.
They also help organizations adapt to changing business conditions and flourish.
Scrum Masters with success stories behind them will remain much in demand for many years to 
come.

manager, and leader.
Project management skills, knowledge, and expertise give a Scrum Master I decided advantage.

scheduling, resource management, project communication, and risk management are essential 
to success.
Demand for Scrum Masters will continue to grow, which lends itself to job security.

Scrum Master Levels
Welcome to this module on Scrum Master levels.
After watching this video, you'll be able to identify the Scrum Master position job requirements as 
regards to experience and skills, describe various salary ranges from entry-level to experienced 
Scrum Masters.
Scrum Masters have varying degrees of expertise and experience.
An entry-level Scrum Master position has less rigid expectations than a more experienced Scrum 
Master position.
The Scrum Alliance uses a three-step certification hierarchy to define these roles, responsibilities, 
and expectations of Scrum Master.
The Project Management Institute, or PMI, offers insight into Scrum Master levels
and skill requirements as well.
We will discuss four levels of Scrum Master experience and expertise.
Level 1, at this level, the Scrum Master has no experience or certifications.
This aspiring Scrum Master should possess some basic project management experience.
However, experience is not mandatory.
Level 2, at this level, the Scrum Master has no experience but has certified Scrum Master CSM 
certification.
CSM certification ensures that you have a basic understanding of the methodology used in Scrum.
You will understand various Scrum roles, essentials of Sprint Planning, keys to execute a successful 
sprint, demos, and retrospectives.
The training you'll receive qualifies you to apply for many entry-level positions and use the skills 
you learned to your advantage.
The Project Management Institute offers a Disciplined Agile Scrum Master Certification or DASM.
Requirements for certification are similar to that of the CSM.
There is a bit more emphasis on understanding Lean foundations and Disciplined Agile principles.
Level 3, at this level, the aspirant has one year of experience as a Scrum Master and five years of 
experience in project management related fields.
The Scrum Master has acquired Advanced Certified Scrum Master or ACSM certification.
As an ACSM, you are expected to understand and be able to apply all of the skills of a CSM.
In addition, you are expected to have coaching, facilitation, collaboration, and Scrum scaling skills 
beyond that of the CSM, the Project Management Institute offers a Disciplined Agile Senior Scrum 
Management certification, or DASSM.
Requirements for the certification are similar to that of the ACSM.
There is a bit more emphasis on understanding team-building techniques and emotional 
intelligence.
Level 4, this is the level where the candidate has at least two years experience as a Scrum Master 
and five years of experience in project management related fields.
They also have a Certified Scrum Professional, Scrum Master, or CSP-SM certification.
As a CSP-SM, you are expected to share experience with practical problems, solutions that go 
beyond the skills required to be successful at other levels.
This requires in-depth training, knowledge, and the skill level essential to excel at this level.
Some of the DASSM requirements discussed previously are included in the CSP-SM certification 
requirements as well.
A recent study conducted by higher ultron.com stated that Scrum Master salary fall within the 25 
highest paying jobs in America.
Salary ranges are based on the candidate's level of experience, location, company skills, and 
industry.
Scrum Master salaries are highly competitive on a worldwide basis.
An individual with no certification and minimal experience will average $69,000 annually.
This confirmates with our level 1 Scrum Master overview.
An entry-level Scrum Master is one with minimal experience but possesses a CSM certification.
On average, starting salaries average $84,000 annually.
This is consonant with our level to Scrum Master overview.
A level 3 Scrum Master can expect to earn approximately $100,000 annually.
Level 4 Scrum Masters earn a salary in the 117,000 annual range.
As you can see, salary will increase as you gain more experience and acquire multiple certifications.
The need for Scrum Masters is increasing and the compensation is excellent.

In this video, you learned four levels of Scrum Master experience and expertise are, level 1, at this 
level, the Scrum Master has no experience or certifications.
Level 2, no experience, but has certified Scrum Master or CSM certification.
Level 3, one year experience as a Scrum Master and five years experience in project management 
related fields, Advanced Certified Scrum Master, ACSM certification, and Disciplined Agile
Senior Scrum Master Certification or DASSM.
Level 4, two years experience as a Scrum Master and five years experience in project management 
related fields, and certified Scrum professional, Scrum Master or CSP-SM certification, including 
DASSM.
Level 1 will earn an average of $69,000 annually.
Level 2 will earn an average of $84,000 annually.
Level 3 will earn approximately $100,000 annually.
Level 4 earns a salary in the $117,000 annual range .

Expert Viewpoints: Why Become a Scrum 
Master

Welcome to Expert Viewpoints, why become a Scrum Master?
In this video, we will hear agile and Scrum experts discuss why someone with a project 
management background would want to become a Scrum Master or develop Scrum Master skills.
You'll also hear which traditional project management skills translate well into Scrum.
Someone with a traditional broad project management background might want to become a Scrum 
Master or develop a Scrum Master skills for several reasons.
The benefits include the opportunity to work in an agile environment which are becoming 
increasingly popular, enhanced ability to adapt to changing project requirements, improved 
collaboration and team dynamics, increased focus on delivering value to customers, and the 
potential for career growth and expanded job opportunities in Agile organizations.
The Scrum Master role offers the opportunity to learn new ways of working outside of a normal 
traditional waterfall approach and will allow you to grow your project management skills.
With Scrum, you will work in a collaborative, adaptable and value driven environment and 
approach to project management.
As a Scrum Master, an experienced project manager would be able to leverage their existing skills 
while embracing an Agile mindset and enjoying the benefits that come with Agile.
Communication and facilitation skills and traditional project management translate well into Scrum.
It really depends on what you want out of your career.
If you love coaching people, if you love making others better, and that you find that rewarding, 
those are the benefits alone.
If you enjoy helping your team build the best product or service possible, best program possible, 
then this is something you would definitely enjoy.
If you enjoy teaching, facilitating, the Scrum Master role would be great.
If you enjoy solving problems, you're going to get to do a lot of that.
And you work very independently in the sense that you do not have a structured day to day set of 
tasks that you clock in, do the work, clock out, go home, it is going to be whatever you need to do 
to support the team.
More and more organizations are transitioning to an Agile framework and developing Scrum Master 
skills will no doubt help your employability.
Also, I found using Scrum empirical processes like transparency, inspection and adaptation with my 
traditional projects greatly increased our chances of success.
You'll be able to transition a number of your soft skills like communication, organization and 
facilitation, along with risk management and working with stakeholders.
First, there is a significant shift in project management to leveraging what refer to as adaptive or 
agile life cycles, and Scrum remains the most widely used adaptive methodology.
This equates to a significant and growing demand for experienced Scrum Masters.
Next, according to a number of recent studies, the need for Scrum Masters is increasing.
Demand for Scrum Masters, according to projections, will continue to grow, which lends itself to 
some excellent job security.
Next, the financial rewards are high.
A recent study by scrum.org in 2022 surveyed Scrum Masters and calculated the average Scrum 
Master salary at approximately $84,000 annually.
As you gain experience, the good news is the average salary increases, Scrum Master can be a 
hugely rewarding role in many other ways.
Scrum Masters assume a role of a servant leader to help other people and the team achieve success.
This is typically hugely rewarding in and of itself.
They also help organizations adapt to changing business conditions and thrive.
Scrum Masters with a track record of doing this will remain in much high demand for many, many 
years to come.
Some traditional project management skills that translate well into Agile or Scrum, to be specific, 
include, but are not limited to planning, project composition, risk management, communication, 
technical competence, stakeholder analysis and engagement.
Again, these are just a few.
There are definitely lots more.
Several skills in traditional project management translate well into Scrum, including communication 
and stakeholder management, planning and organizing, risk management, problem solving and 
leadership.
However, Scrum also requires shift towards servant leadership, facilitation and fostering self-
organizing teams.
The ability to coordinate people really makes a big difference.
If you can motivate others, inspire others, make them believe in what you are doing, you will be 
successful.
And these are all things that you have to do as a project manager.
A lot of times nobody reports to you, so you're asking them to do more work than they are already 
doing for their job.
That happens in Scrum and in project management.
So if you're good at that, that skill really will lend itself to your success.
And most importantly, you really should be an expert communicator and you should be able to get 
the team to communicate with each other.
A lot of times you'll find that that is a struggle, that team members want to just go and do the work.
And you have to build that team environment because it is a team job to complete the project and 
there is no one person that stands out over above the other.
They all have their expertise in the area that you're working on.
But getting them to work as a cohesive unit is one thing that really makes Scrum different than 
project management.
The majority of similarities impact the soft skills area.

Both project managers and Scrum Masters need to develop solid facilitation techniques.
Both are required to plan and execute various meetings and events, or as it is referred to in Scrum, 
ceremonies.
Both need solid organizational skills.
A project manager needs to ensure all planning is accomplished to pave the way for a successful 
project.
Likewise, a Scrum Master ensures all planning is accomplished in an organized manner to pave the 
way for a successful sprint.
Effective communication is critical to both roles.
Both project managers and Scrum Masters are required to interact with numerous stakeholders on a 
daily basis to discuss a myriad of issues, eliminate blockers and ensure everyone is on the same 
page.
Last but not least, conflicts will occur in both a traditional and Scrum project.
Both roles need to effectively promote functional conflict and diffuse functional conflict.

Module 1 and 2 Review and Key Takeaways
The job of the Scrum Master is critical to the success of any organization using Scrum. Let's review 
some highlights and key takeaways from our "Introduction to the Scrum Master Profession" 
Course.
The Scrum Team
The Scrum Master works closely with a product owner and the development team. Key roles 
include:
•	Product Owner: The Product Owner is responsible for maximizing the value resulting from 
the increments or work resulting from each Sprint. They act as the voice of the customer, 
develop product goals, develop initial User Stories, create and manage the Product Backlog, 
and ensure the backlog is transparent, visible, and understood.
•	Scrum Master: Scrum Masters are Servant Leaders. They serve the team and the larger 
organization. They ensure everyone understands the Scrum process, apply servant leadership 
principles by eliminating blockers, shield the team from external distractions, and act as a 
motivational force.
•	Development Team: Developers are committed to creating useable increments during each 
Sprint. They self-organize, complete the Sprint Backlog, adhere to the definition of "done," 
adapt efforts to achieve the sprint goal, and hold each other accountable as professionals.
Scrum Master Skills and Competencies
A Scrum Master requires a number of skills and competencies to be successful. Here is a brief 
review.
•	Coach the team to be self-managed and adept at cross-functional collaboration.
•	Facilitate key events or Scrum "ceremonies" to include Sprint Planning, the Daily Scrum 
Meeting, Sprint reviews, and Sprint Retrospectives. Ensure these events occur on time and 
maximize participation.
•	Serve the Product Owner and team by ensuring all User Stories in the Product Backlog are 
clear and concise, assist in backlog "refinement," and support stakeholder collaboration as 
required.
•	Lead, train, and coach the organization on Scrum adoption.
•	Understand and advocate "Empirical Process Control." By this, we mean promote 
transparency, ensure inspections occur as required, and work with the team to adapt to 
change.
The Scrum Process
The Scrum Master is also a process manager. They work closely with all stakeholders to ensure the 
Scrum process is understood and adhered to.
•	Sprint Planning-User Story Selection: User Stories are the primary means of identifying 
requirements. Initial User Stories submitted by the Product Owner identify each requirement 
by role, need, and value. The Scrum Master ensures acceptance criteria is well-defined and 
understood before User Stories are placed and prioritized in the Product Backlog. The Scrum 
Master facilitates a meeting with the team and Product Owner to select User Stories the team 
believes they can complete in a Sprint.
•	Sprint Planning -Sprint Backlog Development: The Scrum Master ensures the team self-
organizes and completes a Sprint Backlog. The Sprint Backlog breaks each User Story into 
tasks. The team self-manages and determines who will lead the completion of each task.
•	The Sprint: The Scrum Master coaches the team, manages conflict, and facilitates the Daily 
Scrum Meeting. They ensure the Kanban board is updated, Burndown Charts are accurate, 
support the team if blockers are present, and ensure everyone stays on track to accomplish 
Increments as "done."
•	The Review: The Scrum Master sets up the meeting, ensures the team is ready to present, 
coaches the Product Owner to lead the review, and gathers customer feedback on all 
increments produced. The Scrum Master assists the Product Owner in backlog refinement as 
necessary.
•	The Retrospective: The Scrum Master facilitates an end-of-Sprint Retrospective where the 
team shares what went well, what can improve, and votes to implement one positive change 
in the next Sprint.

The Path to Certification PMI-ACP, PMI-
DASM, and CSM  

Welcome to the path, the certification.
After watching this video, you'll be able to summarize the focus of each certification, defined 
testing and experience requirements.
Describe additional Agile, Scrum and project management related certifications impacted by this 
course.
This module will feature three certifications that apply to this course.
These three certifications are popular Agile or Scrum credentials that can help your career.
We will also provide an overview of additional project management certifications that you can 
achieve in this course.
Certified Scrum Master or CSM, is an entry-level Scrum certification administered through the 
Scrum Alliance.
CSM is one of the most popular and recognized Scrum certifications.
A CSM certification recognizes your solid understanding of Scrum and practical ways to apply it to 
your team and organization.
To qualify for CSM, you must complete the following tasks.
Attend an in-person 16 hours Certified Scrum Master Course, CSM, taught by a Certified Scrum 
Trainer, CST.
The cost of the training ranges 700 to $1200.
Most training is conducted online.
Pass the online CSM exam by correctly answering at least 37 out of 50 questions within the one 
hour time limit.
The test is given online and is not proctored.
After passing the CSM test, you must accept the CSM license agreement and complete your Scrum 
Alliance membership profile.
Here is more information from the Scrum Alliance website.
The CSM test contains 50 multiple choice questions based on the CSM learning objectives and 
candidates have one hour to complete it.
The passing score is 74%.
You cannot pause the test, but questions can be bookmarked to answer later during the 60 minute 
time limit.
For more information about which topics and questions are included on the CSM test, please refer 
to our CSM test specifications outline.
It also serves as a great study guide.
After receiving the initial welcome email from Scrum Alliance that contains the account activation 
link, you will have 90 days to complete the CSM test for free.
Students are also given two free attempts to pass the CSM test.
If you fail the test twice or completed after 90 days, you will be prompted to pay a $25 attempt fee.
The CSM test can be an English, Spanish, Castilian, Portuguese, French, Italian, Latin American 
Spanish, German, Japanese, Simplified Chinese, Danish, Czech, Polish and Russian.
DASM is an entry-level Scrum certification administered through the Project Management Institute 
or PMI.
This is a relatively new PMI certification that is rapidly gaining popularity.
To quote PMI, the DASM certification equipped to successfully lead Agile teams, thereby future 
proofing your career in a world in which Agile is fast becoming the way forward.
To qualify for a DASM, you must complete the following tasks.
Complete a DASM course from a registered trainer.
Courses are available using a virtual lead two day training option.
Or you may opt for a self-paced course.
You must complete the training satisfactorily before you are eligible to take the DASM test.
Costs for the training ranges from $399
for the self-paced course to $800.
Pass a test per PMI, "the DASM exam is administered through Pearson VUE.
The exam is an online non-profit or test, including 50 multiple choice questions.
The total exam appointment is 120 minutes.
There's 30 minutes for the introduction, tutorial and survey and up to 90 minutes for completing the 
exam" PMI has not provided a passing score.
However, a passing score is generally about 80%.
Test costs are included with your training costs.
DASM is now available in Spanish and Portuguese.
The PMI ACP certification recognizes an individual's expertise and using Agile practices and their 
projects while demonstrating their increased professional versatility through Agile tools and 
techniques.
This global certification also supports individuals and meeting the needs of organizations that rely 
on project practitioners to apply diverse methods to their project management end quote.
To qualify for PMI ACP, you must submit a resume to PMI that shares the following.
General project experience, you must be able to show 12 months experience over the last five years 
working on project teams, if you do not possess a bachelor's degree or equivalent.
If you have a degree or current PMI project management certification, the experience requirement is 
waived.
Agile project experience.
You must show eight months of Agile team experience.
If you do not have a degree, this experience must be within the past three years.
Training and Agile practices.
If you do not have a degree, you require 21 hour of training.
If you have a degree, you require 35 hours of general training.
Once the resume is approved, you can schedule your test.
The cost for a PMI member is $435.
A non-member has charged $495.
To earn the PMI ASCP certification, you must meet the experience and education requirements and 
pass the PMI ACP exam.
This is a 120 question multiple choice exam.
This is an online proctored examination.
You are allotted three hours to complete this test.
You can prepare for and take the PMI ACP exam and English, Arabic, Japanese, Korean, Portuguese 
and Spanish.

In this video, you learned Certified Scrum Master or CSM, is an entry-level Scrum certification 
administered through the Scrum Alliance. DASM is an entry-level Scrum certification administered 
through the Project Management Institute or PMI. The DASM exam is administered through 
Pearson VUE.
The PMI ASCP certification recognizes individuals expertise and using Agile practices in their 
projects while demonstrating their increased professional versatility through Agile tools and 
techniques .

So definitely go in for it if there's something that you're passionate about.

Overview and Opportunities
