Demo: Status Reporting Review
Welcome to Status Reporting Review.
After watching this video, you will be able to create a project status report.
Hello everyone, and welcome to a quick demonstration on a project status report.
Before we begin, let's go ahead and define the purpose of projects status reports.
First and foremost, is to ensure current status is understood by all key stakeholders.
Secondly, a good status report can help maintain interest and commitment levels.
And third, a status report should be a tool to address issues and help needed.
We have an example of a one page status report and let me repeat that last phrase, one page.
The best status reports are short.
What goes into a status report?
To begin with, we should always have the project identifier, or name.
In this particular case, we have the ABC Company All Hands Meeting.
The status report should also be dated.
Status reports are not a one and done, you're going to go ahead and submit periodic status reports 
and they will build upon one another.
Always define your name and your organization.
In most cases, the project manager is the individual who submits the status report.
In this particular case, we have Sarah Wilson who is in operations.
The next area is very, very important, deliverable status.
And the best method to report deliverable status is using what we call traffic light reporting, which 
is red, yellow, and green.
You'll notice that we have an overview of what red, yellow, and green mean.
Provide a definition that is suitable to your particular project.
The definitions that you see here may work for you or you may want to go ahead and update them, 
and make them more specific for the project that you are managing.
But the bottom line is this, ensure that when people are reporting green, red, and yellow, that 
everyone is using the same definition.
Colour codes are very, very effective.
The three key deliverable status indicators that most stakeholders are going to be interested in is 
scope, schedule, and budget, that's our triangle in a project.
What we want to do is to define the current health of the project in terms of scope, schedule, and 
budget.
And we also want to show how this particular status is trending.
You'll notice in this example, we have scope is currently yellow and trending yellow, schedule is 
fine, green and green, budget is currently green.
However, it's trending toward red.
What follows after your status is help needed.
One of the things that we want to do is to describe the help needed, and help needed is any help that 
will allow us to stay green or return to green.
Normally, a best practice is to describe the help needed in terms of a must have, a should have, or a 
like to have.
Everything should not be a must have.
So in this particular case, we have a must have.
We need to finalize the speaker agenda and who is the source for this help?
The CEO and Operations Manager.
You'll notice above, we had scope, yellow and yellow.
One of the reasons for that is because the speaker agenda has not yet been finalized.
A should have, we need to identify alternative caterer to meet some dietary needs.
And this is again, the operations manager.
And then we have another must have, we may need an additional $2,000.
The initial refreshment estimate was too low and that is assigned to the finance lead.
You'll notice our budget is currently green, but it is trending toward red because we realize that we 
are going to have a funding shortfall.
The next area is for risk, what are some new risks and changes since the last report?
So we have two risks that we can add.
Key personnel absences may impact the overall quality of the project, and limited gluten free food 
choices is driving some of the catering cost overruns.
However, we had a risk that we had reported in our last status report.
AV configuration issues have now been overcome.
What are some issues?
What is an issue?
That is a risk that occurred or questions you need to have responses for.
The food cost estimates were higher than planned, that's no longer a risk, that is an issue.
We need to know where to fit the motivational speaker in the agenda as well.
Are there any recent or pending decisions impacting the project?
Yes, finalization of required speakers is needed to plan the agenda.
And finally, any kind of comments.
And this may seem redundant, but it's not a bad thing to repeat good news, or to reiterate perhaps 
bad news or help needed.
The AV issues previously reported were resolved and the motivational speaker was identified.
Before we close this demo, just five key notes.
Number 1, keep the report brief, shorter reports are much easier to understand.
Number 2, traffic light reporting, green, yellow, and red is a best practice.
It is great to use the colours as you saw in the demo status report that we just shared.
However, remember that some people cannot see colours well, so add the verbiage.
Third, share the most important information first, people normally read from top to bottom.
Next, determine the optimal reporting frequency based on the needs of the project.
If status is slowly changing, perhaps an every other week status reporting schedule will suffice.
And finally, ensure the status report is targeted at the stakeholders who need the information.
Ensure these stakeholders have access to the report.
This concludes our demo on status reporting.
You will have the opportunity to read a scenario, analyse this scenario, and prepare a status report as 
part of your course lab requirements.
Thank you for your attention, have a great rest of your day, and we look forward to seeing you 
again for future demonstrations.

In this video, you learn that when writing a status report, you should provide an overview of the 
status, scope, and budget, review risks and provide updates on current issues, and share current 
health and forecasts.

Demo: Change Request Review
Welcome to Change Request Review.
After watching this video, you will be able to write a standard change request.
Welcome to a short demo.
For the next few minutes, we will highlight a standard change request form whose design conforms 
to a step-by-step integrated change control process championed by the Project Management 
Institute or PMI.
PMI states that all changes should be processed using the following step-by-step process step 
number one log the change.
Every change request submitted should be assigned a unique tracking number.
Step number two, ensure the purpose of the change is clearly documented.
Ensure the reason for the change or the benefits are shared.
Step number three, evaluate the change.
Clearly define the impact to the project baseline if the change is approved as written.
Step number four, provide implementation options.
How can this change be accomplished?
Develop your team's recommended approach.
And finally, step number five, document the decision and reasons why the decision was reached.
Update all project documentation and communicate the change.
With that, let's walk through an example of a change form.
First of all, complete information to include the project stakeholder information and ensure a 
change ID is assigned.
Next, ensure the proposed change is detailed at an appropriate level to ensure understanding of the 
request.
This is accomplished by the requester and validated by the team.
Ensure the reason for the change is described, this is also accomplished by the requester.
Consider the impact to the project baseline and stakeholders.
List assumptions, dependencies, risks and define approval levels for the change.
Define implementation options, most changes will impact scope, schedule, and budget.
Describe the impact for each potential option provided.
Always ensure the team makes a recommendation on the most feasible option.
Finally, document the decision.
This may include accept as-is, accept with modifications, defer, reject or recommend further 
analysis.
Add notes to justify the decision and use the close out checklist to ensure the change is processed 
properly.

In this video, you learn that, a change request should include a request ID,
a description, an evaluation of the change options, and then explain the decision.

Module 4: Lessons Learned Report and 
Retrospectives
Objectives:
•	Explain the importance and process of conducting lessons learned
•	Summarize the Retrospective purpose and facilitation process
•	Review the final AHI App development project status
Introduction:
You can use lessons learned and retrospectives to identify threats to performance, project 
team cohesion, methods, and so on. They can also help identify practices and opportunities.
Lessons Learned:
At the end of each major anticipatory phase of the project, you list the lessons learned. You also 
perform them at the end of the project.
•	Lessons learned help project managers improve project performance. They document what 
went well and what could have gone better. They also include recommendations for 
improving future project performance.
•	The project manager is responsible for implementing lessons learned documenting 
results. The Project Management Institute (PMI) recommends that all lessons learned be 
recorded in a register. All stakeholders can review this register.
•	The Project Manager may need to tailor the lessons learned process to meet the 
organization's needs.
Retrospectives:
•	Retrospectives are conducted at the end of each Scrum Sprint. This is a ceremony 
facilitated by a Scrum Master. Retrospectives are like lessons learned. The team has to 
answer three questions. They include what went well, what can be improved in the next 
Sprint, and what we should change as a team.
•	There is one big difference between lessons learned and a retrospective. The team votes on 
one significant change they will implement immediately in the next Sprint before the 
Retrospective is complete. The Scrum Master documents this change recommendation and 
ensures the team adopts the change immediately.
•	In a Retrospective, there are several methods used for voting.
•	Majority: A change is agreed to if more than 50% of the team agrees.
•	Unanimity: The change is adopted only if 100% of the team agree.
•	Plurality: You can divide the teams according to areas of expertise. This method 
results in the vote of the numerically largest internal group.
•	Fist to Five: "Fist to Five" is a technique for getting feedback or checking consensus 
during a meeting. The Scrum Master presents a recommendation for change. All 
team members are asked to show how much they agree with the statement. 
Participants hold up a certain number of fingers, from five for complete agreement to 
one clenched fist for complete disagreement.
AHI App Development Project Update:
•	The team described five solutions or objectives in the project charter. At the end of the 
project, the app was developed within the specified time frame. The app did not 
include all features as originally planned. Two required data feeds and a number of 
desired reports were not included. Inadequate requirements gathering at the beginning of the 
project resulted in several change requests. The team will incorporate the outstanding 
requirements into version 2.
•	The team added a third Sprint and developed the app within the 90-day development 
window. Additional costs of $7000 were incurred due to equipment requirement 
omissions and inflationary cost factors not considered during initial planning. A few 
minor App interface issues still need to be remedied. IT has forecasted a 15 November 
completion date.
•	Feedback from the customer focus group was positive. The new App satisfied their 
requirements for improved access to all AHI products and pricing and provided secure 
invoicing and order processing as required.
•	IT encountered recruiting issues. They could find and hire only one qualified candidate to 
fill the two vacancies and approved positions. IT is working with Human Relations (HR) to 
add a second new hire. They hope to have a second new hire onboarded by 1 December.
•	The team felt that initial scrum training would have been a great benefit. The 
development team mixed traditional predictive and adaptive methods during the Sprints. 
The team determined that applying a more structured Scrum process would be 
beneficial.
•	Development team velocity was based on assumptions. In the future, the team will strive 
to understand better how much work measured by story points the team can achieve in each 
Sprint.


Demo: Project Close-out Report


Welcome to Project Close out Report.
After watching this video, you will be able to: describe the importance of a project close-out report,
and explain the steps involved in writing a project close-out report.
Welcome to a brief demo on completing a final project close-out report.
A project close-out report is important for a number of reasons.
A project close-out report allows the team and future project managers to learn from both the 
mistakes and successes of a specific project.
All too often, history in the form of mistakes repeats itself.
In addition, best practices learned are often lost.
A high-quality close-out report will help improve future project performance.
Project closure reports are also important, because they serve as a basis to close contracts, 
release project resources, communicate vital information to stakeholders, and plan the 
product or service transition.
A project closeout report is documented to identify the variances from the baseline plans.
This includes comparing planned performance to actual performance in the areas of scope, 
schedule, cost, and risk management.
Let's do a quick report review.
First of all, always date the report and provide key information to provide the project name.
In addition, your division, or department as applicable, the project sponsor, and the project 
manager.
Next, review the project charter, document the original goals of the project.
Review each goal in the previous section.
Evaluate your success or failure in achieving each goal.
This is in essence your project report card.
Next, review your project management plan.
What was the original scope, schedule, and cost baselines?
Compare what actually occurred on the project versus what was planned.
Identify variances, and most importantly, provide ideas on how these variances can be 
avoided on future projects.
Reveal your risk register.
What risks did you predict accurately, and how did your responses fair?
In addition, document risks that caught you by surprise.
How can these surprises be prevented in the future?
Work with the team, and document any outstanding issues that remain to be addressed.
Do not close out the project totally until these issues are resolved.
Lessons learned are next.
Gather the team and document what went well, what you can do better next time, and provide 
any recommendations to improve.
This activity will not help the current project in all likelihood, but it will help future project 
managers immensely.
Determine where the report will be archived or filed.
Find a repository where all project managers have access to the report.
Finally, document when lessons learned were accomplished, and when the project closeout 
was 100 percent complete.
Do, and I emphasize do, take the time to prepare and share this report.
Overall, project management within your organization will in all likelihood improve.

In this video, you learned that project close-out help the team learn from mistakes and successes, 
serve to communicate final information to stakeholders, and identify variances from baseline plans.
When writing a project close-out, you should document the original goals of the project, and 
evaluate the success of each goal.
Provide advice on how variances can be avoided in the future.
Document risks, explain lessons learned, and include the final 100 percent completion date.

•	Documenting deliverable status and help needed
•	Identifying risks and issues
•	Explaining recent and pending decisions that impact the project
•	The steps involved in requesting a change to the project include the following:
•	Providing key information
•	Writing a detailed description that focuses on business needs and requirements
•	Documenting the reason for the change
•	Explaining the impact of the change
•	Identifying possible options to implement the change
•	Documenting the decision and who was responsible for this decision
•	The purpose of reviewing "lessons learned" is to help improve future project performance 
by documenting what went well and what could have gone better
•	A sprint retrospective occurs after each sprint, where the team votes on one significant 
change they will implement in the next sprint before the next retrospective
•	The steps to creating a project closeout report include the following:
•	Providing key information
•	Documenting the project goals from the charter
•	Analyzing the project goals
•	Explaining deviations
•	Identifying any variances to the original scope and explaining why they happened
•	Providing outstanding project-related follow-up issues, their resolution, and who is 
responsible for each

Introduction to Bonus lesson
Introduction
A personal portfolio can be an important career asset. This is true for everyone, whether you are 
looking for a new job or not. Professionals in all industries can and should consider building a 
personal portfolio.
A personal portfolio is a physical book, binder, or electronic file that shows who you are, 
demonstrates your accomplishments, and includes examples of your work. A portfolio shows you 
are ready to take the "next step" in your career.

We include a bonus lesson in this course that explains how to create a portfolio of artifacts to 
demonstrate career readiness. This lesson consists of the following:

demonstrate your skills and accomplishments. You will be better prepared to show who you are and 
what value you bring to any organization.

CAPM Practice Exam Course
Introduction:
The Project Management Institute (PMI) states that "The Certified Associate of Project 
Management (CAPM) is a globally recognized credential that opens the door to opportunities at 
every stage of your career in the field of project management."
CAPM Overview:
To quote PMI, "The CAPM distinguishes your skillset as a project manager and is a crucial 
stepping-stone to career advancement." The current CAPM test requires knowledge of the 
following four domains:
•	Project management fundamentals and core concepts
•	Predictive, plan-based methodologies
•	Agile frameworks/methodologies
•	Business analysis frameworks
Here are some additional specifics from PMI regarding the CAPM certification test:
Prerequisites
•	Have at least 23 contact hours of project management education 
completed before the exam
•	Good news! Your time on this course counts towards your project 
management educational hours.

•	Member: $225 Non-Member: $300
•	Membership costs approximately $75

Questions
150 (135 Scored) There are 15 "Pre-Test" questions
Time to Complete 
Test
180 Minutes
Testing Modality
Online. You can schedule your test to meet your availability.
Passing Score
Approximately 80%

test questions. The course's practice quizzes and graded assessments help you prepare specifically 
for the CAPM test.
You'll have access to helpful test-taking strategies, tips, and an informative overview of test

Guide to Developing a Personal Portfolio
Objectives
•	Explain the purpose of a personal portfolio
•	Summarize potential portfolio contents
•	Describe steps to build a personal portfolio
Purpose
A personal portfolio is a great way to share who you are, showcase the work you have 
accomplished, and demonstrate that you have the skills to excel in a potential new role. A well-
organized portfolio can set you apart from the rest. Here is a summary of personal portfolio 
attributes:
•	Visually demonstrates competencies you would list on a resume or share in an interview
•	Provides proof of your skills, accomplishments, and examples of your work
•	Includes a compilation of some of your best work samples and professional documentation
•	It may be as simple as a binder, or electronically compiled
•	Allows you to SHOW and not simply TELL
Portfolio contents
Your portfolio should be unique and tailored to the role you are pursuing. Tailor the content to serve 
your needs. General contents to consider including:
•	Headshot, brief biographical information, and contact information
•	A personal statement, your career goals, your likes, and your passions
•	Career summary (resume), educational experience, licenses, and certifications
•	Information about past employers and your evaluations
•	List of skills and photos of you at work
•	Published articles, press releases, accolades, and testimonials
•	References
•	Create a contents section and provide links to your best work
Steps to build a portfolio
•	Step 1: Gather materials. Choose examples that are recent, relevant, and significant.
•	Step 2: Organize the portfolio. Include a table of contents and appropriate headers.
•	Step 3: Create a visually appealing portfolio. Maintain consistency in formatting. Quantity 
does not necessarily equate to quality.

Demo: Personal Portfolio Development
Welcome to Personal Portfolio Development.
After watching this video, you will be able to describe the elements of a personal portfolio.
Welcome to a brief overview of how to develop a personal work portfolio.
As we shared in an earlier reading, a personal portfolio is a great way to showcase your work and
demonstrate you have the skills required to satisfy a potential job role.
This short demo will provide an idea of what to include in your portfolio and how to format your 
presentation.
A portfolio can be a hard copy document or an electronic one.
Share your name, title, and contact information.
Always include a picture.
Try to share a variety of pictures throughout the portfolio.
Provide a brief introduction.
Tailor your introduction, so it resonates with the audience you are sharing your portfolio with.
Provide a brief agenda.
You may wish to reference the slide or page number, or turn this into a mini table of contents.
Again, a picture is worth 1000 words and vary your pictures.
The next section provides a miniature persona of yourself.
Share your goals, if possible, try to share goals that the portfolio viewer might embrace as well.
Express your values, again, do your homework.
What values do you possess that would be appreciated by the reader and the organization you are 
targeting?
Share your likes. What drives you?
What are you passionate about?
Always ask yourself, how will my likes add value to the role I am seeking?
Consider a quote that expresses your passion and values, this is optional.
However, if you have a favorite quote or saying that matches the vision or values of the 
organization or role you are targeting, add it.
Always include an overview of your education and certifications.
You don't need to list everything.
Determine which educational and certification particulars support the position you hope to attain, 
and list your job history.
Share your last three or four roles that show you have the experience needed to take that next big 
career step.
Share pictures of you on the job.
Try to have a good mix of you working by yourself and with others.
Choose pictures that show your passion, ability to effectively collaborate, and your professionalism 
on the job.
Again, do your homework, try to choose examples of your work that are meaningful to the portfolio 
reader and pertinent to the role you hope to attain.
Try to limit this part of your portfolio to your hardest hitting top three examples.
Describe the work, share how this work provided positive results, and finally, share a link to the 
work.
Give the reader an opportunity to view the work in detail.
Here's another example of sharing your best work.
This is example number 2.
And here is another example of you sharing your best work, this is example number 3.
Share references, find individuals who work in meaningful positions willing to advocate for you, if 
possible, pictures add impact.
You may wish to add contact information to these references as well.
Provide a brief summary, reiterate who you are, what you stand for, and the value you can bring to 
an organization.
This is your final elevator pitch, tailor this section to the audience.
Always end with a thank you to those who took the time to review your portfolio, reiterate your 
contact information and your smile.
>> In this video, you learned elements of a personal portfolio may include contact information and 
a picture agenda or a table of contents.
Develop a persona for yourself, overview of pertinent education and certifications, work samples 
representing your best work, and work samples that are pertinent to the role, references, and an 
elevator pitch.

Resume and Job Search Tips

Welcome to Resume and Job Search Tips.
After watching this video, you will be able to summarize best practices in resume development.
Discuss best practices for effective job searching.
Describe additional activities to gain experience.
Writing a resume can be a challenge.
You need your resume to be impactful, share compelling story, and capture the attention of the 
reader.
Statistics show an average of six to eight seconds is spent reviewing your resume.
You need your resume to stand out.
Here are a few tips to help you improve the impact of your resume.
Write a resume objective.
Begin with an accurate, brief, and concise objective that gives employers an idea of where you are 
on the career ladder, the role or position you're looking for, and allows them to quickly
determine if you are a good fit for the job.
Tailor this objective to the job you are seeking.
In addition, keep it short.
One or two sentences will suffice.
Carefully review the job description, identify keywords or phrases, then description.
For example, if the job description requires excellent collaborative skills, highlight this in your 
resume.
Outline skills and educational experience that maps to the job description.
For example, if you are applying for a job as a business analyst, your undergraduate degree in
History will likely have little impact.
Rather, share that you attended a BA course and are studying for certification.
Include both soft and technical skills.
Be precise when listing technical skills.
Key in on skills you possess that match those in the job description, include volunteer work and
participation in extra curricular activities that allowed you to gain experience and learn skills that
translate well to the job you are applying for.
Always include a cover letter.
This letter should be brief and should include who you are.
Highlight relevant skills and experiences you possess that can be applied to the job,
your interest in the position, knowledge of what the job entails and how you can effectively fill the 
role.
Show proof that you've researched the company and understand their mission, vision, and needs.
The job search process is both exciting and challenging.
This process is necessary if you want to find a job that truly suits your needs.
Here are a few tips to help you be successful.
Determine what industry you want to work in, the roles you hope to fill,
salary considerations and the types of companies you prefer.
Set a goal to determine how many companies you want to apply to in a given time period.
Be selective, have your plan and stick to it.
No compromises.
Understand the industry in which you want to work.
Target your resume and cover letter to meet the needs of the job.
Learn as much as you can about the company you are targeting.
Know their mission, vision and values, and know how you match their needs.
Review job descriptions, identify key skills, competencies, and certifications required
to be selected for the position.
Build your skills accordingly.
A single resume will often
not allow you to achieve your goals.
Tailor your resume to meet the job description requirements.
There are many outstanding job search sites.
Create an account if necessary, and learn to search by keywords. Sites such as, Indeed, ZipRecruiter, 
Monster, LinkedIn, CareerBuilder, and more are widely used by prospective employers and are 
reputable.
Plan to share a few stories to highlight your skills or problem-solving abilities.
Develop your own 60 second elevator pitch, research common interview questions,
and prepare your responses before you go into the interview.
Sign up for training, seminars, webinars, and conferences in your area or online to enhance your 
project management abilities.
Find courses focusing on various aspects of project management or offer training
and a particular skill you need help developing.
Seek feedback from your peers, get feedback from them, share and ask for ideas and improved 
suggestions.
Focus on various project management methodologies.
Predictive project management is here to stay.
However, Agile and Scrum Methodologies are gaining traction.
Improve competencies in all methodologies.
Find project managers with proven success records and learn from them.
There are many outstanding project managers in every industry.
Bind one who is willing to coach and mentor you.
Join organizations such as the Project Management Institute, PMI, and the Scrum Alliance,
participate in meetings, training, and social get-togethers. Networking can help you land a job 
faster.
It will also give you a competitive edge throughout every stage of your career.
Experts agree that the most connected people are often the most successful.
When you invest in your relationships and networking, both professional and personal,
the time you spend will return high dividends throughout the course of your career.
In this video, you'll learn that, when developing a resume, you should write an objective,
summarize skills and pertinent education at the top, tailor it to the job, include a cover letter.
When searching for a job, you should have a plan and stick to it.
Understand the industry, build your skill set, use reputable social media, practice your interviewing.
Additional activities might include seeking feedback, job shadowing, joining organizations, and 
networking.
